# Gravity in the Solar System {#3.html#x-ck12-R3Jhdml0eSBpbiB0aGUgU29sYXIgU3lzdGVt}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define gravity.
-   Explain how mass and distance influence the gravitational attraction
    between two objects.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600833] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025623806647.jpeg)
</span>

**Did you ever hear the old adage: What goes up must come down?**

Every moment of every day is a field trip to gravity. Gravity is
everywhere! You have a gravitational attraction to your dog. You have
one to your pencil. You even have one to your school principal! These
gravitational attractions are very small compared with the most
important one you have. This is your gravitational attraction to Earth.
It's what keeps you from floating off into space. Gravity holds our
planet together. Gravity keeps Earth orbiting the Sun. We wouldn't be
here without gravity.

### The Role of Gravity {#3.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFJvbGUgb2YgR3Jhdml0eQ.._2-ykm}

All objects in the universe have an attraction to each other. This
attraction is known as **gravity** ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjQtMDUtR3Jhdml0eS1mb3JjZQ..) ). The
strength of the force of gravity depends on two things. One is the mass
of the objects. The other is the distance between the objects. As an
object's mass increases, the attraction increases. As the distance
between the objects increases, the attraction decreases.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-NGI2NmM2NWY1NDdhYjM3Yjk5ZGY5MTFiNjAyMGU2ZjE.-mht"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Xzapro4/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Gravitation.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The strength of gravity depends on the mass of two objects and the
distance between
them](ck12_3_files/20150911025623945815.png "The strength of gravity depends on the mass of two objects and the distance between them")

**Figure 3.6**

The strength of the force of gravity between objects A and B depends on
the mass of the objects and the distance ( *u* ) between them.

</div>

Isaac Newton first described gravity as the force that causes objects to
fall to the ground. Gravity is also the force that keeps the Moon
circling Earth. Gravity keeps Earth circling the Sun. Without gravity,
these objects would fly off into space ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjQtMDQtRWFydGgtbW9vbi1vcmJpdA..) ).

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-ZjEwMGNjY2QxM2I0MmI1MzMxMmNhNTMwNzQ3MzM0MmM.-btl"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NOAA, modified by CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@url="http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/multimedia/display.cfm?IM_ID=6763" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The Moon orbits the Earth, and the Earth-Moon system orbits the
Sun](ck12_3_files/20150911025624055975.jpeg "The Moon orbits the Earth, and the Earth-Moon system orbits the Sun")

**Figure 3.7**

The Moon orbits the Earth, and the Earth-Moon system orbits the Sun.

</div>

Gravity pulls any object on or near Earth toward the planet's center.

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._2-tid}

-   All objects have a gravitational attraction to each other. This is
    called gravity.
-   The attraction is proportional to the mass of the objects. The
    attraction is inversely proportional to the distance between
    the objects.
-   Gravity keeps the Moon orbiting Earth. Gravity keeps the planets
    orbiting the Sun.

# Rotation of Earth {#3.html#x-ck12-Um90YXRpb24gb2YgRWFydGg.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe Earth's rotation on its axis.
-   Explain the day-night cycle.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600838] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025624261877.jpeg)
</span>

**How do you know Earth rotates?**

Something amazing happens every day (unless you live very far north or
very far south)! The amazing thing is that the Sun rises in the east. It
also sets in the west. We know that the Sun doesn't actually move around
Earth. What causes the Sun to rise and set is that Earth rotates on its
axis. This rotation creates day and night.

### Earth's Axis of Rotation {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBBeGlzIG9mIFJvdGF0aW9u_3-iud}

Imagine a line passing through the center of Earth. The line exits the
planet at the top and at the bottom. The point at the top is the North
Pole. The point at the bottom is the South Pole. This imaginary line is
called an **axis** . The points are the north and south geographic
poles. The geographic poles are different from the magnetic poles, and
they are in different places on the planet.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-NGViZWQ1OWYzODVmYWFlODdjZTk0MzdlMGJlNDU0MzU.-knw"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Dennis Nilsson (Wikimedia: DNA-webmaster)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AxialTiltObliquity.png" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 3.0" -->
![Earth's axis of rotation is
tilted](ck12_3_files/20150911025624462442.png "Earth's axis of rotation is tilted")

**Figure 3.8**

Earth rotates on an axis, an imaginary line that goes from the North
(celestial) Pole to the South (celestial) Pole.

</div>

Note that Earth's axis of rotation is tilted. The axis is not
perpendicular to the plane of the ecliptic. This plane is the one that
solar system bodies are mostly lined up in.

Earth spins around its axis, just as a top spins around its spindle.
This spinning movement is called **rotation** . The axis is Earth's
**axis of rotation** . Earth rotates on its axis once every 24 hours.

### Day-Night Cycle {#3.html#x-ck12-RGF5LU5pZ2h0IEN5Y2xl_3-9ch}

To an observer looking down at the North Pole, Earth appears to rotate
counterclockwise. From nearly all points on Earth, the Sun appears to
move across the sky from east to west each day. Of course, the Sun is
not moving from east to west at all; Earth is rotating. The Moon and
stars also seem to rise in the east and set in the west.

Earth’s rotation means that there is a cycle of daylight and darkness
approximately every 24 hours. This is the length of a day. Different
places experience sunset and sunrise at different times, and the amount
of daylight and darkness also differs by location.

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._3-7uj}

-   Sun, Moon, and stars appear to travel from east to west each day.
-   Earth rotates on its axis every 24 hours.
-   Earth's rotation causes the day-night cycle.

# Coriolis Effect {#3.html#x-ck12-Q29yaW9saXMgRWZmZWN0}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain the Coriolis effect.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600844] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025624568604.jpeg)
</span>

**Is this an example of the Coriolis effect?**

Does Coriolis determine which direction water in a toilet will swirl?
Unfortunately, no. Friction and the power of the flush have too big an
influence. But in the atmosphere and oceans, Coriolis affects flow
direction.

### Coriolis Effect {#3.html#x-ck12-Q29yaW9saXMgRWZmZWN0_4-fip}

The **Coriolis effect** is not a force, even though that's what it is
sometimes called. Coriolis does not force anything to happen! Coriolis
is an effect. What does that mean?

The Coriolis effect describes how Earth’s rotation steers winds and
surface ocean currents. Unlike land, air and water move freely (in the
absence of obstacles). The Coriolis effect causes the path of a freely
moving object to appear to curve. This is because Earth is rotating
beneath the object. So even though the object's path is straight, it
appears to curve. The curve appears to be to the right in the Northern
Hemisphere. It appears to be to the left in the Southern Hemisphere.

Here is an example in the Northern Hemisphere. A plane takes off from
City A . The pilot wants to land in City B, which is 500 miles due
north. But the plane will not arrive there without corrections. City B
was due north of City A when the plane took off. But during the time it
takes for the airplane to fly 500 miles, City B moves east. This happens
because of Earth's rotation. So if the airplane flies due north, it will
arrive at a different city, City C. City C is west of City B (in the
Northern Hemisphere). To reach City B, the pilot should curve right
while flying north. The opposite happens in the Southern Hemisphere. In
the flights between cities pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1GbGlnaHRQYXRo) ), the flight paths
look curved. Since a flight path must curve to the right in the Northern
Hemisphere, can you tell which city the plane took off from in each
case?

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-OTM5OWZhYmY2NWY3ZTA3ZmNhYzM1M2Y2ODU1MWIyYjg.-ogj"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Zappy's" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Flight paths look curved due to the Coriolis
effect](ck12_3_files/20150911025624681274.jpeg "Flight paths look curved due to the Coriolis effect")

**Figure 3.9**

The Coriolis effect is the reason that airlines' flight paths look
curved, even though they are the shortest possible path. Although these
flight paths show curves, what's wrong with this picture? (The curves do
not all follow the path due to Coriolis.)

</div>

#### Effect for Air or Water {#3.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0IGZvciBBaXIgb3IgV2F0ZXI._4-kcf}

As wind or an ocean current moves, the Earth spins underneath it. Wind
or water that travels toward the poles from the Equator curves to the
east. Wind or water that travels toward the Equator from the poles
curves to the west. The Coriolis effect bends the direction of surface
currents to the right in the Northern Hemisphere. The currents curve
left in the Southern Hemisphere ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1PY2VhbkN1cnJlbnRz) ).

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-MmVmOWYxNTQwYzUyYTIyYjAyMjc2YTU4YjI0Y2ZkZDk.-a2z"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Navy Oceanographic Office" -->
<!-- @@url="http://icp.giss.nasa.gov/research/ppa/1997/oceanchars/currents.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The Coriolis effect causes winds and currents to form circular
patterns](ck12_3_files/20150911025624767889.png "The Coriolis effect causes winds and currents to form circular patterns")

**Figure 3.10**

The Coriolis effect causes winds and currents to form circular patterns.
The direction that they spin depends on the hemisphere that they are in.

</div>

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._4-aju}

-   Earth rotates beneath freely moving objects like water and air.
    Compared with a spot on the planet, the objects appear to be moving.
-   Freely moving objects appear to move right in the
    Northern Hemisphere. They appear to move left in the
    Southern Hemisphere.
-   Coriolis is an effect rather than a force. Coriolis does not force
    a motion. An object appears to have a change of motion due to the
    Coriolis effect.

    [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mcPs\_OdQOYU](watch?v=mcPs_OdQOYU) (2:11)

# Seasons {#3.html#x-ck12-U2Vhc29ucw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain why seasons occur.
-   Define summer solstice, winter solstice, and equinox.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600850] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025624901055.jpeg)
</span>

**Do you like the seasons?**

Do you live in a place with well-defined seasons? Do you appreciate the
change of the seasons? In other words, are you happy that Earth's axis
is tilted?

### Earth’s Seasons {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGjigJlzIFNlYXNvbnM._5-wp3}

Some people think that Earth is closer to the Sun in the summer and
farther away from the Sun in the the winter. But that's not true! Why
can't that be true? Because when it's summer in one hemisphere, it's
winter in the other. So what does cause the seasons? The seasons are
caused by the 23.5° tilt of Earth’s axis. One hemisphere points more
directly toward the Sun than the other hemisphere. As Earth orbits the
Sun, the tilt of Earth's axis stays lined up with the North Star.

**Solstice** refers to the position of the Sun when it is closest to one
of the poles. At equinox, the Sun is directly over the Equator.

#### Northern Hemisphere Summer {#3.html#x-ck12-Tm9ydGhlcm4gSGVtaXNwaGVyZSBTdW1tZXI._5-yb1}

During summer in the Northern Hemisphere, the North Pole is tilted
toward the Sun. The Sun's rays strike the Northern Hemisphere more
directly ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtUmV2LTE1LU5vcnRoZXJuX1N1bW1lcg..) ). The
region gets a lot of sunlight. **Summer solstice** is June 21 or 22. At
that time, the Sun's rays hit directly at the Tropic of Cancer (23.5°N).
This is the farthest north that the Sun will be directly overhead.
Summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere is winter solstice in the
Southern Hemisphere.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-NTIwYzlmOWU3MWE0NGJlMDMyZjQyNGVhOWNhOTExNzU.-pmf"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Sam McCabe" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Summer solstice in the Northern
Hemisphere](ck12_3_files/20150911025625026948.png "Summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere")

**Figure 3.11**

Summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere.

</div>

#### Northern Hemisphere Winter {#3.html#x-ck12-Tm9ydGhlcm4gSGVtaXNwaGVyZSBXaW50ZXI._5-7gv}

**Winter solstice** for the Northern Hemisphere happens on December 21
or 22. The North Pole of Earth's axis points away from the Sun (
**Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtUmV2LTE1LU5vcnRoZXJuX1dpbnRlcg..) ).
Light from the Sun is spread out over a larger area. With fewer daylight
hours in winter, there is also less time for the Sun to warm the area.
When it is winter in the Northern Hemisphere, it is summer in the
Southern Hemisphere.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-ODgxZDgzZmNkZTg1N2Q3YzI2Yjg1N2IzY2RiOTM2MTI.-78l"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Sam McCabe" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Summer solstice in the Southern
Hemisphere](ck12_3_files/20150911025625146666.png "Summer solstice in the Southern Hemisphere")

**Figure 3.12**

During summer in the Southern Hemisphere, the Sun’s rays directly strike
the Tropic of Capricorn (23.5°S). Sunlight is spread across a large area
near the South Pole. No sunlight reaches the North Pole.

</div>

An animation of the seasons from the University of Illinois is seen
here:
[http://projects.astro.illinois.edu/data/Seasons/seasons.html](seasons.html)
. Notice the area of solar radiation, or insolation, in the lower right
of the screen.

#### Equinox {#3.html#x-ck12-RXF1aW5veA.._5-deh}

**Equinox** comes halfway between the two solstices. At equinoxes, the
Sun's rays shine most directly at the Equator ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTE1MDMtMDg.) ). The daylight and
nighttime hours are exactly equal on an equinox. The autumnal, or fall,
equinox happens on September 22 or 23. The vernal, or spring, equinox
happens March 21 or 22 in the Northern Hemisphere.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-ZDI2ZjdkNTczZjAyMjBjN2M0NGZlMDhjNjZiNzU0NTI.-gdv"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Tom Ruen, Full Sky Observatory" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Seasonearth.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Pictures of Earth during the spring equinox, summer solstice, vernal
equinox, and winter
solstice](ck12_3_files/20150911025625243794.png "Pictures of Earth during the spring equinox, summer solstice, vernal equinox, and winter solstice")

**Figure 3.13**

Where sunlight reaches on spring equinox, summer solstice, vernal
equinox, and winter solstice. The time is 9:00 p.m. Universal Time, at
Greenwich, England.

</div>

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._5-pai}

-   Earth has seasons because of the (23.5°) tilt of its axis
    of rotation.
-   In the Northern Hemisphere, at summer solstice the Sun is closest to
    the North Pole (around June 22). At winter solstice, the Sun is
    closest to the South Pole (around December 22). In the Southern
    Hemisphere, the names are changed.
-   At equinox, the Sun is directly over the Equator. Autumnal equinox
    is around September 22. Spring equinox is around March 22.

# Revolutions of Earth {#3.html#x-ck12-UmV2b2x1dGlvbnMgb2YgRWFydGg.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe Earth's revolution around the Sun.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600855] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025625373653.jpeg)
</span>

**What kind of revolution are we talking about?**

Copernicus caused a revolution. He said that Earth revolved around the
Sun. With his telescope, Galileo found a lot of evidence for this. He
could see moons orbiting Jupiter. If moons can orbit Jupiter, surely
Earth can orbit the Sun. Yes? In the two images above, you can see
Jupiter at two different times, showing moons in different places.

### Earth's Revolution {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBSZXZvbHV0aW9u_6-qsi}

Earth orbits a star. That star is our Sun. One **revolution** around the
Sun takes 365.24 days. That is equal to one year. Earth stays in orbit
around the Sun because of the Sun's gravity ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Tb2xhckVsbGlwc2Vz) ).

Earth's orbit is not a circle. It is a bit elliptical. So as we travel
around the Sun, sometimes we are a little farther away from the Sun.
Sometimes we are closer to the Sun.

Students sometimes think the slightly oval shape of our orbit causes
Earth's seasons. That's not true! The seasons are due to the tilt of
Earth’s axis, as discussed in the previous concept.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-MDJiNTQ0YmRjM2JhOWUxM2I0NzMxYmNkYmEzMGQ2MzM.-lrt"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:Image Editor" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/11304375@N07/2818891443/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Planets in the solar system make elliptical orbits around the
Sun](ck12_3_files/20150911025625484402.jpeg "Planets in the solar system make elliptical orbits around the Sun")

**Figure 3.14**

Earth and the other planets in the solar system make elliptical orbits
around the Sun. The ellipses in this image are highly exaggerated.

</div>

The distance between the Earth and the Sun is about 93 million miles, or
150 million kilometers. Earth revolves around the Sun at an average
speed of about 27 kilometers (17 miles) per second. Mercury and Venus
are closer to the Sun, so they take shorter times to make one orbit.
Mercury takes only about 88 Earth days to make one trip around the Sun.
All of the other planets take longer amounts of time. The exact amount
depends on the planet's distance from the Sun. Saturn takes more than 29
Earth years to make one revolution around the Sun. How old would you be
if you were on Jupiter?

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._6-uxk}

-   Earth's orbit around the Sun is somewhat elliptical.
-   Earth's seasons are not caused by the shape of its orbit.
-   Earth and the other planets of the solar system revolve around
    the Sun.

# Solar Eclipses {#3.html#x-ck12-U29sYXIgRWNsaXBzZXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe solar eclipses.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600860] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025625592397.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you see a solar eclipse?**

Of course! This photo of a partial solar eclipse was taken on May 20,
2012 in Gilbert, Arizona. The maximum was 82% at that location. Further
north people experienced totality. The next two eclipses in North
America will be a partial on October 23, 2014 and a total on August 21,
2017. If you try to view an eclipse, be sure you use eye protection!

### Solar Eclipses {#3.html#x-ck12-U29sYXIgRWNsaXBzZXM._7-wjq}

When a new moon passes directly between the Earth and the Sun, it causes
a **solar eclipse** ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjQtMjEtU29sYXItZWNsaXBzZS1zY2hlbWF0aWM.)
). The Moon casts a shadow on the Earth and blocks our view of the Sun.
This only happens if all three are lined up and in the same plane. This
plane is called the ecliptic. The ecliptic is the plane of Earth’s orbit
around the Sun.

The Moon’s shadow has two distinct parts. The **umbra** is the inner,
cone-shaped part of the shadow. It is the part in which all of the light
has been blocked. The **penumbra** is the outer part of Moon’s shadow.
It is where the light is only partially blocked.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-ZDZkYTJjYmU0YjYzZDVkNTM0MmIzY2VjZGY4ODEyN2U.-x7q"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Sagredo/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Geometry_of_a_Total_Solar_Eclipse.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The moon's position during a solar
eclipse](ck12_3_files/20150911025625704250.jpeg "The moon's position during a solar eclipse")

**Figure 3.15**

During a solar eclipse, the Moon casts a shadow on the Earth. The shadow
is made up of two parts: the darker umbra and the lighter penumbra.

</div>

When the Moon's shadow completely blocks the Sun, it is a total solar
eclipse ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Ub3RhbFNvbGFyRWNsaXBzZQ..) ). If only
part of the Sun is out of view, it is a partial solar eclipse. Solar
eclipses are rare events. They usually only last a few minutes. That is
because the Moon’s shadow only covers a very small area on Earth, and
Earth is turning very rapidly.

Solar eclipses are amazing to experience. The light disappears so that
it's like night, only strange. Birds may sing as they do at dusk. Stars
become visible in the sky. It gets colder outside. Unlike at night,
though, the Sun is out. So during a solar eclipse, it's easy to see the
Sun's corona and solar prominences. This NASA page will inform you on
when solar eclipses are expected:
[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/solar.html](solar.html)

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-NThjZDkxYWJhZjg3MWZhZWEzOWRkNzk0YzQ1NDRkMTA.-icr"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Alexandra Lord" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/atruzzi/5366046285/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of a total solar
eclipse](ck12_3_files/20150911025625797329.jpeg "Picture of a total solar eclipse")

**Figure 3.16**

A photo of a total solar eclipse.

</div>

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._7-qcs}

-   During a solar eclipse, the new moon passes between Earth and Sun.
-   The umbra is the part of the shadow in which light is
    completely blocked.
-   The penumbra is the part of the shadow that is partially lit.

# Lunar Eclipses {#3.html#x-ck12-THVuYXIgRWNsaXBzZXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe lunar eclipses.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600867] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025625936451.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you see a lunar eclipse?**

Again, of course! Anyone with a view of the Moon can see a lunar
eclipse. The next four total lunar eclipses predicted for North America
will be on April 15, 2014, October 8, 2014, April 5, 2015, and September
28, 2015.

### Lunar Eclipses {#3.html#x-ck12-THVuYXIgRWNsaXBzZXM._8-daj}

Sometimes a full moon moves through Earth's shadow. This is a **lunar
eclipse** ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMjQtMjgtTHVuYXItZWNsaXBzZQ..) ). During a
total lunar eclipse, the Moon travels completely in Earth’s umbra.
During a partial lunar eclipse, only a portion of the Moon enters
Earth’s umbra. When the Moon passes through Earth’s penumbra, it is a
penumbral eclipse. Since Earth’s shadow is large, a lunar eclipse lasts
for hours.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-YTlmOWFjZjIxY2I1MmIwNzFiM2ZiNzgxZjY3NWQwZGE.-eic"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Sagredo/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Geometry_of_a_Lunar_Eclipse.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The moon's position during a lunar
eclipse](ck12_3_files/20150911025626044490.png "The moon's position during a lunar eclipse")

**Figure 3.17**

A lunar eclipse.

</div>

Partial lunar eclipses occur at least twice a year, but total lunar
eclipses are less common. The Moon glows with a dull red coloring during
a total lunar eclipse ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjQtMjMtTHVuYXItZWNsaXBzZQ..) ).

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-N2NmMzFhYmY3MmE1NzQzOTY1ZGQ1MmViYzlkZWI0ZGM.-zob"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="U.S. Navy photos by Mass Communication Specialist Seaman Joshua Valcarcel" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Lunar_eclipse_March_2007.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A lunar eclipse is shown in a series of
pictures](ck12_3_files/20150911025626173736.jpeg "A lunar eclipse is shown in a series of pictures")

**Figure 3.18**

A lunar eclipse is shown in a series of pictures.

</div>

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._8-rlq}

-   During a lunar eclipse, the full moon moves through Earth's shadow.
-   Earth's shadow is large so lunar eclipses last longer than
    solar eclipses. They cover more area too.
-   The umbra is the part of the shadow in which light is
    completely blocked.
-   The penumbra is the part of the shadow that is partially lit.

# Lunar Phases {#3.html#x-ck12-THVuYXIgUGhhc2Vz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   List the names of the phases of the moon.
-   Describe what causes the phases of the Moon.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600871] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025626494368.jpeg)
</span>

**Can the Moon cast shadows?**

Of course! A full moon is very bright. It is bright enough to cast
shadows. If you are out away from city lights and the Moon is full you
might cast your own Moon shadow.

### The Phases of the Moon {#3.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFBoYXNlcyBvZiB0aGUgTW9vbg.._9-upl}

The Moon does not produce any light of its own. It only reflects light
from the Sun. The Moon has phases because it orbits around Earth. One
orbit takes about 28 days. As the moon moves around Earth, different
parts of it appear to be lit up by the Sun. The Moon sometimes appears
fully lit and sometimes completely dark. Sometimes it is partially lit.
The different appearances of the Moon are referred to as phases of the
Moon ( **Figure** [below](#3.html#x-ck12-TW9vbl9waGFzZXNfaW1hZ2U.) ).

A **full moon** occurs when the whole side facing Earth is lit. This
happens when Earth is between the Moon and the Sun.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-NmE5NzYxNDBkN2Q3NjFjMDhhODEzYjczZWFhMzQ0Y2M.-zwv"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:OliBac" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/olibac/4140353704/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![The phases of the
moon](ck12_3_files/20150911025626640360.jpeg "The phases of the moon")

**Figure 3.19**

The moon's phases are a result of the moon's orbit around Earth.

</div>

About one week later, the Moon enters the quarter-moon phase. Only half
of the Moon’s lit surface is visible from Earth, so it appears as a half
circle.

Another week later, the Moon moves between Earth and the Sun. The side
of the Moon facing Earth is completely dark. This is called a **new
moon** . Sometimes you can just barely make out the outline of the new
moon in the sky. This is because some sunlight reflects off the Earth
and hits the Moon.

One week after that, the Moon is in another quarter-moon phase. Finally,
in one more week, the Moon is back to full.

Before and after the quarter-moon phases are the gibbous and crescent
phases. During the **crescent** moon phase, the Moon is less than half
lit. It is seen as only a sliver or crescent shape. During the
**gibbous** moon phase, the Moon is more than half lit. It is not full.
The Moon undergoes a complete cycle of phases about every 29.5 days.

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._9-agu}

-   The appearance of the Moon from Earth has distinct phases.
-   A full moon is completely lit; a new moon is completely dark.
-   A gibbous moon is more than half lit; a crescent moon is less than
    half lit.

# Earth's Interior {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBJbnRlcmlvcg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain seismic waves.
-   Describe the ways in which scientists can learn about what's in
    Earth's interior.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600876] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025626746285.jpeg)
</span>

**How deep can we go into Earth's interior?**

Not very deep, that's for sure! The deepest a drill hole has gotten was
the Kola Superdeep Borehole. That hole got to 40,230 feet (12,262 m),
about one-third of the way into the crust in that area. So learning
about what's deeper requires less direct methods. A few of these methods
will be described in this concept.

### Learning About Earth’s Interior {#3.html#x-ck12-TGVhcm5pbmcgQWJvdXQgRWFydGjigJlzIEludGVyaW9y_10-oea}

If someone told you to figure out what is inside Earth, what would you
do? How could you figure out what is inside our planet? How do
scientists figure it out?

#### Seismic Waves {#3.html#x-ck12-U2Vpc21pYyBXYXZlcw.._10-jxx}

Geologists study earthquake waves to “see” Earth's interior. Waves of
energy radiate out from an earthquake’s focus. These waves are called
**seismic waves** ( **Figure** [below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDYtMDE.)
). Seismic waves go different speeds through different materials. They
change speed when they go from one type of material to another. This
causes them to bend. Some seismic waves do not travel through liquids or
gases. They just stop. Scientists use information from seismic waves to
understand what makes up the Earth’s interior.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-MDk1Y2JkMWU2M2NkYTVlYmEzZDBlNDhkNDQzYjZjYjQ.-u40"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung and Laura Guerin" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![The properties of seismic waves allow scientists to understand the
composition of Earth's
interior](ck12_3_files/20150911025626874822.png "The properties of seismic waves allow scientists to understand the composition of Earth's interior")

**Figure 3.20**

The properties of seismic waves allow scientists to understand the
composition of Earth's interior.

</div>

#### Meteorites {#3.html#x-ck12-TWV0ZW9yaXRlcw.._10-kkm}

Scientists study **meteorites** to learn about Earth’s interior.
Meteorites formed in the early solar system. These objects represent
early solar system materials ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDYtMDQtTWV0ZW9yaXRl) ). Some meteorites
are made of iron and nickel. They are thought to be very similar to
Earth's core. An iron meteorite is the closest thing to a sample of the
core that scientists can hold in their hands!

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-MjljN2MxMjZlMjFkYmQwMjkzMzUxZTcxY2NjZDI2NGU.-wse"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Steve Jurvetson (Flickr: jurvetson)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/jurvetson/6098963730/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC-BY 2.0" -->
![Meteorite containing the mafic minerals olivine and pyroxene, as well
as metal flakes similar to the material that separated into the Earth's
core and
mantle](ck12_3_files/20150911025626999811.jpeg "Meteorite containing the mafic minerals olivine and pyroxene, as well as metal flakes similar to the material that separated into the Earth's core and mantle")

**Figure 3.21**

This meteorite contains the mafic minerals olivine and pyroxene. It also
contains metal flakes, similar to the material that separated into
Earth’s core (metal) and mantle (ultramafic rock).

</div>

#### Density {#3.html#x-ck12-RGVuc2l0eQ.._10-wju}

Earth’s overall density is higher than the density of crustal rocks, so
the core must be made of something dense, like metal.

#### Magnetic Field {#3.html#x-ck12-TWFnbmV0aWMgRmllbGQ._10-rhy}

Since Earth has a magnetic field, there must be metal within the planet.
Iron and nickel are both magnetic.

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-lmc}

-   Different types of seismic waves behave differently in
    different materials. Their behavior can tell scientists about the
    material they travel through.
-   Earth must contain metal. Its density, and the fact that it has a
    magnetic field, require it.
-   Meteorites formed early in the solar system. They indicate something
    about Earth's interior.

# Earth's Outer Layers {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBPdXRlciBMYXllcnM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify Earth's layers and describe their characteristics.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600880] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025627100592.jpeg)
</span>

**Does this look familiar?**

Gases, water, rock, and living organisms are all found at Earth's
surface. These materials are also found above or below the surface. They
interact with each other and in doing so alter each other. For example,
the hydrosphere may cause some of the lithosphere to wash away.

### Spheres {#3.html#x-ck12-U3BoZXJlcw.._11-xiy}

Earth is made of layers. Since Earth is round, the layers all have the
ending "-sphere" ( **Figure** [below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjQtMDM.)
).

Some of the different parts of the Earth are the:

-   **Atmosphere** : The thin layer of air, mostly nitrogen and oxygen,
    that surrounds the Earth.
-   **Hydrosphere** : All the water on Earth.
-   **Biosphere** : All the living organisms on Earth.
-   **Lithosphere** : The solid rock part of Earth, including mountains,
    valleys, continents, and all of the rock beneath the oceans.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-NTlkY2U0YWNhYTViNzhiYzE0NDA0YWE5ZWZjMzE5OGU.-sqy"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@url="" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Earth has four layers: atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and
lithosphere](ck12_3_files/20150911025627223862.jpeg "Earth has four layers: atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and lithosphere")

**Figure 3.22**

Earth has four layers: atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and
lithosphere.

</div>

All of Earth’s layers interact. Therefore, Earth’s surface is constantly
undergoing changes.

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._11-egf}

-   Earth is made of layers. The names end in sphere because Earth
    is round.
-   Some of the layers are: atmosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere,
    and lithosphere.
-   The lithosphere is the brittle crust and uppermost mantle.

# Earth's Inner Layers {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBJbm5lciBMYXllcnM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify Earth's internal layers.
-   Describe the characteristics of Earth's layers.
-   Distinguish the lithosphere and from the asthenosphere.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600886] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025627358331.png) </span>

**What's below our feet? What's way below?**

If we could cut Earth open, we'd see the following layers from inside to
outside: inner core, outer core, mantle, and crust. Alternatively, you
can think of the brittle lithosphere riding on the plastic
asthenosphere. Whew!

### Layers by Composition {#3.html#x-ck12-TGF5ZXJzIGJ5IENvbXBvc2l0aW9u_12-pzu}

The layers scientists recognize are pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTA2MDEtMDM.) ).

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-YTlkMzBhNDhkZjY0MmZiOTA3NDcxZDFmOWVjNGUwNGQ.-iho"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Earth-cutaway-schematic-numbered.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Composition of Earth's
layers](ck12_3_files/20150911025627462833.png "Composition of Earth's layers")

**Figure 3.23**

A cross section of Earth showing the following layers: (1) crust (2)
mantle (3a) outer core (3b) inner core (4) lithosphere (5) asthenosphere
(6) outer core (7) inner core.

</div>

Core, mantle, and crust are divisions based on composition:

1.  The **crust** is less than 1% of Earth by mass. The two types are
    oceanic crust and continental crust.
2.  The **mantle** is hot, dense, dark (ultramafic) rock. It represents
    about 68% of Earth's mass.
3.  The **core** is mostly iron metal. The core makes up about 31% of
    the Earth. Earth's metallic core has two layers: a solid inner layer
    and a liquid outer layer.

The terms core, mantle, and crust will be described in more detail in
the next three concepts.

### Layers by Mechanical Properties {#3.html#x-ck12-TGF5ZXJzIGJ5IE1lY2hhbmljYWwgUHJvcGVydGllcw.._12-bzg}

Lithosphere and asthenosphere are divisions based on mechanical
properties:

1.  The **lithosphere** is composed of both the crust and the
    uppermost mantle. The lithosphere is a brittle, rigid solid. It is
    easily cracked or broken.
2.  The **asthenosphere** is below the lithosphere. The asthenosphere is
    also in the upper mantle. This layer is solid, but it can flow
    and bend. A solid that can flow is like silly putty.

This animation shows the layers by composition and by mechanical
properties:
[http://earthguide.ucsd.edu/eoc/teachers/t\_tectonics/p\_layers.html](p_layers.html)
.

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-jou}

-   By composition, Earth is divided into core, mantle, and crust.
-   By mechanical properties, the crust and upper mantle are divided
    into lithosphere and asthenosphere.
-   The core-mantle-crust divisions are based on composition.
-   The lithosphere-asthensophere divisions are based on
    mechanical properties.

# Earth's Crust {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBDcnVzdA..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define Earth's crust.
-   Describe the characteristics of Earth's two types of crust.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600890] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025627573768.jpeg)
</span>

**What do these two photos have in common?**

Both of these photos are of Earth's crust. The crust on the left is on
the continent. It's what you see and walk on every day. The crust on the
right is in the ocean. You may have seen pictures, but to see it in
person you need special equipment.

### Crust {#3.html#x-ck12-Q3J1c3Q._13-wcd}

Crust, mantle, and core differ from each other in chemical composition.
It's understandable that scientists know the most about the crust, and
less about deeper layers. Earth’s **crust** is a thin, brittle outer
shell. The crust is made of rock. This layer is thinner under the oceans
and much thicker in mountain ranges.

#### Oceanic Crust {#3.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW5pYyBDcnVzdA.._13-vfj}

There are two kinds of crust. **Oceanic crust** is made of basalt lavas
that flow onto the seafloor ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DcnVzdGFsR2FiYnJv) ). It is relatively
thin, between 5 to 12 kilometers thick (3 - 8 miles). The rocks of the
oceanic crust are denser (3.0 g/cm ^3^ ) than the rocks that make up the
continents. Thick layers of mud cover much of the ocean floor.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-Y2RmNjI2NjRlNmFmZTE3NmNkMjdiNTZkYTY4ZTk0OWU.-rv0"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Mark A. Wilson (Department of Geology, The College of Wooster)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:GabbroRockCreek1.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Gabbro is a dark dense rock that can be found in oceanic
crust](ck12_3_files/20150911025627726214.jpeg "Gabbro is a dark dense rock that can be found in oceanic crust")

**Figure 3.24**

Gabbro is a dark dense rock that can be found in oceanic crust.

</div>

#### Continental Crust {#3.html#x-ck12-Q29udGluZW50YWwgQ3J1c3Q._13-cl8}

**Continental crust** is much thicker than oceanic crust. It is 35
kilometers (22 miles) thick on average, but it varies a lot. Continental
crust is made up of many different rocks ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DcnVzdGFsR3Jhbml0ZQ..) ). All three
major rock types—igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary—are found in the
crust. On average, continental crust is much less dense (2.7 g/cm ^3^ )
than oceanic crust. Since it is less dense, it rises higher above the
mantle than oceanic crust.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-N2ZmODVhYzI0MTBmZjQ3NDdhM2MxZmY4MWVkNDk4NWI.-pvi"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="David Smith (Flickr:drsmith7383)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/davidrsmith/2834579330/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of a granite quarry, the average composition of continental
crust](ck12_3_files/20150911025627850627.jpeg "Picture of a granite quarry, the average composition of continental crust")

**Figure 3.25**

The average composition of continental crust is granite.

</div>

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._13-5e6}

-   Oceanic crust is thinner and denser than continental crust.
-   Oceanic crust is darker in color and denser (more mafic).
    Continental crust is lighter in color and density (more felsic).
-   Earth's crust is very thin relative to Earth's radius.

# Earth's Mantle {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBNYW50bGU.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the rock of Earth's mantle.
-   Define convection and conduction.
-   Describe the movement of heat in the mantle.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600896] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025627956882.jpeg)
</span>

**What does mantle rock look like?**

You can't go to the mantle but small pieces of the mantle can come to
you. Kimberlite forms deep in the mantle and is erupted violently into
the crust. Kimberlite can contain diamonds. Most kimberlites reached the
surface much earlier in Earth history.

### Mantle {#3.html#x-ck12-TWFudGxl_14-jgh}

Beneath the crust is the **mantle** . The mantle is made of hot, solid
rock. They know this because of seismic waves, meteorites, and the heat
that comes from inside the planet. Mantle rock is mostly **peridotite**
, which is rich in iron and magnesium ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QZXJpZG90aXRl) ). Peridotite is rare
at Earth's surface.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-NDg2NGFiNWJlMWE5NDJjODFlMDQ2YmJlOTI4MTcwMGI.-knu"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Omphacite/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Perid_SanCarlos.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Peridotite is formed of crystals of olivine and
pyroxene](ck12_3_files/20150911025628074375.jpeg "Peridotite is formed of crystals of olivine and pyroxene")

**Figure 3.26**

The rock of the mantle is mostly peridotite. Peridotite is formed of
crystals of olivine (green) and pyroxene (black).

</div>

#### Heat Flow {#3.html#x-ck12-SGVhdCBGbG93_14-f9m}

Through the process of conduction, heat flows from warmer objects to
cooler objects ( **Figure** [below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDYtMDQ.) ).
The lower mantle is heated directly by conduction from the core. In
**conduction** , heat is transferred as atoms collide.

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-ZmJlMGZkZDc4NjA0MTc4MDI2MDgwNTRmNjQ4MjBmODY.-cy3"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![In the process of conduction, heat flows from warmer objects to cooler
objects](ck12_3_files/20150911025628186292.png "In the process of conduction, heat flows from warmer objects to cooler objects")

**Figure 3.27**

In the process of conduction, heat flows from warmer objects to cooler
objects.

</div>

Hot lower mantle material rises upward ( **Figure**
[below](#3.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDYtMDU.) ). As it rises, it cools. At
the top of the mantle it moves horizontally. Over time it becomes cool
and dense enough that it sinks. Back at the bottom of the mantle, it
travels horizontally. Eventually the material gets to the location where
warm mantle material is rising. The rising and sinking of warm and
cooler material is called **convection** .

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-MWQ3MjhmNDUzZDNiMDAwZGNmMzBhZjNkM2FkZGY3ODk.-pva"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Convection cells in the
Earth](ck12_3_files/20150911025628379326.png "Convection cells in the Earth")

**Figure 3.28**

The rising and sinking of mantle material of different temperatures and
densities creates a convection cell.

</div>

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-dsc}

-   The mantle is composed of solid peridotite.
-   Conduction from the core heats the lower mantle.
-   Mantle convection bring hot material up toward the surface. It
    brings cooler material down toward the core.

# Earth's Core {#3.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBDb3Jl}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of Earth's core.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600900] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_3_files/20150911025628476463.jpeg)
</span>

**Is this what the core looks like?**

Yes! The outer core, anyway. The outer core is liquid metal, like in
this photo. Of course, the metal is under an incredible amount of
pressure.

### Core {#3.html#x-ck12-Q29yZQ.._15-4jx}

The dense, iron **core** forms the center of the Earth. Scientists know
that the core is metal. The inner core is solid, and the outer core is
molten. Here are some of the reasons they know this:

-   Metallic meteorites are thought to be from the same type of material
    that is found at the core ( **Figure**
    [below](#3.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Jcm9uTWV0ZW9yaXRl) ).

<div id="3.html#x-ck12-ZDMxNTVhYzg0NzcxNzgyYzAxZGNiZjJiZjAzOWUyNGE.-gyi"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Kevin Walsh (Flickr:kevinzim)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/86624586@N00/10188485/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![An iron meteorite is the closest thing to the Earth’s
core](ck12_3_files/20150911025628579295.jpeg "An iron meteorite is the closest thing to the Earth’s core")

**Figure 3.29**

An iron meteorite is the closest thing to the Earth’s core that we can
hold in our hands.

</div>

-   Scientists calculate Earth's density from the planet's rotation. To
    match the total density, the inner layers must be denser than the
    outer layers. They must be as dense as metal.

<!-- -->

-   Seismic waves show that the outer core is liquid. The inner core
    is solid.

<!-- -->

-   For there to be a magnetic field, there must be liquid metal. The
    metal must be convecting. If the core did not have convecting metal,
    there would be no magnetic field.

### Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._15-gap}

-   Density calculations show that Earth's core is metal.
-   Seismic waves show that the inner core is solid and the outer core
    is liquid.
-   Metallic meteorites and the magnetic field are also clues about the
    makeup of the core.

## Summary {#3.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-0nb}

This Concept deals with some Earth basics. Earth is a planet and has the
characteristics of a planet. Like other planets, it is nearly round.
This is because it has enough mass for its gravity to pull material into
a round shape. Earth's gravity has also pulled in small objects, like
asteroids. So the planet's orbit is cleared. Earth rotates on its axis
and revolves around its star. As a result of its rotation, Earth has a
day-night cycle. The tilt of its axis creates the seasons. Earth has
layers from crust to mantle to core. The core is divided into a liquid
outer core and a solid inner core. The liquid outer core has convection,
which generates the magnetic field. The mantle is solid rock. The crust
has two major types: continental and oceanic. The crust and uppermost
mantle make up the lithosphere. Beneath the lithosphere is the
asthenosphere. The lithosphere is brittle and will break. The
asthenosphere can flow.

</div>

# Earth's Materials and Crust {#4.html#x-ck12-RWFydGgncyBNYXRlcmlhbHMgYW5kIENydXN0-chapter}

<div class="x-ck12-data">

## Introduction {#4.html#x-ck12-SW50cm9kdWN0aW9u-meu}

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025639345847.jpeg)
</span>

**How can you learn about Earth's crust?**

Well, you could travel around and visit Earth's crust in lots of places.
You would see different minerals and rocks everywhere you went. You
would learn that certain rocks indicate that certain processes happened.
For example, the rock basalt means that there was a volcanic eruption
nearby. Since it may not be practical to take such a big trip, where
else could you see materials from Earth's crust? A museum is a great
place! The next time you're in a major city, find a way to spend a few
hours in a natural history museum. In this Concept, we'll learn about a
variety of Earth materials.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [LESSON: 3600910] -->

# Atoms to Molecules {#4.html#x-ck12-QXRvbXMgdG8gTW9sZWN1bGVz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe matter.
-   Understand the parts of matter.
-   Compare a molecule to a compound.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600913] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025639468221.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you see matter?**

Matter is all around you. Everything you see is matter. All of this
matter is made of small particles. The small particles are made of
smaller particles.

### What is Matter? {#4.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBpcyBNYXR0ZXI_-epc}

To understand minerals, we must first understand matter. **Matter** is
the substance that physical objects are made of.

#### Atoms and Elements {#4.html#x-ck12-QXRvbXMgYW5kIEVsZW1lbnRz-i6x}

The basic unit of matter is an **atom** ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BdG9tSWxsdXN0cmF0aW9u) ). At the
center of an atom is its **nucleus** . **Protons** are positively
charged particles in the nucleus. Also in the nucleus are **neutrons**
with no electrical charge. Orbiting the nucleus are tiny electrons.
**Electrons** are negatively charged. An atom with the same number of
protons and electrons is electrically neutral. If the atom has more or
less electrons to protons it is called an **ion** . An ion will have
positive charge if it has more protons than electrons. It will have
negative charge if it has more electrons than protons.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NDM2NWQwNDFlY2Q4YmI3NjY1YjQzOTlkODVlODVhODI.-srg"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jodi So" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of an
atom](ck12_4_files/20150911025639621754.png "Diagram of an atom")

**Figure 4.1**

The nucleus of an atom is made up of protons (blue) and neutrons
(yellow). Electrons (red) orbit around the nucleus.

</div>

An atom is the smallest unit of a chemical **element** . That is, an
atom has all the properties of that element. All atoms of the same
element have the same number of protons.

#### Molecules and Compounds {#4.html#x-ck12-TW9sZWN1bGVzIGFuZCBDb21wb3VuZHM.-o7v}

A **molecule** is the smallest unit of a **chemical compound** . A
compound is a substance made of two or more elements. The elements in a
chemical compound are always present in a certain ratio.

Water is probably one of the simplest compounds that you know. A water
molecule is made of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTAzMDEtMDM.) ). All water molecules have
the same ratio: two hydrogen ions to one oxygen ion.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-YWFiZDZlZWFiNjJlYjJjMGViNjQ1NzU2NDEzM2RmYWQ.-0kg"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Sakurambo/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Image:Water_molecule.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Structure of a water
molecule](ck12_4_files/20150911025639720262.png "Structure of a water molecule")

**Figure 4.2**

A water molecule has two hydrogen ions (shown in gray) bonded to one
oxygen ion (shown in red).

</div>

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-spz}

-   An atom has negatively-charged electrons in orbit around
    its nucleus.
-   The nucleus of an atom is composed of positively-charged protons,
    and neutrons, which have no charge.
-   An atom that gains or loses electrons is an ion.

# Minerals {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbHM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics that define minerals.
-   Give examples of minerals.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600919] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025639826781.jpeg)
</span>

**Are you a mineral?**

There used to be a TV commercial that said "you are what you eat." If
that's true, then you are partly the mineral halite. That's just table
salt, after all.

### What is a Mineral? {#4.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBpcyBhIE1pbmVyYWw__1-had}

A **mineral** is a solid material that forms by a natural process. A
mineral can be made of an element or a compound. It has a specific
chemical composition. Its chemical composition is different from other
minerals. Each type of mineral has physical properties that differ from
others. These properties include crystal structure, hardness, density,
and color. For example, silver is a soft, shiny metal. Salt is a white,
cube-shaped crystal. Diamond is an extremely hard, translucent crystal.

#### Forms by Natural Processes {#4.html#x-ck12-Rm9ybXMgYnkgTmF0dXJhbCBQcm9jZXNzZXM._1-v6o}

Minerals form by natural processes. Minerals are created by processes
that happen in or on the Earth. For example, when hot lava cools,
mineral crystals form. Minerals also precipitate from water. Some
minerals grow when rocks are exposed to high pressures and temperatures.

Could a mineral be made by a process that was not natural? People make
gemstones in a laboratory. Synthetic diamond is a common one. But that
stone is not a mineral. That's because a mineral must be created by
natural processes. This is part of the definition of a mineral.

#### Inorganic Substance {#4.html#x-ck12-SW5vcmdhbmljIFN1YnN0YW5jZQ.._1-8xn}

A mineral is an inorganic substance. It was not made by living
organisms. Organic substances contain carbon. Some types of organic
substances are proteins, carbohydrates, and oils. Everything else is
inorganic. In a few cases, living organisms make inorganic materials.
The calcium carbonate shells made by marine animals are inorganic.

#### Definite Composition {#4.html#x-ck12-RGVmaW5pdGUgQ29tcG9zaXRpb24._1-vw5}

All minerals have a definite chemical makeup. A few minerals are made of
only one kind of element. Silver is a mineral made only of silver atoms.
Diamond and graphite are both made only of the element carbon.

Minerals that are not just a single element are made of chemical
compounds. For example, the mineral quartz is made of the compound
silicon dioxide, or SiO ~2~ . This compound has one atom of the element
silicon for every two atoms of the element oxygen.

Each mineral has its own unique chemical formula. For example, the
mineral hematite has two iron atoms for every three oxygen atoms. The
mineral magnetite has three iron atoms for every four oxygen atoms. Many
minerals have very complex chemical formulas that include several
elements. However, even in more complicated compounds, the elements
occur in definite ratios.

#### Solid Crystals {#4.html#x-ck12-U29saWQgQ3J5c3RhbHM._1-tbh}

Minerals must be solid. For example, ice and water have the same
chemical composition. Ice is a solid, so it is a mineral. Water is a
liquid, so it is not a mineral.

Some solids are not crystals. Glass, or the rock obsidian, are solid.
However, they are not crystals. In a **crystal** , the atoms are
arranged in a pattern. This pattern is regular and it repeats. The image
below shows how the atoms are arranged in halite (table salt) (
**Figure** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTAxMDMtMDI.) ). Halite
contains atoms of sodium and chlorine in a pattern. Notice that the
pattern goes in all three dimensions.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NzdmNGZmYjcyOGE5NDNkMTg1NzkyNjkzNWZlYWM4NmU.-p0x"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Ben Mills (Wikimedia: Benjah-bmm27)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sodium-chloride-3D-ionic.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Halite crystals form from sodium and chloride
ions](ck12_4_files/20150911025639944615.png "Halite crystals form from sodium and chloride ions")

**Figure 4.3**

Sodium ions (purple balls) bond with chloride ions (green balls) to form
halite crystals.

</div>

The pattern of atoms in all halite is the same. Think about all of the
grains of salt that are in a salt shaker. The atoms are arranged in the
same way in every piece of salt.

Sometimes two different minerals have the same chemical composition. But
they are different minerals because they have different crystal
structures. Diamonds are very valuable as gemstones because they are
very pretty and very hard. Graphite is the “lead” in pencils. It's not
hard at all! Amazingly, both are made just of carbon. Compare the
diamond with the pencil lead ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMy1DYXJib25fY29tcG9zaXRl) ). Why are they
so different? The carbon atoms in graphite bond to form layers. The
bonds between each layer are weak. The carbon sheets can just slip past
each other. The carbon atoms in diamonds bond together in all three
directions. This strong network makes diamonds very hard.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NjU0NDMxZGY1NTA5OTliNDZjODhmOWI4YTEyY2E2NDU.-vgc"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Steve Jurvetson (Flickr:jurvetson); (B) Elisa Xyz" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.flickr.com/photos/jurvetson/156830367/; (B) http://www.publicdomainpictures.net/view-image.php?image=3348&#38;picture=pencil" -->
<!-- @@license="(A) CC BY 2.0; (B) Public domain" -->
![Diamonds and graphite are both made from
carbon](ck12_4_files/20150911025640060240.jpeg "Diamonds and graphite are both made from carbon")

**Figure 4.4**

Diamonds (A) and graphite (B) are both made of only carbon, but they're
not much alike.

</div>

#### Physical Properties {#4.html#x-ck12-UGh5c2ljYWwgUHJvcGVydGllcw.._1-j2n}

The patterns of atoms affect a mineral's physical properties. A
mineral's crystal shape is determined by the way the atoms are arranged.
For example, you can see how atoms are arranged in halite ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTAxMDMtMDI.) ). Below, you can see how
salt crystals look under a microscope ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDMtVGFibGVfU2FsdA..) ). Salt crystals
are all cubes whether they're small or large.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NWZkYjFlODY3MTYzN2RhZTA5NmJkM2Q0NTg2ZTE1MzA.-seg"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Chhe/Wikipedia" -->
<!-- @@url="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Salt2.JPG" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Salt crystals are cubic in
shape](ck12_4_files/20150911025640172463.png "Salt crystals are cubic in shape")

**Figure 4.5**

Under a microscope, salt crystals are cubes. In this crystal, the
corners have worn away.

</div>

Physical properties help scientists identify different minerals; this is
explored in the concept "Mineral Identification."

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._1-eb2}

-   A mineral is an inorganic, crystalline solid.
-   A mineral forms through natural processes. It has a definite
    chemical composition.
-   Minerals can be identified by their characteristic
    physical properties. They include crystalline structure, hardness,
    density, breakage, and color.

# Mineral Groups {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbCBHcm91cHM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   List the mineral groups.
-   Describe the characteristics of the different mineral groups.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600923] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025640301380.jpeg)
</span>

**What would you do with this mineral?**

Imagine you are in charge of organizing more than 100 minerals for a
museum exhibit. You know that people learn more if they see the minerals
together in groups. So how would you group the minerals together in the
exhibit? What are some of the possibilities? Size? Shape? Color?

### Mineral Groups {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbCBHcm91cHM._2-yl2}

**Mineralogists** are scientists who study minerals. They divide
minerals into groups based on chemical composition. Even though there
are over 4,000 minerals, most minerals fit into one of eight mineral
groups.

#### Silicate Minerals {#4.html#x-ck12-U2lsaWNhdGUgTWluZXJhbHM._2-tjw}

Silicates are the largest mineral group. About 1,000 silicate minerals
are known. Silicate minerals are also extremely common. They make up
over 90% of Earth's crust!

**Silicates** contain silicon atoms and oxygen atoms. One silicon atom
is bonded to four oxygen atoms. These atoms form a tetrahedron (
**Figure** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTAzLTAxLTA2) ). The silica
tetrahedron is the building block of silicate minerals. Most silicates
contain other elements. These elements include calcium, iron, and
magnesium.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-YzczNDRlMzNkZWIzNDM5YjE1ZDAyMzEwZjUxNWI5NDY.-kto"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![One silicon atom bonds to four oxygen atoms to form a silica
tetrahedron](ck12_4_files/20150911025640422219.jpeg "One silicon atom bonds to four oxygen atoms to form a silica tetrahedron")

**Figure 4.6**

One silicon atom bonds to four oxygen atoms to form a pyramid

</div>

Silicate minerals are divided into six smaller groups. In each group,
the silicate pyramids join together differently. The pyramids can stand
alone. They can form into connected circles called rings. Some pyramids
link into single and double chains. Others form large, flat sheets. Some
join in three dimensions.

Feldspar and quartz are the two most common silicates. In beryl, the
silicate pyramids join together as rings. Biotite is mica. The silicate
pyramids come together to create thin, flexible sheets. Compare the
beryl and the biotite pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDMtU2lsaWNhdGVfY29tcG9zaXRl) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MjhiZmZhMTljZDgxN2QzNDQ5OWQwODYzZmMzMjU0Zjg.-ixx"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Beryl: Image copyright Manamana, 2013; Biotite: Image copyright Tyler Boyes, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Beryl and biotite are both silicate
minerals](ck12_4_files/20150911025640518357.png "Beryl and biotite are both silicate minerals")

**Figure 4.7**

Beryl (a) and biotite (b) are both silicate minerals.

</div>

#### Native Elements {#4.html#x-ck12-TmF0aXZlIEVsZW1lbnRz_2-2pb}

**Native elements** contain only atoms of one type of element. They are
not combined with other elements. There are very few examples of these
types of minerals. Some native elements are rare and valuable. Gold,
silver, sulfur, and diamond are examples.

#### Carbonates {#4.html#x-ck12-Q2FyYm9uYXRlcw.._2-k67}

What do you guess **carbonate** minerals contain? If you guessed carbon,
you would be right! All carbonates contain one carbon atom bonded to
three oxygen atoms. Carbonates may include other elements. A few of
these are calcium, iron, and copper.

Carbonate minerals are often found where seas once covered the land.
Some carbonate minerals are very common. Calcite contains calcium,
carbon, and oxygen. Have you ever been in a limestone cave or seen a
marble tile? Calcite is in both limestone and marble. Azurite and
malachite are also carbonate minerals. They contain copper instead of
calcium. They are not as common as calcite. Malachite and azurite are
used in jewelry; as you can see, they are very colorful ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BenVyaXRlQW5kUmhvZG9jaHJvc2l0ZQ..) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ZWUyYWRhM2RmZjczZTMxYjlmMDMzYTE2NTYyYjU1NzU.-zsf"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Azurite: User:Karelj/Wikimedia Commons; Rhodochrosite: John W. Schulze (Flickr:Gruenemann)" -->
<!-- @@url="Azurite: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Azurit_1.jpg; Rhodochrosite: http://www.flickr.com/photos/13227526@N00/5559115094/" -->
<!-- @@license="Azurite: Public Domain; Rhodochrosite: CC BY 2.0" -->
![Azurite, malachite, and rhodochrosite are carbonate
minerals](ck12_4_files/20150911025640649200.jpeg "Azurite, malachite, and rhodochrosite are carbonate minerals")

**Figure 4.8**

\(a) The deep blue mineral is azurite and the green is malachite. (b)
This red rhodochrosite is a carbonate mineral. Rhodochrosite is usually
pink; the red crystals are rare.

</div>

#### Halides {#4.html#x-ck12-SGFsaWRlcw.._2-pyo}

Halide minerals are salts. They form when salt water evaporates. This
mineral class includes more than just table salt. Halide minerals may
contain the elements fluorine, chlorine, bromine, or iodine. Some halide
minerals combine with metal elements. Common table salt is a halide
mineral that contains the elements chlorine and sodium. Fluorite is a
type of halide that contains fluorine and calcium. Fluorite can be found
in many colors. If you shine an ultraviolet light on fluorite, it will
glow!

#### Oxides {#4.html#x-ck12-T3hpZGVz_2-6wm}

Earth’s crust contains a lot of oxygen. The oxygen can combine with
other elements to create oxide minerals. **Oxides** contain one or two
metal elements combined with oxygen. Oxides are different from
silicates, because they do not contain silicon. Many important metals
are found as oxides. For example, hematite and magnetite are both oxides
that contain iron. Hematite (Fe ~2~ O ~3~ ) has a ratio of two iron
atoms to three oxygen atoms. Magnetite (Fe ~3~ O ~4~ ) has a ratio of
three iron atoms to four oxygen atoms. Notice that the word “magnetite”
contains the word “magnet." Magnetite ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDMtMDItMTMtTWFnbmV0aXRl) ) is a magnetic
mineral.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-YTI2ZmQ4ZTRlOWFjZDU4OWFhMmQ4YTcyNmI4MjZiZGU.-nwr"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Wlad74, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![A crystal of magnetite, which is
magnetic](ck12_4_files/20150911025640756731.jpeg "A crystal of magnetite, which is magnetic")

**Figure 4.9**

Magnetite is one of the most distinctive oxides since it is magnetic.

</div>

#### Phosphates {#4.html#x-ck12-UGhvc3BoYXRlcw.._2-qnv}

Phosphate minerals have a structure similar to silicates. In silicates,
an atom of silicon is bonded to oxygen. In **phosphates** , an atom of
phosphorus, arsenic, or vanadium is bonded to oxygen. There are many
types of phosphate minerals, but phosphate minerals are rare. The
composition of phosphates is complex. For example, turquoise contains
copper, aluminum, and phosphorus ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy0zLTMtVHVycXVvaXNl) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NmVjNjk2NjVjN2I5ZGZmMmJlMGQ2OTY1M2YxZGJhMmI.-ait"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Stephanie Clifford (Flickr:sdixclifford)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/30486689@N08/2932194265/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Turquoise is a phosphate
mineral](ck12_4_files/20150911025640861698.jpeg "Turquoise is a phosphate mineral")

**Figure 4.10**

Turquoise is a phosphate mineral with a beautiful blue color. The stone
is not as rare as some minerals and is commonly used for jewelry.

</div>

#### Sulfates {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VsZmF0ZXM._2-nq6}

**Sulfate** minerals contain sulfur atoms bonded to oxygen atoms. Like
halides, they can form in places where salt water evaporates. Many
minerals belong in the sulfate group, but there are only a few common
sulfate minerals. Gypsum is a common sulfate mineral that contains
calcium, sulfate, and water. Gypsum is found in various forms. For
example, it can be pink and look like it has flower petals. However, it
can also grow into very large white crystals. Gypsum crystals that are
11-meters-long have been found. That is about as long as a school bus!
Gypsum forms at the Mammoth Hot Springs in Yellowstone National Park (
**Figure** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HeXBzdW1JbkhvdFNwcmluZ3M.)
).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ODFkMTUyZTdhMGNhNmViMjU1YjdjZmM5YzllMmEwY2Q.-0ki"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="mark byzewski" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/markbyzewski/6047217639/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Gypsum around Mammoth Hot Springs in Yellowstone National
Park](ck12_4_files/20150911025640979655.jpeg "Gypsum around Mammoth Hot Springs in Yellowstone National Park")

**Figure 4.11**

Gypsum is the white mineral that is common around hot springs. This is
Mammoth Hot Springs in Yellowstone National Park.

</div>

#### Sulfides {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VsZmlkZXM._2-k2y}

**Sulfides** contain metal elements combined with sulfur. Sulfides are
different from sulfates. They do not contain oxygen. Pyrite is a common
sulfide mineral ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy0zLTMtUHlyaXRl) ). It contains iron
combined with sulfur. Pyrite is also known as “fool’s gold.” Gold miners
have mistaken pyrite for gold because pyrite has a greenish gold color.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MGYxYmVkODI5YjNlNWUwNjA5YzhhOTAxNzBlNGFhYTQ.-fa8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright RusGri, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Pyrite, fool's gold, is a sulfide
mineral](ck12_4_files/20150911025641109534.jpeg "Pyrite, fool's gold, is a sulfide mineral")

**Figure 4.12**

Pyrite has a similar color to gold. The appearance of the striations
make pyrite different from gold.

</div>

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._2-mnk}

-   Silicates, made of building blocks of silica tetrahedrons, are the
    most abundant minerals on Earth.
-   Silica tetrahedrons combine together in six different ways to create
    rings, single and double chains, large flat sheets, or
    3-dimensional structures.
-   Other mineral groups have other chemical components like carbonates,
    oxides, or phosphates.
-   Minerals that are native elements are made of only one element.
