# Mineral Identification {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbCBJZGVudGlmaWNhdGlvbg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics that are used to identify minerals.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600928] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025641208582.jpeg)
</span>

**How do you identify a mineral?**

You're in a competition getting ready to go onstage. You discover that
you forgot your shirt! You call your mom and ask her (nicely) to bring
it to you right away. But first you need to let her know which shirt it
is. What would you tell her? You might describe the color, the way the
fabric feels, and the length of the sleeves. These are all physical
properties of your shirt. If you do a good job describing the shirt your
mom will bring the right one. Minerals also have physical properties
that are used to identify them.

### How are Minerals Identified? {#4.html#x-ck12-SG93IGFyZSBNaW5lcmFscyBJZGVudGlmaWVkPw.._3-qtm}

Imagine you were given a mineral sample similar to the pictured below (
**Figure** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HcmVlbkFjdGlub2xpdGU.) ).
You can use a mineral’s properties to identify what type it is. How
would you try to identify your mineral? You can observe some properties
by looking at the mineral. For example, you can see that its color is
green. The mineral has a needle-like, fibrous structure. But you can't
see all mineral properties. You need to do simple tests to determine
some properties. One common one is how hard the mineral is. The
mineral’s physical properties are determined by its chemical composition
and crystal structure.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ZTQzNWI1YzFhYTRlNzJkNDQ4ZTAwN2I4NmExYzE2MDg.-nmy"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Zelenskaya, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![](ck12_4_files/20150911025641300899.jpeg)

**Figure 4.13**

Green actinolite.

</div>

#### Color, Streak, and Luster {#4.html#x-ck12-Q29sb3IsIFN0cmVhaywgYW5kIEx1c3Rlcg.._3-y1c}

Diamonds have many valuable properties. Diamonds are translucent and
extremely hard. The most valuable diamonds are large, well-shaped and
sparkly. Some are not as pretty and are used for industrial purposes.
Turquoise is another mineral that is used in jewelry because of its
striking greenish-blue color. Many minerals have interesting
appearances. Specific terms are used to describe the appearance of
minerals.

#### Color {#4.html#x-ck12-Q29sb3I._3-jur}

Color is probably the easiest property to observe. Unfortunately, you
can rarely identify a mineral only by its color. Sometimes, different
minerals are the same color. For example, you might find a mineral that
is a golden color and think it is gold. But it might actually be pyrite,
or “fool's gold,” which is made of iron and sulfide. It contains no gold
atoms.

A certain mineral may form in different colors. For example, pictured
below are four samples of quartz ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1RdWFydHpWYXJpZXRpZXM.) shows),
including one that is colorless and one that is purple. The purple color
comes from a tiny amount of iron. Iron is not normally found in quartz.
When it is, it is a chemical impurity. Many minerals are colored by
chemical impurities. Other factors can also affect a mineral’s color.
Weathering changes the surface of a mineral. Because color alone is
unreliable, geologists rarely identify a mineral just on its color. To
identify most minerals, they use several properties.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MjYzZTgxODRlMWFiMjUxYTQ0NGM2MTY4OTE0NThlN2U.-b4s"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Lucky Lynda; (B) Rach (Flickr:balanced.crafts); (C) Nozomi Lindenbaum; (D) MAURO CATEB" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.flickr.com/photos/59398710@N07/5660100490/; (B) http://www.flickr.com/photos/balancedcrafts/6835896799/; http://www.flickr.com/photos/nozomi_l/8069981175/; http://www.flickr.com/photos/mauroescritor/6544460363/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![](ck12_4_files/20150911025641406873.jpeg)

**Figure 4.14**

Quartz comes in many different colors including: (A) transparent quartz,
(B) blue agate, (C) rose quartz, and (D) purple amethyst.

</div>

#### Streak {#4.html#x-ck12-U3RyZWFr_3-xaf}

**Streak** is the color of the powder of a mineral. To do a streak test,
you scrape the mineral across an unglazed porcelain plate. The plate is
harder than many minerals, causing the minerals to leave a streak of
powder on the plate. The color of the streak often differs from the
color of the larger mineral sample ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NaW5lcmFsU3RyZWFrUGxhdGU.) ).
Yellow-gold pyrite has a blackish streak. This blackish streak tells you
that the mineral is not gold, because gold has a gold-colored streak.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ODNhZjU1NjYwNzczZDgzZDU2MjFiNjlhZDlhYTFjYjE.-h5y"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Zappy's" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![](ck12_4_files/20150911025641504283.jpeg)

**Figure 4.15**

Rub a mineral across an unglazed porcelain plate to see its streak.
Hematite has a reddish-brown streak.

</div>

Streak is more reliable than color to identify minerals. Different
minerals that are the same color may have a different color streak. For
example, samples of hematite and galena are both dark gray. They can be
told apart because hematite has a red streak and galena has a gray
streak.

#### Luster {#4.html#x-ck12-THVzdGVy_3-au3}

**Luster** describes the way light reflects off of the surface of the
mineral. You might describe diamonds as sparkly or pyrite as shiny. But
mineralogists have special terms to describe luster. They first divide
minerals into metallic and non-metallic luster. Minerals that are opaque
and shiny, like pyrite, are said to have a “metallic” luster. Minerals
with a “non-metallic” luster do not look like metals. There are many
types of non-metallic luster. Six are described below ( **Table**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6bWluZXJhbHNfbm9ubWV0YWxsaWM.) ).

  **Non-Metallic Luster**   **Appearance**
  ------------------------- -------------------------------
  Adamantine                Sparkly
  Earthy                    Dull, clay-like
  Pearly                    Pearl-like
  Resinous                  Like resins, such as tree sap
  Silky                     Soft-looking with long fibers
  Vitreous                  Glassy

Can you match the minerals ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NaW5lcmFsQ29tcG9zaXRl) ) with the
correct luster, listed above ( **Table**
[above](#4.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6bWluZXJhbHNfbm9ubWV0YWxsaWM.) ), without
looking at the caption?

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ZWE0MmEzYmZhNjk0ZGE4ZTc3MTE3ZTQwZDk4NTM2NmU.-sr8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) FancyDiamonds.net; (C) Tony Hisgett (Flickr:ahisgett); (B) Emanuele Longo; (D) Deidre Woollard; (E) Kevin Walsh (Flickr:kevinzim); (F) Dave Dyet; (G) Courtesy of the US Geological Survey and Mineral Information Institute; (H) Flickr:BobMacInnes" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.flickr.com/photos/fancy-diamonds/5511634443/; (B) http://www.flickr.com/photos/em4nu/2700330797/; (C) http://www.flickr.com/photos/hisgett/8030287889/; (D) http://www.flickr.com/photos/deidrew/4918639189/; (E) http://www.flickr.com/photos/86624586@N00/5945787093/; (F) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Ulexite_w-clay_and_realgar_Hydrous_sodium_calcium_borate_Boron_Kern_County_California_1866.jpg; (G) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sphalerite2USGOV.jpg; (H) http://www.flickr.com/photos/lonetown/378758972/" -->
<!-- @@license="(A-E, H) CC BY 2.0; (F-G) Public Domain" -->
![](ck12_4_files/20150911025641609837.jpeg)

**Figure 4.16**

\(A) Diamonds have an adamantine luster. These minerals are transparent
and highly reflective. (B) Kaolinite is a clay with a dull or earthy
luster. (C) Opal’s luster is greasy. (D) Chalcopyrite, like its cousin
pyrite, has metallic luster. (E) Stilbite (orange) has a resinous
luster. (F) The white ulexite has silky luster. (G) Sphalerite has a
submetallic luster. (H) Chert is a mineral with a waxy luster.

</div>

#### Density {#4.html#x-ck12-RGVuc2l0eQ.._3-eov}

You are going to visit a friend. You fill one backpack with books so you
can study later. You stuff your pillow into another backpack that is the
same size. Which backpack will be easier to carry? Even though the
backpacks are the same size, the bag that contains your books is going
to be much heavier. It has a greater density than the backpack with your
pillow.

**Density** describes how much matter is in a certain amount of space.
Substances that have more matter packed into a given space have higher
densities. The water in a drinking glass has the same density as the
water in a bathtub or swimming pool. All substances have characteristic
densities, which does not depend on how much of a substance you have.

Mass is a measure of the amount of matter in an object. The amount of
space an object takes up is described by its volume. The density of an
object depends on its mass and its volume. Density can be calculated
using the following equation:

![\\text{Density}\\; =\\;
\\text{Mass}/\\text{Volume}](ck12_math_images_dir/9e616a18cd4ac8d96732d40a53451c14.png)

Samples that are the same size but have different densities, will have
different masses. Gold has a density of about 19 g/cm ^3^ . Pyrite has a
density of only about 5 g/cm ^3^ . Quartz is even less dense than pyrite
and has a density of 2.7 g/cm ^3^ . If you picked up a piece of pyrite
and a piece of quartz that were the same size, the pyrite would seem
almost twice as heavy as the quartz.

Specific gravity is used to identify minerals. **Specific gravity**
measures how heavy the mineral is relative to the same volume of water.

#### Hardness {#4.html#x-ck12-SGFyZG5lc3M._3-d2j}

**Hardness** is a mineral’s ability to resist being scratched. Minerals
that are not easily scratched are hard. You test the hardness of a
mineral by scratching its surface with a mineral of a known hardness.
Mineralogists use the Mohs Hardness Scale ( **Table**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6TW9oc19TY2FsZQ..) ), as a reference for
mineral hardness. The scale lists common minerals in order of their
relative hardness. You can use the minerals in the scale to test the
hardness of an unknown mineral.

#### Mohs Hardness Scale {#4.html#x-ck12-TW9ocyBIYXJkbmVzcyBTY2FsZQ.._3-1te}

As you can see, diamond is a 10 on the Mohs Hardness Scale. Diamond is
the hardest mineral; no other mineral can scratch a diamond. Quartz is a
7. It can be scratched by topaz, corundum, and diamond. Quartz will
scratch minerals that have a lower number on the scale. Fluorite is one.
Suppose you had a piece of pure gold. You find that calcite scratches
the gold. Gypsum does not. Gypsum has a hardness of 2 and calcite is a
3. That means the hardness of gold is between gypsum and calcite. So the
hardness of gold is about 2.5 on the scale. A hardness of 2.5 means that
gold is a relatively soft mineral. It is only about as hard as your
fingernail.

  **Hardness**   **Mineral**
  -------------- ---------------------
  1              Talc
  2              Gypsum
  3              Calcite
  4              Fluorite
  5              Apatite
  6              Orthoclase feldspar
  7              Quartz
  8              Topaz
  9              Corundum
  10             Diamond

#### Cleavage and Fracture {#4.html#x-ck12-Q2xlYXZhZ2UgYW5kIEZyYWN0dXJl_3-1is}

Different types of minerals break apart in their own way. Remember that
all minerals are crystals. This means that the atoms in a mineral are
arranged in a repeating pattern. This pattern determines how a mineral
will break. When you break a mineral, you break chemical bonds. Because
of the way the atoms are arranged, some bonds are weaker than other
bonds. A mineral is more likely to break where the bonds between the
atoms are weaker.

#### Cleavage {#4.html#x-ck12-Q2xlYXZhZ2U._3-sfl}

**Cleavage** is the tendency of a mineral to break along certain planes.
When a mineral breaks along a plane, it makes a smooth surface. Minerals
with different crystal structures will break or cleave in different ways
( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DbGVhdmFnZUNvbXBvc2l0ZQ..) ). Halite
tends to form cubes with smooth surfaces. Mica tends to form sheets.
Fluorite can form octahedrons.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MjMxZWFkNTQzYTM3MGQyMGZjZTE5YmJjNDE1ODYzYmY.-vpr"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Image copyright Nadezda Boltaca, 2014; (B) Image copyright Tyler Boyes, 2014; (C) Image copyright Nicholas Sutcliffe, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![](ck12_4_files/20150911025641933703.jpeg)

**Figure 4.17**

Minerals with different crystal structures have a tendency to break
along certain planes. (A) Halite breaks into cubes. (B) Muscovite breaks
into sheets. (C) Fluorite breaks into octagons.

</div>

Minerals can form various shapes. Polygons are pictured below (
**Figure** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NaW5lcmFsU3RydWN0dXJlcw..)
). The shapes form as the minerals are broken along their cleavage
planes. Cleavage planes determine how the crystals can be cut to make
smooth surfaces. People who cut gemstones follow cleavage planes.
Diamonds and emeralds can be cut to make beautiful gemstones.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MTk0MjY0NmRlZjVjNTgzMGY3MDlkNmFkYWZhMDVkODk.-6fg"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) User:PDD/Pl.Wikipedia; (B) User:Tomruen/Wikipedia; (C) User:KoenB/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hexahedron_grey.png; (B) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Rhombohedron.png; (C) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Octahedron-wireframe.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![](ck12_4_files/20150911025642045348.png)

**Figure 4.18**

\(A) Cubes have six sides that are all the same size square. All of the
angles in a cube are equal to 90°. (B) Rhombohedra also have six sides,
but the sides are diamond-shaped. (C) Octahedra have eight sides that
are all shaped like triangles.

</div>

#### Fracture {#4.html#x-ck12-RnJhY3R1cmU._3-w0l}

**Fracture** describes how a mineral breaks without any pattern. A
fracture is uneven. The surface is not smooth and flat. You can learn
about a mineral from the way it fractures. If a mineral splinters like
wood, it may be fibrous. Some minerals, such as quartz, fracture to form
smooth, curved surfaces. Pictured below is a mineral that broke forming
a smooth, curved surface ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1PYnNpZGlhbkNsZWF2YWdl) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-N2ZkYWFjNGE1ZTM2YmE2ZDY2ODQ0ZjI2YWRjNGM5MTE.-dyt"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Karelj/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Obsidian_1.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![This mineral formed a smooth, curved surface when it
fractured](ck12_4_files/20150911025642149490.jpeg "This mineral formed a smooth, curved surface when it fractured")

**Figure 4.19**

This mineral formed a smooth, curved surface when it fractured.

</div>

#### Other Identifying Characteristics {#4.html#x-ck12-T3RoZXIgSWRlbnRpZnlpbmcgQ2hhcmFjdGVyaXN0aWNz_3-o4r}

Minerals have other properties that can be used for identification. For
example, a mineral’s shape may indicate its crystal structure. Sometimes
crystals are too small to see. Then a mineralogist may use a special
instrument to find the crystal structure.

Some minerals have unique properties. These can be used to the minerals.
Listed below are some of these properties ( **Table**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6U3BlY2lhbF9NaW5fUHJvcA..) ); an example
of a mineral that has each property is also listed.

  **Property**    **Description**                                                        **Example of Mineral**
  --------------- ---------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------
  Fluorescence    Mineral glows under ultraviolet light                                  Fluorite
  Magnetism       Mineral is attracted to a magnet                                       Magnetite
  Radioactivity   Mineral gives off radiation that can be measured with Geiger counter   Uraninite
  Reactivity      Bubbles form when mineral is exposed to a weak acid                    Calcite
  Smell           Some minerals have a distinctive smell                                 Sulfur (smells like rotten eggs)

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._3-9hb}

-   Some minerals have a unique property that makes them fairly easy
    to identify. But many do not.
-   Different minerals can be identified by different properties.
-   Cleavage can be a unique and beautiful indicator of mineral type.

# Mineral Formation {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbCBGb3JtYXRpb24.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain different ways in which minerals form.
-   Distinguish lava from magma.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600933] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025642248310.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you watch minerals forming?**

Sure! Some kids get crystal growing kits. They mix up a solution and
evaporate off the water. Mineral crystals are left behind. This is
similar to the way halite and some other minerals form. These minerals
evaporate from salt water.

### Mineral Formation {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbCBGb3JtYXRpb24._4-lbz}

Minerals form in a variety of ways. Some minerals form from very hot
fluids. Some form from cool fluids. Some form when solid minerals
rearrange.

#### Formation from Magma and Lava {#4.html#x-ck12-Rm9ybWF0aW9uIGZyb20gTWFnbWEgYW5kIExhdmE._4-2xc}

You are on vacation at the beach. You take your flip-flops off so you
can go swimming. The sand is so hot it hurts your feet. You have to run
to the water. Now imagine if it were hot enough for the sand to melt.

Some places inside Earth are so hot that rock melts. Melted rock inside
the Earth is called magma. **Magma** can be hotter than 1,000 ^o^ C.
When magma erupts onto Earth’s surface, it is known as **lava** (
**Figure** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Mb3dTaWxpY2FMYXZh) ).
Minerals form when magma and lava cool. Some minerals crystallize at
hotter temperatures. These minerals form first. Other minerals form at
cooler temperatures. These minerals form later.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NDEwOTVjYjRkMzdlZjNiMTNlNGMzNjI3NmYxYTQwMGI.-fqr"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hawaiian.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Lava is melted rock that erupts onto Earth’s
surface](ck12_4_files/20150911025642351068.jpeg "Lava is melted rock that erupts onto Earth’s surface")

**Figure 4.20**

Lava is melted rock that erupts onto Earth’s surface.

</div>

#### Formation from Solutions {#4.html#x-ck12-Rm9ybWF0aW9uIGZyb20gU29sdXRpb25z_4-wrs}

Most water on Earth, like the water in the oceans, contains elements.
The elements are mixed evenly through the water. Water plus other
substances makes a solution. The particles are so small that they will
not come out when you filter the water. But the elements in water can
form solid mineral deposits.

#### Minerals from Salt Water {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbHMgZnJvbSBTYWx0IFdhdGVy_4-dgp}

Fresh water contains a small amount of dissolved elements. Salt water
contains many more dissolved elements. Water can only hold a certain
amount of dissolved substances. When the water evaporates, it leaves
behind a solid layer of minerals ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTAzMDMtMDQ.) ). At this time, the
particles come together to form minerals. These solids sink to the
bottom. The amount of mineral formed is the same as the amount dissolved
in the water. Seawater is salty enough for minerals to precipitate as
solids. Some lakes, such as Mono Lake in California, or Utah's Great
Salt Lake, can also precipitate salts.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MWNlZTY3MGI0Nzg4N2M2YWI1OWE5OWU3NzgxYTc3ZWU.-061"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Rebecca Calhoun" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Crystals form when water
evaporates](ck12_4_files/20150911025642452181.jpeg "Crystals form when water evaporates")

**Figure 4.21**

When the water in glass A evaporates, the dissolved mineral particles
are left behind.

</div>

Salt easily precipitates out of water, as does calcite ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Nb25vTGFrZVR1ZmE.) ). The limestone
towers pictured below are made mostly of the mineral calcite. The
calcite was deposited in the salty and alkaline water of Mono Lake, in
California. Calcium-rich spring water enters the bottom of the lake. The
water bubbles up into the alkaline lake. The calcite “tufa” towers form.
When the lake level drops, the tufa towers are revealed.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NzQ5MDg3MmFmN2VjMDUyMjIxZDNlOWNiZWM5M2E0NTE.-bv6"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Clinton Steeds" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/cwsteeds/98597918/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Tufa towers in Mono
Lake](ck12_4_files/20150911025642547486.jpeg "Tufa towers in Mono Lake")

**Figure 4.22**

Tufa towers are found in interesting formations at Mono Lake,
California.

</div>

#### Minerals from Hot Underground Water {#4.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbHMgZnJvbSBIb3QgVW5kZXJncm91bmQgV2F0ZXI._4-ycb}

Underground water can be heated by magma. The hot water moves through
cracks below Earth’s surface. Hot water can hold more dissolved
particles than cold water. The hot, salty solution has chemical
reactions with the rocks around it. The water picks up more dissolved
particles. As it flows through open spaces in rocks, the water deposits
solid minerals. When a mineral fills cracks in rocks, the deposits are
called **veins** . Pictured below is a white quartz vein ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1RdWFydHpDb21wb3NpdGU.) ). When the
minerals are deposited in open spaces, large crystals grow. These rocks
are called geodes. Pictured below is a *geode* that was formed when
amethyst crystals grew in an open space in a rock ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1RdWFydHpDb21wb3NpdGU.) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MjE4MjhlY2Y4MDZhZGIzZWNlNTAyZjFiNmY3YmJkMmY.-hdj"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) James St. John (Flickr:jsj1771); (B) Rach (Flickr:balanced.crafts)" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.flickr.com/photos/jsjgeology/8290507689/; (B) http://www.flickr.com/photos/balancedcrafts/6835895993/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of a quartz vein and a
geode](ck12_4_files/20150911025642650749.jpeg "Picture of a quartz vein and a geode")

**Figure 4.23**

\(A) A quartz vein formed in this rock. (B) Geodes form when minerals
evaporate out in open spaces inside a rock.

</div>

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._4-lt7}

-   Minerals form as magma or lava cools.
-   Minerals form when they precipitate from hot fluids that have
    cooled down.
-   Minerals form from dissolved substances when water evaporates.

# Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-Um9ja3M.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define rock.
-   Describe the three major rock types.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600938] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025642776292.jpeg)
</span>

**Will this rock be there forever?**

Rocks may seem permanent, but they're not. Over time a rock will change
into another type of rock. How this happens is known as the **rock
cycle** . There are three main types of rocks. There are several
processes that can change one type into another. First we need to learn
what the rocks types and processes are.

### What is a Rock? {#4.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBpcyBhIFJvY2s__5-ots}

A **rock** is a naturally formed, non-living Earth material. Rocks are
made of minerals. The minerals may be so tiny that you can only see them
with a microscope. The minerals may be really large. A rock may be made
of only one type of mineral. More often rocks are made of a mixture of
different minerals. A few types of rocks are made from materials that
are not minerals. For example, coal is organic so it is not a mineral,
nor is it made of minerals. Yet coal is a rock.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MWNkYjg3ZGQ0YTUxZDUzZmRkYWE4MDQ1ZDhlYjc1MDY.-zbm"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) www.sqfp.info; (B) James St. John (Flickr:jsj1771); (C) Smabs Sputzer; (D) Stephanie Clifford (Flickr:sdixclifford)" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.flickr.com/photos/shoshot/6242792071/; (B) http://www.flickr.com/photos/jsjgeology/8456423420/;(C) http://www.flickr.com/photos/10413717@N08/6821888672/; (D) http://www.flickr.com/photos/30486689@N08/2932215767/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of granite, basalt, coal, and
jade](ck12_4_files/20150911025643220725.jpeg "Picture of granite, basalt, coal, and jade")

**Figure 4.24**

\(A) Granite has large crystals because it cools slowly. (B) Basalt has
very small crystals because it cools quickly. (C) Coal is made up of
organic material. (D) Jade is made of the mineral jadeite.

</div>

Rocks are named for the combinations of minerals they are made of and
the ways those minerals came together. Remember that different minerals
form under different environmental conditions. So the minerals in a rock
contain clues about the conditions in which the rock formed ( **Figure**
[above](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Sb2NrQ29tcG9zaXRl) ).

### Rock Types {#4.html#x-ck12-Um9jayBUeXBlcw.._5-ldo}

Geologists group rocks based on how they form. There are three major
rock types. Each will be described in more detail in the coming
concepts.

-   **Igneous rocks** form when magma cools below Earth’s surface or
    lava cools at the surface.

<!-- -->

-   **Sedimentary rocks** form when sediments are compacted and
    cemented together. **Sediments** are pieces of rock. They may be
    gravel, sand, silt, or clay. Some sedimentary rocks form the solid
    minerals left behind after a liquid evaporates.

<!-- -->

-   **Metamorphic rocks** form when an existing rock is changed by heat
    or pressure. The minerals in the rock change but do not melt. The
    rock experiences these changes within the Earth.

Rocks can change from one type to another. The rock cycle describes how
this happens.

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._5-c1x}

-   Nearly all rocks are made of minerals. A few are made of materials
    that do not fit the definition of minerals.
-   Igneous rocks form from cooled magma or lava.
-   Metamorphic rocks form as an existing rock is altered by high
    temperature or pressure.
-   Sedimentary rocks form from sediments that are cemented
    and compacted.

# Igneous Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-SWduZW91cyBSb2Nrcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe igneous rocks.
-   Explain igneous rock compositions.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600942] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025643344949.jpeg)
</span>

**Have you seen igneous rocks in the field?**

Igneous rocks are everywhere! One of the most common igneous rocks that
make up the crust is granite. Many mountain ranges are made of granite.
The spectacular features of Yosemite Valley, like Half Dome, are
granitic. Volcanoes are made of igneous rocks, such as basalt. Igneous
rocks are also found where you can't see them. Oceanic crust is mostly
basalt and gabbro. The mantle is peridotite.

### Igneous Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-SWduZW91cyBSb2Nrcw.._6-wkh}

Igneous rocks form when **magma** cools and forms crystals. Magma is
melted rock. What an igneous rock looks like is determined by two
things. One is the composition of the magma. The other is how fast the
magma cools. The rate of cooling determines the texture of the rock.

#### Composition {#4.html#x-ck12-Q29tcG9zaXRpb24._6-sfz}

Different igneous rocks contain minerals with different compositions.
**Mafic** igneous rocks contain mafic minerals. Mafic minerals are dense
and dark in color. They typically contain iron and magnesium; they are
low in silica. Olivine and pyroxene are mafic minerals.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-OGQ2ZTYyMWI1NDZlYTU1OGExNDRjNjYwOTQ0NjJjZjY.-wvx"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Omphacite/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Perid_SanCarlos.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Olivine and pyroxene are mafic igneous
rocks](ck12_4_files/20150911025643497218.jpeg "Olivine and pyroxene are mafic igneous rocks")

**Figure 4.25**

Olivine is the green mineral, pyroxene is the black mineral.

</div>

**Felsic** igneous rocks contain felsic minerals. They typically contain
aluminum and sodium; they are high in silica. Quartz and potassium
feldspar are felsic minerals. Minerals and rocks with a composition in
between mafic and felsic are called intermediate.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ZjhkM2FlZGM2N2NhMWE5MjZmZTczNzA2M2ViODE5MWU.-wy8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Kevin Walsh" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Spanish_granite.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Feldspar and quartz are felsic igneous
rocks](ck12_4_files/20150911025643587869.jpeg "Feldspar and quartz are felsic igneous rocks")

**Figure 4.26**

Potassium feldspar is the pink mineral, plagioclase feldspar is the
white mineral, and quartz is the gray mineral.

</div>

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._6-vky}

-   Magma cools to form igneous rocks. Two factors determine what type
    of rock forms.
-   The composition of the magma determines if the rock is mafic,
    felsic, or intermediate.
-   The rate the magma cools determines the texture of the rock.

# Intrusive and Extrusive Igneous Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-SW50cnVzaXZlIGFuZCBFeHRydXNpdmUgSWduZW91cyBSb2Nrcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Compare and contrast intrusive and extrusive igneous rock.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600947] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025643701204.jpeg)
</span>

**Are these both igneous rocks?**

These rocks don't even look like they're the same type! They are, at
least in the same way that fish and mice are both vertebrates. They both
cooled from magma, but the similarities end there. Can you tell what's
different?

### Cooling {#4.html#x-ck12-Q29vbGluZw.._7-cbz}

Igneous rocks cool from magma. The appearance of the rock is created by
the composition of the magma. It is also determined by the rate that the
magma cools. If the magma cools deep underground, it cools slowly. If
the magma cools at or very near the surface, it cools quickly. This
results in two different rock types. The rock types can be told apart by
the size of their crystals. The size of the crystals creates the texture
of the rock.

#### Intrusive Igneous Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-SW50cnVzaXZlIElnbmVvdXMgUm9ja3M._7-7hv}

**Intrusive** igneous rocks cool underground. Deep in the crust, magma
cools slowly. Slow cooling gives crystals a chance to grow. Intrusive
igneous rocks have relatively large crystals that are easy to see.
Intrusive igneous rocks are also called plutonic. A **pluton** is an
igneous rock body that forms within the crust.

Granite is the most common intrusive igneous rock. Pictured below are
four types of intrusive rocks ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1JZ25lb3VzUm9ja0NvbXBvc2l0ZQ..) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ZGQ1MmQyOWQ4N2NiNmEyMmQ0NjMzZDI1Mzc2OGYzZjE.-l5i"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Image copyright MARGRIT HIRSCH, 2013; (B) Image copyright Tyler Boyes, 2013; (C)  Mark A. Wilson (Department of Geology, The College of Wooster); (D) Image copyright Marcin Sylwia Ciesielski, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="(A, B, D) http://www.shutterstock.com; (C) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:GabbroRockCreek1.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="(A, B, D) Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com; (C) Public domain" -->
![Granite, diorite, gabbro, and peridotite are all intrusive igneous
rocks](ck12_4_files/20150911025643816180.png "Granite, diorite, gabbro, and peridotite are all intrusive igneous rocks")

**Figure 4.27**

\(A) This granite has more plagioclase feldspar than many granites. (B)
Diorite has more dark-colored minerals than granite. (C) Gabbro. (D)
Peridotite contains olivine and other mafic minerals.

</div>

Geological processes have brought some igneous rocks to the surface.
Pictured below is a landscape in California’s Sierra Nevada Mountains
made of granite that has been raised to create mountains ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1MYWtlc0Jhc2luU2llcnJhTmV2YWRh) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ZmJhYmZhZTBmOTE5OTYzZDlhMmMzMjliZGJlZjhlODI.-8jp"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Dcrjsr/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:20LakesBasin_W_half_from_Secret_Lake.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 3.0" -->
![The Sierra Nevada Mountains are made of intrusive igneous
rock](ck12_4_files/20150911025643945937.jpeg "The Sierra Nevada Mountains are made of intrusive igneous rock")

**Figure 4.28**

California’s Sierra Nevada Mountains are intrusive igneous rock exposed
at Earth’s surface.

</div>

#### Extrusive Igneous Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-RXh0cnVzaXZlIElnbmVvdXMgUm9ja3M._7-ntu}

**Extrusive** igneous rocks form above the surface. The lava cools
quickly as it pours out onto the surface ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1FeHRydXNpdmVJZ25lb3VzQ29tcG9zaXRl) ).
Extrusive igneous rocks cool much more rapidly than intrusive rocks. The
rapid cooling time does not allow time for large crystals to form. So
igneous extrusive rocks have smaller crystals than igneous intrusive
rocks. Extrusive igneous rocks are also called **volcanic rocks** .

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ODQ5NTBiNTA3ZjM5OTRkZTBmNWMzN2U5ZTY1NzZkMmY.-4v9"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Courtesy of J.D. Griggs, US Geological Survey; (B) Flickr:SonoranDesertNPS" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pahoeoe_fountain_edit2.jpg; (B) http://www.flickr.com/photos/npssodn/6127116919/" -->
<!-- @@license="(A) Public Domain; (B) CC BY 2.0" -->
![Lava cools to form extrusive igneous rock, and rhyolite formations in
Chiricahua National
Monument](ck12_4_files/20150911025644020674.jpeg "Lava cools to form extrusive igneous rock, and rhyolite formations in Chiricahua National Monument")

**Figure 4.29**

\(A) Lava cools to form extrusive igneous rock. The rocks here are
basalts. (B) The strange rock formations of Chiricahua National Monument
in Arizona are formed of the extrusive igneous rock rhyolite.

</div>

Some extrusive igneous rocks cool so rapidly that crystals do not
develop at all. These form a glass, such as obsidian. Others, such as
pumice, contain holes where gas bubbles were trapped in the lava. The
holes make pumice so light that it actually floats in water. The most
common extrusive igneous rock is basalt. It is the rock that makes up
the ocean floor. Shown below are three types of extrusive igneous rocks
( **Figure** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-RmlndXJlLTA0LTE0LVRleHR1cmVz) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-YTFiNjlhYmU2YTQ0NzFlNjNhM2E2NDhiZjVlNTQyNDM.-g4p"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(a) Kevin Walsh (Flickr: kevinzim); (b) User:deltalimatrieste/Wikimedia Commons; (c) Courtesy of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration" -->
<!-- @@url="(a) http://www.flickr.com/photos/86624586@N00/1125946364/; (b) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pomice_di_veglia.jpg; (c) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pillow_basalt_crop_l.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="(a) CC BY 2.0; (b) Public Domain; (c) Public Domain" -->
![Obsidian, pumice, and basalt are extrusive igneous rocks that cool at
different
rates](ck12_4_files/20150911025644115398.jpeg "Obsidian, pumice, and basalt are extrusive igneous rocks that cool at different rates")

**Figure 4.30**

Different cooling rate and gas content resulted in these different
textures.

</div>

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._7-2ds}

-   Intrusive igneous rocks cool from magma slowly in the crust. They
    have large crystals.
-   Extrusive igneous rocks cool from lava rapidly at the surface. They
    have small crystals.
-   Texture reflects how an igneous rock formed.

# Igneous Rock Classification {#4.html#x-ck12-SWduZW91cyBSb2NrIENsYXNzaWZpY2F0aW9u}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how igneous rocks are classified by composition and by
    cooling rate.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600951] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025644201643.jpeg)
</span>

**Is this igneous rock intrusive or extrusive?**

You can't really tell from this view. A close up view would show small
crystals in a dark colored rock. This indicates rapid cooling from a
basalt lava. The most interesting feature you can see are the hexagonal
"posts." For them to form, cooling must not have been too rapid. This
amazing feature is Devil's Tower in Wyoming.

### Igneous Rock Classification {#4.html#x-ck12-SWduZW91cyBSb2NrIENsYXNzaWZpY2F0aW9u_8-nzw}

Igneous rocks are classified by composition and texture. The composition
can be felsic, intermediate, mafic, or ultramafic. The composition
depends on the minerals the rock includes. A felsic rock will contain
felsic minerals.

The mineral compositions are listed in the **Table**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6aWduZW91c19wcm9wZXJ0aWVz) . The table
includes examples of minerals.

  **Composition**   **Color**      **Density**    **Minerals**
  ----------------- -------------- -------------- ------------------------------------------
  Felsic            Light          Low            Quartz, orthoclase feldspar
  Intermediate      Intermediate   Intermediate   Plagioclase feldspar, biotite, amphibole
  Mafic             Dark           High           Olivine, pyroxene
  Ultramafic        Very dark      Very high      Olivine

Texture indicates how the magma cooled. Magma that cools rapidly has
small or no visible crystals. Magma that cools slowly has large
crystals; reference the **Table**
[above](#4.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6aWduZW91c19wcm9wZXJ0aWVz) for the type of
rock, the amount of silica it has, and examples.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-MWYxN2Q4Y2YxOWFmMWIyZTBlMGVhZWI0NzJlNjViMjY.-dus"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Images copyright Tyler Boyes, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Comparison between rhyolite and
granite](ck12_4_files/20150911025644323233.jpeg "Comparison between rhyolite and granite")

**Figure 4.31**

Is this an intrusive or an extrusive igneous rock?

</div>

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-N2RiNzMwMGZlNGRkZDgzZDhiYmI2YmRiOTY3ZTVjZWU.-1bv"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Images copyright Tyler Boyes, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Comparison between basalt and
gabbro](ck12_4_files/20150911025644428144.jpeg "Comparison between basalt and gabbro")

**Figure 4.32**

Is this an intrusive or an extrusive igneous rock?

</div>

Pictured above are two pairs of igneous rocks ( **Figures**
[above](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1JZ25lb3VzRmVsc2ljQ29tcG9zaXRl) and
[above](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1JZ25lb3VzTWFmaWNDb21wb3NpdGU.) ). The
first pair is two rocks that formed from a felsic magma. The rhyolite
cooled rapidly, and the granite cooled slowly. The second pair is two
rocks that formed from mafic magma. The basalt cooled rapidly, and the
gabbro cooled slowly. The color of the rocks and sizes of the crystals
are your clues. There are other rock pairs that you could find listed
below ( **Table** [below](#4.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6c2lsaWNh) ).

  **Type**              **Amount of Silica**   **Extrusive**   **Intrusive**
  --------------------- ---------------------- --------------- ---------------
  Ultramafic            &lt;45%                Komatiite       Peridotite
  Mafic                 45-52%                 Basalt          Gabbro
  Intermediate          52-63%                 Andesite        Diorite
  Intermediate-Felsic   63-69%                 Dacite          Granodiorite
  Felsic                &gt;69% SiO ~2~        Rhyolite        Granite

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._8-xhb}

-   Igneous rocks are classified first by composition. Categories go
    from from felsic to ultramafic. Color can indicate composition.
-   Texture is second when classifying igneous rocks. Texture indicates
    how a rock cooled.
-   Igneous rocks are categorized in pairs. The two rocks in a pair have
    the same composition but different textures: gabbro-basalt,
    diorite-andesite, and granite-rhyolite.

# Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnRhcnkgUm9ja3M.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe sediments.
-   Describe how sediments become sedimentary rocks.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600957] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025644539895.jpeg)
</span>

**Where can you go to see sediments?**

Sediments are everywhere! One of the most fun places to see sediments is
on a beach. Squishing sand between your toes is a great way to
experience sediments first hand (or foot).

### Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnRhcnkgUm9ja3M._9-tm3}

Most sedimentary rocks form from sediments. The sediments must be packed
together to form a rock. Sedimentary rocks also form as minerals
precipitate from saline water. Sedimentary rock formation is described
in the next concept.

#### Sediments {#4.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnRz_9-ewu}

**Sediments** are small fragments of rocks and minerals. Pebbles, sand,
silt, and clay are examples of sediments. Sedimentary rocks may include
fossils. **Fossils** are materials left behind by once-living organisms.
Fossils can be pieces of the organism, like bones. They can also be
traces of the organism, like footprints.

#### Transport {#4.html#x-ck12-VHJhbnNwb3J0_9-gyc}

Sediments are transported by water, wind, ice, or gravity. These agents
move them from the place where they formed. The sediments are then
deposited in a location.

#### Deposition {#4.html#x-ck12-RGVwb3NpdGlvbg.._9-rfj}

Sediments will eventually settle out of water ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1CZWFjaFNlZGltZW50cw..) ). For example,
rivers carry lots of sediment. Where the water slows, it dumps these
sediments along its banks, into lakes and the ocean.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NzNlYzdlMTZhZjEwMTgyOWUwMmY1ZTZlNmY2ZjI5YWY.-ywo"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Steven Depolo" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/stevendepolo/3902888070/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Cobbles, pebbles, and sand on a beach are all
sediments](ck12_4_files/20150911025644653278.jpeg "Cobbles, pebbles, and sand on a beach are all sediments")

**Figure 4.33**

Cobbles, pebbles, and sands are the sediments that are seen on this
beach.

</div>

When sediments settle out of water, they form horizontal layers. A layer
of sediment is deposited. Then the next layer is deposited on top of
that layer. So each layer in a sedimentary rock is younger than the
layer under it ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HcmFuZENhbnlvblN0cmF0YQ..) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NTQzY2NjMDM5OWIyMWE3OTk4YWE3NTA2NjA5MjE5NDQ.-3ck"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Grand Canyon National Park" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/grand_canyon_nps/6050775941/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Rock layers on top of the Grand Canyon are newer than the bottom
ones](ck12_4_files/20150911025644765203.jpeg "Rock layers on top of the Grand Canyon are newer than the bottom ones")

**Figure 4.34**

The rock layers at the Grand Canyon are horizontal. We know that layers
at the bottom are older than layers at the top.

</div>

Sediments are deposited in many different types of environments. Beaches
and deserts collect large deposits of sand. Sediments also end up at the
bottom of the ocean and in lakes, ponds, rivers, marshes, and swamps.
Avalanches produce large piles of sediment. The environment where the
sediments are deposited determines the type of sedimentary rock that can
form.

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._9-x4r}

-   Sediments are small fragments of minerals, rocks, or fossils.
-   Sediments range in size from tiny bits of silt or clay to
    enormous boulders.
-   Sediments are deposited in many different environments.

# Lithification of Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-TGl0aGlmaWNhdGlvbiBvZiBTZWRpbWVudGFyeSBSb2Nrcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how sediments become rock.
-   Distinguish clastic and chemical sedimentary rocks.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600961] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025644876385.jpeg)
</span>

**What steps led to this rock formation?**

What do you see? The rock is a sandstone, so first there were rocks that
weathered and eroded. The cross-bedding indicates that the sand was
deposited in a dune. The sand was then buried deeply enough that it
turned into rock. This concept will explore how something like sand
could become a rock.

### Sedimentary Rock Formation {#4.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnRhcnkgUm9jayBGb3JtYXRpb24._10-x1s}

There are two main types of sedimentary rocks: clastic and chemical.
Clastic rocks are made of sediments, which are sometimes called clasts.
Creating rocks from sediments is called **lithification** . Chemicals
precipitate from liquid to form chemical sedimentary rocks.

#### Clastic Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-Q2xhc3RpYyBSb2Nrcw.._10-dtf}

Over time, deposited sediments may harden into rock. First, the
sediments are **compacted** . That is, they are squeezed together by the
weight of sediments on top of them. Next, the sediments are **cemented**
together. Minerals fill in the spaces between the loose sediment
particles. These cementing minerals come from the water that moves
through the sediments. Sedimentary rocks that form from sediments are
called “clastic rocks.“ Clastic rocks are rock fragments that are
compacted and cemented together ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DbGFzdGljQ29tcG9zaXRl) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-ODQ2MDdhZjEwZmUzY2EwYzAxNjY4YzFlODZiZjg5YmI.-ycr"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Conglomerate: Image copyright Lagui, 2013; Sandstone: Image copyright Sura Nualpradid, 2013; Mudstone: Image copyright Le Do, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Conglomerate, sandstone, and mudstone have different sediment
sizes](ck12_4_files/20150911025645088363.jpeg "Conglomerate, sandstone, and mudstone have different sediment sizes")

**Figure 4.35**

Conglomerates have larger clasts than sandstone, which have larger
clasts than mudstone.

</div>

#### Chemical Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-Q2hlbWljYWwgU2VkaW1lbnRhcnkgUm9ja3M._10-pva}

Chemical sedimentary rocks form when crystals precipitate out from a
liquid. The mineral halite, also called rock salt, forms this way. You
can make halite! Leave a shallow dish of salt water out in the Sun. As
the water evaporates, salt crystals form in the dish. There are other
chemical sedimentary rocks, like gypsum ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HeXBzdW1Qcm9wZXJ0aWVz) ).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NDY0MGQ4ZGFhZjI5OGFlYTc5YjhlZDk5MDA2ZTQ2NjU.-vjw"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Tommy (Flickr:paleo_bear)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/paleo_bear/8540760709/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Gypsum is a chemical sedimentary
rock](ck12_4_files/20150911025645197363.jpeg "Gypsum is a chemical sedimentary rock")

**Figure 4.36**

Gypsum, with its rose-like structure, is a chemical sedimentary rock.

</div>

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-emk}

-   Compaction and cementation lead to lithification of
    sedimentary rocks.
-   Sediments are compacted by the weight of the rocks and sediments
    above them.
-   Sediments are cemented by fluids that bind sediments together.
-   Minerals precipitate to form sedimentary rocks.

# Sedimentary Rock Classification {#4.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnRhcnkgUm9jayBDbGFzc2lmaWNhdGlvbg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how sedimentary rocks are classified.
-   List some common sedimentary rocks.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600967] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025645320952.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you tell which type of rock these are?**

If you look up close, you would be able to see grains of sand. From this
distance, you can see different layers from where the sand was laid
down. This rock is sandstone. The sand grains are cemented together to
make sandstone. Sandstone is a common type of sedimentary rock.

### Types of Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgU2VkaW1lbnRhcnkgUm9ja3M._11-rpw}

The main types of sedimentary rocks are clastic or chemical. Some
sedimentary rocks are a third type, organic. Clastic sedimentary rocks
are made of sediments. The sediments differ in size. Chemical
sedimentary rocks are made of minerals that precipitate from saline
water. Organic sedimentary rocks are made from the bodies of organisms.

#### Clastic Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-Q2xhc3RpYyBTZWRpbWVudGFyeSBSb2Nrcw.._11-6ut}

**Clastic sedimentary rocks** are grouped by the size of the sediment
they contain. Conglomerate and breccia are made of individual stones
that have been cemented together. In conglomerate, the stones are
rounded. In breccia, the stones are angular. Sandstone is made of
sand-sized particles. Siltstone is made of smaller particles. Silt is
smaller than sand but larger than clay. Shale has the smallest grain
size. Shale is made mostly of clay-sized particles and hardened mud.

  --------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Rock**                 **Sediment Size**        **Other Features**
  ------------------------ ------------------------ ------------------------
  Conglomerate             Large                    Rounded

  Breccia                  Large                    Angular

  Sandstone                Sand-sized               

  Siltstone                Silt-sized, smaller than 
                           sand                     

  Shale                    Clay-sized, smallest     
  --------------------------------------------------------------------------

When sediments settle out of calmer water, they form horizontal layers.
One layer is deposited first, and another layer is deposited on top of
it. So each layer is younger than the layer beneath it. When the
sediments harden, the layers are preserved.

#### Chemical Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-Q2hlbWljYWwgU2VkaW1lbnRhcnkgUm9ja3M._11-sqf}

Sedimentary rocks formed by the crystallization of chemical precipitates
are called **chemical sedimentary rocks** . Dissolved ions in fluids
precipitate out of the fluid and settle out, just like the halite
pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDQtMDMtMjUtRXZhcG9yaXRlLWhhbGl0ZS1jb2JibGU.)
).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-NzdiOTM2YTEyZjhkN2M2ZmU2NjZkZDQzM2EwYTk2ODA.-okg"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Mark A. Wilson (Department of Geology, The College of Wooster)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:HaliteEncrustedCobbleDeadSea.JPG" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Halite forming on a rock in the Dead
Sea](ck12_4_files/20150911025645425686.jpeg "Halite forming on a rock in the Dead Sea")

**Figure 4.37**

The evaporite, halite, on a cobble from the Dead Sea, Israel.

</div>

Living creatures can help chemicals become sedimentary rocks. Limestone
is an example.

#### Organic Sedimentary Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-T3JnYW5pYyBTZWRpbWVudGFyeSBSb2Nrcw.._11-yxd}

The bodies of organisms can make a sedimentary rock. Plant bodies are
lithified to become coal. When shells are cemented together they make a
type of limestone. So limestone can be considered chemical or organic.

-   Clastic sedimentary rocks are classified based on how they form and

-   Chemical sedimentary rocks precipitate from fluids.

# Metamorphic Rocks {#4.html#x-ck12-TWV0YW1vcnBoaWMgUm9ja3M.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how metamorphic rocks form.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600971] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025646898409.jpeg)
</span>

**What is the history of this rock?**

The rock in this photo is a banded gneiss. The bands are made of
different minerals. The light bands are more felsic, and the dark bands
are more mafic. The minerals separated due to heat and pressure. The
waviness of the bands also shows how the rock was hot enough to alter.
It was not hot enough to melt all the way.

### Metamorphism {#4.html#x-ck12-TWV0YW1vcnBoaXNt_12-zc3}

Metamorphic rocks start off as some kind of rock. The starting rock can
be igneous, sedimentary, or even another metamorphic rock. Heat and/or
pressure then change the rock into a metamorphic rock. The change can be
physical, chemical, or both.

During metamorphism, a rock may change chemically. Ions move in or out
of a mineral. This creates a different mineral. The new minerals that
form during metamorphism are more stable in the new environment. Extreme
pressure may lead to physical changes. If pressure is exerted on the
rock from one direction, the rock forms layers. This is **foliation** .
If pressure is exerted from all directions, the rock usually does not
show foliation.

There are two main types of metamorphism: contact and regional.

#### Contact Metamorphism {#4.html#x-ck12-Q29udGFjdCBNZXRhbW9ycGhpc20._12-eom}

**Contact metamorphism** results when magma contacts a rock. The rock
changes because of the magma's extreme heat ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Db250YWN0TWV0YW1vcnBoaXNtQ29tcG9zaXRl)
).

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-OGE5OTUxYjQyYjk0MTNjNGE4MTZhNGU3M2Y1ZGUyMTk.-bky"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) User:Fed/Ru.Wikipedia; (B) Flickr:CoreForce" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hornfels.jpg; (B) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:East_Face.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="(A) Public Domain; (B) CC BY 2.0" -->
![Hornfels is a metamorphic rock that makes up the Rocky
Mountains](ck12_4_files/20150911025647019486.jpeg "Hornfels is a metamorphic rock that makes up the Rocky Mountains")

**Figure 4.38**

\(A) Hornfels is a rock that is created by contact metamorphism. (B)
Hornfels is so hard that it can create peaks like the Rocky Mountains.

</div>

#### Regional Metamorphism {#4.html#x-ck12-UmVnaW9uYWwgTWV0YW1vcnBoaXNt_12-utg}

**Regional metamorphism** occurs over a wide area. Great masses of rock
are exposed to pressure from rock and sediment layers on top of it. The
rock may also be compressed by other geological processes. If the rock
is buried deeply, it may experience high temperatures.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-OGVlOGJlNDExYzY3MzY0NTMwNmEyZTA0MzBhYTE3OWU.-g2n"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Image copyright katatonia82, 2013; (B) Renee French" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.shutterstock.com; (B) CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="(A) Used under license from Shutterstock.com; (B) CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Regional metamorphic rocks display foliation, which can result in
blueschist](ck12_4_files/20150911025647138874.jpeg "Regional metamorphic rocks display foliation, which can result in blueschist")

**Figure 4.39**

\(A) Regional metamorphic rocks often display layering called foliation.
(B) Regional metamorphism with high pressures and low temperatures can
result in blueschist.

</div>

Metamorphism does not cause a rock to melt completely. It only causes
the minerals to change by heat or pressure. If the rock melts
completely, it will cool to become an igneous rock.

Hornfels is a rock with alternating bands of dark and light crystals.
Hornfels is a good example of how minerals rearrange themselves during
metamorphism ( **Figure**
[above](#4.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1SZWdpb25hbE1ldGFtb3JwaGlzbUNvbXBvc2l0ZQ..)
). The minerals in hornfels separate by density. The result is that the
rock becomes banded. Gneiss forms by regional metamorphism from
extremely high temperature and pressure.

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-ict}

-   Any type of rock—igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic—can become a
    metamorphic rock.
-   Contact metamorphism occurs when a rock is altered by heat from a
    nearby magma.
-   Regional metamorphism occurs over a large area when a rock is buried
    or compressed.

**What's the difference in these two rocks?**

The rock on the left was the sedimentary rock shale. Now it's the
metamorphic rock slate. Slate looks very similar to shale, but harder
and more platy. The rock on the right is gneiss. The light and dark
minerals have separated into bands. Gneiss is produced by higher
temperature metamorphism. The original rock was different in both cases.

# Rocks and Processes of the Rock Cycle {#4.html#x-ck12-Um9ja3MgYW5kIFByb2Nlc3NlcyBvZiB0aGUgUm9jayBDeWNsZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain the processes of the rock cycle.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3600979] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_4_files/20150911025648337847.jpeg)
</span>

**Is this what geologists mean by the rock cycle?**

Okay, maybe not. The rock cycle shows how any type of rock can become
any other type of rock. The three rock types are joined together by the
processes that change one to another.

### The Rock Cycle {#4.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFJvY2sgQ3ljbGU._14-ns5}

You learned about the three rock types: igneous, sedimentary, and
metamorphic. You also learned that all of these rocks can change. In
fact, any rock can change to become any other type of rock. These
changes usually happen very slowly. Some changes happen below Earth’s
surface. Some changes happen above ground. These changes are all part of
the rock cycle. The **rock cycle** describes each of the main types of
rocks, how they form, and how they change.

The figure below shows how the three main rock types are related to each
other ( **Figure**
[below](#4.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDQtMDEtOC1Sb2NrLWN5Y2xl) ). The arrows
within the circle show how one type of rock may change to rock of
another type. These are the processes that change one rock type to
another rock type.

<div id="4.html#x-ck12-YmY0MWNjMzU5ZjcxNTZiNjAwNTRiZGQ4MmYzNTY0NDE.-whd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Woudloper/Wikimedia Commons; modified by CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Rockcycle.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The Rock
Cycle](ck12_4_files/20150911025648438774.jpeg "The Rock Cycle")

**Figure 4.40**

The Rock Cycle.

</div>

#### Processes of the Rock Cycle {#4.html#x-ck12-UHJvY2Vzc2VzIG9mIHRoZSBSb2NrIEN5Y2xl_14-ia0}

There are three main processes that can change rock:

-   Cooling and crystallization. Deep within the Earth, temperatures can
    get hot enough to create magma. As magma cools, crystals grow,
    forming an igneous rock. The crystals grow larger if the magma cools
    slowly, as it does if it remains deep within the Earth. If the magma
    cools quickly, the crystals will be very small. When crystals form
    from magma it is called **crystallization** .

<!-- -->

-   Weathering and erosion. Water, wind, ice, and even plants and
    animals all act to wear down rocks. Over time they can break larger
    rocks into sediments. Rocks break down by the process called
    **weathering** . Moving water, wind, and glaciers then carry these
    pieces from one place to another. This is called **erosion** . The
    sediments are eventually dropped, or **deposited** , somewhere. This
    process is called **sedimentation** . The sediments may then be
    compacted and cemented together. This forms a sedimentary rock. This
    whole process can take hundreds or thousands of years.

<!-- -->

-   Metamorphism. This long word means “to change form.“ A rock
    undergoes metamorphism if it is exposed to extreme heat and pressure
    within the crust. With **metamorphism** , the rock does not melt all
    the way. The rock changes due to heat and pressure. A metamorphic
    rock may have a new mineral composition and/or texture.

An interactive rock cycle diagram can be found here:
[http://www.classzone.com/books/earth\_science/terc/content/investigations/es0602/es0602page02.cfm?chapter\_no=investigation](es0602page02.cfm?chapter_no=investigation)

The rock cycle really has no beginning or end. It just continues. The
processes involved in the rock cycle take place over hundreds,
thousands, or even millions of years. Even though for us rocks are solid
and unchanging, they slowly change all the time.

### Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-3kh}

-   The three main rock types are igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary.
-   The three processes that change one rock to another are
    crystallization, metamorphism, and erosion and sedimentation.
-   Any rock can transform into any other rock by passing through one or
    more of these processes. This creates the rock cycle.

## Summary {#4.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-zdc}

All matter is made of tiny particles. Protons, neutrons, and electrons
form atoms that bond together to create molecules. Atoms are the
smallest units that have the properties of an element. Molecules are the
smallest units of a compound. Chemical bonds hold molecules together.
Molecules form the different types of minerals. The silicates make up
most of Earth's crust. Minerals come together to create the three major
rock types. They are igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. Igneous
rocks form from cooled magma. Sedimentary rocks form from compacted or
cemented sediments. Metamorphic rocks are those that have been altered
by heat and pressure. These three rock types are the material part of
the rock cycle. They are connected by different processes. Different
processes convert any type of rock into any other type of rock. These
processes are weathering and erosion, crystallization, and burial and
pressure, among others. Each rock contains a story of how it formed. For
most rocks it is possible to know what it formed from.

</div>

# Plate Tectonics {#5.html#x-ck12-UGxhdGUgVGVjdG9uaWNz-chapter}

<div class="x-ck12-data">

## Introduction {#5.html#x-ck12-SW50cm9kdWN0aW9u-fte}

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_5_files/20150911025701198542.jpeg)
</span>

**Is the theory of plate tectonics an example of how a theory comes to
be?**

Scientific ideas do not come to a scientist fully formed. They usually
start as observations. Somewhere along the way the scientist develops a
hypothesis. The scientist finds evidence to support or refute the
hypothesis. If the evidence is in support, the idea evolves into
something bigger. By the time an idea is a theory it is extremely
complex. A theory has a tremendous amount of data to support it. Nothing
substantial refutes it. It probably is extremely important in the area
it addresses. Plate tectonics provides a tremendous example of how a
theory comes to be. In this section we will follow the development of
the theory of plate tectonics. It begins as an observation on how South
America and Africa fit together. And becomes the framework on which much
of geology hangs.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [LESSON: 3601028] -->

# Continental Drift {#5.html#x-ck12-Q29udGluZW50YWwgRHJpZnQ.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify the evidence Wegener had in support of his continental
    drift hypothesis.
-   Apply the steps of scientific method to Wegener's
    scientific investigation.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601032] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_5_files/20150911025701334374.jpeg)
</span>

**What does a scientist do with an interesting observation?**

Alfred Wegener made an observation. From that observation, he made a
hypothesis. He collected evidence that would support or refute his
hypothesis. What did that process look like?

### Wegener’s Idea {#5.html#x-ck12-V2VnZW5lcuKAmXMgSWRlYQ..-zou}

**Alfred Wegener** , born in 1880, was a meteorologist and explorer. In
1910, he noticed that South America and Africa appeared to fit together
like puzzle pieces. He was certainly not the first person to notice
this. But he was intrigued by the idea and thought a lot about it. He
wondered if the two continents were once joined and then moved apart? He
set out to find evidence to support or refute this idea.

### Wegener’s Evidence {#5.html#x-ck12-V2VnZW5lcuKAmXMgRXZpZGVuY2U.-qsr}

Here is the main evidence that Wegener and his supporters collected for
his continental drift hypothesis:

#### Fit of the Continents {#5.html#x-ck12-Rml0IG9mIHRoZSBDb250aW5lbnRz-kei}

The continents appear to fit together, and not just South America and
Africa. If the continental margins are included, the fit is even better.

<div id="5.html#x-ck12-OGYwZTNiMzg3ZjNiYWI0NmQzNjQ4MmRhZGNjNzQ0MDY.-mei"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright plena, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Continental drift from Pangaea to
now](ck12_5_files/20150911025701506665.jpeg "Continental drift from Pangaea to now")

**Figure 5.1**

This figure shows the evolution of the continents, from the
super-continent Pangaea to the way they look now.

</div>

#### Distribution of Fossils {#5.html#x-ck12-RGlzdHJpYnV0aW9uIG9mIEZvc3NpbHM.-hdq}

Wegener found fossil evidence that the continents were once joined (
**Figure** [below](#5.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDYtMDc.) ). The same type of
plant and animal fossils are found on continents that are now widely
separated. These organisms would not have been able to travel across the
oceans. So how did the fossils get so far apart?

Fossils of the seed fern Glossopteris are found across all of the
southern continents. These seeds are too heavy to be carried across the
ocean by wind. Mesosaurus fossils are found in South America and South
Africa. Mesosaurus could swim, but only in fresh water. Cynognathus and
Lystrosaurus were reptiles that lived on land. Both of these animals
were unable to swim at all. Their fossils have been found across South
America, Africa, India, and Antarctica.

Wegener thought that all of these organisms must have lived side by
side. The lands later moved apart so that the fossils are separated.

<div id="5.html#x-ck12-OTYxOTRlYmI2MDE1N2Y5NDkzOGQwZjE1MjJhOGNiNmQ.-qhd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey, User:Osvaldocangaspadilla/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Snider-Pellegrini_Wegener_fossil_map.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Fossil remains of organisms on South America and
Africa](ck12_5_files/20150911025701616611.png "Fossil remains of organisms on South America and Africa")

**Figure 5.2**

Wegener used fossil evidence to support his continental drift
hypothesis. The fossils of these organisms are found on lands that are
now far apart. Wegener suggested that when the organisms were alive, the
lands were joined and the organisms were living side-by-side.

</div>

#### Distribution of Rocks and Structures {#5.html#x-ck12-RGlzdHJpYnV0aW9uIG9mIFJvY2tzIGFuZCBTdHJ1Y3R1cmVz-lps}

Wegener found rocks of the same type and age on both sides of the
Atlantic Ocean. He thought that it could not be a coincidence! He said
that the rocks must have formed side by side. These rocks then drifted
apart on separate continents.

Wegener also matched up mountain ranges across the Atlantic Ocean. The
Appalachian Mountains were just like mountain ranges in eastern
Greenland, Ireland, Great Britain, and Norway. Wegener concluded that
they formed as a single mountain range. This mountain range broke apart
as the continents split up. The mountain range separated as the
continents drifted.

#### Climate Zones {#5.html#x-ck12-Q2xpbWF0ZSBab25lcw..-aux}

Climate is found in zones around the planet. Warm tropical climates are
mostly found near the Equator. Glaciers are mostly found nearer the
poles. Wegener assumed that these things were true in the ancient past.

#### Glaciers {#5.html#x-ck12-R2xhY2llcnM.-9f1}

Wegener looked at evidence from ancient glaciers. Glaciers are found in
very cold climates near the poles. The evidence left by some ancient
glaciers is very close to the Equator. Did glaciers once exist near the
poles? Wegener knew that this was extremely unlikely! However, if the
continents had moved, the glaciers would have been centered close to the
South Pole.

#### Tropics {#5.html#x-ck12-VHJvcGljcw..-gll}

Coral reefs are found only in warm water. Coal swamps are also found in
tropical and subtropical environments. Wegener discovered ancient coal
seams and coral reef fossils in areas that are much too cold today.
Wegener thought that ancient coral and coal plants existed at about the
same latitude where they are found today. He again stated that it was
the continents that moved. An animation showing that Earth’s climate
belts remain in roughly the same position while the continents move is
seen here: [http://www.scotese.com/paleocli.htm](paleocli.htm) .

An animation showing how the continents split up can be found here:
[http://www.exploratorium.edu/origins/antarctica/ideas/gondwana2.html](gondwana2.html)
.

### Summary {#5.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-stq}

-   Alfred Wegener made an observation. Africa and South America
    appeared to fit together like puzzle pieces.
-   Wegener then asked an important question and set about to answer it.
    Were the continents once joined and then they drifted apart?
-   Wegener collected a great deal of evidence to support his idea.
    Wegener’s evidence included the fit of the continents, the
    distribution of ancient fossils, the placement of similar rocks and
    structures on the opposite sides of oceans, and indicators of
    ancient climate found in locations where those climates do not
    exist today.

# Wegener and the Continental Drift Hypothesis {#5.html#x-ck12-V2VnZW5lciBhbmQgdGhlIENvbnRpbmVudGFsIERyaWZ0IEh5cG90aGVzaXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define the continental drift hypothesis.
-   Describe issues with the continental drift hypothesis.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601036] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_5_files/20150911025701730076.jpeg)
</span>

**What is continental drift?**

Wegener put together a tremendous amount of evidence that the continents
had been joined. He advanced a great idea. But other scientists didn't
accept it.

### Wegener’s Continental Drift Hypothesis {#5.html#x-ck12-V2VnZW5lcuKAmXMgQ29udGluZW50YWwgRHJpZnQgSHlwb3RoZXNpcw.._1-ocv}

Wegener put his idea and his evidence together in his book, *The Origin
of Continents and Oceans* . The book was first published in 1915. He
included evidence that the continents had been joined. New editions of
the book containing additional evidence were published later.

In his book he said that around 300 million years ago, the continents
had all been joined. They created a single landmass he called Pangaea,
meaning “all earth” in ancient Greek. The supercontinent later broke
apart. Since then the continents have been moving into their current
positions. He called his hypothesis **continental drift** .

### The Problem with the Hypothesis {#5.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFByb2JsZW0gd2l0aCB0aGUgSHlwb3RoZXNpcw.._1-0t6}

Wegener had a lot of evidence to support his hypothesis. But he had a
problem. The problem was that he could not explain how the continents
could move through the oceans. He suggested that continental drift
occurred like an icebreaker plows through sea ice ( **Figure**
[below](#5.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy1JY2VicmVha2Vy) ). He thought the
continents could cut through the ocean floor.

<div id="5.html#x-ck12-ZmJmMDVjYzJiY2U1NGVkNDRkNjI3MTViNjkxNmVmZTg.-cdv"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Patrick Kelley, US Coast Guard" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/usgeologicalsurvey/4371016246/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Wegener thought continental drift occurred as continents cut through
the ocean floor, in the same way as this icebreaker plows through sea
ice](ck12_5_files/20150911025701876884.jpeg "Wegener thought continental drift occurred as continents cut through the ocean floor, in the same way as this icebreaker plows through sea ice")

**Figure 5.3**

An icebreaking ship.

</div>

Other scientists didn't buy his idea. They thought that the continents
would be much more deformed than they are.

Wegener believed that Africa and South America had once been joined. He
had the evidence. But very few scientists accepted his idea. He needed a
mechanism that they would accept.

Alfred Wegener died in 1930 on an expedition on the Greenland icecap.
The continental drift hypothesis was put to rest for a few decades. It
was when technology could provide even more evidence for continental
drift that scientists looked into the idea again. Technology also helped
scientists to develop a mechanism for how continents could drift.

### Summary {#5.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._1-5iz}

-   Alfred Wegener said that the continents had been joined as a single
    landmass, which he called Pangaea.
-   Wegener thought that Pangaea was together about 300 million
    years ago.
-   Wegener could not develop a mechanism for continents moving through
    oceanic crust that other scientists would accept.
