# Faults {#6.html#x-ck12-RmF1bHRz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe joints and faults.
-   Identify types of faults.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601170] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025723395474.jpeg)
</span>

**Why is this lake so long and straight?**

The photo is of Crystal Springs Reservoir near the San Francisco Bay
Area. The water has collected in a low point in the land. The reason for
the low point is a fault, the San Andreas Fault. On one side of the
reservoir is the Pacific Plate. On the other side is the North American
Plate. Would this be a good place to build a home?

### Fractures {#6.html#x-ck12-RnJhY3R1cmVz_3-uzs}

A rock under enough stress will fracture. There may or may not be
movement along the fracture. If there is not movement, the fracture is a
joint. If there is movement, the fracture is a fault.

#### Joints {#6.html#x-ck12-Sm9pbnRz_3-pdz}

If there is no movement on either side of a fracture, the fracture is
called a **joint** . Basalt rocks in Asia show horizontal and vertical
joints ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Db2x1bW5hckpvaW50aW5nQXNpYQ..) ).
These joints formed as the lava cooled and contracted.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZGRiYTlkYjhhMWRhOTFkNGQxNzJlZTE0OGRmNzg2Nzc.-hrk"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright      Spaceport9, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Columnar joints in basalt in
Asia](ck12_6_files/20150911025723615727.jpeg "Columnar joints in basalt in Asia")

**Figure 6.9**

Columnar joints in basalt in Asia.

</div>

#### Faults {#6.html#x-ck12-RmF1bHRz_3-ahq}

If the rocks on one or both sides of a fracture move, the fracture is
called a **fault** ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1GYXVsdGVkWm9uZU1vYWI.) ). Faults can
occur alone or in clusters. A cluster of faults creates a **fault zone**
. Earthquakes happen when rocks break and move suddenly. The energy
released causes an earthquake.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NGI0ODEzYzE3YTNhMDgwYjdiMzk2YmJkYjZmNzJiZTY.-gnu"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Renee French" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Faults along an outcrop in Moab,
Utah](ck12_6_files/20150911025723718998.jpeg "Faults along an outcrop in Moab, Utah")

**Figure 6.10**

A series of faults offset this outcrop along Highway 191 in Moab, Utah.

</div>

#### Dip-Slip Fault {#6.html#x-ck12-RGlwLVNsaXAgRmF1bHQ._3-orz}

**Slip** is the distance rocks move along a fault, as one block of rock
moves past the other. The angle of a fault is called the fault’s **dip**
. If the fault dips at an angle, the fault is a **dip-slip fault** (
**Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1EaXBTbGlwRmF1bHQ.) ).

Imagine you are standing on a road looking at the fault. The hanging
wall is the rock that overlies the fault. The footwall is beneath the
fault. If you are walking along a fault, the hanging wall is above you.
The footwall is where your feet would be. Miners often extract mineral
resources along faults. They used to hang their lanterns above their
heads. That is why these layers were called the hanging wall.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZDk3YzJiNTU4MzUzZWY0MGE1NWY2ZGVhZWQ4Zjc3NzA.-x40"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Hsu.shihhung/Zh.Wikipedia" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Dip_slip_fault.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Diagram of a reverse and normal
fault](ck12_6_files/20150911025723824560.jpeg "Diagram of a reverse and normal fault")

**Figure 6.11**

Block A is the hanging wall and block B is the footwall. The left
diagram shows a reverse, or thrust, fault and the right diagram shows a
normal fault.

</div>

#### Normal Faults {#6.html#x-ck12-Tm9ybWFsIEZhdWx0cw.._3-sdz}

In **normal faults** , the hanging wall drops down relative to the
footwall. Normal faults are caused by tension that pulls the crust
apart. This causes the hanging wall to slide down. Normal faults can
build huge mountain ranges in regions experiencing tension ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1FYXN0ZXJuU2llcnJhTmV2YWRhcw..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YWNhZDdhMTA4OWU2YjJiMzBmMjIwNTIxYTMxNDE3YWM.-mxs"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Frank Kovalchek (Flickr:Alaskan Dude)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/72213316@N00/7033797473/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![The Sierra Nevada Mountain formed due to a normal
fault](ck12_6_files/20150911025723934416.jpeg "The Sierra Nevada Mountain formed due to a normal fault")

**Figure 6.12**

The Sierra Nevada Mountains in eastern California rose up along a normal
fault.

</div>

An animation of a normal fault is seen here:
[http://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/animations/animation.php?flash\_title=Normal+Fault&flash\_file=normalfault&flash\_width=220&flash\_height=320](animation.php?flash_title=Normal+Fault&flash_file=normalfault&flash_width=220&flash_height=320)
.

#### Thrust Faults {#6.html#x-ck12-VGhydXN0IEZhdWx0cw.._3-wis}

When compression squeezes the crust into a smaller space, the hanging
wall pushes up relative to the footwall. This creates a **reverse
fault** . A **thrust fault** is a type of reverse fault. With a thrust
fault the angle of the fault is close to horizontal. Rocks can slip many
miles along thrust faults ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Mb29uUG9pbnRUaHJ1c3Q.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-OTA1ZWM4NTU5OGVmZWM0Y2U5MWQ3MGYwMWYxYjJiMmY.-xcg"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:Hitchster" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/hitchster/2772761844/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of a thrust
fault](ck12_6_files/20150911025724055898.jpeg "Picture of a thrust fault")

**Figure 6.13**

In this thrust fault, the rock on the right is thrust over the rock on
the left. The rock on the right has also started to fold because of this
movement.

</div>

An animation of a thrust fault is seen here:
[http://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/animations/animation.php?flash\_title=Thrust+Fault&flash\_file=thrustfault&flash\_width=220&flash\_height=320](animation.php?flash_title=Thrust+Fault&flash_file=thrustfault&flash_width=220&flash_height=320)
.

#### Strike-Slip Faults {#6.html#x-ck12-U3RyaWtlLVNsaXAgRmF1bHRz_3-8nt}

A **strike-slip fault** is a dip-slip fault where the dip of the fault
plane is vertical. Strike-slip faults result from shear stresses. If you
stand with one foot on each side of a strike-slip fault, one side will
be moving toward you while the other side moves away from you. If your
right foot moves toward you, the fault is known as a right-lateral
strike-slip fault. If your left foot moves toward you, the fault is a
left-lateral strike-slip fault ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TdHJpa2VTbGlwRmF1bHQ.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MTE4OWRjODdjNTlmZmJkYjEyYjI4OGE0Zjg0YzU4NzY.-xbg"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Strikeslip-fault.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of a strike-slip
fault](ck12_6_files/20150911025724184190.png "Diagram of a strike-slip fault")

**Figure 6.14**

Diagram of a right lateral strike-slip fault.

</div>

An animation of a strike-slip fault is seen here:
[http://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/animations/animation.php?flash\_title=Strike-Slip+Fault&flash\_file=strikeslip&flash\_width=240&flash\_height=310](animation.php?flash_title=Strike-Slip+Fault&flash_file=strikeslip&flash_width=240&flash_height=310)
.

#### San Andreas Fault {#6.html#x-ck12-U2FuIEFuZHJlYXMgRmF1bHQ._3-onz}

The San Andreas Fault in California is a right-lateral strike slip fault
( **Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyc2NpLTA3LTAyLTA1) ). It is also
a transform fault because the San Andreas is a plate boundary. Unlike
what some people think, California will not fall into the ocean someday.
The land west of the San Andreas Fault is moving northeastward, while
the North American plate moves southwest. Someday, millions of years
from now, Los Angeles will be a suburb of San Francisco!

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MWU4MmJkOGIzZDNmMzdkNmFkODIzN2U5Mjg2MDI3MzA.-n9d"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Kate Barton, David Howell, Joe Vigil, US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sanandreas.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The San Andreas Fault is a strike-slip
fault](ck12_6_files/20150911025724275573.jpeg "The San Andreas Fault is a strike-slip fault")

**Figure 6.15**

The San Andreas Fault runs up through California. This transform fault
separates the Pacific plate on the west and the North American plate on
the east.

</div>

People sometimes say that California will fall into the ocean someday.
This is not true! Someday Los Angeles will be a suburb of San Francisco
(or will it be the other way around?).

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._3-op4}

-   A fracture with no movement on either side is a joint.
-   Dip-slip faults show vertical movement. In a normal fault, the
    hanging wall drops down relative to the footwall. The reverse is
    true of a reverse fault.
-   Strike-slip faults have horizontal motions due to shear stress.

# Mountain Building {#6.html#x-ck12-TW91bnRhaW4gQnVpbGRpbmc.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how converging or diverging plates can create
    mountain ranges.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601175] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025724405741.jpeg)
</span>

**How do plate motions create mountains?**

Plate tectonic processes create some of the world's most beautiful
places. The North Cascades Mountains in Washington State are a
continental volcanic arc. The mountains currently host some glaciers.
There are many features left by the more abundant ice age glaciers.
Changes in altitude make the range a habitable place for many living
organisms.

### Stress and Mountain Building {#6.html#x-ck12-U3RyZXNzIGFuZCBNb3VudGFpbiBCdWlsZGluZw.._4-b7o}

Many processes create mountains. Most mountains form along plate
boundaries. A few mountains may form in the middle of a plate. For
example, hotspot volcanoes.

#### Continent-Continent Convergence {#6.html#x-ck12-Q29udGluZW50LUNvbnRpbmVudCBDb252ZXJnZW5jZQ.._4-0mq}

Most of the world’s largest mountains form as plates collide at
convergent plate boundaries. Continental crust is too buoyant to get
pushed down into the mantle. So when the plates smash together, the
crust crumples upward. This creates mountains. Folding and faulting in
these collision zones makes the crust thicker.

The world’s highest mountain range, the Himalayas, is growing as India
collides with Eurasia. About 80 million years ago, India was separated
from Eurasia by an ocean ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMTYtaW5kaWEtbW92ZW1lbnQ.) ). As the
plates collided, pieces of the old seafloor were forced over the Asian
continent. This old seafloor is now found high in the Himalayas (
**Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMTctaGltYWxheWFz) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YjAxNzFjNmIxODU4ZGYwMGE4YzE1OWRhY2NlYzZjMGI.-okr"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Pierre D&#232;zes 1999, "Tectonic and metamorphic Evolution of the Central Himalayan Domain in Southeast Zanskar (Kashmir, India)"" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:India_71-0_Ma.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Author allows use for any purpose, provide reference is made to http://comp1.geol.unibas.ch/zanskar/" -->
![The Himalaya Mountains rise as India rams into
Eurasia](ck12_6_files/20150911025724516314.png "The Himalaya Mountains rise as India rams into Eurasia")

**Figure 6.16**

As India rams into Eurasia, the Himalaya Mountains rise.

</div>

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MDJjYTZiZjFjODBlNmE1NzlkY2I2Zjk3NDlkZDBhNzM.-my0"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="McKay Savage" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mckaysavage/499181482/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of the Himalaya
Mountains](ck12_6_files/20150911025724616872.jpeg "Picture of the Himalaya Mountains")

**Figure 6.17**

The Himalayas.

</div>

#### Oceanic Plate Subduction {#6.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW5pYyBQbGF0ZSBTdWJkdWN0aW9u_4-pl5}

Volcanic mountain ranges form when oceanic crust subducts into the
mantle at convergent plate boundaries. The Andes Mountains are a chain
of coastal volcanic mountains. They are forming as the Nazca plate
subducts beneath the South American plate ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTctMTgtQ290b3BheGk.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-OWVjOWNjNGQ5NzgzY2Y4ZWVlODg3NTVlOGNkMTVmMWI.-mvh"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Dave Lonsdale" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/davelonsdale/6310830697/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![The Andes Mountains formed due to oceanic plate
subduction](ck12_6_files/20150911025724723189.jpeg "The Andes Mountains formed due to oceanic plate subduction")

**Figure 6.18**

Cotopaxi is in the Andes Mountains of Ecuador. The 19,300 foot tall
mountain is the highest active volcano in the world.

</div>

#### Rifting {#6.html#x-ck12-UmlmdGluZw.._4-wcg}

Mid-ocean ridges form at divergent plate boundaries. As the ocean floor
separates an enormous line of volcanoes is created.

Continents can also rift apart; a process called **continental rifting**
. When continental crust is pulled apart, it breaks into blocks. These
blocks of crust are separated by normal faults. This is known as **block
faulting** . The blocks slide up or down. The result is alternating
mountain ranges and valleys. This topography is known as basin-and-range
( **Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Ib3JzdEFuZEdyYWJlbg..) ).
The area near Death Valley, California is the center of a classic
basin-and-range province ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjAtZGVhdGgtdmFsbGV5) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YTFhMzYxM2FiZGUwYzgyMzlkZjBlN2I3YzdhYzFiODU.-r6l"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey, Gregors" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Fault-Horst-Graben.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![How a basin-and-range
forms](ck12_6_files/20150911025724826631.png "How a basin-and-range forms")

**Figure 6.19**

This diagram shows how a basin-and-range forms.

</div>

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZTI3MWVlZmQ0NmFkNTUyNzY5NjAwYjMzZGQ5ZjljNDA.-wlv"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright kavram, 2011" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Picture of a basin and
range](ck12_6_files/20150911025724945604.jpeg "Picture of a basin and range")

**Figure 6.20**

This photograph was taken from a basin with a range in the distance near
Death Valley, California.

</div>

Here you can find a very quick animation of movement of blocks in a
basin-and-range setting:
[http://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/animations/animation.php?flash\_title=Horst+%26amp%3B+Graben&flash\_file=horstandgraben&flash\_width=380&flash\_height=210](animation.php?flash_title=Horst+%26amp%3B+Graben&flash_file=horstandgraben&flash_width=380&flash_height=210)
.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._4-z0a}

-   Converging or diverging plates cause mountains to grow.
-   Subduction of oceanic crust beneath a continental or oceanic plate
    creates a chain of volcanoes.
-   Tensional forces bring about block faulting. This creates a
    basin-and-range valleys and mountains.

# Earthquake Characteristics {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBDaGFyYWN0ZXJpc3RpY3M.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define earthquakes.
-   Explain why earthquakes occur.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601182] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025725152102.jpeg)
</span>

**What causes the greatest damage in an earthquake?**

This photo shows the Mission District of San Francisco burning after the
1906 earthquake. The greatest damage in earthquakes is usually not from
the ground shaking. The greatest damage is caused by the effects of that
shaking. In this earthquake, the shaking broke the gas mains and the
water pipes. When the gas caught fire, there was no way to put it out.
Fire causes the greatest damage in many earthquakes.

### Earthquake! {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSE._5-b4w}

An **earthquake** is sudden ground movement. This movement is caused by
the sudden release of the energy stored in rocks. An earthquake happens
when so much stress builds up in the rocks that the rocks break. An
earthquake’s energy is transmitted by seismic waves.

### Causes of Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-Q2F1c2VzIG9mIEVhcnRocXVha2Vz_5-jta}

Almost all earthquakes occur at plate boundaries. All types of plate
boundaries have earthquakes. Convection within the Earth causes the
plates to move. As the plates move, stresses build. When the stresses
build too much, the rocks break. The break releases the energy that was
stored in the rocks. The sudden release of energy is an earthquake.
During an earthquake the rocks usually move several centimeters. Rarely,
they may move as much as a few meters. **Elastic rebound theory**
describes how earthquakes occur ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjEtZWxhc3RpYy1yZWJvdW5k) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YTY2ZmUzNWVhODY0ZTM1ODQ2MjU5ZGYxODk1OWRjYmE.-hck"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of the elastic rebound
theory](ck12_6_files/20150911025725275282.png "Diagram of the elastic rebound theory")

**Figure 6.21**

Elastic rebound theory. Stresses build on both sides of a fault. The
rocks deform plastically as seen in Time 2. When the stresses become too
great, the rocks return to their original shape. To do this, the rocks
move, as seen in Time 3. This movement releases energy, creating an
earthquake.

</div>

Elastic rebound theory in an animation:
[http://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/animations/animation.php?flash\_title=Elastic+Rebound&flash\_file=elasticrebound&flash\_width=300&flash\_height=350](animation.php?flash_title=Elastic+Rebound&flash_file=elasticrebound&flash_width=300&flash_height=350)
.

### Focus and Epicenter {#6.html#x-ck12-Rm9jdXMgYW5kIEVwaWNlbnRlcg.._5-qby}

The two important words used to describe an earthquake's location are
focus and epicenter.

#### Focus {#6.html#x-ck12-Rm9jdXM._5-rqn}

The point where the rock ruptures is the earthquake’s **focus** . The
focus is below the Earth’s surface. A shallow earthquake has a focus
less than 70 kilometers (45 miles). An intermediate-focus earthquake has
a focus between 70 and 300 kilometers (45 to 200 miles). A deep-focus
earthquake is greater than 300 kilometers (200 miles). About 75% of
earthquakes have a focus in the top 10 to 15 kilometers (6 to 9 miles)
of the crust. Shallow earthquakes cause the most damage. This is because
the focus is near the Earth's surface, where people live.

#### Epicenter {#6.html#x-ck12-RXBpY2VudGVy_5-72c}

The area just above the focus, on the land surface, is the earthquake’s
**epicenter** ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjItZXBpY2VudGVy) ). The towns or
cities near the epicenter will be strongly affected by the earthquake.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YWFkMmI2NDk4YzVjMTUyN2Y1NDVlZTU2YzIzMWU1MTI.-9vc"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jodi So" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![The epicenter and focus of an
earthquake](ck12_6_files/20150911025725374345.jpeg "The epicenter and focus of an earthquake")

**Figure 6.22**

The focus of an earthquake is where the ground breaks. The epicenter is
the point at the surface just above the focus.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._5-nfg}

-   A sudden release of energy stored in rocks causes an earthquake.
-   The focus is where the rocks rupture. The epicenter is the point on
    the ground directly above the focus.
-   Most earthquakes are shallow. Shallow earthquakes do the
    most damage.

# Earthquake Zones {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBab25lcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain the relationship between plate boundaries and earthquakes.
-   Summarize the location of most of the world's earthquakes.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601188] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025725506888.jpeg)
</span>

**What caused the earthquake in Angol, Chile in 2010?**

Angol, Chile experienced a huge 8.8 magnitude earthquake in February
2010. The earthquake was due to subduction of the Nazca plate beneath
South America. This subduction zone is part of the Pacific Ring of Fire.

### Annual Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-QW5udWFsIEVhcnRocXVha2Vz_6-wkc}

In a single year, on average, more than 900,000 earthquakes are
recorded. About 150,000 of them are strong enough to be felt. Each year
about 18 earthquakes are major, with a Richter magnitude of 7.0 to 7.9,
and on average one earthquake has a magnitude of 8 to 8.9.

Magnitude 9 earthquakes are rare. The United States Geological Survey
lists five since 1900 ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2ljLTA3MDMtMDQ.) and **Table**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6TWFnOUVRcw..) ). All but the Great Indian
Ocean Earthquake of 2004 occurred somewhere around the Pacific Ocean
basin.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZTk2NGU2N2Y4MjIwODk4Y2MzOWRiZWE1Mzg5ZmQzNzY.-w4y"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Army" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AlaskaQuake-FourthAve.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Damage due to the Good Friday Earthquake in
Alaska](ck12_6_files/20150911025725602443.jpeg "Damage due to the Good Friday Earthquake in Alaska")

**Figure 6.23**

The 1964 Good Friday Earthquake centered in Prince William Sound, Alaska
released the second most amount of energy of any earthquake in recorded
history.

</div>

  **Location**                    **Year**   **Magnitude**
  ------------------------------- ---------- ---------------
  Valdivia, Chile                 1960       9.5
  Prince William Sound, Alaska    1964       9.2
  Great Indian Ocean Earthquake   2004       9.1
  Kamchatka, Alaska               1952       9.0
  Tōhoku, Japan                   2011       9.0

### Earthquake Zones {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBab25lcw.._6-ljc}

Nearly 95% of all earthquakes take place along one of the three types of
plate boundaries.

-   About 80% of all earthquakes strike around the Pacific Ocean basin
    because it is lined with convergent and transform boundaries (
    **Figure**
    [below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDctMjMtRWFydGhxdWFrZXMtOC4wLWdyZWF0ZXI.) ).
    The region around the Pacific is called the Pacific **Ring of Fire**
    due to its earthquakes and volcanoes.
-   About 15% take place in the Mediterranean-Asiatic Belt. Convergence
    is causing the Indian Plate to run into the Eurasian Plate.
-   The remaining 5% are scattered around other plate boundaries. A few
    earthquakes take place away from plate boundaries. These are
    intraplate earthquakes.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZDEwNjA1MTc3OWFiOWQ2NzU1MzBhZWY1M2Q5MmIwNWI.-16s"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqarchives/year/mag8/magnitude8_1900_date.php" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of strong earthquake
epicenters](ck12_6_files/20150911025725760869.png "Map of strong earthquake epicenters")

**Figure 6.24**

Earthquake epicenters for magnitude 8.0 and greater events since 1900.
The earthquake depth shows that most large quakes are shallow focus, but
some subducted plates cause deep focus quakes.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._6-zrs}

-   Small earthquakes are extremely common, but the largest earthquakes
    are extremely rare.
-   The vast majority of earthquakes happen at plate boundaries.
-   The Pacific Ocean basin has the most earthquakes due to convergent
    and transform plate boundaries. The Himalaya region has the second
    most due to the convergence of India and Asia.

# Earthquakes at Transform Plate Boundaries {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZXMgYXQgVHJhbnNmb3JtIFBsYXRlIEJvdW5kYXJpZXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe earthquakes that take place at transform plate boundaries.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601194] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025725874982.jpeg)
</span>

**What does the future of San Francisco hold?**

The last large earthquake along the San Andreas Fault in the San
Francisco area stuck in 1906. The city was devastated. Studies show that
big quakes occur every 125 years or more. Small quakes seem to precede
large ones, and there have been some small ones in recent years. What do
you think the future holds for San Francisco?

### Transform Plate Boundaries {#6.html#x-ck12-VHJhbnNmb3JtIFBsYXRlIEJvdW5kYXJpZXM._7-wfo}

Transform plate boundaries produce enormous and deadly earthquakes.
These quakes at transform faults are shallow focus. This is because the
plates slide past each other without moving up or down.

The San Andreas Fault that runs through much of California is an
enormous transform plate boundary. It is the plate boundary between
Pacific and North American plates. The largest earthquake in recorded
history on the San Andreas Fault occurred in 1906. The quake's epicenter
was just north of in San Francisco. About 3,000 people died and 28,000
buildings were lost, mostly in the fire that followed the earthquake.

There are many other faults spreading off the San Andreas, to take up
the plate motion. In total the San Andreas Fault system produces around
10,000 earthquakes a year ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjQtQmF5LUFyZWEtRmF1bHQtTGluZXM.) ).
While most of those earthquakes cannot even be felt by people nearby,
occasionally one is very strong. In the San Francisco Bay Area, the
Hayward Fault was the site of a magnitude 7.0 earthquake in 1868.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MmY4MWJmODRmYjg1YzhiZmQ4ODRlOTNhMWNkYmYzZWE.-tpk"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

![Map of faults in the San Francisco Bay
Area](ck12_6_files/20150911025726031457.png "Map of faults in the San Francisco Bay Area")

**Figure 6.25**

The San Andreas Fault runs through the San Francisco Bay Area. Other
related faults cross the region. Lines indicate strike slip faults.
Lines with hatches are thrust faults.

</div>

Other significant earthquakes in California include the 1989 Loma Prieta
earthquake near Santa Cruz ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjMtTG9tYS1QcmlldGE.) ) and the 1994
Northridge earthquake near Los Angeles.

</div>

Although California is prone to many natural hazards, including volcanic
eruptions at Mt. Shasta or Mt. Lassen, and landslides on coastal cliffs,
the natural hazard the state is linked with is earthquakes. In this
video, the boundaries between three different tectonic plates and the
earthquakes that result from their interactions are explored.

-   **Tectonic Plates** at
    [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=upEh-1DpLMg](watch?v=upEh-1DpLMg) (1:59)

[![](ck12_6_files/tmpGLV5Up.jpeg)](upEh-1DpLMg)

Click on the image above for more content

New Zealand also has a transform fault with strike-slip motion, causing
about 20,000 earthquakes a year! Only a small percentage of those are
large enough to be felt. A 6.3 quake in Christchurch in February 2011
killed about 180 people.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._7-cch}

-   Transform fault earthquakes have shallow focus because the plates
    meet near the surface.
-   The San Andreas Fault is actually a fault zone made up of a number
    of other active faults.
-   New Zealand also has a transform plate boundary.

# Earthquakes at Convergent Plate Boundaries {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZXMgYXQgQ29udmVyZ2VudCBQbGF0ZSBCb3VuZGFyaWVz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe earthquakes that take place at convergent plate boundaries.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601200] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025726365967.jpeg)
</span>

**What damage is done to people's lives by earthquakes?**

In a large earthquake hundreds or thousands of people may die. Many more
may lose their homes and livelihoods. After a large quake, the world's
attention turns to help the victims. But soon there is another disaster
in the news, and the world's attention turns. People may be left
homeless due to an earthquake for many years.

### Convergent Plate Boundaries {#6.html#x-ck12-Q29udmVyZ2VudCBQbGF0ZSBCb3VuZGFyaWVz_8-hkd}

Earthquakes at convergent plate boundaries mark the location of the
subducting lithosphere. The motion of the lithosphere as it plunges
through the mantle causes the quakes ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDctMjAtRWFydGhxdWFrZS1lcGljZW50ZXJz) ).
At greater depths, the plate heats up enough to deform plastically.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZTU4MThiMWZlYjhmNWM0NjlmOTBkZjNlMTY5NDVkMDA.-7nt"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/eq_depot/2009/eq_090929_mdbi/neic_mdbi_c.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A cross section of earthquake
epicenters](ck12_6_files/20150911025726532594.png "A cross section of earthquake epicenters")

**Figure 6.27**

A cross section of earthquake epicenters. The depth outlines the
subducting plate. There are shallow, intermediate, and deep earthquakes.

</div>

Convergent plate boundaries produce earthquakes most of the way around
the Pacific Ocean basin.

#### Ocean-Ocean: Japan {#6.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW4tT2NlYW46IEphcGFu_8-sgj}

Earthquakes in Japan are caused by ocean-ocean convergence. In this part
of the Pacific Ocean, oceanic crust subducts beneath oceanic crust. This
creates as many as 1,500 earthquakes every year.

In March 2011, the 9.0 magnitude Tōhoku earthquake struck off of
northeastern Japan. Damage from the quake was severe. Even more severe
was the damage from the tsunami generated by the quake ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy0yMDExVG9ob2t1RWFydGhxdWFrZURhbWFnZQ..)
and **Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyc2NpLTA3LTAyLTA4) ). A
**tsunami** is an enormous ocean wave or set of waves generated by an
underwater earthquake. In all, 25,000 people were known dead or missing.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZjkwODUxOTFlZmFkZjg3Y2Q2Zjg4NTg5ZTQyNDJjMmE.-ayv"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->

tsunami](ck12_6_files/20150911025726649814.jpeg "The damage caused in Japan from an earthquake and tsunami")

**Figure 6.28**

The damage in Miyako, Iwate, Japan after a 9.0 magnitude earthquake and
the massive tsunami it generated struck in March, 2011.

</div>

[http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/seqs/events/usc0001xgp/]() .

[http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2011/03/11/world/asia/maps-of-earthquake-and-tsunami-damage-in-japan.html](maps-of-earthquake-and-tsunami-damage-in-japan.html)
.

#### Ocean-Continent: Cascades {#6.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW4tQ29udGluZW50OiBDYXNjYWRlcw.._8-7uw}

The Pacific Northwest of the United States is at risk from a potentially
massive earthquake. The subduction of three small plates beneath North
America produces active volcanoes, the Cascades. The region also
experiences earthquakes. However, large earthquakes only hit every 300
to 600 years. The last was in 1700. That quake had an estimated
magnitude of around 9. A quake of that magnitude today could produce an
incredible amount of destruction and untold fatalities.

An image of earthquake epicenters beneath the Pacific Northwest and the
depth to the epicenter is shown here: [http://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/91/]() .

Elastic rebound at a subduction zone generates an earthquake in this
animation:
[http://www.iris.edu/hq/files/programs/education\_and\_outreach/aotm/5/AOTF5\_Subduction\_ElasticRebound480.mov](AOTF5_Subduction_ElasticRebound480.mov)
.

#### Continent-Continent: Asia {#6.html#x-ck12-Q29udGluZW50LUNvbnRpbmVudDogQXNpYQ.._8-z5k}

The collision of two continents also creates massive earthquakes. Many
earthquakes happen in the region in and around the Himalayan Mountains.
The 2001 Gujarat, India earthquake is responsible for about 20,000
deaths, with many more people injured or made homeless ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NdXphZmZhcmFiYWQyMDA1S2FzaG1pckVhcnRocXVha2U.)
).

**Figure 6.30**

Damage from the 2005 Kashmir earthquake.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._8-aez}

-   Earthquakes occur all along the subducting plate as it plunges into
    the mantle.
-   All three types of convergent plate boundaries produce
    massive earthquakes.
-   Subduction zones around the Pacific Rim are responsible for many of
    the world's earthquakes.

# Intraplate Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-SW50cmFwbGF0ZSBFYXJ0aHF1YWtlcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify the causes of intraplate earthquakes.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601206] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025727104468.jpeg)
</span>

**When can you go up in the Washington Monument again?**

An earthquake in August 2011 in Virginia cracked the top of the
Washington Monument. After 32 months of repair, the monument reopened to
the public. Other sites in Washington, D.C., like the National
Cathedral, were also damaged.

### Intraplate Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-SW50cmFwbGF0ZSBFYXJ0aHF1YWtlcw.._9-uge}

About 5% of earthquakes take place within a plate, away from plate
boundaries. These **intraplate earthquakes** are caused by stresses
within a plate. Since plates move over a spherical surface, zones of
weakness are created. Intraplate earthquakes happen along these zones of
weakness. The earthquakes may take place along ancient faults or rift
zones.

#### 2011 Virginia Earthquake {#6.html#x-ck12-MjAxMSBWaXJnaW5pYSBFYXJ0aHF1YWtl_9-l4d}

In August 2011, the eastern seaboard of the U.S. was rocked by a
magnitude 5.8 earthquake. While not huge, most of the residents had
never experienced an earthquake. Many didn't know what had happened!

This region is no longer part of an active plate boundary. But a few
hundred million years ago, at the end of the Paleozoic, things were
different. Continent-continent convergence was bringing Pangaea
together. This region was being uplifted into the ancestral Appalachian
mountains. There are still ancient faults that sometimes reactivate.

#### New Madrid Earthquake {#6.html#x-ck12-TmV3IE1hZHJpZCBFYXJ0aHF1YWtl_9-vfi}

In 1812, a magnitude 7.5 earthquake struck near New Madrid, Missouri.
The earthquake was strongly felt over approximately 50,000 square miles.
The quake even altered the course of the Mississippi River. Because very
few people lived in the area at the time, only 20 people died. Many more
people live there today ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy1OZXdNYWRyaWQ.) ). A similar earthquake
today would undoubtedly kill many people and cause a great deal of
property damage. The New Madrid Seismic Zone continues to be active.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZTIwZjZmODZjMmNjMzBjOGFkMTg2NzNmNzE4MGRjZTE.-5qw"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.usgs.gov/blogs/features/usgs_top_story/200th-anniversary-of-new-madrid-earthquakes" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The map of the New Madrid seismic
zone](ck12_6_files/20150911025727407930.jpeg "The map of the New Madrid seismic zone")

**Figure 6.31**

The New Madrid seismic zone is located in the interior of the North
American plate (near Missouri, Arkansas, Tennessee, Kentucky, and
Illinois).

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._9-knk}

-   Intraplate earthquakes occur because solid lithosphere travels on a
    round planet.
-   Intraplate earthquakes hit reactivated ancient faults.
-   Intraplate earthquakes are not usually as large as quakes along
    plate boundaries. Still, they can do a great deal of damage.

# Seismic Waves from Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-U2Vpc21pYyBXYXZlcyBmcm9tIEVhcnRocXVha2Vz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the different types of seismic waves.
-   Explain how scientists attempt to predict earthquakes.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601211] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025728009847.jpeg)
</span>

**Are seismic waves like ocean waves?**

Yes, in some ways. Ocean waves travel at the interface between the sea
surface and the atmosphere. They have all the features that all waves
have. Some seismic waves also travel at an interface. Which ones?

### Seismic Waves {#6.html#x-ck12-U2Vpc21pYyBXYXZlcw.._10-mtf}

Seismic waves are the energy from earthquakes. Seismic waves move
outward in all directions away from their source. Each type of seismic
wave travels at different speeds in different materials. All seismic
waves travel through rock, but not all travel through liquid or gas.
Geologists study seismic waves to learn about earthquakes and the
Earth’s interior.

#### Wave Structure {#6.html#x-ck12-V2F2ZSBTdHJ1Y3R1cmU._10-xki}

Seismic waves are just one type of wave. Sound and light also travel in
waves. Every wave has a high point called a **crest** and a low point
called a **trough** . The height of a wave from the center line to its
crest is its **amplitude** . The horizontal distance between waves from
crest to crest (or trough to trough) is its **wavelength** ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjctc2Vpc21pYy13YXZlcw..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZjViZWQyZjlkNDEyZGFkNWEwY2Y0YzUyNjQ3ZDQ0OTU.-kyp"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Raymond Chou" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of a
wave](ck12_6_files/20150911025728359778.png "Diagram of a wave")

**Figure 6.32**

The energy from earthquakes travels in waves, such as the one shown in
this diagram.

</div>

#### Types of Seismic Waves {#6.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgU2Vpc21pYyBXYXZlcw.._10-yg1}

There are two major types of seismic waves. **Body waves** travel
through the Earth’s interior. **Surface waves** travel along the ground
surface. In an earthquake, body waves are responsible for the sharp
jolts. Surface waves are responsible for the rolling motions that do
most of the damage in an earthquake.

#### Body Waves {#6.html#x-ck12-Qm9keSBXYXZlcw.._10-xmu}

**Primary waves (P-waves)** and **secondary waves (S-waves)** are the
two types of body waves ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjgtYm9keS13YXZlcw..) ). Body waves
move at different speeds through different materials.

P-waves are faster. They travel at about 6 to 7 kilometers (about 4
miles) per second. Primary waves are so named because they are the first
waves to reach a seismometer. P-waves squeeze and release rocks as they
travel. The material returns to its original size and shape after the
P-wave goes by. For this reason, P-waves are not the most damaging
earthquake waves. P-waves travel through solids, liquids, and gases.

S-waves are slower than P-waves. They are the second waves to reach a
seismometer. S-waves move up and down. They change the rock’s shape as
they travel. S-waves are about half as fast as P-waves, at about 3.5 km
(2 miles) per second. S-waves can only move through solids. This is
because liquids and gases don’t resist changing shape.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NmQxYmE2YTQzMGNhYmI3MzE4ODY0OGRiZmFlMmYyOWI.-0q6"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pswaves.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![P-waves and S-waves are the two types of body
waves](ck12_6_files/20150911025728613633.png "P-waves and S-waves are the two types of body waves")

**Figure 6.33**

P-waves and S-waves are the two types of body waves.

</div>

#### Surface Waves {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VyZmFjZSBXYXZlcw.._10-9gf}

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZDBkMjU3NWU4YTMyNzVhNmU4ZDg5NzA2M2U2YzRjY2E.-q2f"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pswaves.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Love waves and Rayleigh waves are the two types of surface
waves](ck12_6_files/20150911025728747822.png "Love waves and Rayleigh waves are the two types of surface waves")

**Figure 6.34**

Love waves and Rayleigh waves are the two types of surface waves.

</div>

Surface waves travel along the ground outward from an earthquake’s
epicenter. Surface waves are the slowest of all seismic waves. They
travel at 2.5 km (1.5 miles) per second. There are two types of surface
waves. **Love waves** move side-to-side, much like a snake. **Rayleigh
waves** produce a rolling motion as they move up and backward (
**Figure** [above](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMjktc3VyZmFjZS13YXZlcw..)
). Surface waves cause objects to fall and rise. They also cause objects
to sway back and forth. These motions cause damage to rigid structures
during an earthquake.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-r6z}

-   Body waves travel through the body of a planet. Surface waves travel
    along the surface.
-   There are two types of body waves: P-waves travel fastest and
    through solids, liquids, and gases; S-waves only travel
    through solids.
-   Surface waves are the slowest, but they do the most damage in
    an earthquake.

# Predicting Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-UHJlZGljdGluZyBFYXJ0aHF1YWtlcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how scientists attempt to predict earthquakes.
-   Describe the signs of an upcoming earthquake.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601219] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025728884678.jpeg)
</span>

**What if you could predict an earthquake?**

What would make a good prediction? Knowing where, when, and the
magnitude of the quake would make it possible for people to evacuate. If
you were right, you would be famous! But if you were wrong, many people
would be angry with you.

### Earthquake Prediction {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBQcmVkaWN0aW9u_11-oqs}

Scientists are a long way from being able to predict earthquakes. A good
prediction must be detailed and accurate. Where will the earthquake
occur? When will it occur? What will be its approximate magnitude? With
a good prediction, authorities could get people to evacuate. But if the
prediction were wrong, a lot of money would be lost as people closed
businesses and skipped work. Plus people would be unlikely to believe
the authorities the next time.

#### Predicting Where {#6.html#x-ck12-UHJlZGljdGluZyBXaGVyZQ.._11-t9w}

Where an earthquake will occur is the easiest feature to predict. How
would you predict this? Scientists know that earthquakes take place at
plate boundaries. They tend to happen where they’ve happened before (
**Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMzctVVMtcXVha2UtaGF6YXJkLW1hcA..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NTkwM2FkNThlNmMwODRkYWE3YTA4YzAxYTA1MTdlMTc.-lr5"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2005/3038/508fs3038.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of earthquake probability regions in the United
States](ck12_6_files/20150911025729029954.png "Map of earthquake probability regions in the United States")

**Figure 6.35**

This map shows earthquake probability regions in the United States.

</div>

Fault segments behave consistently. A segment with frequent small
earthquakes will likely continue to have frequent small earthquakes. A
fault segment with infrequent huge earthquakes will likely have
infrequent huge earthquakes. The image below shows the probabilities of
earthquakes striking along various faults in the San Francisco area (
**Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2ljLTA3MDMtMDU.) ). The time
frame is between 2003 (when the work was done) and 2032.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZTgxZjE3YTc1YWMyMDEyMThmZWU4ZTAyMDAwZGY0OTc.-loa"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Eq-prob.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of probabilities of earthquake along faults in the San Francisco
Bay
Area](ck12_6_files/20150911025729161232.jpeg "Map of probabilities of earthquake along faults in the San Francisco Bay Area")

**Figure 6.36**

The probabilities of earthquakes striking along various faults in the
San Francisco area between 2003 (when the work was done) and 2032.

</div>

#### Predicting When {#6.html#x-ck12-UHJlZGljdGluZyBXaGVu_11-xpb}

When an earthquake will occur is much more difficult to predict. Stress
on a fault builds up at the same rate over time. So earthquakes should
occur at regular intervals. But, so far, scientists cannot predict when
quakes will occur even to within a few years. Around Parkfield,
California, an earthquake of magnitude 6.0 or higher occurs about every
22 years. So seismologists predicted that one would strike in 1993. But
that quake came in 2004—11 years late ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDctNDMtQXJvdW5kLVBhcmtmaWVsZA..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZWFiN2YzZmZmNTkyNzIwMTMxODIxOTdhMDYwZTEzMmE.-sve"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Graph of earthquake years in Parkfield,
California](ck12_6_files/20150911025729269176.jpeg "Graph of earthquake years in Parkfield, California")

**Figure 6.37**

Trying to predict an earthquake in Parkfield, California.

</div>

### Earthquake Signs {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBTaWducw.._11-0vr}

There are sometimes signs that a large earthquake is coming. There may
be small quakes, called **foreshocks** . These can occur a few seconds
to a few weeks before a major quake. Unfortunately, foreshocks are not
very useful for predicting large earthquakes. Many quakes do not have
foreshocks. Also, small earthquakes are not necessarily followed by a
large earthquake.

There are other possible signs before an earthquake. The ground may
tilt. Ground tilting is caused by the buildup of stress in the rocks.
This may happen before a large earthquake, but it doesn't always. Water
levels in wells may fluctuate. This is because water may move into or
out of fractures before an earthquake. This is also an uncertain way to
predict an earthquake. The difference in arrival times of P-waves and
S-waves may decrease just before an earthquake occurs.

Folklore tells of animals behaving strangely just before an earthquake.
Most people tell stories of these behaviors after the earthquake.
Chinese scientists have actively studied the behavior of animals before
earthquakes to see if there is a connection. So far nothing concrete has
come of these studies.

Actions can reduce the damage once an earthquake has started.
Seismometers can detect P-waves a few seconds before more damaging
S-waves and surface waves arrive. In this time computers can shut down
gas mains and electrical transmission lines. They can initiate
protective measures in chemical plants, nuclear power plants, mass
transit systems, airports, and roadways. Just a few seconds can be
tremendously valuable.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._11-sm2}

-   A good prediction must indicate when and where an earthquake will
    take place.
-   Fault segments behave the same way over time.
-   Signs that an earthquakes may occur include foreshocks, ground
    tilting, water levels in wells, and the relative arrival times of P-
    and S-waves.

# 21st Century Tsunami {#6.html#x-ck12-MjFzdCBDZW50dXJ5IFRzdW5hbWk.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe tsunami.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601226] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025729413744.jpeg)
</span>

**Why should you pay attention in school?**

Eleven-year-old Tilly Smith and her family were walking along the beach
in Phuket, Thailand on December 26, 2004. Tilly noticed that the sea was
bubbling. She thought this was like a video she'd seen in geography
class two weeks earlier. The English schoolgirl insisted to her parents
that a tsunami was coming. Her warning saved the approximately 100
tourists and civilians who were on that beach.

### Tsunami {#6.html#x-ck12-VHN1bmFtaQ.._12-zdj}

Earthquakes can cause **tsunamis** . These deadly ocean waves may result
from any shock to ocean water. A shock could be a meteorite impact,
landslide, or a nuclear explosion. But most come from large underwater
earthquakes.

An underwater earthquake creates a tsunami this way: the movement of the
crust displaces water. The displacement forms a set of waves. The waves
travel at jet speed through the ocean. Since the waves have low
amplitudes and long wavelengths, they are unnoticed in deep water. As
the waves reach shore they compress. They are also pushed upward by the
shore. For these reasons, tsunamis can grow to enormous wave heights.
Tsunami waves can cause tremendous destruction and loss of life.
Fortunately, few undersea earthquakes generate tsunamis.

#### The Boxing Day Tsunami, 2004 {#6.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEJveGluZyBEYXkgVHN1bmFtaSwgMjAwNA.._12-5nu}

The Boxing Day Tsunami struck on December 26, 2004. The tsunami was
caused by one of the largest earthquakes ever recorded. The Indian Ocean
Earthquake registered magnitude 9.1. The quake struck near Sumatra,
Indonesia, where the Indian plate is subducting beneath the Burma plate.
It released about 550 million times the energy of the atomic bomb
dropped on Hiroshima.

Several tsunami waves were created. The waves went around the Indian
Ocean and struck eight countries ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy0yMDA0SW5kb25lc2lhVHN1bmFtaU1hcA..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-OWY1NWJlMGFlMTI5MTQ5Njk2Y2M5YTBhN2NhNDIyNzQ.-9do"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NOAA, NGDC" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/hazard/tsu_travel_time_events.shtml" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of the area hit by the Boxing Day
Tsunami](ck12_6_files/20150911025729581646.jpeg "Map of the area hit by the Boxing Day Tsunami")

**Figure 6.38**

Travel time map for the Boxing Day Tsunami (in hours). Countries near
red, orange, and yellow areas were affected the most.

</div>

About 230,000 people died. More than 1.2 million people lost their
homes. Many more lost their way of making a living. Fishermen lost their
boats, and businesspeople lost their restaurants and shops. Many marine
animals washed onshore, including dolphins, turtles, and sharks.

#### Japan Tsunami, 2011 {#6.html#x-ck12-SmFwYW4gVHN1bmFtaSwgMjAxMQ.._12-qwc}

The Japanese received a one-two punch in March 2011. The 2011 Tōhoku
earthquake offshore was a magnitude 9.0, and damage from the quake was
extensive. The earthquake generated massive tsunami waves which hit the
island nation. Waves in some regions topped 9 meters (27 feet).

The tsunami did much more damage than the massive earthquake. In the
photo of Sendai ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDctVG9ob2t1LWVhcnRocXVha2UtYWVyaWFs) ),
the black smoke is coming from an oil refinery. The refinery was set on
fire due to the earthquake. The tsunami prevented efforts to extinguish
the fire for several days.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZjVlYThmYjZmMDE2MGQ0YjQ0OWQ3ZmI4YTAwNzY0ODk.-7eh"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Navy" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:SH-60B_helicopter_flies_over_Sendai.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Damage caused by the 2011 earthquake and
tsunami](ck12_6_files/20150911025729684383.jpeg "Damage caused by the 2011 earthquake and tsunami")

**Figure 6.39**

An aerial view shows the damage to Sendai, Japan caused by the
earthquake and tsunami.

</div>

Worst of all was the damage done to nuclear power plants along the
northeastern coast. Eleven reactors were automatically shut down. Power
and backup power were lost at the Fukushima plant. This lead to
equipment failures, meltdowns, and the release of radioactive materials.
Cleanup of the disabled plants will go on for many years.

### Tsunami Warning Systems {#6.html#x-ck12-VHN1bmFtaSBXYXJuaW5nIFN5c3RlbXM._12-ggk}

Most of the Indian Ocean tragedy could have been avoided if a warning
system had been in place ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMzItdHN1bmFtaS13YXJuaW5nLXN5c3RlbQ..)
). As of June 2006, the Indian Ocean now has a warning system.
Communities around the Pacific have had a tsunami warning system since
1948.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZWU3ZjNjYTVkYWZiODkyMWZlNzc3MTNjODEyMGZjNDQ.-2em"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:youngthousands" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/theyoungthousands/2609041263/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of a tsunami warning
sign](ck12_6_files/20150911025729804823.jpeg "Picture of a tsunami warning sign")

**Figure 6.40**

This sign is part of the tsunami warning system used in communities
around the Pacific Ocean since 1948.

</div>

As in Japan, warning systems aren’t always helpful. People in
communities very close to the earthquake do not have enough time to move
out of the area. Farther away from the quake, evacuation of low-lying
areas saves lives.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-lp5}

-   Tsunamis have relatively low amplitude and long wavelengths. They
    are not noticeable until they move up a shore.
-   Tsunami warning systems are now found in most locations where
    tsunamis are possible.
-   The Boxing Day Tsunami of 2004 came from a massive earthquake. The
    waves traveled across the Indian Ocean, causing death and
    destruction in 12 nations.
-   In Japan, the tsunami struck very quickly after the 9.0 earthquake
    in the subduction zone offshore. Many more people died from the
    tsunami than the quake.

# Measuring Earthquake Magnitude {#6.html#x-ck12-TWVhc3VyaW5nIEVhcnRocXVha2UgTWFnbml0dWRl}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe instruments scientists use to measure earthquakes.
-   Explain the information seismograms provide.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601231] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025729915888.jpeg)
</span>

**Have you ever felt an earthquake?**

Small earthquakes are fairly common in some parts of the world.
Depending on the quake, the land, and the setting, people experience
them differently. You may wonder why your chair is moving, when you are
sitting still. You may think someone is running across the roof. In a
skyscraper, you may be swaying. Seismometers quantify this and record
the energy released in the quake.

### Measuring Seismic Waves {#6.html#x-ck12-TWVhc3VyaW5nIFNlaXNtaWMgV2F2ZXM._13-qhb}

Seismic waves are measured on a seismograph. Seismographs contain a lot
of information, and not just about earthquakes.

#### Seismometers {#6.html#x-ck12-U2Vpc21vbWV0ZXJz_13-ae8}

A **seismograph** is a machine that records seismic waves. In the past,
seismographs produced a **seismogram** . A seismogram is a paper record
of the seismic waves the seismograph received. Seismographs have a
weighted pen suspended from a stationary frame. A drum of paper is
attached to the ground. As the ground shakes in an earthquake, the pen
remains stationary but the drum moves beneath it. This creates the
squiggly lines that make up a seismogram ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TZWlzbW9ncmFwaFBpbmF0dWJv) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MDY4NGU1ZWQzNTc4ZmU4NGQzY2MzOWE5OGFhOTI5ZDA.-e0w"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of R. P. Hoblitt, US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Seismograph_Pinatubo.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Picture of a
seismograph](ck12_6_files/20150911025730044691.jpeg "Picture of a seismograph")

**Figure 6.41**

This seismograph records seismic waves.

</div>

Modern **seismometers** record ground motions using electronic motion
detectors. The data are then kept digitally on a computer.

#### What We Learn from Seismograms {#6.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBXZSBMZWFybiBmcm9tIFNlaXNtb2dyYW1z_13-hge}

Seismograms contain a lot of information about an earthquake: its
strength, length, and distance. Wave height is used to determine the
magnitude of the earthquake. The seismogram shows the different arrival
times of the seismic waves ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMzQtc2Vpc21vZ3JhbS1QLVMtd2F2ZS1hcnJpdmFs)
). The first waves are P-waves since they are the fastest. S-waves come
in next and are usually larger than P-waves. The surface waves arrive
just after the S-waves. If the earthquake has a shallow focus, the
surface waves are the largest ones recorded.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MDJhZDA2ODNmODgzZTZjMmQ3ZDBlM2VlMDcwMzcxNWU.-qop"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Crickett/Wikipedia" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Seismogram.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![These seismograms show the arrival of P-waves and
S-waves](ck12_6_files/20150911025730190123.png "These seismograms show the arrival of P-waves and S-waves")

**Figure 6.42**

These seismograms show the arrival of P-waves and S-waves.

</div>

A seismogram may record P-waves and surface waves, but not S-waves. This
means that it was located more than halfway around the Earth from the
earthquake. What does that mean? Earth's outer core is liquid. S-waves
cannot travel through liquid. So the liquid outer core creates an S-wave
shadow zone on the opposite side of the Earth from the quake.

Like most things, seismographs are now digital. Information from seismic
waves is fed into computers at seismic stations around the world.

This animation shows three different stations picking up seismic waves:
[http://www.iris.edu/hq/files/programs/education\_and\_outreach/aotm/10/4StationSeismoNetwork480.mov](4StationSeismoNetwork480.mov)
.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._13-h8t}

-   A seismograph records seismic waves on a seismogram. A seismometer
    is a digital seismic wave recorder.
-   S-waves do not travel through liquids. So a seismogram with no
    S-waves is on the other side of the planet from the quake.
-   Seismographs yield a tremendous amount of information about
    an earthquake.

# Locating Earthquake Epicenters {#6.html#x-ck12-TG9jYXRpbmcgRWFydGhxdWFrZSBFcGljZW50ZXJz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how to find an earthquake epicenter.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601238] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025730297753.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you find an earthquake epicenter?**

The epicenter of the 2011 Japan earthquake was just offshore of Sendai.
This is where the Pacific Plate plunges into a subduction zone. The
earthquake had a relatively shallow depth of 20 miles (32 km). Remember
that shallow quakes typically cause the most damage. How do scientists
find an earthquake epicenter?

### Finding the Epicenter {#6.html#x-ck12-RmluZGluZyB0aGUgRXBpY2VudGVy_14-zlf}

One seismogram indicates the distance to the epicenter. This is
determined by the P-and S-wave arrival times. If a quake is near the
seismograph, the S-waves arrive shortly after the P-waves. If a quake is
far from the seismograph, the P-waves arrive long before the S-waves.
The longer the time is between the P-and S-wave arrivals, the further
away the earthquake was from the seismograph. First, seismologists
calculate the arrival time difference. Then they know the distance to
the epicenter from that seismograph. They can connect all the points
that are that distance from the seismic station. This makes a circle
around the station!

Next, the seismologists try to determine the location of the earthquake
epicenter. To do this they need the distances to the epicenter from at
least three seismographs. Let’s say that they know that an earthquake’s
epicenter is 50 kilometers from Kansas City. They draw a circle with a
50 km radius around that seismic station. They do this twice more around
two different seismic stations. The three circles intersect at a single
point. This is the earthquake’s epicenter ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMzUtZmluZGluZy1lcGljZW50ZXI.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-N2M3NzIxMmE1MmRhYTY4ZTdjZDE2MzdjZWFhNzVlZTg.-yrl"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@url="" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Finding an earthquake epicenter using 3
seismographs](ck12_6_files/20150911025730424253.png "Finding an earthquake epicenter using 3 seismographs")

**Figure 6.43**

Seismographs in Portland, San Francisco, and Salt Lake City are used to
find an earthquake epicenter.

</div>

Of course, it's been a long time since scientists drew circles to locate
an earthquake epicenter. This is all done digitally now. but it's a
great way to learn the basics of locating an epicenter.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-d2t}

-   To find an earthquake epicenter you need at least
    three seismographs.
-   Find the distance from each seismograph to the earthquake epicenter.
-   The interception of the three circles is the epicenter.

### Explore More {#6.html#x-ck12-RXhwbG9yZSBNb3Jl_14-r0s}

    [http://teachertube.com/viewVideo.php?video\_id=44551](viewVideo.php?video_id=44551) (2:40)

[![](ck12_6_files/emb_multimedia.png)](embed.php%3Fpg%3Dvideo_44551%26hash%3Dd5cf6dea66e29e53da7798e9bf94f0f8)

# Scales that Represent Earthquake Magnitude {#6.html#x-ck12-U2NhbGVzIHRoYXQgUmVwcmVzZW50IEVhcnRocXVha2UgTWFnbml0dWRl}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how scientists express the size and intensity of
    an earthquake.
-   Compare the Richter magnitude scale to the moment magnitude scale.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601243] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025730522357.jpeg)
</span>

**How do scientists measure earthquakes?**

This 8.8 magnitude earthquake in Chile in 2010 caused over 500 deaths
and thousands of injuries. Earthquakes and the damage they cause can be
measured in a few different ways. One way is to describe the damage. The
other way is to measure the energy of the quake.

### Earthquake Intensity {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBJbnRlbnNpdHk._15-ibz}

The ways seismologists measure an earthquake have changed over the
decades. Initially, they could only measure what people felt and saw:
the intensity. For this, they used the Mercalli scale.

##### Mercalli Scale {#6.html#x-ck12-TWVyY2FsbGkgU2NhbGU._15-grb}

Early in the 20th century, earthquakes were described in terms of what
people felt and the damage that was done to buildings. The **Mercalli
intensity scale** describes earthquake intensity.

There are many problems with the Mercalli scale. The damage from an
earthquake is affected by many things. The type of ground a building
sits on is very important to what happens to that building in a quake.
Different people experience an earthquake differently. Using this scale,
comparisons between earthquakes were difficult to make. A new scale was
needed.

### Earthquake Magnitude {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBNYWduaXR1ZGU._15-pni}

For decades scientists have had equipment that can measure earthquake
magnitude. The earthquake magnitude is the energy released during the
quake.

#### The Richter Magnitude Scale {#6.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFJpY2h0ZXIgTWFnbml0dWRlIFNjYWxl_15-jgf}

Charles Richter developed the **Richter magnitude scale** in 1935. The
Richter scale measures the magnitude of an earthquake's largest jolt of
energy. This is determined by using the height of the waves recorded on
a seismograph.

The Richter scale is logarithmic. The magnitudes jump from one level to
the next. The height of the largest wave increases 10 times with each
level. So the height of the largest seismic wave of a magnitude 5 quake
is 10 times that of a magnitude 4 quake. A magnitude 5 is 100 times that
of a magnitude 3 quake. With each level, thirty times more energy is
released. A difference of two levels on the Richter scale equals 900
times more released energy.

The Richter scale has limitations. A single sharp jolt measures higher
on the Richter scale than a very long intense earthquake. Yet, this is
misleading because the longer quake releases more energy. Earthquakes
that release more energy are likely to do more damage. As a result,
another scale was needed.

#### The Moment Magnitude Scale {#6.html#x-ck12-VGhlIE1vbWVudCBNYWduaXR1ZGUgU2NhbGU._15-rev}

The **moment magnitude scale** is the favored method of measuring
earthquake magnitudes. It measures the total energy released by an
earthquake. Moment magnitude is calculated by two things. One is the
length of the fault break. The other is the distance the ground moves
along the fault. Japan's Tōhoku earthquake in 2011 had a magnitude of
9.0 ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDctMzYtamFwYW4tdHN1bmFtaS1kYW1hZ2U.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NGM3MzI2ZmI0NTFhNmQxODkzYmI2OGJhN2ZiMzU0ZTA.-edu"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Navy" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tsunami_damage_north_of_Sendai_1x1_resized.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Earthquake and tsunami damage in
Japan](ck12_6_files/20150911025730652519.jpeg "Earthquake and tsunami damage in Japan")

**Figure 6.44**

Earthquake and tsunami damage in Japan, 2011. The Tōhoku earthquake had
a magnitude of 9.0.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._15-wfz}

-   Mercalli Intensity Scale depends on many factors other than the
    amount of energy released in the earthquake. These factors include
    the type of rock in the region. They also include the quality of the
    structures built in the area.
-   The Richter scale is a logarithmic scale that measures the largest
    jolt of energy released by an earthquake.
-   The moment magnitude scale is a logarithmic scale that measures the
    total amount of energy released by an earthquake.

# Earthquake Damage {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBEYW1hZ2U.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify factors that make an earthquake damaging and deadly.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601249] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025730752108.jpeg)
</span>

**Is earthquake magnitude the most important factor in determining
damage?**

The type of construction has a tremendous effect on what happens during
an earthquake. Damage and deaths are directly affected by the
construction in an earthquake. For example, enormous damage was done in
the 2011 Christchurch, New Zealand earthquake. However, far less was
damaged in an earthquake of the same magnitude near the area in Iceland
seen above.

### Damage from Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-RGFtYWdlIGZyb20gRWFydGhxdWFrZXM._16-bkl}

We know that earthquakes kill lots of people. However, the ground
shaking almost never kills people. Unlike in cartoons, the ground does
not swallow someone up! Deaths depend somewhat on an earthquake's size
and the type of ground people inhabit. But a very important factor is
the quality of the structures. People are killed when structures fall on
them. More damage is done and more people are killed by the fires that
follow an earthquake. Of course, the number of deaths is different from
the property damage that a quake does.

#### What Makes an Earthquake Deadly? {#6.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBNYWtlcyBhbiBFYXJ0aHF1YWtlIERlYWRseT8._16-ql8}

What makes an earthquake deadly?

-   Population density. The magnitude 9.2 Great Alaska Earthquake, near
    Anchorage, of 1964 resulted in only 131 deaths. At the time few
    people lived in the area ( **Figure**
    [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTA3MDQtMDM.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MjBkZjI0MDhkZmM4MDVkMTJkMzY2MDQ1NmQwYTgzOWM.-5dw"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AlaskaQuake-Turnagain.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A landslide in a neighborhood in Anchorage, Alaska, after the 1964
Great Alaska
earthquake](ck12_6_files/20150911025730847150.jpeg "A landslide in a neighborhood in Anchorage, Alaska, after the 1964 Great Alaska earthquake")

**Figure 6.45**

A landslide in a neighborhood in Anchorage, Alaska, after the 1964 Great
Alaska earthquake.

</div>

-   Size, but not size. No one dies in a magnitude 1.0 earthquake. But
    large quakes to not always kill a lot of people. Only about 2,000
    people died in the 1960 Great Chilean earthquake. This was the
    largest earthquake ever recorded. The Indian Ocean earthquake of
    2004 was one of the largest ever. Still, most of the 230,000
    fatalities were caused by the tsunami, not the earthquake.
-   Ground type. Solid bedrock vibrates less than soft sediments, so
    there is less damage on bedrock. Sometimes sediments become
    saturated with water. They then undergo **liquefaction** and become
    like quicksand ( **Figure**
    [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTA3MDQtMDI.) ). Soil on a hillside
    may become a landslide.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MGVlYWE1MzBhYTk3ODIwZTBjMjY0ZDZkOTE0ZDI2Yzc.-co4"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of I.D. Celebi, US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:MexCity85quake.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Liquefaction of sediments in Mexico City caused the collapse of many
buildings in the 1985
earthquake](ck12_6_files/20150911025730960425.jpeg "Liquefaction of sediments in Mexico City caused the collapse of many buildings in the 1985 earthquake")

**Figure 6.46**

Liquefaction of sediments in Mexico City caused the collapse of many
buildings in the 1985 earthquake.

</div>

Earthquake effects on buildings are seen in this animation:
[http://www.iris.edu/hq/files/programs/education\_and\_outreach/aotm/6/SeismicBuilding-Narrated480.mov](SeismicBuilding-Narrated480.mov)
.

#### City Planning {#6.html#x-ck12-Q2l0eSBQbGFubmluZw.._16-lr1}

In earthquake-prone areas, city planners try to reduce hazards. They
look at both the likelihood of a quake and the damage one would do. For
example, in the San Francisco Bay Area, maps show how much shaking is
expected for different ground types ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTA3MDQtMDE.) ). This allows planners to
locate new hospitals and schools more safely.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MjZhZWM3OWZiNWNkMTJiMjg3YmQwYWRkN2ZlODhmZDQ.-o7c"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Association of Bay Area Governments" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:RogersCrkNorthHayward.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The expected Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale for an earthquake of
magnitude 7.1 on the northern portion of the Hayward
Fault](ck12_6_files/20150911025731066174.png "The expected Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale for an earthquake of magnitude 7.1 on the northern portion of the Hayward Fault")

**Figure 6.47**

The expected Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale for an earthquake of
magnitude 7.1 on the northern portion of the Hayward Fault.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._16-aio}

-   Seismic waves rarely kill anyone. Structures falling on people and
    fires or tsunamis after the earthquake cause many more fatalities.
-   City planning can lessen the damage done by earthquakes.
-   Population density and ground type affect the number of fatalities.

# Earthquake Safe Structures {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZSBTYWZlIFN0cnVjdHVyZXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify steps that can be taken to make buildings safer and avoid
    fires in earthquake-prone areas.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601255] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025731210092.jpeg)
</span>

**Why is California Memorial Stadium called a "tectonic time bomb"?**

The California Memorial Stadium is the home of football at the
University of California, Berkeley. The site probably looked flat and
easy to build on in 1922. But now scientists know that the Hayward Fault
passes directly beneath both end zones. The stadium has been renovated
in a \$321 million project. The renovation involved 10 miles of steel
cables, silicone fluid-filled shock absorbers, concrete piers, 3-feet of
sand, plastic sheeting, and stone columns. Go Bears!

### New Construction {#6.html#x-ck12-TmV3IENvbnN0cnVjdGlvbg.._17-jht}

New construction can be made safer in many ways:

-   Skyscrapers and other large structures built on soft ground must be
    anchored to bedrock. Sometimes the bedrock lies hundreds of meters
    below the ground surface.
-   The correct building materials must be used. Houses should bend
    and sway. Wood and steel are better than brick, stone, and adobe,
    which are brittle and will break.
-   Larger buildings must sway, but not so much that they touch
    nearby buildings. Counterweights and diagonal steel beams are used
    to hold down sway.
-   Large buildings can be placed on rollers so that they move with
    the ground.
-   Buildings may be placed on layers of steel and rubber to absorb the
    shock of the waves.
-   Connections, such as where the walls meet the foundation, must be
    made strong.
-   In a multi-story building, the first story must be well supported.

The Transamerica Building in San Francisco, pictured below, rests on a
52-foot deep steel and concrete foundation. Steel rods reinforce the
building internally and X-shaped trusses support it externally. In the
1989 Loma Prieta earthquake, the building shook for more than a minute
and swayed more than 12 inches in each direction, but was not damaged.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YTRjNzRmMmQyYmI4NjVmY2Q4NDJmM2YzZmQxYmQxOTM.-xuo"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Leonard G./Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:TransamericaPyramidFromTI.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The Transamerica Pyramid is more stable than a standard
skyscraper](ck12_6_files/20150911025731328051.jpeg "The Transamerica Pyramid is more stable than a standard skyscraper")

**Figure 6.48**

The Transamerica Pyramid in San Francisco is more stable in an
earthquake or in high winds than a rectangular skyscraper.

</div>

### Retrofitting {#6.html#x-ck12-UmV0cm9maXR0aW5n_17-n10}

Older buildings can be made more earthquake safe by **retrofitting** .
Steel or wood can be used to reinforce a building's structure and its
connections. Elevated freeways and bridges can also be retrofitted so
that they do not collapse ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1CcmlkZ2VSZXRyb2ZpdA..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YmE5ZjA4NjI4N2RkZjY0YTA4MDg0ODdlOTlmNTVkYjU.-6vd"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:Osbornb" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/osbornb/4354627325/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Bridge retrofitted to meet earthquake safety
standards](ck12_6_files/20150911025731451388.jpeg "Bridge retrofitted to meet earthquake safety standards")

**Figure 6.49**

This bridge in San Diego, California, was built in 1931. It was
retrofitted and reopened in 2010 to meet earthquake standards.

</div>

### Preventing Fire Damage {#6.html#x-ck12-UHJldmVudGluZyBGaXJlIERhbWFnZQ.._17-2ce}

Fires often cause more damage than the earthquake. Fires start because
seismic waves rupture gas and electrical lines. Breaks in water mains
make it difficult to fight the fires ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDctNDktU0YtRWFydGhxdWFrZQ..) ). The
shapes of pipes can make a big difference. Straight pipes will break in
a quake. Builders zigzag pipes so that they bend and flex when the
ground shakes. In San Francisco, water and gas pipelines are separated
by valves. Areas can be isolated if one segment breaks.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NzFkYzRiODM4YWVjNWE3ZTdmODIxNDM1NTAyMTdhNTE.-kek"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of H. D. Chadwick, modified by Durova" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sfearthquake3b.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![In the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, fire was much more destructive
than the ground
shaking](ck12_6_files/20150911025731538555.jpeg "In the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, fire was much more destructive than the ground shaking")

**Figure 6.50**

In the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, fire was much more destructive
than the ground shaking.

</div>

##### Making Choices {#6.html#x-ck12-TWFraW5nIENob2ljZXM._17-ut8}

Strong, sturdy structures are expensive to build. Communities must
decide how safe to make their buildings. They must weigh how great the
hazard is, what different building strategies will cost, and how much
risk they are willing to take.

See more here:
[http://science.kqed.org/quest/video/the-hayward-fault-predictable-peril/]()
.

[![](ck12_6_files/tmpS_7wFV.jpeg)](3jtAKPO4iHA%3Fwmode%3Dtransparent%26rel%3D0%26hash%3D23b8889f14f86d11225ab4fedf1d4e95)

Click on the image above for more content

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._17-8ma}

-   New structures that are built to meet earthquake safety codes do
    much better in earthquakes.
-   Old buildings can be retrofitted for better safety.
-   Cost is an important factor in deciding how safe to make the
    structures in an area.
