# Staying Safe in an Earthquake {#6.html#x-ck12-U3RheWluZyBTYWZlIGluIGFuIEVhcnRocXVha2U.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify how you can prepare for an earthquake.
-   Describe ways to stay safe during and after an earthquake.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601260] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025731641064.jpeg)
</span>

**How can you prepare for an earthquake?**

If you live in earthquake country, the actions you take before, during,
and after a quake could make the difference in your comfort for several
days, or even your survival.

### Protecting Yourself in an Earthquake {#6.html#x-ck12-UHJvdGVjdGluZyBZb3Vyc2VsZiBpbiBhbiBFYXJ0aHF1YWtl_18-0r7}

There are many things you can do to protect yourself before, during, and
after an earthquake.

#### Before the Earthquake {#6.html#x-ck12-QmVmb3JlIHRoZSBFYXJ0aHF1YWtl_18-vgl}

-   Have an engineer evaluate the house for structural integrity. Make
    sure the separate pieces—floor, walls, roof, and foundation—are all
    well-attached to each other.
-   Bracket or brace brick chimneys to the roof.
-   Be sure that heavy objects are not stored in high places.
-   Secure water heaters all around and at the top and bottom.
-   Bolt heavy furniture onto walls with bolts, screws, or strap hinges.
-   Replace halogen and incandescent light bulbs with fluorescent bulbs
    to lessen fire risk.
-   Check to see that gas lines are made of flexible material so that
    they do not rupture. Any equipment that uses gas should
    be well-secured.
-   Everyone in the household should know how to shut off the gas line.
-   Prepare an earthquake kit with three days supply of water and food,
    a radio, and batteries.
-   Place flashlights all over the house and in the glove box of
    your car.
-   Keep several fire extinguishers around the house to fight
    small fires.
-   Be sure to have a first aid kit. Everyone should know basic first
    aid and CPR.
-   Plan in advance how you will evacuate and where you will go. Do not
    plan on driving, as roadways will likely be damaged.

#### During the Earthquake {#6.html#x-ck12-RHVyaW5nIHRoZSBFYXJ0aHF1YWtl_18-ueh}

-   If you are in a building, get beneath a sturdy table, cover your
    head, and hold on.
-   Stay away from windows, mirrors, and large furniture.
-   If the building is structurally unsound, get outside as fast
    as possible.
-   If you are outside, run to an open area away from buildings and
    power lines that may fall.
-   If you are in a car, stay in the car and stay away from structures
    that might collapse, such as overpasses, bridges, or buildings.

#### After the Earthquake {#6.html#x-ck12-QWZ0ZXIgdGhlIEVhcnRocXVha2U._18-dyn}

-   Be aware that **aftershocks** , smaller quakes that come after the
    main trembler, are likely.
-   Avoid dangerous areas like hillsides that may experience
    a landslide.
-   Turn off water and power to your home.
-   Call 911 only if there is a real emergency. Many people will be
    trying to get through to emergency services.
-   Be prepared to wait for help or instructions. Assist others
    as necessary.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._18-39r}

-   Before an earthquake, be sure that your home is secure. Be sure that
    you have supplies to last a few days.
-   During an earthquake, get to a safe place.
-   After an earthquake, avoid dangerous situations, wait for
    instructions, and assist as necessary.

# Volcano Characteristics {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2FubyBDaGFyYWN0ZXJpc3RpY3M.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define volcano.
-   Discuss volcano locations and stages.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601265] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025731782244.jpeg)
</span>

**Is Earth the only planet to have volcanoes?**

On Earth, active volcanoes are found on all continents except Australia.
Volcanoes even erupt under the ice on Antarctica! Volcanoes are also
common elsewhere in the solar system. In fact, the biggest volcano is on
Mars. This image is of Olympus Mons, which is a shield volcano. Olympus
Mons is three times the height of Mt. Everest. But its slopes are very
gentle.

### Volcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2Fub2Vz_19-ysn}

A volcano is a vent from which the material from a magma chamber
escapes. This may include lava, rock fragments, ash, and gases. Volcanic
eruptions can come from many types of structures. Most people think of
volcanoes as large, peaky cones. But volcanoes can be large and broad,
or tiny little cones. Volcanic eruptions can come from fractured domes,
a vent in the ground, or from a giant hole in the ground.

### Where They Are {#6.html#x-ck12-V2hlcmUgVGhleSBBcmU._19-chi}

Volcanoes are a vibrant manifestation of plate tectonics processes.
Volcanoes are common along convergent and divergent plate boundaries.
They are also found within lithospheric plates at hotspots. Wherever
mantle is able to melt, volcanoes are likely to be the result.

The Pacific Ocean basin is a good place to look for different types of
volcanoes. The light blue wavy line that goes up the right-center of the
diagram is the East Pacific Rise. The rise is made of volcanoes at a
divergent plate boundary. Trenches due to subduction are on the west and
east sides of the basin. Subduction creates island arcs that are seen in
the Western Pacific. Subduction also creates continental arcs seen along
Central and South America. Hawaii is the line of volcanoes trending
southeast-northwest near the center-top of the image ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMDItRWFzdC1QYWNpZmljLVJpc2U.) ). The
Hawaiian volcanoes are due to a hotspot.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZDljOGI3MmNkMTBjYTFlZTFmMTgyNDljZTQ4MWI1MzA.-xn8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:East_Pacific_Rise.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of volcanoes in the Pacific
Ocean](ck12_6_files/20150911025731893674.jpeg "Map of volcanoes in the Pacific Ocean")

**Figure 6.51**

Volcanoes at divergent plate boundaries are in the East Pacific Rise.
Convergent plate boundaries, where there are trenches, have volcanoes.
Hotspot volcanoes are in chains in the middle of the ocean basin.

</div>

### Creating Magma {#6.html#x-ck12-Q3JlYXRpbmcgTWFnbWE._19-lyq}

Volcanoes erupt because mantle rock melts. This is the first stage in
creating a volcano. How can rock melt? One way is if the temperature
rises. Another way is if the pressure on the rock decreases; this will
lower the rock's melting temperature. The melting temperature of a rock
also goes down if water is added. Every time there is a volcanic
eruption, one or more of these things happens. For each type of volcano
mentioned in these concepts, think about how and why melting occurs.

### Stages {#6.html#x-ck12-U3RhZ2Vz_19-fjc}

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NDg4NDhhMGQ4OTRiZTc1MjFjNzhmZmQ3MjZiNDU4ZDQ.-dr6"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Zappy's" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Volcanoes can be active, dormant, or
extinct](ck12_6_files/20150911025732004130.jpeg "Volcanoes can be active, dormant, or extinct")

**Figure 6.52**

Volcanoes can be active, dormant, or extinct.

</div>

Of all the volcanoes in the world, very few are erupting at any given
time. Scientists question whether a volcano that is not erupting will
ever erupt again and then describe it as active, dormant, or extinct.

-   **Active** : Currently erupting or showing signs of erupting soon.
-   **Dormant** : No current activity, but has erupted recently.
-   **Extinct** : No activity for some time; will probably not
    erupt again.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._19-jn8}

-   Volcanoes are located along convergent and divergent
    plate boundaries. They can be found in the middle of plates at
    hot spots.
-   Magma can be created when temperature rises, pressure lowers, or
    water is added.
-   Volcanoes may be active, dormant, or extinct. This depends on
    whether there is the possibility of magma in their magma chambers.

# Volcanoes at Plate Boundaries {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2Fub2VzIGF0IFBsYXRlIEJvdW5kYXJpZXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe volcanic activity at convergent and divergent
    plate boundaries.
-   Explain why volcanic activity occurs at these plate boundaries.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601271] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025732115561.jpeg)
</span>

**What good are plate boundaries?**

Plate boundaries create natural resources, such as gold. But plate
boundaries also create beautiful scenery like mountains. Volcanoes at
convergent plate boundaries can be beautiful to look at. They can also
be beautiful to visit or even climb!

### Convergent Plate Boundaries {#6.html#x-ck12-Q29udmVyZ2VudCBQbGF0ZSBCb3VuZGFyaWVz_20-wey}

Converging plates can be oceanic, continental, or one of each. If at
least one is oceanic, it will subduct. A subducting plate creates
volcanoes. Many of the world's volcanoes are the result of subduction at
a convergent plate boundary. A map of the world's active volcanoes is
pictured below ( **Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDgtMDEtTWFw)
).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MDExZTRkMTUyZWUxMzhiM2Y2NmFmZjI5MmU0NDdlMTk.-rzl"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image courtesy of US Geological Survey/Cascades Volcano Observatory" -->
<!-- @@url="http://vulcan.wr.usgs.gov/Glossary/PlateTectonics/Maps/map_plate_tectonics_world.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![World map of active
volcanoes](ck12_6_files/20150911025732199125.jpeg "World map of active volcanoes")

**Figure 6.53**

World map of active volcanoes.

</div>

#### Melting {#6.html#x-ck12-TWVsdGluZw.._20-1f4}

Mantle melting can come about three ways: (1) when the temperature
rises, (2) if the pressure lowers (which lowers the melting point), and
(3) if water is added, which lowers the melting point. Two of these (1
and 3) might explain why there are volcanoes at convergent plate
boundaries: the temperature of the subducting plate increases as it
sinks into the hot mantle (1). Sediments lying on top of the subducting
plate contain water. As the sediments subduct, the water rises into the
overlying mantle material. This lowers the melting temperature of the
mantle (3). When the mantle above the subducting plate melts, volcanoes
form above it. This leads to volcanoes in an island arc or continental
arc.

#### Pacific Rim {#6.html#x-ck12-UGFjaWZpYyBSaW0._20-6rx}

Convergent plate boundaries are found around much of the Pacific Ocean
basin. Trenches mark subduction zones. Volcanoes are found in an arc
above those subduction zones.

The Cascades ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy1DYXNjYWRlVm9sY2FuaWNBcmM.) ) are a chain
of volcanoes at a convergent boundary. In this region, an oceanic plate
is subducting beneath a continental plate.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NjJjZmE0YjQ4NjBiMWI1OGUyZjM2NWFhZGM5OGQxNzI.-etx"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA, modified by Black Tusk" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Cascade_Volcanic_Arc.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of volcanoes on the Cascade
Range](ck12_6_files/20150911025732318366.jpeg "Map of volcanoes on the Cascade Range")

**Figure 6.54**

The Cascade Range is formed by volcanoes created from subduction of
oceanic crust beneath the North American continent.

</div>

The Cascades have been active for 27 million years. The mountains we see
today are no more than 2 million years old. The volcanoes receive a lot
of winter snow, and many are covered by glaciers ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Nb3VudFJhaW5pZXI.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MGZlNGE2ODM4NjkzNjc5NmNiMzFlYWFmZThmODE5ZWU.-usq"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Christopher Boswell, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Picture of Mt. Rainier in
Washington](ck12_6_files/20150911025733074955.jpeg "Picture of Mt. Rainier in Washington")

**Figure 6.55**

Mt. Rainier, Washington.

</div>

The Cascades are shown on this interactive map with photos and
descriptions of each of the volcanoes:
[http://www.iris.edu/hq/files/programs/education\_and\_outreach/aotm/interactive/6.Volcanoes4Rollover.swf](6.Volcanoes4Rollover.swf)
.

### Divergent plate boundaries {#6.html#x-ck12-RGl2ZXJnZW50IHBsYXRlIGJvdW5kYXJpZXM._20-9qt}

At divergent plate boundaries hot mantle rock rises into the space where
the plates are moving apart. As the hot mantle rock rises, it goes from
higher to lower pressure. This is because there is no longer the weight
of all the rock above it. Lower pressure lowers the melting temperature
of the rock (2 in the previous section). This is why there is volcanism
at divergent plate boundaries. Lava erupts through long cracks in the
ground, or **fissures.**

#### Mid-Ocean Ridges {#6.html#x-ck12-TWlkLU9jZWFuIFJpZGdlcw.._20-r7b}

Volcanoes erupt at mid-ocean ridges, such as the Mid-Atlantic ridge.
Seafloor spreading creates new seafloor in the rift valleys. This type
of volcanism makes all of the ocean floor! Where a hotspot is located
along the ridge, such as at Iceland, volcanoes grow high enough to
create islands ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1JY2VsYW5kVm9sY2Fubw..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-OTEzYmI4YmFjMWQyMDAxNTZlMDkxYzZiNzBmN2FjYWQ.-tj6"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Gislij20, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![A volcanic eruption on
Iceland](ck12_6_files/20150911025733164560.jpeg "A volcanic eruption on Iceland")

**Figure 6.56**

A volcanic eruption on Iceland, where the Mid-Atlantic Ridge breaches
the ocean surface.

</div>

#### Continental Rifting {#6.html#x-ck12-Q29udGluZW50YWwgUmlmdGluZw.._20-psd}

Eruptions are found at divergent plate boundaries as continents break
apart, known as **continental rifting** . The Mount Gahinga volcanoes (
**Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Nb3VudEdhaGluZ2E.) ) are in
the East African Rift between the African and Arabian plates. Baja
California is breaking apart from mainland Mexico, also by continental
rifting.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZDU3ZTZkOWNhMDllMzA2NTM1ZDNjNDAyNjVlNjdkM2U.-bxt"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright PRILL, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Mount Gahinga, a mountain in Uganda, located in the East African Rift
valley](ck12_6_files/20150911025733269131.jpeg "Mount Gahinga, a mountain in Uganda, located in the East African Rift valley")

**Figure 6.57**

Mount Gahinga, a mountain in Uganda, located in the East African Rift
valley.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._20-ai7}

-   Subduction at convergent plate boundaries leads to melting
    and volcanoes.
-   Convergent plate boundaries line the Pacific Ocean basin so that
    volcanic arcs line the region.
-   Melting at divergent plate boundaries is due to release of pressure.
-   At mid-ocean ridges seafloor is pulled apart and new seafloor
    is created. Rifting in a continent can create a new
    ocean eventually.

# Volcanoes at Hotspots {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2Fub2VzIGF0IEhvdHNwb3Rz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe hotspots and the volcanic activity they create.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601276] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025733366630.jpeg)
</span>

**What does an intraplate eruption look like?**

The Hawaiian Islands are formed from a hotspot beneath the Pacific
Ocean. Volcanoes grow above the hotspot. Lava flows down the hillsides,
and some of it reaches the ocean, causing the islands to grow. Too hot
now, but a great place in the future for beach lovers!

### Volcanic Hotspots {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2FuaWMgSG90c3BvdHM._21-08n}

Some volcanoes form over active **hotspots** . Scientists count about 50
hotspots on the Earth. Hotspots lie directly above a column of hot rock
called a **mantle plume** . Mantle plumes continuously bring hot rock up
from the mantle toward the crust ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMDMtbWFudGxlLXBsdW1lcw..) ). The rock
melts due to the release of pressure.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NmU3YjlmOTBjZmQzM2U0MTRhZjc2YThlZmVmNjExMmM.-xdw"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Foulger/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CourtHotspots.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of mantle plumes around the
world](ck12_6_files/20150911025733520490.png "Map of mantle plumes around the world")

**Figure 6.58**

Mantle plumes are found all over the world, especially in the ocean
basins. The size of the eruptions is different at different plumes.

</div>

Hotspots may be in the middle of a tectonic plate. They create
intraplate volcanoes.

#### Hotspots in the Oceans {#6.html#x-ck12-SG90c3BvdHMgaW4gdGhlIE9jZWFucw.._21-xq2}

Hotspots are much more common beneath ocean crust. This is because ocean
crust is thinner. The plume can more easily penetrate this crust. As the
tectonic plates move above a hotspot, they form a chain of volcanoes.
The islands of Hawaii formed over a hotspot in the middle of the Pacific
plate. The volcanoes are massive shield volcanoes that together create
the islands. The lavas are mafic and have low viscosity. These lavas
produce beautiful ropy flows of pāhoehoe and clinkery flows of a'a.
These lava types will be described in more detail in the concept
"Effusive Eruptions."

The Hawaii hotspot has been active for tens of millions of years. The
volcanoes of the Hawaiian Islands formed at this hotspot. Older
volcanoes that formed at the hotspot have eroded below sea level. These
are called the Emperor Seamounts.

Loihi seamount is currently active beneath the water southeast of the
Big Island of Hawaii. One day, the volcano will rise above sea level.
Loihi will join the volcanoes of the island or create a new island (
**Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMDQtTG9paGk.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YWJjNmVjMmY5ZTBjYWQ2NGFmNjliYzBiZmM5ZjVmNTM.-r3m"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of John Smith and Brooks Bays, NOAA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Loihi_3d.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of the Loihi
seamount](ck12_6_files/20150911025733653902.png "Map of the Loihi seamount")

**Figure 6.59**

A bathymetric map of Loihi seamount. Loihi will be the next shield
volcano in the Hawaiian-Emperor chain.

</div>

A hotspot beneath Hawaii, the origin of the voluminous lava produced by
the shield volcano Kilauea can be viewed here:
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=byJp5o49IF4](watch?v=byJp5o49IF4)
(2:06).

[![](ck12_6_files/tmpAqthhY.jpeg)](byJp5o49IF4)

Click on the image above for more content

Hotspots may also be active at plate boundaries. This is especially
common at mid-ocean ridges. Iceland is formed by a hotspot along the
Mid-Atlantic Ridge.

#### Hotspots within Continents {#6.html#x-ck12-SG90c3BvdHMgd2l0aGluIENvbnRpbmVudHM._21-lsw}

Hotspots are found within continents, but not as commonly as within
oceans. They are not common because it takes a massive mantle plume to
penetrate the thick continental crust. Eruptions from these hotspots are
rare but massive. The Yellowstone hotspot is a famous example of a
continental hotspot.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._21-bqh}

-   Volcanoes grow above hotspots. A hotspot is a zone of melting above
    a mantle plume.
-   Hotspot volcanoes are better able to penetrate oceanic crust than
    continental crust. We see many more hotspot volcanoes in the oceans.
-   Shield volcanoes commonly form above hotspots in the oceans.

# Magma Composition at Volcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-TWFnbWEgQ29tcG9zaXRpb24gYXQgVm9sY2Fub2Vz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe types of magma composition.
-   Explain the effect of magma composition on types of eruptions.
-   Compare magma to lava.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601283] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025733775901.jpeg)
</span>

**Are all volcanic eruptions alike?**

The type of eruption a volcano has depends on the type of magma in its
chamber. Some eruptions are explosive. Some eruptions are quiet. All
eruptions are amazing!

### Magma {#6.html#x-ck12-TWFnbWE._22-y9w}

Magma forms deep beneath the Earth’s surface. Rock melts below the
surface under tremendous pressure and high temperatures. Molten rock
flows like taffy or hot wax. Most magmas are formed at temperatures
between 600 ^o^ C and 1300 ^o^ C ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NYWdtYUNoYW1iZXI.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NGJmZWIzN2YzYzEwM2Y1YTAwMjA2ZmUwOWYwMTE1Njk.-s7q"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of National Park Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Yellowstome_magma_chamber.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of a magma chamber under
Yellowstone](ck12_6_files/20150911025733892531.jpeg "Diagram of a magma chamber under Yellowstone")

**Figure 6.60**

Magma beneath a volcano erupts onto the volcano’s surface. This image is
of a magma chamber underlying Yellowstone.

</div>

Magma collects in **magma chambers** beneath Earth’s surface. Magma
chambers are located where the heat and pressure are great enough to
melt rock. These locations are at divergent or convergent plate
boundaries or at hotpots.

The chemistry of a magma determines the type of igneous rock it forms.
The chemistry also determines how the magma moves. The higher the amount
of silica in the magma, the higher the viscosity. **Viscosity** is a
liquid's resistance to flow. Viscous magmas tend to stay below the
surface or erupt explosively. These are felsic magmas, which are high in
silica. When magma is fluid and runny, it is not viscous. This magma
often reaches the surface by flowing out in rivers of lava. These are
low-silica mafic magmas.

### Lava {#6.html#x-ck12-TGF2YQ.._22-fa2}

The way lava flows depends on what it is made of. Thick lava doesn’t
flow easily. It may block the vent of a volcano. If the lava traps a lot
of gas, the pressure builds up. After the pressure becomes greater and
greater, the volcano finally explodes. Ash and pyroclasts shoot up into
the air. Pumice, with small holes in solid rock, shows where gas bubbles
were when the rock was still molten.

Fluid lava flows down mountainsides. The rock that the flow becomes
depends on which type of lava it is and where it cools. The three types
of flows are a’a, pahoehoe, and pillow lava.

-   A’a lava is the thickest of the non-explosive lavas. A'a forms a
    thick and brittle crust, which is torn into rough, rubbly pieces.
    The solidified surface is angular, jagged, and sharp ( **Figure**
    [below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BQUZsb3c.) ). A'a can spread over
    large areas as the lava continues to flow underneath.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MjI5ZWE1YzRhMDhhN2MxZTYzMzQyYThlOWM5MDI0NTM.-ajr"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright rthoma, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Solidified A'a flow in
Hawaii](ck12_6_files/20150911025734005374.jpeg "Solidified A'a flow in Hawaii")

**Figure 6.61**

A'a flows can also be found in Hawaii and are much sharper and more
jagged than pahoehoe.

</div>

-   Pāhoehoe lava is thinner than a'a, and flows more readily. Its
    surface looks more wrinkly and smooth. Pāhoehoe lava flows in a
    series of lobes that form strange, twisted shapes and natural rock
    sculptures ( **Figure**
    [below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMTAtcGFob2Vob2UtZmxvdw..) ).
    Pāhoehoe lava can form lava tubes. The outer layer of the lava flow
    cools and solidifies. The inner part of the flow remains fluid. The
    fluid lava flows through and leaves behind a tube.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-N2VmMDY5ZWE1ZjVhZjU4Mjc2NGRhMWE4NGZjMDlhM2U.-4i2"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Makuahine Pa'i Ki'i" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/hawaii-mcgraths/4280082817/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Ropy pahoehoe flows are common on Kilauea Volcano in
Hawaii](ck12_6_files/20150911025734121500.jpeg "Ropy pahoehoe flows are common on Kilauea Volcano in Hawaii")

**Figure 6.62**

Ropy pahoehoe flows are common on Kilauea Volcano in Hawaii.

</div>

-   Pillow lava is created from lava that enters the water. The volcanic
    vent may be underwater. The lava may flow over land and enter the
    water ( **Figure**
    [below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1PY2VhbkJhc2FsdA..) ). Once in the
    water, the lava cools very quickly. The lava forms round rocks that
    resemble pillows. Pillow lava is particularly common along
    mid-ocean ridges.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YjcyZDFhNzBmNzk0ODE0N2ZlODdjODUxMGZmM2ZhYzA.-uvh"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Claudio Rossol, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Lava erupting in the water can form bulbous, pillowy
forms](ck12_6_files/20150911025734256814.jpeg "Lava erupting in the water can form bulbous, pillowy forms")

**Figure 6.63**

Lava erupting in the water can form bulbous, pillowy forms.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._22-gc9}

-   Magmas differ in composition, which affects viscosity. Magma
    composition has a large effect on how a volcano erupts.
-   Felsic lavas are more viscous and erupt explosively or do not erupt.
    Mafic lavas are less viscous and erupt effusively.
-   Different lava types create different rock types, such as pahoehoe
    and a'a. Lavas that cool underwater become pillow lavas.

# Explosive Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-RXhwbG9zaXZlIEVydXB0aW9ucw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the causes and effects of explosive volcanic eruptions.
-   Define lahar, pyroclast, and pyroclastic flow.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601289] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025734400225.jpeg)
</span>

**What would cause a giant explosion like this one?**

The type of eruption a volcano has depends on the composition of the
magma. Silica-rich, felsic magma can trap a lot of gas. So these magmas
produce explosive eruptions. Silica-poor mafic magmas trap little gas.
These magmas produce quiet eruptions. Which type of eruption do you
think is safest to be near?

### Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-RXJ1cHRpb25z_23-1iz}

All volcanoes share the same basic features. First, mantle rock melts.
The molten rock collects in magma chambers that can be 160 kilometers
(100 miles) beneath the surface. As the rock heats, it expands. The hot
rock is less dense than the surrounding rock. The magma rises toward the
surface through cracks in the crust. A volcanic **eruption** occurs when
the magma reaches the surface. Lava can reach the surface gently or
explosively.

#### Explosive Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-RXhwbG9zaXZlIEVydXB0aW9ucw.._23-vkw}

An **explosive eruption** produces huge clouds of volcanic ash. Chunks
of the volcano fly high into the atmosphere. Explosive eruptions can be
tens of thousands of times as powerful as an atomic bomb ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1JY2VsYW5kVm9sY2FubzI.) ). Hot magma
beneath the surface mixes with water. This forms gases. The gas pressure
grows until it must be released. The volcano erupts in an enormous
explosion.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NzQ3OWQwMjQ3NmM3MThlMmY0ZDAzYjNkZjIzMjYyODU.-inp"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Johann Helgason, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Eruption of Eyjafjallajökull volcano in Iceland in
2010](ck12_6_files/20150911025734548200.jpeg "Eruption of Eyjafjallajökull volcano in Iceland in 2010")

**Figure 6.64**

Eyjafjallajökull volcano in Iceland spewed ash into the atmosphere in
2010. This was a fairly small eruption, but it disrupted air travel
across Europe for six days.

</div>

Ash and particles shoot many kilometers into the sky. The material may
form a mushroom cloud, just like a nuclear explosion. Hot fragments of
rock, called **pyroclasts** , fly up into the air at very high speeds.
The pyroclasts cool in the atmosphere. Some ash may stay in the
atmosphere for years. The ash may block out sunlight. This changes
weather patterns and affects the temperature of the Earth. For a year or
two after a large eruption, sunsets may be especially beautiful
worldwide.

Volcanic gases can form poisonous, invisible clouds. The poisonous gases
may be toxic close to the eruption. The gases may cause environmental
problems like acid rain and ozone destruction.

#### Mt. St. Helens {#6.html#x-ck12-TXQuIFN0LiBIZWxlbnM._23-ucq}

In 1980, Mount St. Helens, located between Portland, Oregon and Seattle,
Washington, erupted explosively. The eruption killed 57 people,
destroyed 250 homes, and swept away 47 bridges. The volcano blew off its
top so that it lost over 400 meters (1,300 feet) of height. Mt. St.
Helens is still active ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMDUtTXQtc3QtaGVsZW5z) ). Within the
crater, a new lava dome formed.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YzJhMGFkOGMyOWRkNjk4MTViZGEyNjI2M2IwYmVjZTQ.-kfd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of (A) Robert Krimmel, US Geological Survey; (B) Lyn Topinka, US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://vulcan.wr.usgs.gov/Volcanoes/MSH/Images/MSH80/framework.html; (B) http://vulcan.wr.usgs.gov/Volcanoes/MSH/Images/blowdown.html" -->
<!-- @@license="" -->
![Mt. St. Helens eruption and
aftermath](ck12_6_files/20150911025734657289.png "Mt. St. Helens eruption and aftermath")

**Figure 6.65**

\(A) Mount St. Helens eruption on May 18, 1980. Mt. Adams is in the
background on the right. (B) The eruption of Mt. St. Helens blew down
acres of trees like they were toothpicks.

</div>

Much of the damage in the eruption was due to pyroclastic flows.
**Pyroclastic flows** of pyroclasts and ash knock down everything in
their path. The temperature inside a pyroclastic flow may be as high as
1,000°C (1,800°F). A pyroclastic flow at Montserrat volcano is seen in
this video:
[http://faculty.gg.uwyo.edu/heller/SedMovs/Sed%20Movie%20files/PyroclasticFlow.MOV](PyroclasticFlow.MOV)
.

**Lahars** are mixtures of ash and water that travel down river valleys.
On Mount St. Helens, the eruption melted glaciers. The water mixed with
ash from the eruption and created tremendous lahars. The lahars raced
down valleys and knocked out many bridges.

Mt St. Helens was not a very large eruption for the Cascades. Mt. Mazama
blew itself apart in an eruption about 42 times more powerful than Mount
St. Helens in 1980. Today all that remains of that huge stratovolcano is
Crater Lake ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDgtMTItQ3JhdGVyLWxha2U.) and **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DcmF0ZXJMYWtl) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MDYzMjJmNDJhMWUxNjI0MzdiYmU5ZTNmNTg0NzlmMTQ.-zga"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Mazama_bathymetry_survey_map.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Crater Lake fills the caldera of the collapsed Mt.
Mazama](ck12_6_files/20150911025734797354.jpeg "Crater Lake fills the caldera of the collapsed Mt. Mazama")

**Figure 6.66**

Crater Lake fills the caldera of the collapsed Mt. Mazama. The
bathymetry of the lake shows volcanic features such as cinder cones.

</div>

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YWFhMmI1ZjUzYzBhZDU5MmUzN2VkZDcwOGJiNDQ1MDM.-2fh"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Chris M Morris (Flickr:cm195902)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/79666107@N00/3961106372/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of Crater
Lake](ck12_6_files/20150911025734928159.jpeg "Picture of Crater Lake")

**Figure 6.67**

Crater Lake, located in Crater Lake National Park in southern Oregon.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._23-5md}

-   Felsic magmas erupt explosively, creating pyroclastic eruptions.
-   Pyroclastic eruption types include tephra, ash, and lahars.
-   Mt. Mazama blew its top off and then collapsed, creating Crater Lake
    in Oregon.

# Effusive Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-RWZmdXNpdmUgRXJ1cHRpb25z}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the causes and effects of effusive volcanic eruptions.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601295] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025735033401.jpeg)
</span>

**Isn't this an explosive eruption?**

This is a strombolian eruption. This type of eruption was named for Mt.
Stromboli in Italy. Strombolian eruptions spew lava into the air. But
these eruptions do not have a massive explosion. They create lava flows.

### Effusive Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-RWZmdXNpdmUgRXJ1cHRpb25z_24-cdp}

Mafic magma creates gentler **effusive eruptions** . There is little or
no gas. The lava is thin and fluid so that it flows over the ground like
a river. Mafic magma pushes toward the surface through fissures.
Eventually, the magma reaches the surface and erupts through a vent (
**Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1MYXZhUml2ZXI.) ). Effusive
eruptions are common in Hawaii, where lavas are mafic.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MmY3NmM1MDViYmJiOTU2OWVmODFjZTU3Nzc2OGExMmU.-kyd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Linda M. Foster, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![In effusive eruptions, lava flows readily, producing rivers of molten
rock](ck12_6_files/20150911025735135748.jpeg "In effusive eruptions, lava flows readily, producing rivers of molten rock")

**Figure 6.68**

In effusive eruptions, lava flows readily, producing rivers of molten
rock.

</div>

-   The Kilauea volcanic eruption in 2008 is seen in this short video:
    [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BtH79yxBIJI](watch?v=BtH79yxBIJI) .

<!-- -->

-   A Quicktime movie with thermal camera of a lava stream within the
    vent of a Hawaiian volcano is seen here:
    [http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/kilauea/update/archive/2009/Nov/OverflightFLIR\_13Jan2010.mov](OverflightFLIR_13Jan2010.mov) .

### Effusive Eruptions Damage {#6.html#x-ck12-RWZmdXNpdmUgRXJ1cHRpb25z_24IERhbWFnZQ..-p6y}

Effusive eruptions rarely kill anyone because they move slowly. People
can usually be evacuated before an effusive eruption. Still, effusive
eruptions can be destructive. There is not much anyone can do to stop a
lava flow from destroying a building or road ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDgtMTktRXJ1cHRpb24tS2lsYXVlYQ..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YTE3ZmY4NDc2MzliZjlkNDRjNThhNmM1MGY0N2Q5NzA.-5xv"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://gallery.usgs.gov/photos/06_18_2010_im15GtrFFA_06_18_2010_35" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Road covered by lava from an eruption at Kilauea in
Hawaii](ck12_6_files/20150911025735231566.jpeg "Road covered by lava from an eruption at Kilauea in Hawaii")

**Figure 6.69**

A road is overrun by an eruption at Kilauea volcano in Hawaii.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._24-gcf}

-   Mafic magma creates effusive eruptions. The pressure builds but the
    lava flows fairly quietly.
-   Effusive eruptions cause damage but rarely kill anyone.
-   Mafic magma cools into different types of flows like a'a, pāhoehoe,
    and pillow lava.

# Predicting Volcanic Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-UHJlZGljdGluZyBWb2xjYW5pYyBFcnVwdGlvbnM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how scientists attempt to predict volcanic eruptions.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601301] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025735360282.jpeg)
</span>

**What is one of the deadliest science jobs?**

No one can predict exactly when a volcanic eruption will take place.
There are clues, but no one knows exactly when. Sometimes a volcano will
erupt when scientists are studying it. Volcanologists have a high
fatality rate among scientists because forecasting eruptions is so
difficult.

### Predicting Volcanic Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-UHJlZGljdGluZyBWb2xjYW5pYyBFcnVwdGlvbnM._25-acx}

Volcanic eruptions can be devastating, particularly to the people who
live close to volcanoes. Volcanologists study volcanoes to be able to
predict when a volcano will erupt. Many changes happen when a volcano is
about to erupt. Even so, eruptions are very difficult to predict.

#### History of Volcanic Activities {#6.html#x-ck12-SGlzdG9yeSBvZiBWb2xjYW5pYyBBY3Rpdml0aWVz_25-fia}

Scientists study a volcano’s history to try to predict when it will next
erupt. They want to know how long it has been since it last erupted.
They also want to know the time span between its previous eruptions.
Scientists watch both active and dormant volcanoes closely for signs
that show they might erupt.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZDc5ZTkwNzE1YzhlMTY1Y2JiNGZlZDQ1MzMwOWZjZGE.-dai"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Ralph Arvesen (Flickr:rarvesen)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rarvesen/9429614139/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of Mount Rainier in
Washington](ck12_6_files/20150911025735501429.jpeg "Picture of Mount Rainier in Washington")

**Figure 6.70**

Mount Rainier in Washington State is currently dormant. The volcano
could, and probably will erupt again.

</div>

#### Earthquakes {#6.html#x-ck12-RWFydGhxdWFrZXM._25-jkv}

Earthquakes may take place every day near a volcano. But before an
eruption, the number and size of earthquakes increases. This is the
result of magma pushing upward into the magma chamber. This motion
causes stresses on neighboring rock to build up. Eventually the ground
shakes. A continuous string of earthquakes may indicate that a volcano
is about to erupt. Scientists use seismographs to record the length and
strength of each earthquake.

#### Slope Tilt {#6.html#x-ck12-U2xvcGUgVGlsdA.._25-jgv}

All that magma and gas pushing upward can make the volcano’s slope begin
to swell. Ground swelling may change the shape of a volcano or cause
rock falls and landslides. Most of the time, the ground tilting is not
visible. Scientists detect it by using tiltmeters, which are instruments
that measure the angle of the slope of a volcano.

#### Gases {#6.html#x-ck12-R2FzZXM._25-qjv}

Scientists measure the gases that escape from a volcano to predict
eruptions. Gases like sulfur dioxide (SO ~2~ ), carbon dioxide (CO ~2~
), hydrochloric acid (HCl), and water vapor can be measured at the site.
Gases may also be measured from satellites. The amounts of gases and the
ratios of gases are calculated to help predict eruptions.

#### Remote Monitoring {#6.html#x-ck12-UmVtb3RlIE1vbml0b3Jpbmc._25-vjf}

Satellites can be used to monitor more than just gases ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMTQtcmVtb3RlLW1vbml0b3Jpbmc.) ).
Satellites can look for high temperature spots or areas where the
volcano surface is changing. This allows scientists to detect changes
accurately and safely.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MmE5MGIwYjgwYjlhZTFiY2FjMmY1Njk4MzE5YWNmMjY.-fgv"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Jesse Allen &#38; Robert Simmon, NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Mount_Cleveland_2010-06-01.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Picture of Mount Cleveland in
Alaska](ck12_6_files/20150911025735595143.jpeg "Picture of Mount Cleveland in Alaska")

**Figure 6.71**

Mount Cleveland, in Alaska, is monitored by satellite.

</div>

### Costs and Benefits of Predictions {#6.html#x-ck12-Q29zdHMgYW5kIEJlbmVmaXRzIG9mIFByZWRpY3Rpb25z_25-jdb}

No scientist or government agency wants to announce an eruption and then
be wrong. There is a very real cost and disruption to society during a
large-scale evacuation. If the scientists are wrong, people would be
less likely to evacuate the next time scientists predicted an eruption.
But if scientists predict an eruption that does take place, it could
save many lives.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._25-jkd}

-   Volcanologists use several lines of evidence to try to forecast
    volcanic eruptions.
-   Magma moving beneath a volcano will cause earthquakes and
    slope deformation. Gases may be released from the magma out of the
    volcano vent.
-   Deciding whether to call for an evacuation is very tricky.

# Types of Volcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgVm9sY2Fub2Vz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of different types of volcanoes.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601307] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025735713462.jpeg)
</span>

**What does an active volcano look like?**

Climbing up Mount St. Helens and looking into the crater at the steaming
dome is an incredible experience. The slope is steep and the landscape
is like something from another planet. Nothing's alive up there, except
maybe a bird. When you're standing on the top, you can see other
Cascades volcanoes: Mt. Adams, Rainier, Hood, Jefferson, and sometimes
more.

### Volcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2Fub2Vz_26-7jg}

A volcano is a vent through which molten rock and gas escape from a
magma chamber. Volcanoes differ in many features, such as height, shape,
and slope steepness. Some volcanoes are tall cones, and others are just
cracks in the ground ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NdEZ1amk.) ). As you might expect, the
shape of a volcano is related to the composition of its magma. The three
types of volcanoes are composite, shield, and cinder cones.

#### Composite Volcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-Q29tcG9zaXRlIFZvbGNhbm9lcw.._26-4df}

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NWZjYzRjOWVjODhkNjQ0ZjBjZjg3YTVmZjg5YzdmNzI.-g85"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Alpsdake/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Mount_Fuji_from_Lake_Yamanaka_1995-7-30.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Mt. Fuji is a composite
volcano](ck12_6_files/20150911025735942299.jpeg "Mt. Fuji is a composite volcano")

**Figure 6.72**

Mt. Fuji is a well-known composite volcano.

</div>

**Figure** [above](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NdEZ1amk.) shows Mt. Fuji,
a classic example of a composite volcano. **Composite volcanoes** have
broad bases and steep sides. These volcanoes usually have a large crater
at the top. The crater was created during the volcano's last eruption.

Composite volcanoes are also called stratovolcanoes. This is because
they are formed by alternating layers (strata) of magma and ash (
**Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TdHJhdG92b2xjYW5v) ). The
magma that creates composite volcanoes tends to be thick. The steep
sides form because the lava cannot flow too far from the vent. The thick
magma may also create explosive eruptions. Ash and pyroclasts erupt into
the air. Much of this material falls back down near the vent. This
creates the steep sides of stratovolcanoes. The composition of magma
that erupts at composite volcanoes is usually felsic (rhyolite) or
intermediate (andesite).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-Y2RjMGQxODA3NWIzMDExYWJhMDVkMDE0NjIyZjI5MmI.-y5c"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Stratovolcano.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Cross section of a composite volcano, revealing alternating layers of
rock and
ash](ck12_6_files/20150911025736056082.jpeg "Cross section of a composite volcano, revealing alternating layers of rock and ash")

**Figure 6.73**

A cross section of a composite volcano reveals alternating layers of
rock and ash. Frequently there is a large crater at the top from the
last eruption.

</div>

Composite volcanoes are common along convergent plate boundaries. When a
tectonic plate subducts, it melts. This creates the thick magma needed
for these eruptions. The Pacific Ring of Fire is dotted by composite
volcanoes.

#### Shield Volcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-U2hpZWxkIFZvbGNhbm9lcw.._26-93r}

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZmZlZjk0YjEwMDhiOWZmNDM5ZDQ0MzQ0YzFhZDIwYTk.-tao"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of LCDR Eric Johnson, NOAA Corps" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Line5377_-_Flickr_-_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![The Mauna Kea volcano in Hawaii is a shield
volcano](ck12_6_files/20150911025736193213.jpeg "The Mauna Kea volcano in Hawaii is a shield volcano")

**Figure 6.74**

Mauna Kea volcano in Hawaii.

</div>

**Shield volcanoes** look like a huge ancient warrior’s shield laid
down. Pictured above is Mauna Kea Volcano ( **Figure**
[above](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1LaWxhdWVhU2hpZWxk) ) taken from Mauna
Loa Volcano. Both volcanoes are part of the Big Island of Hawaii. A
shield volcano has a very wide base. It is much flatter on the top than
a composite volcano. The lava that creates shield volcanoes is
relatively thin. The thin lava spreads out. This builds a large, flat
volcano, layer by layer. The composition of lava at shield volcanoes is
mafic. Shield volcanoes are very large. For example, the Mauna Loa
Volcano has a diameter of more than 112 kilometers (70 miles). The
volcano forms a significant part of the island of Hawaii. The top of
nearby Mauna Kea Volcano is more than ten kilometers (6 miles) from its
base on the seafloor.

Shield volcanoes often form along divergent plate boundaries. They also
form at hotspots, like Hawaii. Shield volcano eruptions are
non-explosive.

This *Volcanoes 101* video from National Geographic discusses where
volcanoes are found and what their properties come from:
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uZp1dNybgfc](watch?v=uZp1dNybgfc) (3:04)

[![](ck12_6_files/tmpVQj3TP.jpeg)](uZp1dNybgfc)

Click on the image above for more content

#### Cinder Cones {#6.html#x-ck12-Q2luZGVyIENvbmVz_26-1xx}

**Cinder cones** are the smallest and most common type of volcano.
Cinder cones have steep sides like composite volcanoes. But they are
much smaller, rarely reaching even 300 meters in height. Cinder cones
usually have a crater at the summit. Cinder cones are composed of small
fragments of rock, called cinders. The cinders are piled on top of one
another. The cinders can be mafic, intermediate, or felsic in
composition. These volcanoes usually do not produce streams of lava.
Cinder cones often form near larger volcanoes. Most composite and shield
volcanoes have nearby cinder cones.

Cinder cones usually build up very rapidly. They only erupt for a short
time. Many only produce one eruption. For this reason, cinder cones do
not reach the sizes of stratovolcanoes or shield volcanoes ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMTktY2luZGVyLWNvbmU.) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NjQ0MjQyZjJmZGE3YTc3NTk1ZDZkOWVmOGE1MTViZDE.-byb"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:orvalrochefort" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/orvalrochefort/3628684989/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A cinder cone volcano in Lassen National
Park](ck12_6_files/20150911025736307106.jpeg "A cinder cone volcano in Lassen National Park")

**Figure 6.75**

A cinder cone volcano in Lassen National Park.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._26-wsx}

-   Magma composition determines both eruption type and volcano type.
-   Composite volcanoes are common at convergent boundaries. Shield
    volcanoes are produced at divergent plate boundaries and intraplate.
-   Cinder cones are made of small fragments of a variety of
    compositions usually from a single eruption. They are found with
    composite and shield volcanoes.

# Supervolcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VwZXJ2b2xjYW5vZXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of supervolcanoes and their eruptions.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601312] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025736436493.jpeg)
</span>

**Is this a supervolcano?**

Lake Toba in Indonesia is 100 km (62 mi) by 30 km (19 mi). The water
fills a giant caldera created by a supervolcano. The eruption took place
about 75,000 years ago, Earth's largest eruption in the past 25 million
years. So much material was ejected into space that there was a 6- to
10-year volcanic winter. Some scientists think that only 10,000 humans
survived worldwide. The numbers of other mammals also plummeted.

### Calderas {#6.html#x-ck12-Q2FsZGVyYXM._27-dt2}

During a massive eruption, all of the material may be ejected from a
magma changer. Without support, the mountain above the empty chamber may
collapse. This produces a huge **caldera** . Calderas are generally
round, bowl-shaped formations ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMjAtY2FsZGVyYQ..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZTEwNzVkZTJmZmNjMWFmM2I4MzNlZjlmYzliYTJhYmE.-cig"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flavia (Flickr:Flavia_ff)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mistressf/788501243/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Map of Crater Lake, created by a
caldera](ck12_6_files/20150911025736573875.jpeg "Map of Crater Lake, created by a caldera")

**Figure 6.76**

Crater Lake, Oregon is the remnant of Mount Mazama. After an enormous
eruption the mountain collapsed, forming a caldera. Crater Lake should
actually be named Caldera Lake. Wizard Island, within the lake, is a
cinder cone.

</div>

### Supervolcanoes {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VwZXJ2b2xjYW5vZXM._27-yh0}

**Supervolcano** eruptions are extremely rare in Earth's history. It’s a
good thing because they are unimaginably large. A supervolcano must
erupt more than 1,000 cubic km (240 cubic miles) of material. Imagine
how large that is compared with 1.2 km ^3^ for Mount St. Helens. Mount
Pinatubo, a large eruption in the Philippines in 1991, erupted only 25
km ^3^ of material. Not surprisingly, supervolcanoes are the most
dangerous type of volcano.

#### Supervolcano Eruptions {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VwZXJ2b2xjYW5vIEVydXB0aW9ucw.._27-wvs}

The exact cause of supervolcano eruptions is still debated. However,
scientists think that a very large magma chamber erupts entirely in one
catastrophic explosion. This creates a caldera into which the surface
collapses ( **Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTA4MDMtMDY.) ).
The composition of the eruption is felsic or highly felsic.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NmQxNjM3YWUxYTIwMTVkOWU3ZmEzN2RmMDVkZDVjNmY.-a2l"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Santorini_Landsat.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The caldera at Santorini in Greece is so large that it can only be
seen by
satellite](ck12_6_files/20150911025736725217.jpeg "The caldera at Santorini in Greece is so large that it can only be seen by satellite")

**Figure 6.77**

The caldera at Santorini in Greece is so large that it can only be seen
by satellite.

</div>

#### Yellowstone Caldera {#6.html#x-ck12-WWVsbG93c3RvbmUgQ2FsZGVyYQ.._27-ywn}

The largest supervolcano in North America is beneath Yellowstone
National Park in Wyoming. Much of the national park lies within the
enormous Yellowstone Caldera. It is so large that you can stand on one
rim and not see the other side.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NDc3MjFiYTJmYzgzYWUzMzAzYzdjM2RhYTdlM2IzNjE.-tfz"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the National Park Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.nps.gov/yell/naturescience/caldera-rim.htm" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of the Yellowstone Caldera, the remains of a
supervolcano](ck12_6_files/20150911025736837093.png "Map of the Yellowstone Caldera, the remains of a supervolcano")

**Figure 6.78**

What would cause such a giant caldera?

</div>

Yellowstone sits above a hotspot that has erupted catastrophically three
times: 2.1 million, 1.3 million, and 640,000 years ago. Yellowstone has
produced many smaller (but still enormous) eruptions more recently (
**Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDgtMzEtWWVsbG93c3RvbmUtQ2FsZGVyYQ..) ).
Fortunately, current activity at Yellowstone is limited to the region’s
famous geysers. No one knows when the supervolcano will erupt again.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-M2Y0NjU1ZmZiYTBiODMxZjc5MjM0ZTIzMDYwNWZjMzY.-crc"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Kbh3rd/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Yellowstone_Caldera.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of the Yellowstone hotspot and
caldera](ck12_6_files/20150911025736946338.png "Diagram of the Yellowstone hotspot and caldera")

**Figure 6.79**

The Yellowstone hotspot has produced enormous felsic eruptions. The
Yellowstone caldera collapsed in the most recent super eruption.

</div>

### Supervolcano Eruptions and Life on Earth {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VwZXJ2b2xjYW5vIEVydXB0aW9ucyBhbmQgTGlmZSBvbiBFYXJ0aA.._27-yhe}

A supervolcano could change life on Earth as we know it. Ash could block
sunlight so much that photosynthesis would be reduced and global
temperatures would plummet. Volcanic eruptions could have contributed to
some of the mass extinctions in our planet’s history. No one knows when
the next super eruption will be.

Interesting volcano videos are seen on National Geographic Videos,
Environment Video, Natural Disasters, Earthquakes:
[http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/player/environment/]() . The
video, “Mammoth Mountain,” is particularly interesting; it explores Hot
Creek and the volcanic area it is a part of in California.

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._27-vgf}

-   A caldera forms after a massive eruption. The top of the volcano
    collapses, forming a basin.
-   Supervolcano eruptions are rare but massive and deadly.
-   Yellowstone Caldera is a supervolcano that has erupted
    catastropically three times.
-   Supervolcano eruptions can change the course of life on Earth.

# Volcanic Landforms {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2FuaWMgTGFuZGZvcm1z}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the landforms created by volcanic activity.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601319] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025737071279.jpeg)
</span>

**Why does this massive rock stick out like this?**

Shiprock in New Mexico is visible for many miles around. Shiprock is the
neck of an old volcano. The magma cooled into a rock that was harder
than the surrounding volcano. So the volcano eroded away and left the
neck. The peak is on the land of the Navajo Nation, for whom it has
great religious significance.

### Landforms from Lava {#6.html#x-ck12-TGFuZGZvcm1zIGZyb20gTGF2YQ.._28-imw}

Extrusive igneous rocks cool at the surface. Volcanoes are one type of
feature that forms from extrusive rocks. Several other interesting
landforms are also extrusive features. Intrusive igneous rocks cool
below the surface. These rocks do not always remain hidden. Rocks that
formed in the crust are exposed when the rock and sediment that covers
them is eroded away.

#### Volcanoes and Vents {#6.html#x-ck12-Vm9sY2Fub2VzIGFuZCBWZW50cw.._28-gx1}

The most obvious landforms created by lava are volcanoes. These are
mostly cinder cones, composite volcanoes, and shield volcanoes.
Eruptions also take place through other types of vents, commonly from
fissures ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDgtMzMtZmlzc3VyZS1lcnVwdGlvbg..) ). The
eruptions that created the entire ocean floor are essentially fissure
eruptions.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MGNmYjY5ZTFkNzBhZDI4MGZhYzMyOTQyZjVmNTI4ZDQ.-xsy"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of D. W. Peterson, US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://volcanoes.usgs.gov/images/pglossary/FissureEruption_examps.php" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A fissure eruption on Mauna Loa in Hawaii travels toward Mauna Kea on
the Big
Island](ck12_6_files/20150911025737179714.jpeg "A fissure eruption on Mauna Loa in Hawaii travels toward Mauna Kea on the Big Island")

**Figure 6.80**

A fissure eruption on Mauna Loa in Hawaii travels toward Mauna Kea on
the Big Island.

</div>

#### Lava Domes {#6.html#x-ck12-TGF2YSBEb21lcw.._28-weo}

When lava is thick, it flows slowly. If thick lava makes it to the
surface, it cannot flow far from the vent. It often stays right in the
middle of a crater at the top of a volcano. Here the lava creates a
large, round **lava dome** ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Nb25vQ3JhdGVy) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YTc0NzEyZWRmZTM0OGE0ZmVhN2UyYmE5M2E5MjBkMDE.-if8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Rick Whitacre, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![The Mono Craters in California are lava
domes](ck12_6_files/20150911025737274694.jpeg "The Mono Craters in California are lava domes")

**Figure 6.81**

The Mono Craters in California are lava domes.

</div>

Lava flows often make mounds right in the middle of craters at the top
of volcanoes ( **Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTA4MDQtMDI.)
).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-NWE2MTNlNjUxNGNkYzM0NzdkY2MzOWMyMjRmYjk2N2M.-yie"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Willie Scott, US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:MSH06_aerial_crater_from_north_high_angle_09-12-06.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Lava domes forming in the crater of Mount St.
Helens](ck12_6_files/20150911025737363633.jpeg "Lava domes forming in the crater of Mount St. Helens")

**Figure 6.82**

Lava domes may form in the crater of composite volcanoes, as at Mount
St. Helens.

</div>

#### Lava Plateaus {#6.html#x-ck12-TGF2YSBQbGF0ZWF1cw.._28-nsz}

A **lava plateau** is made of a large amount of fluid lava. The lava
flows over a large area and cools. This creates a large, flat surface of
igneous rock. Lava plateaus may be huge. The Columbia Plateau covers
over 161,000 square kilometers (63,000 square miles). It makes up parts
of the states of Washington, Oregon, and Idaho ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMDgtMzYtQ29sdW1iaWEtUGxhdGV1YQ..) ).

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MjkyNWVkNjY2YmU4MjcxY2U5NzlmNzg2ZmMxYmNiODE.-ops"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Kelvin Kay (Wikipedia: Kkmd)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Vistahouse.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Layers of basalt created the Columbia Plateau, which is a lava
plateau](ck12_6_files/20150911025737444735.jpeg "Layers of basalt created the Columbia Plateau, which is a lava plateau")

**Figure 6.83**

Layer upon layer of basalt have created the Columbia Plateau, which
covers more than 161,000 square kilometers (63,000 square miles) in
Washington, Oregon, and Idaho.

</div>

#### Land {#6.html#x-ck12-TGFuZA.._28-x2f}

New land is created in volcanic eruptions. The Hawaiian Islands are
shield volcanoes. These volcanoes formed from fluid lava ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMjItSGF3YWlpYW4tSXNsYW5kcw..) ). The
island grows as lava is added on the coast. New land may also emerge
from lava that erupts from beneath the water. This is one way that new
land is created.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MjUwMTA4Yjk1MzJiMDgzYWM1YzRhNzAzN2EyM2JjODM.-pfa"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

### Landforms from Magma {#6.html#x-ck12-TGFuZGZvcm1zIGZyb20gTWFnbWE._28-8xw}

Magma that cools underground forms **intrusions** ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMDgtMjMtaW50cnVzaW9ucw..) ). Usually this
magma is very viscous felsic magma. This magma does not rise easily and
so cools slowly underground. Intrusions become land formations if they
are exposed at the surface by uplift and erosion.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-ZGIxMWZmYWJhYjcxNDY1YTQ0NGZjMTA0NjljZDdlMDg.-tq6"

<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![The Sierra Nevada Mountains are granite
intrusions](ck12_6_files/20150911025737668080.jpeg "The Sierra Nevada Mountains are granite intrusions")

**Figure 6.85**

The granite intrusions that form the Sierra Nevada in California are
well exposed.

</div>

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._28-bta}

-   Landforms created by lava include volcanoes, domes, and plateaus.
-   New land can be created by volcanic eruptions.
-   Landforms created by magma include volcanic necks and domes.

# Hot Springs and Geysers {#6.html#x-ck12-SG90IFNwcmluZ3MgYW5kIEdleXNlcnM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define hot springs and geysers.
-   Explain how hot springs and geysers work.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601325] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_6_files/20150911025737784901.jpeg)
</span>

**Hot spring, anyone?**

Hot water from underground can pool at hot springs. Even some animals
enjoy relaxing in nature's hot tubs. Care to join them?

### Hot Springs and Geysers {#6.html#x-ck12-SG90IFNwcmluZ3MgYW5kIEdleXNlcnM._29-fns}

Water sometimes comes into contact with hot rock. The water may emerge
at the surface as either a hot spring or a geyser.

#### Hot Springs {#6.html#x-ck12-SG90IFNwcmluZ3M._29-qdc}

When hot water gently rises to the surface, it creates a **hot spring**
. A hot spring forms where a crack in the Earth allows water to reach
the surface after being heated underground. Many hot springs are used by
people and animals as natural hot tubs ( **Figure**
[below](#6.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1ZZWxsb3dzdG9uZVNwcmluZ0Jpc29u) ). Some
people believe that hot springs can cure illnesses. Hot springs are
found all over the world, even in Antarctica!

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-YWMxZGJkZWRkZmM3YTczOWFlYWViMGU1MzlhNWJjZGI.-ajw"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Sascha Burkard, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Hot spring in Yellowstone during
winter](ck12_6_files/20150911025737931022.jpeg "Hot spring in Yellowstone during winter")

**Figure 6.86**

Even in winter, the water in this hot spring in Yellowstone doesn't
freeze. Bison move near hot springs to escape the extreme cold.

</div>

#### Geysers {#6.html#x-ck12-R2V5c2Vycw.._29-rut}

**Geysers** are also created by water that is heated beneath the Earth’s
surface. The water may become superheated by magma. It becomes trapped
in a narrow passageway. The heat and pressure build as more water is
added. When the pressure is too much, the superheated water bursts out
onto the surface. This is a **geyser** .

There are only a few areas in the world where the conditions are right
for the formation of geysers. Only about 1,000 geysers exist worldwide.
About half of them are in the United States. The most famous geyser is
Old Faithful at Yellowstone National Park. The geyser erupts every 60 to
70 minutes, shooting hot water nearly 60 meters in the air. It is rare
for a geyser to erupt so regularly, which is why Old Faithful is famous.
Castle Geyser ( **Figure** [below](#6.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTA4MDQtMDY.)
) is another geyser at Yellowstone Park; however, it does not erupt as
frequently or predictably as Old Faithful.

<div id="6.html#x-ck12-MzkzYmFjN2E0ZWQ2ODRjYzQ4NDE2MTc4NzhmNTBkNzg.-jvd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="CK-12 Foundation - Miles Orchinik" -->
<!-- @@url="http://miles-home.smugmug.com/Nature/Yellowstone-journal/9367656_bN4r9#626955315_Q6X9j" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Castle Geyser erupting in Yellowstone National
Park](ck12_6_files/20150911025738033535.jpeg "Castle Geyser erupting in Yellowstone National Park")

**Figure 6.87**

Castle Geyser is one of the many geysers at Yellowstone National Park.
Castle erupts regularly, but not as frequently or predictably as Old
Faithful.

</div>

The Old Faithful web cam shows periodic eruptions of Yellowstone’s
famous geyser in real time:
[http://www.nps.gov/features/yell/live/live4.htm](live4.htm)

### Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._29-del}

-   When magma heats groundwater, it may come to the surface as a hot
    spring or a geyser.
-   Geysers erupt because the water is trapped. The water becomes
    superheated until finally the pressure builds enough for it to break
    the seal.
-   Yellowstone is famous for its geysers. Old Faithful erupts the
    most regularly.

## Summary {#6.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-3oy}

Plate tectonic processes explain why we see many types of geological
activity where we do. Stresses build up in some locations. These
stresses may cause folding or faulting. Earthquakes strike along all
three types of plate boundaries. The most damaging earthquakes are
shallow focus. People in earthquake-prone regions must be aware of the
potential damage from earthquakes. Seismologists have scales for
measuring earthquake intensity and magnitude. Cities in earthquake zones
must build safe structures. They also have guidelines for being safe in
earthquakes. Earthquakes are often associated with volcanoes. Volcanoes
erupt at all types of plate boundaries except transform. Volcanic
eruptions can be quiet or explosive. Volcanoes have a variety of shapes.
The shapes range from large shields, to classic peaks, to small cones.
Supervolcano eruptions are rare but extremely deadly. Volcanic activity
creates unique landforms. Hot springs and geysers result when water
meets hot rock below ground. Some geological activity, both earthquakes
and volcanic eruptions, is located away from plate boundaries.

</div>

# Water on Earth {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgb24gRWFydGg.-chapter}

<div class="x-ck12-data">

## Introduction {#7.html#x-ck12-SW50cm9kdWN0aW9u-igb}

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025800080159.jpeg)
</span>

**How does Earth's water move?**

When astronauts see Earth from space, this is how it looks. Notice how
blue the planet appears. That’s because oceans cover much of Earth’s
surface. The water in those oceans is in constant motion. Water is also
found in the clouds that rise above the planet and travel across the
sky. The water may precipitate out as rain or snow. Water passes through
soil and into groundwater. Or it is taken up by the leaves of plants and
then enters the atmosphere. Water moves into and out of animals. Water
may remain as ice in a glacier for thousands of years. This chapter is
about Earth's most dynamic substance: water.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [LESSON: 3601362] -->

# Distribution of Water on Earth {#7.html#x-ck12-RGlzdHJpYnV0aW9uIG9mIFdhdGVyIG9uIEVhcnRo}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Know where Earth's water is located.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601365] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025800150359.jpeg)
</span>

**Where is Earth's Water?**

Here's a photo of Earth from space again. It's pretty easy to see where
most of Earth's water is. It's in the oceans. Nearly all of Earth's
water is in the seas. Although it's extremely useful for ocean
ecosystems, it's not very useful for people. So where is the water that
we can use?

### Where Is Earth’s Freshwater? {#7.html#x-ck12-V2hlcmUgSXMgRWFydGjigJlzIEZyZXNod2F0ZXI_-h7l}

Most of Earth’s water is salt water in the oceans. As seen below, only 3
percent of Earth’s water is fresh ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDItV29ybGRzLVdhdGVyLURpc3RyaWJ1dGlvbg..)
). **Freshwater** is water that contains little or no dissolved salt.
Most freshwater is frozen in ice caps and glaciers. Glaciers cover the
peaks of some tall mountains. For example, the Cascades Mountains in
North America and the Alps Mountains in Europe are capped with ice. Ice
caps cover vast areas of Antarctica and Greenland. Chunks of ice
frequently break off ice caps. They form icebergs that float in the
oceans.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MWI4ZmNkYTQwMzQzMGRiYzgzMzUzNGE2ZjgwZjBlMzY.-l8u"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of the distribution of Earth's
water](ck12_7_files/20150911025800214734.jpeg "Diagram of the distribution of Earth's water")

**Figure 7.1**

What percentage of Earth’s surface freshwater is water vapor in the air?

</div>

Only a tiny fraction of Earth’s freshwater is in the liquid state. Most
liquid freshwater is under the ground in layers of rock. Of freshwater
on the surface, the majority occurs in lakes and soil. What percentage
of freshwater on the surface is found in living things?

Water can remain in a particular location for a long time. This is known
as a **reservoir** . Reservoirs for water include oceans, glaciers,
ponds, or even the atmosphere. A water molecule may pass through a
reservoir very quickly or may remain for much longer. The amount of time
a molecule stays in a reservoir is known as its **residence time** . The
residence time of water in the ocean is 3,200 years. Of course, not
every molecule stays that long. That number is an average for all
molecules.

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-6pk}

-   Of Earth's water, 97% is in the oceans.
-   Of the remaining 3%, much is trapped in ice and glaciers.
-   A substance is stored in a reservoir. The amount of time it stays in
    that reservoir is its residence time.

# States of Water {#7.html#x-ck12-U3RhdGVzIG9mIFdhdGVy}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the water molecule.
-   Identify the three states of water.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601372] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025800281885.jpeg)
</span>

**What are the three states of water in this photo?**

Water is present as liquid, solid, and gas in this photo. We take water
for granted here on Earth because there is a lot of it!

### The Water Molecule {#7.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFdhdGVyIE1vbGVjdWxl_1-cxo}

A molecule of water ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy1XYXRlck1vbGVjdWxl) ) is made of three
atoms bonded together. Two of these atoms are hydrogen and one atom is
oxygen. The hydrogen ions have a positive electrical charge. The oxygen
atom has a negative electrical charge. The hydrogen atoms are located on
one side and the oxygen atom on the other. This means that the side with
the hydrogen ions has a slightly positive charge. The other side, the
side without the hydrogen ions, has a slightly negative charge. The
water molecule is a **polar molecule** .

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NjFhZmJhZmI1ZGYwYjQ3MjllMmNkYzRmODFiYjkxMWE.-tq7"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Booyabazooka/Wikipedia" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Water_molecule.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of a water
molecule](ck12_7_files/20150911025800353432.png "Diagram of a water molecule")

**Figure 7.2**

A water molecule. The side with the hydrogen atoms has a slightly
positive charge. The side with the oxygen atom has a slightly negative
charge.

</div>

Water has remarkable properties. Water expands when it freezes, even
though all other substances contract. This means that in the winter ice
on a pond or lake will float. Water has high surface tension because
polar molecules tend to stick together. That's why drops stick together
or some bugs can walk on the surface of a pond. Without water, life
might not be able to exist on Earth. If it did exist, it would not be as
diverse or as complex.

### Three States of Matter {#7.html#x-ck12-VGhyZWUgU3RhdGVzIG9mIE1hdHRlcg.._1-wj7}

Water is the only substance on Earth that is present in all three states
of matter. This means that water is present as a solid, liquid, and gas.
Earth is the only planet where water is present in all three states. All
three phases may be present in a single location or in a region. The
three phases are solid (ice or snow), liquid (water), and gas ( **water
vapor** ). See ice, water, and clouds pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XYXRlclN0YXRlc0NvbXBvc2l0ZQ..) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MWNiNzE3YzZiOGVhN2I2MjI0YjU5ZTE3NjE2ZjliMTU.-tew"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Natalie Lucier; (B) Gareth Haywood; (C) Lynn Greyling" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.flickr.com/photos/natalielucier/3623933920/; (B) http://www.flickr.com/photos/gazhaywood/7101897147/; (C) http://www.publicdomainpictures.net/view-image.php?image=50359&#38;picture=catching-clouds" -->
<!-- @@license="(A) CC BY 2.0; (B) CC BY 2.0; (C) Public Domain" -->
![Ice, liquid, and water vapor are the three phases of
water](ck12_7_files/20150911025800415527.jpeg "Ice, liquid, and water vapor are the three phases of water")

**Figure 7.3**

\(A) Ice floating in the sea. Can you find all three phases of water in
this image? (B) Liquid water. (C) Water vapor is invisible, but clouds
that form when water vapor condenses are not.

</div>

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._1-c1p}

-   Water is a polar molecule. On one side there is a positive
    electrical charge. On the other side there is a negative charge.
-   Water is the only substance on Earth that is stable in all
    three states.
-   Earth is the only planet in the solar system that has water in all
    three states.
