# Processes of the Water Cycle {#7.html#x-ck12-UHJvY2Vzc2VzIG9mIHRoZSBXYXRlciBDeWNsZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe reservoirs of the water cycle.
-   Describe the processes that carry water between reservoirs.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601378] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025800476890.jpeg)
</span>

**Where have these water molecules been?**

Did you ever wonder where the water molecules you drink came from? Were
some of the molecules trapped in a glacier? Flowing along the bottom of
the ocean? Up high in a thundercloud? Maybe a water molecule that you
drink today once quenched the thirst of a dinosaur. It's all entirely
possible.

### The Water Cycle {#7.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFdhdGVyIEN5Y2xl_2-blh}

The **water cycle** ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDMtV2F0ZXItQ3ljbGU.) ) is the
movement of water through the oceans, atmosphere, land, and living
things. The water cycle is powered by energy from the Sun.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MGZjOWJjNGJiMzAyY2MyOWVlYTBhZGUzNDhkMGUwYjM.-wxd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA/Atmospheric Infrared Sounder" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/atmospheric-infrared-sounder/8265046380/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Diagram of the water
cycle](ck12_7_files/20150911025800541357.png "Diagram of the water cycle")

**Figure 7.4**

The water cycle has no beginning or end. Water just keeps moving along.

</div>

Water keeps cycling. The water cycle repeats over and over again. Each
water molecule has probably been around for billions of years. That’s
because Earth’s water is constantly recycled.

#### Processes in the Water Cycle {#7.html#x-ck12-UHJvY2Vzc2VzIGluIHRoZSBXYXRlciBDeWNsZQ.._2-9ab}

Water keeps changing state as it goes through the water cycle. This
means that it can be a solid, liquid, or gas. How does water change
state? How does it keep moving through the cycle? As seen above (
**Figure** [above](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDMtV2F0ZXItQ3ljbGU.) ),
several processes are involved.

-   **Evaporation** changes liquid water to water vapor. Energy from the
    Sun causes water to evaporate. Most evaporation is from the oceans
    because they cover so much area. The water vapor rises into
    the atmosphere.
-   **Transpiration** is like evaporation because it changes liquid
    water to water vapor. In transpiration, plants release water vapor
    through their leaves ( **Figure**
    [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1UcmFuc3BpcmF0aW9u) ). This water
    vapor rises into the atmosphere.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NTY1MzFjNjRhYmU2MzEwMzdkMjUwMDAzNTE4YWRhNjY.-cyl"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Zappy's" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Plant drawing up water and releasing water vapor through
transpiration](ck12_7_files/20150911025800589122.jpeg "Plant drawing up water and releasing water vapor through transpiration")

**Figure 7.5**

Liquid water is taken up by plant roots. The plant releases water vapor
into the atmosphere. This is transpiration.

</div>

-   **Condensation** changes water vapor to liquid water. As air rises
    higher into the atmosphere, it cools. Cool air can hold less water
    vapor than warm air. So some of the water vapor condenses into
    water droplets. Water droplets may form clouds. Below is an example
    of condensation ( **Figure**
    [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Db25kZW5zYXRpb24.) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NzcxYmFhZGUxNjMyZTRkMTMxYjEzNDkxNzY2ODYwODk.-aen"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Beatrice Murch (Flickr:blmurch)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/blmurch/1288069767/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Condensation on a cold
bottle](ck12_7_files/20150911025800643132.jpeg "Condensation on a cold bottle")

**Figure 7.6**

A bottle that comes out of the refrigerator is cold. It cools the air
near the bottle. Cooler air can hold less water so water vapor condenses
onto the bottle.

</div>

-   **Precipitation** is water that falls from clouds to
    Earth’s surface. Water droplets in clouds fall to Earth when they
    become too large to stay aloft. The water falls as rain if the air
    is warm. If the air is cold, the water may freeze and fall as snow,
    sleet, or hail. Most precipitation falls into the oceans. Some falls
    on land.
-   **Runoff** is precipitation that flows over the surface of the land.
    This water may travel to a river, lake, or ocean. Runoff may pick up
    fertilizer and other pollutants and deliver them to a water body. In
    this way, runoff may pollute bodies of water.
-   **Infiltration** is the process by which water soaks into
    the ground. Some of the water may seep deep underground. Some may
    stay in the soil, where plants can absorb it with their roots.

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._2-xvi}

-   The water cycle recognizes all of the reservoirs of water. It also
    describes the processes that carry water between the reservoirs.
-   Water changes state by evaporation, condensation, and sublimation.
-   Plants release water through their leaves by transpiration.

# Uses of Water {#7.html#x-ck12-VXNlcyBvZiBXYXRlcg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the different ways in which humans use water.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601382] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025800700511.jpeg)
</span>

**Dynamic Earth and dynamic human development come together—where?**

At a water park! There may be nothing as fun as a water park on a hot
day. Fun is one of the uses of water. What are some others?

### Water Consumption {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgQ29uc3VtcHRpb24._3-efa}

Humans use six times as much water today as they did 100 years ago.
People living in developed countries use a far greater proportion of the
world’s water than people in less developed countries. What do people
use all of that water for?

### How We Use Water {#7.html#x-ck12-SG93IFdlIFVzZSBXYXRlcg.._3-s3s}

The image below shows how people use water worldwide ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjEtMDEtZ2xvYmFsLXdhdGVyLXVzZQ..) ). The
greatest use is for agriculture and then industry. Municipal use is
last, but it is also important. Municipal use refers to water used by
homes and businesses in communities.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NGU2ODNkZjAwN2QyMWE1ODRkZWE5OTU1ZDBjNWZlOWU.-1ag"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Graph showing water use by agricultural, municipal, and industrial
sectors](ck12_7_files/20150911025800761550.jpeg "Graph showing water use by agricultural, municipal, and industrial sectors")

**Figure 7.7**

In this global water use chart, see how much is used in agriculture. Why
do you think so much water is used in agriculture?

</div>

#### Agriculture {#7.html#x-ck12-QWdyaWN1bHR1cmU._3-vhy}

Many crops are grown where there isn’t enough rainfall for plants to
thrive. For example, crops are grown in deserts of the American
Southwest. How is this possible? The answer is irrigation.
**Irrigation** is any way of providing extra water to plants. Most of
the water used in agriculture is used for irrigation. Livestock also use
water, but they use much less.

Irrigation can waste a lot of water. The type of irrigation pictured
below ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1PdmVyaGVhcmRJcnJpZ2F0aW9u) ) is the
most wasteful. The water is sprayed into the air and then falls to the
ground. But much of the water never reaches the crops. Instead, it
evaporates in the air or runs off the fields. Irrigation water may cause
other problems. The water may dissolve agricultural chemicals such as
pesticides. When the water soaks into the ground, the dissolved
chemicals do too. They may enter groundwater or run off into rivers or
lakes. Salts in irrigation water can also collect in the soil. The soil
may get too salty for plants to grow.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-OWQ5OGVlNTliNzFmMmMwZTk1YTcwYmIxZDZlNDFkZDU.-mrl"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="John Holm (Flickr:foto3116)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/29385617@N00/2720597511/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Overhead irrigation
system](ck12_7_files/20150911025800818810.jpeg "Overhead irrigation system")

**Figure 7.8**

Overhead irrigation systems like this one are widely used to irrigate
crops on big farms. What are some drawbacks of irrigation?

</div>

#### Industry {#7.html#x-ck12-SW5kdXN0cnk._3-gyz}

Almost a quarter of the water used worldwide is used in industry.
Industries use water for many purposes. Chemical processes need a lot of
water. Water is used to generate electricity. An important way that
industries use water is to cool machines and power plants.

#### Household Uses {#7.html#x-ck12-SG91c2Vob2xkIFVzZXM._3-zy7}

Think about all the ways people use water at home. Besides drinking it,
they use it for cooking, bathing, washing dishes, doing laundry, and
flushing toilets. The water used inside homes goes down the drain. From
there it usually ends up in a sewer system. At the sewage treatment
plant, water is treated and prepared for reuse.

Households may also use water outdoors. If your family has a lawn or
garden, you may water them with a hose or sprinkler. You probably use
water to wash the car ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DYXJXYXNoaW5n) ). Much of the water
used outdoors evaporates or runs off into the gutter. The runoff water
may end up in storm sewers that flow into a body of water, such as the
ocean.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-OWRhOTg1MTU5MGFiMzY0ZjhlYjhkNjc5M2QxMDI1OTk.-wdz"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Chief Mass Communication Specialist Steve Carlson, U.S. Navy" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:US_Navy_110831-N-NT881-079_Sailors_assigned_to_the_guided-missile_submarine_USS_Ohio_(SSGN_726)_and_Navy_Operational_Support_Center_Cincinnati_part.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![People washing a
car](ck12_7_files/20150911025800883991.jpeg "People washing a car")

**Figure 7.9**

What will happen to the water that runs off the car? Where will it go?

</div>

#### Fun {#7.html#x-ck12-RnVu_3-us7}

Fun wasn't on the pie chart ( **Figure**
[above](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjEtMDEtZ2xvYmFsLXdhdGVyLXVzZQ..) ), but
it's important, too! There are many ways to use water for fun, from
white water rafting to snorkeling. When you do these activities, you
don’t actually use water. You are doing the activity on or in the water.
What do you think is the single biggest use of water for fun? Believe it
or not, it’s golf! Keeping golf courses green uses an incredible amount
of water. Since many golf courses are in sunny areas, much of the water
is irrigation water. Like any similar sprinkler system, much of this
water is wasted. It evaporates or runs off the ground.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NTA2MTA5MGQ0ZjU2NjU2M2JhMmQzZmI2MzA4Y2MwMTA.-2rz"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Kristin Smith, 20114" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Golf course in a
desert](ck12_7_files/20150911025800937103.jpeg "Golf course in a desert")

**Figure 7.10**

Sunshine brings golfers to the desert, but a lot of water is needed to
make the desert green enough to play.

</div>

#### Environment {#7.html#x-ck12-RW52aXJvbm1lbnQ._3-q3v}

It's important to leave some water for the environment. In some places,
water is used for wildlife habitat. Man-made lakes create places for
fish and water birds. Leaving water in the ecosystems keeps the
environment good for many species of plants and animals.

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._3-2xo}

-   People use water for agriculture, industry, and consumption.
-   Water can also be used for fun and for the environment.
-   Some water must remain in the environment to support ecosystems.

# Water Distribution {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgRGlzdHJpYnV0aW9u}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how water is distributed across the globe.
-   Explain the causes and consequences of too little water.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601387] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025800996047.jpeg)
</span>

**What do you have to do to get water?**

In the developed world, we just open a tap. Clean water is available all
the time. In many developing regions, women have to walk long distances
to get clean water. Sometimes there isn't a source of clean water, and
they just get what they can find. We take water for granted in the
developed world.

### Water Problems: Not Enough Water {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgUHJvYmxlbXM6IE5vdCBFbm91Z2ggV2F0ZXI._4-7yj}

Most Americans have plenty of fresh, clean water. But many people around
the world do not. In fact, water scarcity is the world’s most serious
resource problem. How can that be? Water is almost everywhere. But much
of it is unusable. What is usable is not always where it is needed.

#### Where Is All the Water? {#7.html#x-ck12-V2hlcmUgSXMgQWxsIHRoZSBXYXRlcj8._4-2px}

One problem is that only a tiny fraction of Earth’s water is fresh,
liquid water that people can use. More than 97 percent of Earth’s water
is salt water in the oceans. Just 3% is freshwater. Most of the
freshwater is frozen in ice sheets, icebergs, and glaciers ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HbGFjaWVyQW5kQ3J1aXNlU2hpcA..) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NjdlN2YzNDJjMWU5YmVjYjhhY2UwNDg1MjAwM2E5ODY.-c6g"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Frank Kovalchek (Flickr:Alaskan Dude)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/72213316@N00/7588197286/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Glaciers store a lot of frozen
freshwater](ck12_7_files/20150911025801068151.jpeg "Glaciers store a lot of frozen freshwater")

**Figure 7.11**

This glacier in Alaska stores a lot of frozen freshwater.

</div>

#### Rainfall and the Water Supply {#7.html#x-ck12-UmFpbmZhbGwgYW5kIHRoZSBXYXRlciBTdXBwbHk._4-xil}

Rainfall varies around the globe. About 40% of the land gets very little
rain. About the same percentage of the world’s people don’t have enough
water. You can compare global rainfall with the worldwide freshwater
supply at the two URLs below. Drier climates generally have less water
for people to use. In some places, people may have less water available
to them for an entire year than many Americans use in a single day! How
much water is there where you live?

-   Global rainfall:
    [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:World\_precip\_annual.png](File:World_precip_annual.png)
-   Freshwater supply:
    [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:2006\_Global\_Water\_Availability.svg](File:2006_Global_Water_Availability.svg)

#### Wealth and the Water Supply {#7.html#x-ck12-V2VhbHRoIGFuZCB0aGUgV2F0ZXIgU3VwcGx5_4-hgy}

Richer nations can drill deep wells, build large dams, or supply people
with water in other ways. In these countries, just about everyone has
access to clean running water in their homes, and water is cheap and
easy to get. It’s no surprise that people in these countries use the
most water. In poorer nations, there is little money to develop water
supplies. Therefore, people get their water where they can.

#### Water Shortages {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgU2hvcnRhZ2Vz_4-teq}

Water shortages are common in much of the world. People are most likely
to run short of water during droughts. A **drought** is a period of
unusually low rainfall. Human actions have increased how often droughts
occur. One way people can help to bring on a drought is by cutting down
trees. Trees add a lot of water vapor to the air. With fewer trees, the
air is drier and droughts are more common.

We already use six times as much water today as we did a hundred years
ago. As the number of people rises, our need for water will grow. By the
year 2025, only half the world’s people will have enough clean water.
Water is such a vital resource that serious water shortages may cause
other problems.

-   Crops and livestock may die, so people will have less
    food available.
-   Other uses of water, such as industry, may have to stop. This
    reduces the jobs people can get and the products they can buy.
-   People and nations may fight over water resources.
-   In extreme cases, people may die from lack of water.

The **Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XYXRlclN0cmVzcw..)
shows the global water situation in the 2030s with water stress and
water scarcity on the map.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MTYxZDdkNDFkYzUwZjYyNTY1YjEwZDA0NzQxNTVhOGI.-rzn"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="J Liu, C Folberth, et al." -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0057750" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.5" -->
![](ck12_7_files/20150911025801137416.png)

**Figure 7.12**

Blues indicate no predicted water stress; pinks and lavenders predict
water stress, and salmon to brown indicates water scarcity (variations
of those colors indicate the amount of irrigation that will be done to
produce crops).

</div>

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._4-pgv}

-   Fresh water is not evenly distributed across the planet.
-   Many of the world's people live without access to enough
    clean water. That percentage is likely to increase as
    populations grow.
-   During a drought, life may become very hard for many people.

# Safety of Water {#7.html#x-ck12-U2FmZXR5IG9mIFdhdGVy}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the causes and consequences of unsafe water.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601393] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025801253513.jpeg)
</span>

**What do you see in this photo?**

The Ganges River is sacred to the people of India. It is also a major
source of water for drinking and bathing for millions of people. An
estimated 400 million people are affected by pollution in the Ganges.
What can be done to protect a water body that has so much pressure
placed on it?

### Water Safety {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgU2FmZXR5_5-iro}

The water Americans get from their faucets is safe. This water has been
treated and purified. At least 20% of the world’s people do not have
clean drinking water always available. That's more than 1 billion
people. They must drink water from where they can get it. Maybe straight
from a river or pond ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjEtMDgtZHJpbmtpbmctd2F0ZXI.) ). Human
wastes may be in the water. If that's the case, the water will probably
contain pathogens. **Pathogens** are organisms that cause diseases.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-ZjMxOWQwMmNhODk4YTFhMTZiMjMzMGRjNGMxM2ZkYmM.-ono"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

ground](ck12_7_files/20150911025801327236.jpeg "Girl getting water from a hole in the ground")

**Figure 7.13**

This girl is getting drinking water from a hole that has been dug. It
may be the only source of water in this remote part of Tanzania where
she lives.

</div>

#### Waterborne Disease {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXJib3JuZSBEaXNlYXNl_5-wqh}

Unsafe drinking water causes 88% of diseases worldwide. In many nations,
these diseases are the leading cause of death in children under the age
of five. More than 14,000 people die every day from such diseases.
Cholera is caused by bacteria. A person gets guinea worm from drinking
the guinea worm larvae ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMjEtMjItRHJhY3VuY3VsaWFzaXM.) ). The
cholera bacteria and guinea worms are pathogens.

Guinea worm.

</div>

    for drinking and washing.
-   Waterborne diseases cause death and illness to people in many parts
    of the world.
-   Government programs and international aid help to provide safe
    drinking water for some people.

# Conserving Water {#7.html#x-ck12-Q29uc2VydmluZyBXYXRlcg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe ways to conserve water.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601398] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025801460698.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you figure out how to do these things better?**

The photos above are of water being wasted. Water being used for
irrigation with much flying into the air. A large fountain in the
desert. Excess water being used to wash a car. These sorts of waste
occur all the time. How can these activities be done without so much
waste? How can irrigation or car washing use less water? What can people
enjoy in the desert that doesn't involve so much water?

### Conserving Water {#7.html#x-ck12-Q29uc2VydmluZyBXYXRlcg.._6-x0a}

Conserving water means using less of it. Of course, this mostly applies
to people in the wealthy nations that have the most water and also waste
the most.

#### Saving Water in Irrigation {#7.html#x-ck12-U2F2aW5nIFdhdGVyIGluIElycmlnYXRpb24._6-jdk}

**Irrigation** is the single biggest use of water. Overhead irrigation
wastes a lot of water. **Drip irrigation** ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1EcmlwSXJyaWdhdGlvbg..) ) wastes a lot
less. Water pipes run over the surface of the ground. Tiny holes in the
pipes are placed close to each plant. Water slowly drips out of the
holes and soaks into the soil around the plants. Very little of the
water evaporates or runs off the ground.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-ZjEyYTZhZjg3MDg5ZmUwMGI3ZmE4Zjc2MjEzZDhkZWY.-ctn"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Photo by Jeff Vanuga, USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:VineyardDrip.JPG" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Drip irrigation helps save
water](ck12_7_files/20150911025801525067.jpeg "Drip irrigation helps save water")

**Figure 7.15**

The above is a drip irrigation system. Look at the soil in the photo.
It’s damp around each plant but dry everywhere else.

</div>

#### Rationing Water {#7.html#x-ck12-UmF0aW9uaW5nIFdhdGVy_6-tcs}

Some communities save water with rationing. Much rationing takes place
only during times of drought. During rationing, water may not be used
for certain things. For example, communities may ban lawn watering and
car washing. People may be fined if they use water in these ways. You
can do your part. Follow any bans where you live.

#### Saving Water at Home {#7.html#x-ck12-U2F2aW5nIFdhdGVyIGF0IEhvbWU._6-4de}

It’s easy to save water at home. If you save even a few gallons a day
you can make a big difference in the long run. The best place to start
saving water is in the bathroom. Toilet flushing is the single biggest
use of water in the home. Showers and baths are the next biggest use.
Follow the tips below to save water at home.

-   Install water-saving toilets. They use only about half as much water
    per flush. A single household can save up to 20,000 gallons a year
    with this change alone!
-   Remember what they say about bathroom flushing in California during
    rationing: If it's yellow, let it mellow; if it's brown, flush it
    down!
-   Take shorter showers. You can get just as clean in five minutes as
    you can in 10. And you’ll save up to 50 gallons of water each time
    you shower. That’s thousands of gallons each year.
-   Use low-flow shower heads. They use about half as much water as
    regular shower heads. They save thousands of gallons of water.
-   Fix leaky shower heads and faucets. All those drips really add up.
    At one drip per second, more than 6,000 gallons go down the drain in
    a year—per faucet!
-   Don’t leave the water running while you brush your teeth. You could
    save as much as 10 gallons each time you brush. That could add up to
    7,000 gallons in a year.
-   Landscape your home with plants that need little water. This could
    result in a huge savings in water use. Look at the garden pictured
    below ( **Figure**
    [below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjEtMTktbG93LXdhdGVyLWdhcmRlbg..) );
    it shows that you don’t have to sacrifice beauty to save water.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MmVhZTAyOGUzOWY2Y2EzMWM3MDU5MDI2N2JmMmRhM2I.-zz1"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Paul Joseph" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/91255327@N00/708975017" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Garden with cactus that need very little
water](ck12_7_files/20150911025801589639.jpeg "Garden with cactus that need very little water")

**Figure 7.16**

This beautiful garden contains only plants that need very little water.

</div>

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._6-byj}

-   Drip irrigation uses much less water than other methods.
-   People can reduce water consumption by taking shorter showers,
    installing water-saving devices, and many other methods.
-   Communities sometimes ration water during times of drought.

# Streams and Rivers {#7.html#x-ck12-U3RyZWFtcyBhbmQgUml2ZXJz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define stream and describe its parts.
-   Define watershed and divide.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601404] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025801647373.jpeg)
</span>

**What makes this river so much fun to raft?**

Whitewater rafting is a popular recreational activity. The river is fast
because its in the mountains traveling downhill. There is a lot of water
from snow melt higher up. Sometimes water is added from springs. Did you
ever go whitewater rafting? It's fun!

### What Are Streams and Rivers? {#7.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBBcmUgU3RyZWFtcyBhbmQgUml2ZXJzPw.._7-uxi}

A **stream** is a body of freshwater that flows downhill in a channel.
The channel of a stream has a bottom, or bed, and sides called banks.
Any size body of flowing water can be called a stream. Usually, though,
a large stream is called a **river** .

#### Features of Streams and Rivers {#7.html#x-ck12-RmVhdHVyZXMgb2YgU3RyZWFtcyBhbmQgUml2ZXJz_7-m96}

All streams and rivers have several features in common ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDUtUml2ZXItRmVhdHVyZXM.) ). The
place where a stream or river starts is its **source** . The source
might be a spring, where water flows out of the ground. Or the source
might be water from melting snow on a mountain top, like the stream
pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HbGFjaWVyTmF0aW9uYWxQYXJrUml2ZXI.) ).
A single stream may have multiple sources.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-YTQ5Nzg0OWI1OGZiYTNhNzE1NmYzZjVhNTQ2NjJmMjg.-xli"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Miles Orchinik" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Rapid stream in Glacier National
Park](ck12_7_files/20150911025801711015.jpeg "Rapid stream in Glacier National Park")

**Figure 7.17**

A stream flows fast and steep where it originates in the mountains. This
stream, in Glacier National Park in Montana, is coming from snow melt.

</div>

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NDQ5YjVhN2IwZDkzN2VmZDg4NDI4NWJlOTM3YzgyOTM.-bam"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of the features of a
river](ck12_7_files/20150911025801775961.jpeg "Diagram of the features of a river")

**Figure 7.18**

Water in a stream flows along the ground from higher to lower elevation.
What force causes the water to keep flowing?

</div>

A stream or river probably ends when it flows into a body of water, such
as a lake or an ocean. A stream ends at its **mouth** . As the water
flows into the body of water, it slows down and drops the sediment it
was carrying. The sediment may build up to form a delta.

Several other features of streams and rivers are also shown above (
**Figure** [above](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDUtUml2ZXItRmVhdHVyZXM.)
).

-   Small streams often flow into bigger streams or rivers. The small
    streams are called **tributaries** . A river and all its tributaries
    make up a river system.
-   At certain times of year, a stream or river may overflow its banks.
    The area of land that is flooded is called the **floodplain** . The
    floodplain may be very wide where the river flows over a nearly
    flat surface.
-   A river flowing over a floodplain may wear away broad curves. These
    curves are called **meanders** . Pictured below is an example of
    this ( **Figure**
    [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Tb3V0aENhcm9saW5hRXN0dWFyeQ..) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MThjYjNhNTAxZjRjM2FjMmViMjkyOGZhNGZmNzJkNWM.-qoj"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright John Wollwerth, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![A river meanders across an estuary in South
Carolina](ck12_7_files/20150911025801851151.jpeg "A river meanders across an estuary in South Carolina")

**Figure 7.19**

A river meanders across an estuary in South Carolina.

</div>

#### River Basins and Divides {#7.html#x-ck12-Uml2ZXIgQmFzaW5zIGFuZCBEaXZpZGVz_7-dt6}

All of the land drained by a river system is called its basin, or
**watershed** . One river system’s basin is separated from another river
system’s basin by a **divide** . The divide is created by the highest
points between the two river basins. Precipitation that falls within a
river basin always flows toward that river. Precipitation that falls on
the other side of the divide flows toward a different river. A
**continental divide** separates rivers that flow into different oceans.

Pictured below are the major river basins in the U.S. ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1VU1JpdmVyQmFzaW5z) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-YTExNjhjZjg2YTQxNDA4NWZiZTNiZGE5ZWFkMTgyY2E.-n4y"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the National Weather Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://water.weather.gov/ahps/rfc/rfc.php" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The river basins in the United
States](ck12_7_files/20150911025801939686.png "The river basins in the United States")

**Figure 7.20**

River basins in the U.S.

</div>

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._7-hnw}

-   A moving body of water of any size is a stream. A river is a
    large stream.
-   A tributary begins at its headwaters on one side of a divide. Two
    tributaries come together at a confluence.
-   A river ends at an estuary. If the river drops sediment, it may
    create a delta.

# Ponds and Lakes {#7.html#x-ck12-UG9uZHMgYW5kIExha2Vz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of ponds and lakes.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601408] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025802017913.jpeg)
</span>

**Why are lakes important?**

Lakes are important habitats for lots of plants and animals. The slow
motions of the water are easier for organisms to live in than the water
from rapidly moving streams. Some animals live on land but get at least
part of their food from lakes or ponds. This eagle is fishing for its
meal. What would happen if lakes dried up?

### Ponds and Lakes {#7.html#x-ck12-UG9uZHMgYW5kIExha2Vz_8-nyd}

After a heavy rain, you may find puddles of water standing in low spots.
The same principle explains why water collects in ponds and lakes. Water
travels downhill, so a depression in the ground fills with standing
water. A **pond** is a small body of standing water. A **lake** is a
large body of standing water. Most lakes have freshwater, but a few are
salty. The Great Salt Lake in Utah is an example of a saltwater lake.

The water in a large lake may be so deep that sunlight cannot penetrate
all the way to the bottom. Without sunlight, water plants and algae
cannot live on the bottom of the lake. That’s because plants need
sunlight for photosynthesis.

#### Water in Ponds and Lakes {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgaW4gUG9uZHMgYW5kIExha2Vz_8-hky}

Ponds and lakes may get their water from several sources. Some falls
directly into them as precipitation. Some enters as runoff and some from
streams and rivers. Water leaves ponds and lakes through evaporation and
also as outflow.

#### How Lakes Form {#7.html#x-ck12-SG93IExha2VzIEZvcm0._8-udf}

The depression that allows water to collect to form a lake may come
about in a variety of ways. The Great Lakes, for example, are glacial
lakes. A glacial lake forms when a glacier scrapes a large hole in the
ground. When the glacier melts, the water fills the hole and forms a
lake. A kettle lake forms in the sediment left by a glacier when a block
of ice melts. Kettle lakes are found where continental glaciers once
covered the land ( *Figure* '
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1EZW5hbGlNb29zZQ..) ). Over time lakes
get water from rain, streams, and groundwater coming to the surface.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-YmQ1MTRiMzJlZTY4ODhkNTAyNzk1YjY0ZmJkZDY4MDc.-vjr"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Jacob W. Frank, National Park Services" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/denalinps/6187093400/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A moose in a kettle lake at Denali National Park in
Alaska](ck12_7_files/20150911025802082725.jpeg "A moose in a kettle lake at Denali National Park in Alaska")

**Figure 7.21**

A moose in a kettle lake at Denali National Park in Alaska.

</div>

Other lakes are crater lakes or rift lakes ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDgtQ3JhdGVyLWFuZC1SaWZ0LUxha2Vz) ).
Crater lakes form when volcanic eruptions create craters that fill with
water. Rift lakes form when movements of tectonic plates create low
places that fill with water.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MjBiMDY5MTRhNjRhMTY0NWQ0NmQ4OGMwYWY0YjAwZDM.-tqk"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Left: Indrik myneur; Right: Courtesy of UNEP/GRID" -->
<!-- @@url="Left: http://www.flickr.com/photos/myneur/4301791831/; Right: http://na.unep.net/atlas/africa/book.php" -->
<!-- @@license="Left: CC BY 2.0; Right: Non-copyrighted and available for free use" -->
![Craters and rifts become lakes when they fill with
water](ck12_7_files/20150911025802146715.jpeg "Craters and rifts become lakes when they fill with water")

**Figure 7.22**

Craters and rifts become lakes when they fill with water. Where does the
water come from?

</div>

#### The Great Lakes {#7.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEdyZWF0IExha2Vz_8-4ej}

Large lakes are similar to oceans. They have tides and currents. Large
lakes can affect weather patterns. The Great Lakes ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDctVGhlLUdyZWF0LUxha2Vz) ) contain
22% of the world’s fresh surface water. The largest of them, Lake
Superior, has a tide that rises and falls several centimeters each day.
The Great Lakes cause “lake effect” snow. In the winter, a large amount
of snow may fall downwind of the relatively warm lakes. The Great Lakes
are home to countless species of fish and wildlife.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-ZGZiOTQ3MmM3M2FmNzE2OTZmNjAwZjVlNWRjMWIxMWY.-bnr"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Jeff Schmaltz, MODIS Rapid Response Team, Goddard Space Flight Center" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=45615" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Satellite image of the Great
Lakes](ck12_7_files/20150911025802211807.jpeg "Satellite image of the Great Lakes")

**Figure 7.23**

The Great Lakes of North America get their name from their great size.

</div>

#### Reservoirs {#7.html#x-ck12-UmVzZXJ2b2lycw.._8-8gx}

Many lakes are not natural, but are human-made. People dam a stream in a
suitable spot. Water backs up behind the dam, creating a lake. These
lakes are "reservoirs" ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Ib292ZXJEYW0.) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NTljZWQ0OWU2OWZmZGY3OGM3ZmNiYjA2ODJmNzYxOWU.-kox"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:snakefisch/Wikipedia" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hoover_dam_from_air.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Hoover Dam created Lake Mead along the Colorado
River](ck12_7_files/20150911025802294909.jpeg "Hoover Dam created Lake Mead along the Colorado River")

**Figure 7.24**

Hoover Dam, near Las Vegas, Nevada, creates a reservoir on the Colorado
River. The reservoir is called Lake Mead.

</div>

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._8-njd}

-   Ponds are small water bodies often fed by springs.
-   A lake or pond may form wherever water can collect. A lake basin
    could be a volcanic crater, where a glacier has carved out a
    depression, or a fault zone.
-   A reservoir is a man-made lake.

# Flooding {#7.html#x-ck12-Rmxvb2Rpbmc.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain the causes and effects of floods.
-   Describe types of flood protection.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601414] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025802355460.jpeg)
</span>

**Is the water cycle perfect?**

The amount of water Earth has doesn't change. So if the water cycle were
perfect, there would always be the right amount of water in each
reservoir. In winter, there would be the right amount of snow. The snow
would melt in the right amounts and at the right times in the spring. A
good amount of rain would fall. Not so little that there would be a
drought and not so much that there would be a flood. But the water cycle
is not perfect. Floods are all too common.

### Floods {#7.html#x-ck12-Rmxvb2Rz_9-sa8}

A **flood** occurs when so much water enters a stream or river that it
overflows its banks. Flood waters from a river are pictured below (
**Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1JbmRpYW5hRmxvb2Q.) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NmE2MDcwODQzZGU4MzY0Njg5NTRlZDU4MTA2YWJiMGI.-uia"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="John Lucito (Flickr:jlucito)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/jlucito/2864459590/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Flooding in
Indiana](ck12_7_files/20150911025802428738.jpeg "Flooding in Indiana")

**Figure 7.25**

Flooding in Indiana.

</div>

Floods are a natural part of the water cycle, but they can cause a lot
of damage. Farms and homes may be lost, and people may die. In 1939,
millions of people died in a flood in China. Although freshwater is
needed to grow crops and just to live, too much freshwater in the same
place at once can be deadly.

#### Causes of Floods {#7.html#x-ck12-Q2F1c2VzIG9mIEZsb29kcw.._9-3tg}

Floods may occur when deep snow melts quickly in the spring. More often,
floods are due to heavy rainfall. Floods happen when rain falls more
quickly than water can be absorbed into the ground or carried away by
rivers or streams.

Extremely heavy rains across the Midwestern U.S. in April 2011 led to
flooding of the rivers in the Mississippi River basin in May 2011 (
**Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTMtMjAuNS1SYWluMDQyOTIwMTE.)
and **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTMtMjUtTWF5LTIwMTEtRmxvb2Rz) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NzBjOGEzNDI1NzYyNWMwNzcyY2I2NWUzZWMyZDFlNzA.-fae"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service, National Weather Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pcpnweekending04292011.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Heavy rainfall in 2011 lead to the Mississippi River
floods](ck12_7_files/20150911025802490854.jpeg "Heavy rainfall in 2011 lead to the Mississippi River floods")

**Figure 7.26**

This map shows the accumulated rainfall across the U.S. in the days from
April 22 to April 29, 2011.

</div>

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-OWVlOGI3ZDAwMzY0MjI0NTVmYjIxM2JlZTZhNjZkZTM.-arf"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Jesse Allen and Robert Simmon, NASA's Earth Observatory" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=50475" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Flooding in 2011 of the Mississippi River, and the opening of the New
Madrid
Floodway](ck12_7_files/20150911025802558872.png "Flooding in 2011 of the Mississippi River, and the opening of the New Madrid Floodway")

**Figure 7.27**

Record flow in the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers has to go somewhere.
Normal spring river levels are shown in 2010. The flooded region in the
image from May 3, 2011 is the New Madrid Floodway, where overflow water
is meant to go. 2011 is the first time since 1927 that this floodway was
used.

</div>

#### Buffers to Flooding {#7.html#x-ck12-QnVmZmVycyB0byBGbG9vZGluZw.._9-si0}

Heavily vegetated lands are less likely to experience flooding. Plants
slow down water as it runs over the land, giving it time to enter the
ground. If the ground is too wet to absorb more water, plants still slow
the water’s passage. Slower water keeps all the water from entering the
stream at once. Wetlands play a key role in minimizing the impacts of
floods. Wetlands act as a buffer between land and high water levels.
Flooding is often more severe in areas that have been recently logged.

#### Flood Protection {#7.html#x-ck12-Rmxvb2QgUHJvdGVjdGlvbg.._9-dt4}

People protect areas that might flood with dams. In dire situations,
they use sandbags ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1JbmRpYW5hU2FuZGJhZ3M.) ). Dams are
usually very effective, but high water levels sometimes cause a dam to
break. In that case, flooding can be catastrophic. Flood waters can also
overflow a dam. People may line a river bank with **levees** to protect
against floods. These are high walls that keep the stream within its
banks during floods. Flood protection in one location sometimes causes
problems elsewhere. For example, a levee in one location may just force
the high water upstream or downstream. This will lead to flooding in a
different location. Sometimes water gets so high that the river must be
allowed to flood.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-YjRhMzZlM2Q0NWJkYWU0MjE1Y2M4YWRlODQ4YmNkYjI.-9b0"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="U.S. Army" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/soldiersmediacenter/2868010820/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Sandbags create levees to try to stop a
flood](ck12_7_files/20150911025802634293.jpeg "Sandbags create levees to try to stop a flood")

**Figure 7.28**

Sandbags are put out to try to keep floodwaters from overtaking a town.

</div>

### Effects of Floods {#7.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0cyBvZiBGbG9vZHM._9-mxx}

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-M2M0ZTVkNWU2ODYwNWFkMmE3YjljMjNlNGI3NzUxMWE.-st0"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:Andrew&#174;" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Nile_Flood_plain_limits_%282009%29.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Image of the fertile Nile
floodplain](ck12_7_files/20150911025802704736.jpeg "Image of the fertile Nile floodplain")

**Figure 7.29**

Within the floodplain of the Nile, soils are fertile enough for
productive agriculture. Beyond this, infertile desert soils prevent
viable farming.

</div>

Amazingly, floods can be good. Flood waters carry nutrients that are
deposited on the floodplain. So floodplains are good places for farming.
In the past, the Nile River ( **Figure**
[above](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1OaWxlRmxvb2RwbGFpblNvaWw.) ) in Egypt
flooded each year. The flood waters brought much-needed nutrients in to
farms. In the 1960s Egypt built the Aswan Dam to protects crop and
settlements from the floods. However, after the dam was built, farmers
began to need fertilizers to feed their crops.

“Floods 101” is a National Geographic video found in Environment Video,
Natural Disasters, Landslides, and more:
[http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/player/environment/]() .

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._9-ptx}

-   Too much water in a drainage will result in a flood.
-   Floods are made worse when vegetation is cleared, when the land is
    already soaked, or when hillsides have been logged.
-   People build dams and levees to protect from flooding. In an
    emergency, sandbags can be put out.
-   Floods are a source of nutrients on a floodplain.

# Glaciers {#7.html#x-ck12-R2xhY2llcnM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the formation, movement, and characteristics of glaciers.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601419] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025802766773.jpeg)
</span>

**Can solid ice really move?**

Yes! This is the Hubbard Glacier in Alaska. As the glacier meets the
relatively warm seawater, it calves. Pieces of the glacier break off and
fall into the water. These icebergs may be as large as a ten-story
building.

### Where are the Glaciers? {#7.html#x-ck12-V2hlcmUgYXJlIHRoZSBHbGFjaWVycz8._10-oa0}

Nearly all glacial ice is in the polar regions. The largest ice sheets
are in Antarctica and Greenland. The remaining 1% of Earth's ice is
found elsewhere, like in the mountains, for example. At higher
altitudes, temperatures are colder. Snow is more likely to fall and not
melt. Except Australia, every continent has glaciers in the high
mountains.

### Types of Glaciers {#7.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgR2xhY2llcnM._10-vkt}

The types of glaciers are:

-   **Continental glaciers** are large ice sheets that cover relatively
    flat ground. These glaciers flow outward from where the greatest
    amounts of snow and ice accumulate.
-   **Alpine (valley) glaciers** flow downhill. Ice accumulates near the
    top of a mountain and then travels down existing valleys (
    **Figure**
    [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy0wOC0wNy0wMC1Td2lzcy1HbGFjaWVy) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-N2U4MWZjNzdiYWZhYjhlNTFkYjVlZGQ5YzJiZWI3ZDQ.-9y2"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Frank Paul, University of Zurich, NASA Goddard Photo and Video" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/39463459@N08/3679540914/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![An alpine glacier in the Swiss
Alps](ck12_7_files/20150911025802824893.jpeg "An alpine glacier in the Swiss Alps")

**Figure 7.30**

An alpine glacier in the Swiss Alps. Where do you think the word
"alpine" came from?

</div>

-   **Ice caps** are large glaciers that cover a larger area than just
    a valley. An ice cap can bury an entire mountain range or region (
    **Figure**
    [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BbnRhcmN0aWNhR2xvYmVWaWV3) ).
    Glaciers come off of ice caps into valleys.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-Nzg3N2U4MGQyNmVhZjY2MzA2N2Q4MjQ3ZjQyNzM1Njg.-cq1"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Global_View_of_the_Arctic_and_Antarctic.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The continent of Antarctica is covered with an ice
cap](ck12_7_files/20150911025802882660.jpeg "The continent of Antarctica is covered with an ice cap")

**Figure 7.31**

The continent of Antarctica is covered with an ice cap.

</div>

### Glacial Growth {#7.html#x-ck12-R2xhY2lhbCBHcm93dGg._10-awd}

Glaciers are not static; they grow, they move and they shrink.
Currently, most glaciers are shrinking.

#### Formation {#7.html#x-ck12-Rm9ybWF0aW9u_10-fy9}

Glaciers grow when snowfall exceeds melting. Snow falls higher on the
glacier. Over time, the snow converts to granular ice known as firn. As
more snow and ice collect, the firn becomes denser. This is now glacial
ice.

Glaciers form only on land because water is too warm. When a glacier
flows into water, it usually breaks up into icebergs. Those icebergs
eventually melt into the water.

#### Movement {#7.html#x-ck12-TW92ZW1lbnQ._10-6z4}

How does an ice field become a glacier? In other words, why does the ice
move? Whether an ice field moves depends on the amount of ice. It also
depends on the steepness of the slope and the roughness of the ground
surface. Ice moves where the pressure is so great that the ice needs to
move away. Ice also slides at the bottom. Often the ground is lubricated
by water that melted from the glacier above. Under some conditions, a
glacier will move extremely fast. Under other conditions, the glacier
may not move and will become an ice sheet.

Because the ice is moving, glaciers have cracks called **crevasses** (
**Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Ccmlrc2RhbHNicmVlbkdsYWNpZXI.) ).
There is a large crevasse at the top of an alpine glacier called a
**bergshrund** . Below the bergshrund, the ice is moving downhill. Above
the bergshrund, the ice is stuck to the mountain.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MWViZWVjYmRkMGFmOTc1NjNkNGFiNjc0MWE2MzIzYzU.-nu6"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:jirihnidek" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/jirihnidek/2775593054/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Crevasses in a glacier are the result of
movement](ck12_7_files/20150911025802947692.jpeg "Crevasses in a glacier are the result of movement")

**Figure 7.32**

Crevasses in a glacier are the result of movement.

</div>

#### Shrinking {#7.html#x-ck12-U2hyaW5raW5n_10-xsa}

Glaciers are melting back in many locations around the world. When a
glacier no longer moves, it is called an ice sheet. This usually happens
when it is less than 0.1 km2 in area and 50 m thick.

In Glacier National Park ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy1HcmlubmVsbEdsYWNpZXI.) ), many glaciers
have become ice sheets. In 1850, the park had 150 glaciers. There are
only about 25 today. The reason that there is so much melting is that
summer temperatures have risen. Scientists estimate that the park will
have no active glaciers as early as 2020.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-YjExMmE1NzE0ZmU3ZmU4MDY4MmYxZWQ1ODIzNTRiNzI.-k6a"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Robert Simmon, NASA's Earth Observatory, using ALI data from the EO-1 team and Global Land Ice Measurements from Space" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=43942" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Satellite image of Glacier National Park, and its shrinking
glaciers](ck12_7_files/20150911025803000367.jpeg "Satellite image of Glacier National Park, and its shrinking glaciers")

**Figure 7.33**

This satellite image shows Grinnell Glacier, Swiftcurrent Glacier, and
Gem Glacier in 2003. The outlines show the extent of the glaciers in
1950. Gem Glacier is only 0.020 km ^2^ (5 acres) in area. This makes it
about one-fifth the size of the smallest active glaciers. Is Gem really
a glacier?

</div>

### Glaciers as a Resource {#7.html#x-ck12-R2xhY2llcnMgYXMgYSBSZXNvdXJjZQ.._10-e4r}

Melting glaciers in mountain regions provide an important source of
water in the summer. Organisms and nearby human populations may depend
on glacial melt water during long dry summers. People near the Andes in
South America are just some of the groups that rely on glacial meltwater
in the summer.

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-mhl}

-   Glaciers are ice that moves.
-   Continental glaciers form in a central location with ice moving
    outward in all directions. Alpine glaciers form in high mountains
    and travel through valleys. Ice caps cover large areas.
-   Because glaciers move, they have characteristic features like
    crevasses and bergshrunds.

### Explore More {#7.html#x-ck12-RXhwbG9yZSBNb3Jl_10-afk}

# Introduction to Groundwater {#7.html#x-ck12-SW50cm9kdWN0aW9uIHRvIEdyb3VuZHdhdGVy}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define aquifer and explain how aquifers form and recharge.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601425] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025803068160.jpeg)
</span>

**What are these faucets tapping into?**

This certainly is an odd sight! We expect to see water at Earth's
surface, but coming out of solid rock? Amazingly, much of Earth's fresh
water is hidden from sight. It is present in rock and soil. In fact, 20
times more of Earth’s liquid freshwater is found below the surface than
on the surface.

### Groundwater {#7.html#x-ck12-R3JvdW5kd2F0ZXI._11-lpx}

Freshwater below Earth’s surface is called **groundwater** . The water
infiltrates, or seeps down into, the ground from the surface. How does
this happen? And where does the water go?

#### Porous and Impermeable Rock {#7.html#x-ck12-UG9yb3VzIGFuZCBJbXBlcm1lYWJsZSBSb2Nr_11-zpj}

Water infiltrates the ground because soil and rock may have air spaces
between the grains. These pores, or tiny holes, result in the rock's
**porosity** . If water can move through a rock, the rock is
**permeable** . Eventually, the water reaches a layer of rock that is
not porous. This rock is **impermeable** . Water stops moving downward
when it reaches an impermeable layer.

This animation shows porosity and permeability:
[http://www.nature.nps.gov/GEOLOGY/usgsnps/animate/POROS\_3.MPG](POROS_3.MPG)
. The water droplets are found in the pores between the sediment grains.
This is porosity. When the water can travel between pores, that’s
permeability.

The diagram below ( **Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XZWxs)
) shows two layers of porous rock. The top layer is not saturated; it is
not full of water. The next layer is saturated. The water in this layer
has nowhere else to go. It cannot seep any deeper into the ground
because the rock below it is impermeable.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-ZWJhYTM2MDRiNmI3ZGE5MzQ2YmE0ODVhY2QxZDdlN2Q.-5pw"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Geoff Ruth and Hana Zavadska" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of an
aquifer](ck12_7_files/20150911025803150133.jpeg "Diagram of an aquifer")

**Figure 7.34**

Water seeps into the ground through permeable material. The water stops
when it reaches an impermeable rock. Predict the purpose of the well in
the diagram.

</div>

#### The Water Table {#7.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFdhdGVyIFRhYmxl_11-gnx}

The top of the saturated rock layer above ( **Figure**
[above](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XZWxs) ) is called the **water table**
. The water table isn’t like a real table. It doesn’t remain firmly in
one place. Instead, it rises or falls, depending on how much water seeps
down from the surface. The water table is higher when there is a lot of
rain, and it is lower when the weather is dry.

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._11-iuq}

-   Water infiltrates into the ground.
-   There is much more fresh water underground than on the surface.
-   A rock layer must be porous and permeable to be a good aquifer. An
    impermeable layer makes up the bottom of an aquifer.
-   The water table rises and falls with additions or subtractions to
    the groundwater system.

# Groundwater Aquifers {#7.html#x-ck12-R3JvdW5kd2F0ZXIgQXF1aWZlcnM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the features of an aquifer.
-   Define water table and explain how changes in the water table occur.
-   Explain how springs are created.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601430] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025803218599.jpeg)
</span>

**Do you take water for granted?**

In some parts of the world, gathering water for the family is a process
that takes several hours. This is usually considered to be women's work.
What are you doing during the hours that girls your age might be helping
their mothers gather water?

### Aquifer {#7.html#x-ck12-QXF1aWZlcg.._12-nfh}

An underground layer of rock that is saturated with groundwater is
called an **aquifer** . A diagram of an aquifer is pictured below (
**Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMTItQXF1aWZlcg..) ).
Aquifers are generally found in porous rock, such as sandstone. Water
infiltrates the aquifer from the surface. The water that enters the
aquifer is called **recharge** .

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-ZGMxMTZhZWNmZTBlNTUwZWE4YzM0OGJmOTMxNzhlZGM.-8es"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of an
aquifer](ck12_7_files/20150911025803272587.jpeg "Diagram of an aquifer")

**Figure 7.35**

An aquifer is a layer of saturated porous rock. It lies below the water
table. An impermeable layer, such as clay, is below the aquifer.

</div>

#### Human Use of Aquifers {#7.html#x-ck12-SHVtYW4gVXNlIG9mIEFxdWlmZXJz_12-9eb}

Most land areas have aquifers beneath them. Many aquifers are used by
people for fresh water. The closer to the surface an aquifer is, the
easier it is to get the water. However, an aquifer close to the surface
is also more likely to become polluted. Pollutants can seep down through
porous rock in recharge water.

An aquifer that is used by people may not be recharged as quickly as its
water is removed. The water table may lower and the aquifer may even run
dry. If this happens, the ground above the aquifer may sink. This is
likely to damage any homes or other structures built above the aquifer.

#### Wells {#7.html#x-ck12-V2VsbHM._12-j7p}

Most groundwater does not flow out of an aquifer as a spring or geyser.
So to use the water that's stored in an aquifer, people must go after
it. How? They dig a well. A **well** ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMTgtV2F0ZXItV2VsbA..) ) is a hole
that is dug or drilled through the ground down to an aquifer.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NTMxMzMxNjdjOGJiOTIxY2JmNGQwMGZkNTc5MTM5OWI.-bts"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of the next
well](ck12_7_files/20150911025803337648.jpeg "Diagram of the next well")

**Figure 7.36**

A well runs from the surface to a point below the water table. Why must
a well go lower than the water table?

</div>

People have depended on water from wells for thousands of years. To
bring water to the surface takes energy because the force of gravity
must be overcome. Today, many wells use electricity to pump water to the
surface. However, in some places, water is still brought to the surface
the old-fashioned way—with human labor. The well pictured below (
**Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XYXRlcldlbGw.) ) is an
example of this type of well. A hand-cranked pulley is used to lift the
bucket of water to the surface.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MGY5OTJjNGMxY2ExODMwNTI1ZDRmNjcyODUzZWMyY2Q.-5it"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Wadas Jerzy, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![This old water well uses human muscle power to bring water to the
surface](ck12_7_files/20150911025803392803.jpeg "This old water well uses human muscle power to bring water to the surface")

**Figure 7.37**

This old water well uses human muscle power to bring water to the
surface.

</div>

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-alc}

-   An aquifer is a saturated layer of rock or soil.
-   Most groundwater use is from wells.
-   People use fresh water from aquifers from springs or wells.

# Springs and Geysers {#7.html#x-ck12-U3ByaW5ncyBhbmQgR2V5c2Vycw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the features of an aquifer.
-   Explain how springs are created.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601437] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025803466277.jpeg)
</span>

**A sacred spring**

At Tampak Siring in Bali, Indonesia, spring water emerges into a temple.
The water is thought to have healing powers. Many Hindu people come to
the temple to emerge in the water and pray. They hope the water will
cure their diseases.

### Springs {#7.html#x-ck12-U3ByaW5ncw.._13-vnh}

The top of an aquifer may be high enough in some places to meet the
surface of the ground. This often happens on a slope. The water flows
out of the ground and creates a **spring** . A spring may be just a tiny
trickle, or it may be a big gush of water.

Water flowing out of the ground at a spring may flow downhill and enter
a stream. If the water from a spring can’t flow downhill, it may spread
out to form a pond or lake instead. In the desert, the only reliable
water may be from springs ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1OZXZhZGFOYXR1cmFsU3ByaW5n) ). A spring
may allow wildlife to inhabit an uninhabitable area.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-Yzg5NWVhZjcwZjk3NjIyZTE2ZTE4Y2IxYzI0NjBjN2M.-5yu"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright trekandshoot, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![A desert oasis is created by a spring in
Nevada](ck12_7_files/20150911025803532282.jpeg "A desert oasis is created by a spring in Nevada")

**Figure 7.38**

A desert oasis is created by a spring in Nevada.

</div>

#### Artesian Spring {#7.html#x-ck12-QXJ0ZXNpYW4gU3ByaW5n_13-bzi}

Sometimes an aquifer is confined. A confined aquifer is trapped between
two impermeable rock layers. Pressure from the rock layer on top forces
the water out where the aquifer reaches the ground surface. Water that
flows up to the surface naturally is an **artesian spring** . If people
drill a well into a confined aquifer, the water may flow to the surface
without assistance. This is an artesian well ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HZXJtYW5XZWxs) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-ZTM5NmQ2OGQ1ZmE4ZGE2YmIwMTA0Y2Y2MjJkYjRjNTM.-ktg"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Benjamin Davidson" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/tukanuk/2817796858/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![An artesian well supplies the water for this
fountain](ck12_7_files/20150911025803594146.jpeg "An artesian well supplies the water for this fountain")

**Figure 7.39**

This artesian well supplies the water for Schönbrunn Palace in Germany.

</div>

#### Mineral Springs and Hot Springs {#7.html#x-ck12-TWluZXJhbCBTcHJpbmdzIGFuZCBIb3QgU3ByaW5ncw.._13-bsi}

Some springs have water that contains minerals. Groundwater dissolves
minerals out of the rock as it seeps through the pores. The water in
some springs is hot because it is heated by hot magma. Many hot springs
are also mineral springs. That’s because hot water can dissolve more
minerals than cold water.

Springs in Yellowstone National Park are hot and contain dissolved
minerals. Morning Glory Pool ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1ZZWxsb3dzdG9uZU1vcm5pbmdHbG9yeVBvb2w.)
) has a bright green color from dissolved minerals. Along the edge are
thick orange mats of bacteria. The bacteria use the minerals in the hot
water to make food.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-OGVhMTk0MzNjMjBkNDEwNDcyODhiOGExMGQ3ZWQ3OGE.-3ye"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Matt Howry (Flickr:mhowry)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mhowry/617743389/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Morning Glory Pool in Yellowstone National Park is a mineral
spring](ck12_7_files/20150911025803651989.jpeg "Morning Glory Pool in Yellowstone National Park is a mineral spring")

**Figure 7.40**

Morning Glory Pool in Yellowstone National Park is a mineral spring.

</div>

### Geysers {#7.html#x-ck12-R2V5c2Vycw.._13-uzk}

Heated groundwater may become trapped in spaces within rocks. Pressure
builds up as more water seeps into the spaces. When the pressure becomes
great enough, the water bursts out of the ground at a crack or weak
spot. This is called a **geyser** . When the water erupts from the
ground, the pressure is released. Then more water collects and the
pressure builds up again. This leads to another eruption.

Old Faithful ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1PbGRGYWl0aGZ1bA..) ) is the best-known
geyser in the world. The geyser erupts faithfully every 90 minutes, day
after day. During each eruption, it may release as much as 30,000 liters
of water!

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MmJiZDIwOGQ2MjBmMDY4MTQzNDcwNmJiM2IyY2ZjMDI.-oin"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="John Sullivan" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Old_faithful_geyser.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Old Faithful is a geyser in Yellowstone National
Park](ck12_7_files/20150911025803715650.jpeg "Old Faithful is a geyser in Yellowstone National Park")

**Figure 7.41**

Old Faithful in Yellowstone National Park is a geyser named for its
regular cycle of eruptions.

</div>

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._13-ycz}

-   Earth's internal heat can create a hot spring.
-   If hot water becomes trapped, pressure may build up. When the water
    breaks free, it creates a geyser.

# Groundwater Depletion {#7.html#x-ck12-R3JvdW5kd2F0ZXIgRGVwbGV0aW9u}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain the causes and consequences of groundwater depletion.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601447] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025803766150.jpeg)
</span>

**What makes the desert bloom? Water!**

You hear a lot about making the desert bloom. Many plants do well in the
desert if they are given water. Since deserts do not have much water,
groundwater is used. In many desert locations, groundwater is being
pumped much faster than it is being recharged. What will happen in the
future?

### Human Use of Aquifers {#7.html#x-ck12-SHVtYW4gVXNlIG9mIEFxdWlmZXJz_14-lin}

Most land areas have aquifers beneath them. Many aquifers are used by
people for freshwater. The closer to the surface an aquifer is, the
easier it is to get the water. However, an aquifer close to the surface
is also more likely to become polluted. Pollutants can seep down through
porous rock in recharge water.

People may use the water in an aquifer faster than it is recharged. When
this happens, the water table will lower. Wells may go dry. To get to
the water, the well will need to be dug deeper.

As the water table lowers, the ground above the aquifer may sink. This
is called **subsidence** . When the ground subsides, any homes or other
structures built above the aquifer will be damaged. The San Joaquin
Valley of California is one of the world’s major agricultural areas. So
much groundwater has been pumped that the land has subsided many tens of
feet.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NzA4MzBkY2Y2NGFhOGYzNjFiMTBlN2M0ZmRkMGE5ZWQ.-nog"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Gwsanjoaquin.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Subsidence due to groundwater
depletion](ck12_7_files/20150911025803827350.jpeg "Subsidence due to groundwater depletion")

**Figure 7.42**

The signs on the pole show where ground level was at different years.
The subsidence is due to groundwater depletion.

</div>

#### The Ogallala Aquifer {#7.html#x-ck12-VGhlIE9nYWxsYWxhIEFxdWlmZXI._14-0qb}

One of the biggest aquifers in the world is the Ogallala aquifer. As you
can see below ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMTMtT2dhbGxhbGEtQXF1aWZlcg..) ), this
aquifer lies beneath parts of eight U.S. states. In some places, it is
less than a meter deep. In other places, it is hundreds of meters deep.
The water in the aquifer is mostly from the last ice age.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-MWVhMDM2MDI1OGUwNjNhMzZiZmZjNzYyYTBiMDRmYWM.-spg"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Aquifer map courtesy of US Geological Survey; composite created by CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@url="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ogallala_Aquifer_map.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Aquifer map is in the public domain" -->
![Map of the Ogallala
aquifer](ck12_7_files/20150911025803885998.jpeg "Map of the Ogallala aquifer")

**Figure 7.43**

In this map, the area over the Ogallala aquifer is shaded in blue.

</div>

The Ogallala aquifer is an important source of freshwater in the
American Midwest. This is a major farming area, and much of the water is
used to irrigate crops. The water in this aquifer is being used up ten
times faster than it is recharged. If this continues, what might happen
to the Ogallala aquifer?

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-qle}

-   When water is pumped from an aquifer, the water table goes down.
    Wells must be drilled deeper to get water.
-   The Ogallala Aquifer was filled in the ice age. It is heavily used
    to irrigate Midwestern farms. The use rate is several times faster
    than the recharge rate.
-   Ground subsidence is a consequences of groundwater overuse.

# Water Pollution {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgUG9sbHV0aW9u}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the sources of water pollution.
-   Describe the causes and consequences of unsafe water.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601454] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025803946762.jpeg)
</span>

**Do you live near water? Do you see pollution?**

Water pollution is a worldwide problem. Almost anything released into
the air or onto the land can end up in Earth’s water.

### Surface Water Pollution {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VyZmFjZSBXYXRlciBQb2xsdXRpb24._15-fwn}

Water pollution may come from one source. For example, chemicals from a
factory may empty into a stream. Water pollution may come from more than
one source, too. For example, chemicals may rain from the air into that
same stream. It is much more difficult to control pollution from more
than one source.

In the developed nations there are three main sources of water
pollution:

1.  Agriculture.
2.  Industry.
3.  Municipal, or community.

#### Agriculture {#7.html#x-ck12-QWdyaWN1bHR1cmU._15-ei3}

Chemicals that are applied to farm fields include fertilizers and
pesticides. Excess chemicals can be picked up by rainwater. The
chemicals can end up in streams, ponds, lakes, or the ocean. Dissolved
fertilizer causes tremendous numbers of water plants and algae to grow.
This can lead to dead zones where nothing can live in lakes or the
coastal oceans.

Waste from livestock can also pollute water. The waste contains
**pathogens** that can cause diseases. Many farms in the U.S. have
thousands of animals. These farms produce millions of gallons of waste.
The waste is stored in huge lagoons, like the one pictured below (
**Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjAtMTEtbWFudXJlLWxhZ29vbg..)
). Many leaks from these lagoons have occurred.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-M2M4NThhMmUxN2ZhYmI2Y2Q3MGNkM2QwOWJlYjlhOWM.-4ed"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Photo by Copterviews.com, courtesy of USDA Agricultural Research Services" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.ars.usda.gov/is/graphics/photos/mar05/d033-1.htm" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A pond of hog
manure](ck12_7_files/20150911025804022512.jpeg "A pond of hog manure")

**Figure 7.44**

This is a pond of hog manure. Check out the vehicles at the bottom of
the picture for scale.

</div>

#### Industry {#7.html#x-ck12-SW5kdXN0cnk._15-p3j}

Factories and power plants may pollute water with harmful substances.

-   Many industries produce toxic chemicals.
-   Nuclear power plants produce **radioactive** wastes.
-   Oil tanks and pipelines can leak.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-ZTY2NDVlYjc1YTBkYWNmODgxZTViMDAxOGUzZGQ5NTg.-y3g"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Marine Photobank" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Oiled_Bird_-_Black_Sea_Oil_Spill_111207.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Duck coated by oil
spill](ck12_7_files/20150911025804089050.jpeg "Duck coated by oil spill")

**Figure 7.45**

Oil spills are hard to clean up and kill a lot of wildlife.

</div>

#### Municipal {#7.html#x-ck12-TXVuaWNpcGFs_15-cx9}

“Municipal” refers to the community. Households and businesses in a
community can pollute the water supply. Municipal pollution comes from
sewage, storm drains, septic tanks, boats, and runoff from yards. For
example:

-   People apply chemicals to their lawns. The excess can run off into
    surface waters.
-   People may dispose of harmful substances incorrectly. For example,
    motor oil must not be drained into a storm sewer.
-   Municipal sewage treatment plants dump treated wastewater into
    rivers or lakes. But the wastewater may not be treated for
    everything, or it may not be treated enough.

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._15-brk}

-   Pollution enters water from municipal, industrial,
    agricultural sources.
-   Fertilizer runoff can create dead zones in the ocean.
-   People pollute water when they apply excess chemicals to their lawn.
    They may also dispose of pollutants incorrectly.

# Protecting Water From Pollution {#7.html#x-ck12-UHJvdGVjdGluZyBXYXRlciBGcm9tIFBvbGx1dGlvbg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how the water supply can be protected.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601462] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_7_files/20150911025804148523.jpeg)
</span>

**How could a river burn?**

In the mid 1900s, rivers sometimes caught fire. The Cuyahoga River did
several times. The river was so full of oil and industrial waste that it
was flammable. Nothing could live in it. A fire on the Cuyahoga River in
1969 gained national attention. Something had to be done to protect the
water supply.

### Protecting the Water Supply {#7.html#x-ck12-UHJvdGVjdGluZyB0aGUgV2F0ZXIgU3VwcGx5_16-k6m}

The water supply can be harmed in two major ways. The water can be
polluted, and it can be overused. Protecting the water supply must
address both problems. We need to reduce how much pollution ends up in
the water supply—keeping water from being polluted is easier and cheaper
than cleaning it. We need to treat water that’s already polluted. We
need to conserve water by using less.

### Controlling Water Pollution {#7.html#x-ck12-Q29udHJvbGxpbmcgV2F0ZXIgUG9sbHV0aW9u_16-i8f}

Disasters, such as rivers burning, led to new U.S. laws to protect the
water. For example, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) was
established, and the Clean Water Act was passed. Now, water is routinely
tested. Pollution is tracked to its source, and polluters are forced to
fix the problem and clean up the pollution. They are also fined. These
consequences have led industries, agriculture, and communities to
pollute the water much less than before.

#### The Clean Water Act {#7.html#x-ck12-VGhlIENsZWFuIFdhdGVyIEFjdA.._16-5az}

Keeping water clean often requires laws. Laws ensure that people behave
responsibly. The Clean Water Act regulates water pollution in the U.S.
The law allows the EPA to set standards for water quality. The EPA
regulates the pollutants that can enter waterways. The agency can
provide money for wastewater treatment plants. The law was passed in
1972.

International groups are trying to improve global water quality. The
United Nations and other groups provide the technology for treating
water. They educate people in how to protect and improve their water (
**Figure** [below](#7.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XYXRlclNhbXBsaW5n) ).

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-NWM3ZDQwNzEyNGJhODU4OTlkOGRlZjFmOTNjNmI5ODY.-a7d"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:AdmlCrunch" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/admlcrunch/2239508737/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Scientists studying water
pollution](ck12_7_files/20150911025804222951.jpeg "Scientists studying water pollution")

**Figure 7.46**

Scientists control water pollution by sampling the water and studying
the pollutants that are in the water.

</div>

### Water Treatment {#7.html#x-ck12-V2F0ZXIgVHJlYXRtZW50_16-iwr}

Water treatment is a series of processes that remove unwanted substances
from water. The goal of water treatment is to make the water safe to
return to the natural environment or to the human water supply. Treating
water for other purposes may not include all the same steps. That’s
because water used in agriculture or industry may not have to be as
clean as drinking water.

Below, you can see how water for drinking is treated ( **Figure**
[below](#7.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjEtMTctd2F0ZXItdHJlYXRtZW50LXBsYW50) ).
Treating drinking water requires at least four processes:

1.  Chemicals are added to untreated water. They cause solids in the
    water to clump together. This is called **coagulation** .
2.  The water is moved to tanks. The clumped solids sink to the bottom
    of the water. This is called **sedimentation** .
3.  The water is passed through filters that remove smaller particles
    from the water. This is called **filtration** .
4.  Chlorine is added to the water to kill bacteria and other microbes.
    This is called **disinfection** . Finally, the water is pure enough
    to drink.

<div id="7.html#x-ck12-YmJmYjk0YmFmZTQxMzhjOGNhMjk1Mjk4OWEzNDBiMmE.-jyp"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US EPA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://water.epa.gov/learn/kids/drinkingwater/watertreatmentplant_index.cfm" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, and disinfection are the four
steps of treating
water](ck12_7_files/20150911025804279905.png "Coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, and disinfection are the four steps of treating water")

**Figure 7.47**

Four processes are used to treat water to make it safe for drinking.

</div>

### What Can You Do? {#7.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBDYW4gWW91IERvPw.._16-cfl}

What can individuals do to protect water quality?

-   Dispose of motor oil and household chemicals properly. Phone your
    community for instructions.
-   Use lawn, garden, and farm chemicals sparingly. Use them wisely.
    Excess chemicals will run off into the water supply.
-   Repair automobile or boat engine leaks immediately.
-   Keep litter, pet waste, leaves, and grass clippings out of street
    gutters and storm drains.

### Summary {#7.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._16-ovk}

-   There are multiple levels of water treatment. Some water is cleaned
    enough for use on lawns. Some must be made safe for drinking.
-   Individuals can protect water by following some guidelines.
-   The Clean Water Act regulates pollutants and provides money for
    wastewater treatment plants to be built.
-   Keeping water from becoming polluted is easier, less expensive, and
    safer than cleaning it once it is polluted.
