# Mesosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-TWVzb3NwaGVyZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the mesosphere.
-   Describe the phenomena that appear in the mesosphere.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601560] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025824984907.jpeg)
</span>

**Next up: A field trip to the mesosophere!**

Not so fast. The mesosphere is the least known layer of the atmosphere.
The mesosphere lies above the highest altitude an airplane can go. It
lies below the lowest altitude a spacecraft can orbit. Maybe that's just
as well. If you were in the mesosphere without a space suit, your blood
would boil! This is because the pressure is so low that liquids would
boil at normal body temperature.

### Mesosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-TWVzb3NwaGVyZQ.._6-x2e}

The **mesosphere** is the layer above the stratosphere. It rises to
about 85 kilometers (53 miles) above the surface. Temperature decreases
with altitude in this layer.

#### Temperature in the Mesosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-VGVtcGVyYXR1cmUgaW4gdGhlIE1lc29zcGhlcmU._6-w0t}

There are very few gas molecules in the mesosphere. This means that
there is little matter to absorb the Sun’s rays and heat the air. Most
of the heat that enters the mesosphere comes from the stratosphere
below. That’s why the mesosphere is warmest at the bottom.

#### Meteors in the Mesosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-TWV0ZW9ycyBpbiB0aGUgTWVzb3NwaGVyZQ.._6-klf}

Did you ever see a meteor shower ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QZXJzZWlkTWV0ZW9yU2hvd2Vy) )? Meteors
burn as they fall through the mesosphere. The space rocks experience
friction with the gas molecules. The friction makes the meteors get very
hot. Many meteors burn up completely in the mesosphere.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-M2M4NTc3ODI3ZmRkM2RjOWE4NDdhNGM2MjhmMzg4MjM.-un3"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:mLu" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/luppes777/9500098785/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![The Perseid meteor
shower](ck12_8_files/20150911025825037859.jpeg "The Perseid meteor shower")

**Figure 8.10**

The Perseid meteor shower with the Milky Way.

</div>

#### Red Sprites and Blue Jets {#8.html#x-ck12-UmVkIFNwcml0ZXMgYW5kIEJsdWUgSmV0cw.._6-pko}

Red sprites and blue jets are electrical discharges ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1SZWRTcHJpdGVCbHVlSmV0Mg..) ). They are
not the same thing as lightning. They more closely resemble the
discharges seen in fluorescent tubes. These events occur much higher up
in the atmosphere than lightning.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-OGY3OTBmOWRkMTE5ODU5MTE5M2M0MWExM2YyYjAzM2Y.-jou"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Lightning_sprites.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Altitude of blue jets and red
sprites](ck12_8_files/20150911025825093902.jpeg "Altitude of blue jets and red sprites")

**Figure 8.11**

Red sprites occur higher in the atmosphere than blue jets, while both
occur higher than lightning.

</div>

#### Polar Mesospheric Clouds {#8.html#x-ck12-UG9sYXIgTWVzb3NwaGVyaWMgQ2xvdWRz_6-3ng}

Clouds in the mesosphere are very rare. The ones that exist occur near
the poles. The clouds are called **polar mesospheric clouds** . At the
edge of these clouds are noctilucent clouds ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Ob2N0aWx1Y2VudENsb3Vkcw..) ). They are
forming more often now, perhaps as a result of climate change.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-NmJmMzJkOTM3NzJiOWI2ODdkZWEyMjlkYzQ0NzczZTQ.-sve"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Zufzzi/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Noctilucent_clouds_near_Moscow.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Noctilucent clouds in the
mesosphere](ck12_8_files/20150911025825153847.jpeg "Noctilucent clouds in the mesosphere")

**Figure 8.12**

Noctilucent clouds are the highest clouds in the atmosphere.

</div>

#### Mesopause {#8.html#x-ck12-TWVzb3BhdXNl_6-yjc}

At the top of the mesosphere is the mesopause. Temperatures here are
colder than anywhere else in the atmosphere. They are as low as -100° C
(-212° F)! Nowhere on Earth’s surface is it that cold.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._6-r2d}

-   The mesosphere has a very low density of gas molecules.
-   Temperature decreases in the mesosphere with altitude. This is
    because the heat source is the stratosphere.
-   The mesosphere has red sprites, blue jets, and two types of clouds.
-   The mesosphere is no place for human life!

# Thermosphere and Beyond {#8.html#x-ck12-VGhlcm1vc3BoZXJlIGFuZCBCZXlvbmQ.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of the thermosphere.
-   Explain how aurora form.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601564] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025825209349.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you take a field trip to the thermosphere? Maybe some day!**

The inhabitants of the International Space Station and other space
stations live in the thermosphere. They are not directly in the
thermosphere, of course. They must be inside the station or inside a
space suit at all times. Maybe some day you will join them!

### Thermosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-VGhlcm1vc3BoZXJl_7-sz0}

The **thermosphere** is the layer above the mesosphere. It rises to 600
kilometers (372 miles) above the surface. The International Space
Station and other space stations orbit Earth in this layer.

#### Temperature in the Thermosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-VGVtcGVyYXR1cmUgaW4gdGhlIFRoZXJtb3NwaGVyZQ.._7-hep}

Temperature increases with altitude in the thermosphere. Surprisingly,
it may be higher than 1000° C (1800° F) near the top of this layer! The
Sun’s energy there is very strong. The molecules absorb the Sun’s energy
and are heated up. But there are so few gas molecules that the air still
feels very cold. Molecules in the thermosphere gain or lose electrons.
They then become charged particles called ions.

#### Magnetosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-TWFnbmV0b3NwaGVyZQ.._7-lci}

Earth's **magnetosphere** is controlled by the magnetic field. The
magnetosphere protects the planet from the **solar wind** . The solar
wind is ions that fly from the Sun to Earth very fast. The magnetosphere
protects Earth's ozone layer. So life on Earth needs the protection of
the magnetosphere.

#### Northern and Southern Lights {#8.html#x-ck12-Tm9ydGhlcm4gYW5kIFNvdXRoZXJuIExpZ2h0cw.._7-6vi}

Have you ever seen a brilliant light show in the night sky? Sometimes
the ions in the thermosphere glow at night. Storms on the Sun energize
the ions and make them light up. In the Northern Hemisphere, the lights
are called the northern lights, or aurora borealis. In the Southern
Hemisphere, they are called southern lights, or aurora australis. They
are referred to together as the **aurora** ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BdXJvcmFGcm9tRWFydGg.) and **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BdXJvcmFGcm9tU3BhY2U.) ).

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-Nzc3ZDNhMmQ5YWVlYjFlNjA1YjQzNjdjMTk0YTVjOWE.-wqh"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:zhengxu" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/efz3x/231570209/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of the aurora
borealis](ck12_8_files/20150911025825280474.jpeg "Picture of the aurora borealis")

**Figure 8.13**

The aurora as seen from the Northern Hemisphere, known as the Aurora
Borealis.

</div>

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-YTgyN2U0MzU2MmJiNzY4NzhhZjUyOGM0NGU2MjY4MDc.-5vd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

.

[![](ck12_8_files/tmpNkNt3c.jpeg)](o6soo_lFbGI%3Fwmode%3Dtransparent%26rel%3D0%26hash%3D80c376da866ce14ada67e11faba680d0)

Click on the image above for more content

### Exosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-RXhvc3BoZXJl_7-i2i}

The **exosphere** is the layer above the thermosphere. This is the top
of the atmosphere. The exosphere has no real upper limit; it just
gradually merges with outer space. Gas molecules are very far apart in
this layer, but they are really hot. Earth’s gravity is so weak in the
exosphere that gas molecules sometimes just float off into space.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._7-70v}

-   The solar wind is made of high speed particles from the Sun. The
    magnetosphere protects Earth from the solar wind.
-   Particles from the Sun energize ions in the thermosphere. This
    creates the northern and southern lights.
-   Gas molecules are exceedingly rare in the exosphere.

# Electromagnetic Energy in the Atmosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-RWxlY3Ryb21hZ25ldGljIEVuZXJneSBpbiB0aGUgQXRtb3NwaGVyZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify types of energy.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601567] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025825399444.jpeg)
</span>

**Where can you find energy?**

Picture yourself sitting by the campfire. You and your family are using
the fire to stay warm on a chilly evening. As the Sun goes down, the air
gets colder. You move closer to the fire. Heat from the fire warms you.
Light from the fire allows you to see your relatives. Maybe you put
marshmallows on a stick and roast them. Yum.

### What Is Energy? {#8.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBJcyBFbmVyZ3k__8-woa}

What explains all of these events? The answer can be summed up in one
word: energy. **Energy** is defined as the ability to do work. Doing
anything takes energy. A campfire obviously has energy. You can feel its
heat and see its light. You can use its energy to cook food.

#### Forms of Energy {#8.html#x-ck12-Rm9ybXMgb2YgRW5lcmd5_8-zci}

Heat and light from the campfire are forms of energy. There are many
other forms of energy. Here are a few that are important in Earth
science:

-   chemical energy: Energy that is let off after a chemical reaction.
-   luminous energy: Also called light.
-   nuclear energy: Energy that is let off when the atom of a nucleus
    is split.
-   radiant energy: Energy of electromagnetic radiation. This is the
    topic of the concept "Solar Energy on Earth."
-   sound energy: Energy from sound waves.
-   thermal energy: Also called heat.

#### Conservation of Energy {#8.html#x-ck12-Q29uc2VydmF0aW9uIG9mIEVuZXJneQ.._8-meu}

Energy cannot be created or destroyed. It can change form. For example,
a piece of wood has chemical energy stored in its molecules. When the
wood burns, the chemical energy changes to heat energy and light energy.

Lightning converts electric potential energy into three kinds of energy.
They are light energy, sound energy, and thermal energy.

You convert food energy to movement ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HaXJsUnVubmluZ1dpdGhBcHBsZQ..) ).
That's another way energy is transferred from one form to another!

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-NzAwYTdhMjgwZTU5YTA5ZGI1MzQzY2JkMGFmZmZmOWY.-zj1"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright dotshock, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![This apple is a source of
energy](ck12_8_files/20150911025825474833.jpeg "This apple is a source of energy")

**Figure 8.15**

If the girl eats this apple it will provide the energy needed for her to
run.

</div>

#### Movement of Energy {#8.html#x-ck12-TW92ZW1lbnQgb2YgRW5lcmd5_8-n4o}

Energy can move from one place to another. It can travel through space
or matter. That’s why you can feel the heat of a campfire and see its
light. These forms of energy travel from the campfire to you.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._8-voz}

-   Energy is the ability to do work.
-   Energy cannot be created or destroyed. Energy can only change forms.
-   Energy can change from one type to more than one type. For example,
    electric potential energy before a lightning strike can turn into
    light, sound, and heat.

# Solar Energy on Earth {#8.html#x-ck12-U29sYXIgRW5lcmd5IG9uIEVhcnRo}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how solar energy moves.
-   Describe the different wavelengths of solar energy.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601571] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025825540893.jpeg)
</span>

**Just how important is this star?**

Almost all energy at Earth's surface comes from the Sun. The Sun’s
energy heats the planet and the air around it. This causes the
atmosphere to move and create weather. Sunlight also powers
photosynthesis and life on Earth.

### The Sun's Energy {#8.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFN1bidzIEVuZXJneQ.._9-jzf}

Most of the energy at Earth's surface comes from the Sun. Solar energy
travels in tiny packets that move in waves. The waves have different
wavelengths. Waves with different wavelengths carry different amounts of
energy.

#### Photons of Energy {#8.html#x-ck12-UGhvdG9ucyBvZiBFbmVyZ3k._9-weu}

The Sun gives off energy in tiny packets called **photons** . Photons
travel in waves. These waves make up **electromagnetic radiation** . The
image below models a wave of light ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XYXZlbGVuZ3Ro) ). Notice the
wavelength in the figure. Waves with shorter wavelengths have more
energy.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-OThiNmMzOTdjMGE0N2NjOGFjYjA2MWVmZWQwNGU5NGQ.-oga"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://science.hq.nasa.gov/kids/imagers/ems/waves3.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of a
wave](ck12_8_files/20150911025825629082.png "Diagram of a wave")

**Figure 8.16**

This curve models a wave. Based on this figure, how would you define
wavelength?

</div>

#### Electromagnetic Spectrum {#8.html#x-ck12-RWxlY3Ryb21hZ25ldGljIFNwZWN0cnVt_9-bxf}

Energy from the Sun has a wide range of wavelengths. The total range of
energy is called the **electromagnetic spectrum** ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMDgtRWxlY3Ryb21hZ25ldGljLXNwZWN0cnVt)
).

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-OTdkYjhmYzU3ODMzZDkzNWUyMjI2ZmM0NTU5ZDgzOGU.-q3k"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of EPA; modified by CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.epa.gov/climatestudents/basics/today/greenhouse-effect.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The electromagnetic
spectrum](ck12_8_files/20150911025825682000.png "The electromagnetic spectrum")

**Figure 8.17**

Compare the wavelengths of radio waves and gamma rays. Which type of
wave has more energy?

</div>

**Visible light** is the only light that humans can see. Different
wavelengths of visible light appear as different colors. Radio waves
have the longest wavelengths. They also have the least amount of energy.
**Infrared light** has wavelengths too long for humans to see, but we
can feel them as heat. The atmosphere absorbs the infrared light.
**Ultraviolet (UV) light** is in wavelengths too short for humans to
see. The most energetic UV light is harmful to life. The atmosphere
absorbs most of this UV light from the Sun. Gamma rays have the highest
energy, and they are the most damaging rays. Fortunately, gamma rays
don’t penetrate Earth’s atmosphere.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._9-syf}

-   Ultraviolet radiation has the highest energy; infrared the lowest.
-   Solar energy travels in photons. Photons travel in waves, which make
    up electromagnetic radiation.
-   Visible light is the wavelengths of light humans can see.

# Heat Transfer in the Atmosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-SGVhdCBUcmFuc2ZlciBpbiB0aGUgQXRtb3NwaGVyZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how radiation, conduction and convection work in
    the atmosphere.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601575] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025825750227.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you see energy moving?**

It's hard to see energy moving. But energy is the reason that air moves,
and it is sometimes possible to see that. In this photo, differences in
temperature are causing air to move—in fantastic ways!

### How Energy Moves Through the Atmosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-SG93IEVuZXJneSBNb3ZlcyBUaHJvdWdoIHRoZSBBdG1vc3BoZXJl_10-rbp}

Energy travels through space or material. Heat energy is transferred in
three ways: radiation, conduction, and convection.

#### Radiation {#8.html#x-ck12-UmFkaWF0aW9u_10-iq8}

**Radiation** is the transfer of energy by waves. Energy can travel as
electromagnetic waves through air or empty space. The Sun's energy
travels through space by radiation. After sunlight heats the planet's
surface, some heat radiates back into the atmosphere.

#### Conduction {#8.html#x-ck12-Q29uZHVjdGlvbg.._10-2ai}

In **conduction** , heat is transferred from molecule to molecule by
contact. Warmer molecules vibrate faster than cooler ones. They bump
into the cooler molecules. When they do, they transfer some of their
energy. Conduction happens mainly in the lower atmosphere. Can you
explain why?

#### Convection {#8.html#x-ck12-Q29udmVjdGlvbg.._10-3vv}

**Convection** is the transfer of heat by a current. Convection happens
in a liquid or a gas. Air near the ground is warmed by heat radiating
from Earth's surface. The warm air is less dense, so it rises. As it
rises, it cools. The cool air is dense, so it sinks to the surface. This
creates a convection current ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMDktQ29udmVuY3Rpb24tY3VycmVudA..) ).
Convection is the most important way that heat travels in the
atmosphere.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-OGY0OWIwMDY5ZDM3ODU1ZjRlZmU4MGE5MmQzYzMwMzk.-917"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of a convection
current](ck12_8_files/20150911025825813181.png "Diagram of a convection current")

**Figure 8.18**

Convection currents are the main way that heat moves through the
atmosphere. Why does warm air rise?

</div>

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-dw3}

-   In conduction, heat moves from areas of more heat to areas of
    less heat. The substances must be in direct contact.
-   In convection, materials move depending on their heat relative to
    nearby materials.
-   In radiation, energy moves by waves.

# Solar Energy and Latitude {#8.html#x-ck12-U29sYXIgRW5lcmd5IGFuZCBMYXRpdHVkZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the different amounts of solar energy that strike at
    different latitudes.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601579] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025825873341.jpeg)
</span>

**This is Antarctica. What season is this?**

The Sun is always up, even in the middle of the night. That's the photo
on the left. In the day, the Sun never gets too high in the sky. That's
the photo on the right. So, this is summer. In the winter, it's just
dark in Antarctica.

### Energy and Latitude {#8.html#x-ck12-RW5lcmd5IGFuZCBMYXRpdHVkZQ.._11-lne}

Different parts of Earth’s surface receive different amounts of sunlight
( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMgRVMtMTUtMTAtU3VuLXJheXMtYW5kLWxhdGl0dWRl) ).
The Sun’s rays strike Earth’s surface most directly at the Equator. This
focuses the rays on a small area. Near the poles, the Sun’s rays strike
the surface at a slant. This spreads the rays over a wide area. The more
focused the rays are, the more energy an area receives, and the warmer
it is.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-M2QyMDNlMDY4ZWEzYTIyODNmZWFjNWM0NzJiOTIxYWM.-mqz"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Laura Guerin" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of latitude and energy
received](ck12_8_files/20150911025825944393.jpeg "Diagram of latitude and energy received")

**Figure 8.19**

The lowest latitudes get the most energy from the Sun. The highest
latitudes get the least.

</div>

The difference in solar energy received at different latitudes drives
**atmospheric circulation** . Places that get more solar energy have
more heat. Places that get less solar energy have less heat. Warm air
rise, and cool air sinks. These principles mean that air moves around
the planet. The heat moves around the globe in certain ways. This
determines the way the atmosphere moves.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._11-nsb}

-   A lot of the solar energy that reaches Earth hits the Equator.
-   Much less solar energy gets to the poles.
-   The difference in the amount of solar energy drives
    atmospheric circulation.

# Greenhouse Effect {#8.html#x-ck12-R3JlZW5ob3VzZSBFZmZlY3Q.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the greenhouse effect.
-   Explain how human actions contribute to the greenhouse effect.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601582] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025826007050.jpeg)
</span>

**How does the atmosphere resemble a greenhouse?**

Farmers use greenhouses to extend the growing season. A greenhouse traps
heat. Days that are too cool for a growing plant can be made to be just
right. Similar to a greenhouse, greenhouse gases in the atmosphere keep
Earth warm.

### The Greenhouse Effect {#8.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEdyZWVuaG91c2UgRWZmZWN0_12-i3l}

When sunlight heats Earth’s surface, some of the heat radiates back into
the atmosphere. Some of this heat is absorbed by gases in the
atmosphere. This is the **greenhouse effect** , and it helps to keep
Earth warm. The greenhouse effect allows Earth to have temperatures that
can support life.

Gases that absorb heat in the atmosphere are called **greenhouse gases**
. They include carbon dioxide and water vapor. Human actions have
increased the levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMTEtR3JlZW5ob3VzZS1lZmZlY3Rz) ). The
added gases have caused a greater greenhouse effect. How do you think
this affects Earth’s temperature?

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-YjU5MjE3NWU4NTIzMWQzMmNlMGEyZDNjMzkyNmMwMDM.-bue"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Will Elder, National Park Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.nps.gov/goga/naturescience/climate-change-causes.htm" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of the natural and human enhanced greenhouse
effect](ck12_8_files/20150911025826073450.jpeg "Diagram of the natural and human enhanced greenhouse effect")

**Figure 8.20**

Human actions have increased the natural greenhouse effect.

</div>

Like a blanket on a sleeping person, greenhouse gases act as insulation
for the planet. The warming of the atmosphere is because of
**insulation** by greenhouse gases. Greenhouse gases are the component
of the atmosphere that moderate Earth’s temperatures.

#### Greenhouse Gases {#8.html#x-ck12-R3JlZW5ob3VzZSBHYXNlcw.._12-vuj}

Greenhouse gases include CO ~2~ , H ~2~ O, methane, O ~3~ , nitrous
oxides (NO and NO ~2~ ), and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). All are a
normal part of the atmosphere except CFCs. The table below shows how
each greenhouse gas naturally enters the atmosphere ( **Table**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6Z3JlZW5ob3VzZV9nYXNfZW50ZXJpbmdfdGhlX2F0bW9zcGhlcmU.)
).

  **Greenhouse Gas**    **Source**
  --------------------- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  Carbon dioxide        Respiration, volcanic eruptions, decomposition of plant material; burning of fossil fuels
  Methane               Decomposition of plant material under some conditions, biochemical reactions in stomachs
  Nitrous oxide         Produced by bacteria
  Ozone                 Atmospheric processes
  Chlorofluorocarbons   Not naturally occurring; made by humans

Different greenhouse gases have different abilities to trap heat. For
example, one methane molecule traps 23 times as much heat as one CO ~2~
molecule. One CFC-12 molecule (a type of CFC) traps 10,600 times as much
heat as one CO ~2~ . Still, CO ~2~ is a very important greenhouse gas,
because it is much more abundant in the atmosphere.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-ttk}

-   Greenhouse gases include CO ~2~ , H ~2~ O, methane, O ~3~ , nitrous
    oxides (NO and NO ~2~ ), and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
-   Greenhouse gases trap heat in the troposphere. Some greenhouse gases
    can trap more heat than others.
-   Levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere are increasing due to
    human activities.

# Circulation in the Atmosphere {#8.html#x-ck12-Q2lyY3VsYXRpb24gaW4gdGhlIEF0bW9zcGhlcmU.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain why atmospheric circulation occurs.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601586] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025826132903.jpeg)
</span>

**Where can you go to experience wind?**

Wind is one of the most obviously dynamic features of our dynamic
planet. For a long time Mt. Washington in New Hampshire was known as the
windiest place on Earth. It no longer is called that, but it's still
plenty windy. A wind speed of 231 miles per hour was recorded on the
mountain in April 1934. In a 200 mph wind, you would not be able to
stand up. Temperatures due to wind chill would be outrageously cold!

### Atmospheric Circulation {#8.html#x-ck12-QXRtb3NwaGVyaWMgQ2lyY3VsYXRpb24._13-zqn}

**Wind** is just moving air. You can't really see it. Whether it’s a
gentle breeze or strong wind, you are most aware of air when it moves (
**Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMTktRWZmZWN0cy1vZi1haXItbW92ZW1lbnQ.)
). You can feel its molecules press against you. You can see things,
like dirt and leaves, moving in the wind. And you can see object moving,
like flags and trees, as a result of the wind.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-NzM2YjgzMTAwZTZmNjA5NzBhOTNmMjk1Y2FjNmY1OTQ.-drs"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="From left to right: Julian Lim (Flickr:julianlimjl); Nico Nelson; Euan Morrison (Flickr:euan1234)" -->
<!-- @@url="From left to right: http://www.flickr.com/photos/julianlim/4838480578/; http://www.flickr.com/photos/niconelson/4289796215/; http://www.flickr.com/photos/euanzkamera/7909241274/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Effects of the wind
blowing](ck12_8_files/20150911025826188640.jpeg "Effects of the wind blowing")

**Figure 8.21**

How can you tell the wind is blowing in these photos?

</div>

#### Why Air Moves {#8.html#x-ck12-V2h5IEFpciBNb3Zlcw.._13-vdi}

Air movement takes place in the troposphere. This is the lowest layer of
the atmosphere. Air moves because of differences in heating. These
differences create convection currents and winds ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMjAtQ29udmVjdGlvbi1jdXJyZW50LWFuZC13aW5k)
).

-   Air in the troposphere is warmer near the ground. The warm air rises
    because it is light. The light, rising air creates an area of low
    air pressure at the surface.
-   The rising air cools as it reaches the top of the troposphere. The
    air gets denser, so it sinks to the surface. The sinking, heavy air
    creates an area of high air pressure near the ground.
-   Air always flows from an area of higher pressure to an area of
    lower pressure. Air flowing over Earth’s surface is called
    **wind** . The greater the difference in pressure, the stronger the
    wind blows.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-MmQ0ZjZhMTI0Yzc4NmJmM2Q2ZDljNGFkYTUyNGExMDI.-gup"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of a convection
cell](ck12_8_files/20150911025826248978.jpeg "Diagram of a convection cell")

**Figure 8.22**

Differences in air temperature cause convection currents and wind.

</div>

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._13-7sq}

-   Warm air rises because it is less dense. This creates an area of
    low pressure.
-   Cool air sinks because it is denser. This creates an area of
    high pressure.
-   Wind blows from areas of high pressure to areas of low pressure.

# Local Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-TG9jYWwgV2luZHM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the types of local winds and how they are created.
-   Explain how local winds influence a region's environment.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601591] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025826313126.jpeg)
</span>

**Which large rainstorms are crucial for people in some parts of the
world?**

India, Pakistan, and other nations in southern Asia are great places to
go to see monsoon rains. The region depends on the water they bring.
Parts of the Southwestern United States also receive monsoon rains.
These rains break the summer heat. They also provide water to desert
plants. With winter rains and summer rains, these deserts are more lush
than many.

### Local Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-TG9jYWwgV2luZHM._14-o2i}

Local winds are winds that blow over a limited area. Local winds blow
between small low and high pressure systems. They are influenced by
local geography. Nearness to an ocean, lake, or mountain range can
affect local winds. Some examples are found below. Local winds can
affect the weather and climate of a region.

#### Land and Sea Breezes {#8.html#x-ck12-TGFuZCBhbmQgU2VhIEJyZWV6ZXM._14-tng}

Ocean water is slower to warm up and cool down than land. So the sea
surface is cooler than the land in the daytime. It is also cooler than
the land in the summer. The opposite is also true. The water stays
warmer than the land during the night and the winter. These differences
in heating cause local winds known as land and sea breezes ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMjEtTGFuZC1hbmQtc2VhLWJyZWV6ZQ..) ).

-   A **sea breeze** blows from sea to land during the day or in summer.
    That’s when air over the land is warmer than air over the water. The
    warm air rises. Cool air from over the water flows in to take
    its place.
-   A **land breeze** blows from land to sea during the night or
    in winter. That’s when air over the water is warmer than air over
    the land. The warm air rises. Cool air from the land flows out to
    take its place.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-Y2RhODZlZGVhNzNiYzAyZDg3MjU4NjZiNTQ2OWY1NzI.-f8e"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyueng" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Land and sea breezes blow in different directions if it is day or
night](ck12_8_files/20150911025826534740.png "Land and sea breezes blow in different directions if it is day or night")

**Figure 8.23**

Land and sea breezes blow because of daily differences in heating.

</div>

#### Monsoons {#8.html#x-ck12-TW9uc29vbnM._14-nrb}

**Monsoons** are like land and sea breezes, but on a larger scale. They
occur because of seasonal changes in the temperature of land and water.
In the winter, they blow from land to water. In the summer, they blow
from water to land. In regions that experience monsoons, the seawater
offshore is extremely warm. The hot air absorbs a lot of the moisture
and carries it over the land. Summer monsoons bring heavy rains on land.
Monsoons occur in several places around the globe. The most important
monsoon in the world is in southern Asia ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMjItTW9uc29vbnM.) ). These monsoons
are important because they carry water to the many people who live
there.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-MjVhMmUyNGM5NjI4NTE4MWQxOWJiYWM2OTAzYjlhMjQ.-tjm"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Map courtesy of the Central Intelligence Agency's World Factbook; modified by CK-12 Foundation - Hana Zavadska" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Asia-map.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Monsoons blow over southern
Asia](ck12_8_files/20150911025826610110.png "Monsoons blow over southern Asia")

**Figure 8.24**

Monsoons blow over southern Asia.

</div>

#### Mountain and Valley Breezes {#8.html#x-ck12-TW91bnRhaW4gYW5kIFZhbGxleSBCcmVlemVz_14-vw7}

The air on a mountain slope warms more than the air over the nearby
valley. The warm air rises and brings cool air up from below. This is a
**valley breeze** . At night the mountain slope cools more than the air
over the valley. The air flows downhill creating a **mountain breeze** .

#### Katabatic Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-S2F0YWJhdGljIFdpbmRz_14-ctp}

**Katabatic winds** move the same way as mountain and valley breezes.
However, they are much stronger. Katabatic winds form over a high
plateau that is surrounded by mountains. In winter, the plateau grows
cold. Air sinks through the gaps in the mountains. Over Antarctica and
Greenland, these winds are frigid.

#### Chinook Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-Q2hpbm9vayBXaW5kcw.._14-dum}

**Chinook winds** ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTE1MDQtMDQ.) ) occur when air is forced
over a mountain range. Warm air rises over the Sierra Nevada in
California, for example, because it is pushed eastward by the westerly
winds. The air cools as it rises and precipitates. The air is now dry.
It sinks down the far side of the mountains and may create strong winds.
These Chinook winds are relatively warm. If there is snow, the winds may
melt it quickly. The dry sinking air creates a **rainshadow effect** .
Rainshadow effect is responsible for many of the world's deserts.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-YjgxOGNjNzBkNmUxMDRlYTk3YWY4M2FkNzgzNmI3Njk.-pnr"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Federal Aviation Administration" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Chinook_wind.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of Chinnok
winds](ck12_8_files/20150911025826696385.jpeg "Diagram of Chinnok winds")

**Figure 8.25**

As air rises over a mountain it cools and loses moisture. The air warms
by compression on the leeward side. The resulting warm and dry winds are
Chinook winds. The leeward side of the mountain experiences rainshadow
effect.

</div>

#### Santa Ana Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-U2FudGEgQW5hIFdpbmRz_14-cvu}

**Santa Ana winds** ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTE1MDQtMDU.) ) are responsible for many
large fires in Southern California ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DYWxpZm9ybmlhV2lsZGZpcmU.) ). The
Santa Ana winds arrive at the end of California’s long summer drought
season. Air east of the Sierra Nevada Mountains cools in late fall. This
creates a high pressure zone. The air is then forced downhill through
the deserts of the Southwest. It blows westward toward the ocean. The
air is blocked by the San Gabriel and San Bernardino Mountains. So it is
funneled rapidly through the mountain passes. If a fire starts, it
spreads quickly. The result is large-scale devastation.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-Y2VhNThiMzA0NmQ5MGYxZGNmMzllOTlhYmY0ZWNkMTU.-jv8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AERONET_La_Jolla.2007297.aqua.250m.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Satellite image of Santa Ana
winds](ck12_8_files/20150911025826765472.jpeg "Satellite image of Santa Ana winds")

**Figure 8.26**

The winds are especially fast through Santa Ana Canyon, for which they
are named. Santa Ana winds blow dust and smoke westward over the Pacific
from Southern California.

</div>

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-NWJjZDUwMWE4NmMwZjkzNmFkNGU4OWNkMTQ4M2RhOTA.-0uf"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Alex Miroshnichenko (Flickr:Miro-Foto)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/miro-foto/1740236383/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Santa Ana winds fuel wildfires in Southern
California](ck12_8_files/20150911025826828037.jpeg "Santa Ana winds fuel wildfires in Southern California")

**Figure 8.27**

In October 2007, Santa Ana winds fueled many fires that together burned
426,000 acres of wild land and more than 1,500 homes in Southern
California.

</div>

#### Desert Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-RGVzZXJ0IFdpbmRz_14-k0r}

High summer temperatures on the desert create high winds and monsoon
storms. Strong winds in the desert can pick up dust and blow it around.
A dust storm known as a **haboob** ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QaG9lbml4SGFib29i) ) forms in the
downdrafts on the front of a thunderstorm.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-NDVjNzg1NTc3NTUwZTBjYzczMzQyYjA5YTIxOWFiN2I.-hl8"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Greg Gorman" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/gwgpix/9272471026/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of a haboob in Phoenix,
Arizona](ck12_8_files/20150911025826904835.jpeg "Picture of a haboob in Phoenix, Arizona")

**Figure 8.28**

A haboob in the Phoenix metropolitan area, Arizona.

</div>

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-gfo}

-   Local winds blow between high pressure and low pressure areas.
-   Winds blow up and down slope, on and off land and sea, through
    deserts or over mountain passes.
-   Some local winds are well known in an area: haboobs in the desert,
    Santa Ana winds in Southern California, Chinook winds in Colorado.

# Global Wind Belts {#8.html#x-ck12-R2xvYmFsIFdpbmQgQmVsdHM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how global winds form.
-   Explain how global winds influence climate.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601596] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025826963473.jpeg)
</span>

**How did the "trade winds" get their name?**

Not so long ago ships could only sail in the direction the wind was
blowing, more-or-less. For centuries, a trip could be made or broken by
how hard the wind blew. The trade winds were named because they were a
reliable way to get across the ocean. Ships engaged in trade needed
these winds to take or leave goods. The trade winds are one of the
global wind belts.

### Global Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-R2xvYmFsIFdpbmRz_15-8fn}

**Global winds** are winds that occur in belts that go all around the
planet ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMjMtR2xvYmFsLXdpbmRz) ). Like local
winds, global winds are caused by unequal heating of the atmosphere.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-MjNiODEwZjI3ZmYxYjcyNmE1OWEyNjUyMzc3M2JlNjA.-kqr"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Map of global wind
belts](ck12_8_files/20150911025827039506.png "Map of global wind belts")

**Figure 8.29**

Global winds occur in belts around the globe.

</div>

#### Heating and Global Winds {#8.html#x-ck12-SGVhdGluZyBhbmQgR2xvYmFsIFdpbmRz_15-8ah}

Earth is hottest at the Equator and gets cooler toward the poles. The
differences in heating create huge convection currents in the
troposphere. At the Equator, for example, warm air rises up to the
tropopause. When it can’t rise any higher, it flows north or south.

By the time the moving air reaches 30°N or °S latitude, it has cooled
somewhat. The cool air sinks to the surface. Then it flows over the
surface back to the Equator. Other global winds occur in much the same
way. There are three enormous convection cells north of the Equator and
three south of the Equator.

#### Global Winds and the Coriolis Effect {#8.html#x-ck12-R2xvYmFsIFdpbmRz_15IGFuZCB0aGUgQ29yaW9saXMgRWZmZWN0-r2o}

Earth is spinning as air moves over its surface. This causes the
Coriolis effect. Winds blow on a diagonal over the surface due to
Coriolis effect. From which direction do the northern trade winds blow?

Without the Coriolis effect the global winds would blow north to south
or south to north. But the Coriolis effect makes them blow northeast to
southwest or the reverse in the Northern Hemisphere. The winds blow
northwest to southeast or the reverse in the Southern Hemisphere.

The wind belts have names. The Trade Winds are nearest the Equator. The
next belt is the westerlies. Finally are the polar easterlies. The names
are the same in both hemispheres.

#### Jet Streams {#8.html#x-ck12-SmV0IFN0cmVhbXM._15-ddx}

**Jet streams** are fast-moving air currents high in the troposphere.
They are also the result of unequal heating of the atmosphere. Jet
streams circle the planet, mainly from west to east. The strongest jet
streams are the polar jets. PIctured below is the northern polar jet (
**Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMjQtTm9ydGhlcm4tcG9sYXItamV0LXN0cmVhbQ..)
).

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-MmE2OTE0YTg1ZTBiMjc4OTZjNjRiNmU4MGQ3NTc4NTM.-fxk"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Centennial of Flight Commission/NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jet_Stream.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The Northern Polar Jet
Stream](ck12_8_files/20150911025827099606.png "The Northern Polar Jet Stream")

**Figure 8.30**

This jet stream helps planes fly quickly from west to east over North
America. How do you think it affects planes that fly from east to west?

</div>

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._15-ed8}

-   Global winds blow from high to low pressure at the base of the
    atmospheric circulation cells.
-   The globe has six atmospheric circulation cells. Three are north of
    the Equator and three are south. These cells have names.
-   Jet streams are fast moving rivers of air going in
    opposite directions.

# Types of Air Pollution {#8.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgQWlyIFBvbGx1dGlvbg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Distinguish between primary and secondary pollutants.
-   Learn the sources of pollutants.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601602] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025827170922.jpeg)
</span>

**What is a pollution advisory?**

Urban areas in sunny locations have pollution advisories. This happens
when ozone levels get high. On these days, you should stay indoors or
exercise early or late in the day. Drive less and avoid filling your
tank.

### Air Pollutants {#8.html#x-ck12-QWlyIFBvbGx1dGFudHM._16-h2x}

There are two main types of air pollutants: primary and secondary. Most
air pollutants come from burning fossil fuels. Some come from burning
forests. Some are due to the evaporation of chemicals.

#### Types of Air Pollutants {#8.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgQWlyIFBvbGx1dGFudHM._16-n8k}

There are two basic types of pollutants in the air. They are known as
primary pollutants and secondary pollutants.

-   **Primary pollutants** enter the air directly. Some are released by
    natural processes, like ash from volcanoes. Most are released by
    human activities.
    -   Carbon oxides are released when fossil fuels burn.
    -   Nitrogen oxides form when nitrogen and oxygen combine at
        high temperatures. This occurs in hot exhausts from vehicles,
        factories, and power plants.
    -   Sulfur oxides are produced when sulfur and oxygen combine. This
        happens when coal that contains sulfur burns.
    -   Toxic heavy metals include mercury and lead. Mercury comes
        from smokestacks. Both metals have industrial uses.
    -   Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are carbon compounds, such
        as methane. VOCs are released by many human activities. Raising
        livestock, for example, produces a lot of methane.
    -   **Particulates** are solid particles. These particles may be
        ash, dust, or even animal wastes. Many are released when fossil
        fuels burn.

<!-- -->

-   **Secondary pollutants** form from primary pollutants. Many occur as
    part of **photochemical smog** . This type of smog is seen as a
    brown haze in the air. Photochemical smog forms when certain
    pollutants have a chemical reaction in the presence of sunlight.
    Photochemical smog consists mainly of **ozone** (O ~3~ ). Ozone near
    the ground is a pollutant ( **Figure**
    [below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Pem9uZUZvcm1hdGlvbg..) ). This
    ozone is harmful to humans and other living things. However, ozone
    in the stratosphere protects Earth from the Sun's harmful
    ultraviolet radiation.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-ZGFkMGQxYTY3NTQxMDI5OTc2YzBhNTkwYzBiNzY0ZWU.-fgf"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Formation of ozone as a
pollutant](ck12_8_files/20150911025827231956.png "Formation of ozone as a pollutant")

**Figure 8.31**

Ozone forms near the ground as a secondary pollutant.

</div>

#### Sources of Air Pollutants {#8.html#x-ck12-U291cmNlcyBvZiBBaXIgUG9sbHV0YW50cw.._16-if9}

Most pollutants enter the air when fossil fuels burn. Some are released
when forests burn. Others evaporate into the air.

#### Burning Fossil Fuels {#8.html#x-ck12-QnVybmluZyBGb3NzaWwgRnVlbHM._16-u58}

Burning fossil fuels releases many pollutants into the air. These
pollutants include carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen dioxide,
and sulfur dioxide.

-   Motor vehicles account for almost half of fossil fuel use.
-   Power plants and factories account for more than a quarter of fossil
    fuel use ( **Figure**
    [below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TbW9rZXN0YWNrcw..) ).
-   Homes and other buildings burn fossil fuels.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-OTNmMzVmZGE0YzZiY2FjYTExZTU4NDZmYTRmMzQwMDE.-ov0"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Steven Greenwood (Wikipedia: Riffsyphon)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Cumberland_Power_Plant_smokestacks.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Pollution from a power
plant](ck12_8_files/20150911025827319611.jpeg "Pollution from a power plant")

**Figure 8.32**

Smoke stacks release a lot of pollutants into the air.

</div>

#### Burning Forests {#8.html#x-ck12-QnVybmluZyBGb3Jlc3Rz_16-snu}

Millions of acres of forest have been cut and burned to make way for
farming ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMDUtc2xhc2gtYW5kLWJ1cm4tYWdyaQ..) ).
Burning trees produces most of the same pollutants as burning fossil
fuels.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-YzFmZWFlYzA1NzM3YjYwYWFlYmQwNzQ5MWNlYzk5ZWE.-ecq"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jami Dwyer (Wikipedia: Jamidwyer)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Lacanja_burn.JPG" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Slash-and-burn
agriculture](ck12_8_files/20150911025827370008.jpeg "Slash-and-burn agriculture")

**Figure 8.33**

Cutting and burning trees to clear land for farming is called
slash-and-burn agriculture. How does this affect the atmosphere?

</div>

#### Evaporation of VOCs {#8.html#x-ck12-RXZhcG9yYXRpb24gb2YgVk9Dcw.._16-mco}

VOCs enter the air by evaporation. VOCs are found in many products, like
paints and petroleum products. Methane is a VOC that evaporates from
livestock waste and landfills.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._16-m0m}

-   There are many types of primary pollutants, including carbon oxides,
    nitrogen oxides, sulfur oxides, particulates, lead, and volatile
    organic compounds.
-   Secondary pollutants form from chemical reactions that occur when
    pollution is exposed to sunlight.
-   Most pollutants enter the atmosphere from fossil fuel burning.
    Burning forests and evaporation of some chemicals account for most
    of the rest.

# Effects of Air Pollution on the Environment {#8.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0cyBvZiBBaXIgUG9sbHV0aW9uIG9uIHRoZSBFbnZpcm9ubWVudA..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how air pollution damages the environment and human health.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601608] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025827424446.jpeg)
</span>

**Why do we treat the atmosphere like a dump?**

On a smoggy day, you're breathing garbage. Many human activities dump
trash into the air. The trash is gases and particles, but it's still
trash. Would we tolerate all this trash if it were in our houses?

### Effects of Pollutants {#8.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0cyBvZiBQb2xsdXRhbnRz_17-lgs}

Air pollution is harmful to human beings and other living things. About
22 million people die from air pollution each year. Breathing polluted
air increases the risk of developing lung diseases such as asthma and
lung cancer. Breathing bad air also increases the chances of dying from
other diseases. Children are most likely to be affected by air
pollution. That’s because their lungs are still developing and growing.
Children also take in more air for their size than adults do. Some air
pollutants damage the environment as well as the health of living
things. The type of damage depends on the pollutant. Air pollution can
also harm the environment.

#### Types of Pollutants {#8.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgUG9sbHV0YW50cw.._17-my9}

This concept explores the effects of different pollutants on the
environment and human health. The pollutants include particulates,
ozone, nitrogen oxides, sulfur oxides, carbon monoxide, heavy metals,
and VOCs.

#### Particulates {#8.html#x-ck12-UGFydGljdWxhdGVz_17-icq}

Particulates cause lung diseases. They can also increase the risk of
heart disease and the number of asthma attacks. Particulates block
sunlight from reaching Earth’s surface. This means there is less energy
for photosynthesis. Less photosynthesis means that plants and
phytoplankton produce less food. This affects whole ecosystems.

#### Ozone {#8.html#x-ck12-T3pvbmU._17-aps}

The ozone in smog may damage plants. The effects of ozone add up over
time. Plants such as trees, which normally live a long time, are most
affected. Entire forests may die out if ozone levels are very high.
Other plants, including crop plants, may also be damaged by ozone.
Below, you can see evidence of ozone damage ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMDYtb3pvbmUtZGFtYWdl) ).

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-ODYxODAyYjRiMzE1MDRiYWU4MWI4ZTM3MTIwNDA5MTY.-8nb"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.ars.usda.gov/Main/docs.htm?docid=18279&#38;page=3" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Ozone damaged leaves on a bean
plant](ck12_8_files/20150911025827485255.jpeg "Ozone damaged leaves on a bean plant")

**Figure 8.34**

Ozone damaged snap bean plants are shown on the left. Healthy snap bean
plants are shown on the right.

</div>

The ozone in smog is also harmful to human health. The image below shows
the levels of ozone to watch out for ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMDctb3pvbmUtaW5kZXg.) ). Some people
are especially sensitive to ozone. They can be harmed by levels of ozone
that would not affect most other people. These people include those with
lung or heart problems.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-OWYyZWRiYjc4ODc0YjI0ZDVkNTM1YmVhNTc5NmJhYmE.-tgu"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jodi So" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of an ozone air quality
index](ck12_8_files/20150911025827557583.jpeg "Diagram of an ozone air quality index")

**Figure 8.35**

The ozone air quality index gives the parts of ozone per million parts
of air. How many parts of ozone are unhealthy for everyone?

</div>

#### Nitrogen and Sulfur Oxides {#8.html#x-ck12-Tml0cm9nZW4gYW5kIFN1bGZ1ciBPeGlkZXM._17-hra}

Both nitrogen and sulfur oxides are toxic to humans. These compounds can
cause lung diseases or make them worse. Nitrogen and sulfur oxides form
acid rain, which is described in the next concept.

#### Carbon Monoxide {#8.html#x-ck12-Q2FyYm9uIE1vbm94aWRl_17-fk7}

Carbon monoxide (CO) is toxic to both plants and animals. CO is deadly
to people in a confined space, such as a closed home. Carbon monoxide is
odorless and colorless, so people can’t tell when they are breathing it.
That’s why homes should have carbon monoxide detectors.

#### Heavy Metals {#8.html#x-ck12-SGVhdnkgTWV0YWxz_17-ya9}

Heavy metals, such as mercury and lead, are toxic to living things. They
can enter food chains from the atmosphere. The metals build up in the
tissues of organisms by **bioaccumulation** ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMDktYmlvYWNjdW11bGF0aW9uLW1lcmN1cnk.)
). Heavy metals accumulate as they are passed up a food chain. Imagine a
low-level consumer eating a producer. That consumer takes in all of the
heavy metals from all of the producers that it eats. Then a higher-level
consumer eats the low-level consumer. The higher-level consumer
accumulates all of the heavy metals from all of the lower-level
consumers that it eats. In this way, an organism accumulates a lot of
heavy metals. At high levels in the food chain, the heavy metals may
become quite concentrated.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-Y2M2NTllYzg0MjBjYjRmMGQ3ZmY4MjE0OGQyZWY5MDM.-ksw"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US EPA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.epa.gov/greatlakes/atlas/glat-ch4.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Bioaccumulation of
mercury](ck12_8_files/20150911025827607787.png "Bioaccumulation of mercury")

**Figure 8.36**

This diagram shows how mercury bioaccumulates. Compare the parts per
million (ppm) of mercury in phytoplankton and gull eggs. Can you explain
the difference?

</div>

The higher up a food chain that humans eat, the greater the levels of
toxic metals they take in. That’s why people should avoid eating too
much large fish, such as tuna. Tuna are predators near the top of their
food chains. They have been shown to contain high levels of mercury. In
people, heavy metals can damage the brain and other organs. Unborn
babies and young children are most affected. That’s because their organs
are still developing.

#### VOCs {#8.html#x-ck12-Vk9Dcw.._17-7lk}

VOCs are toxic to humans and other living things. In people, they can
cause a wide range of problems. These can range from eye and nose
irritation to brain damage and cancer. Levels of VOCs are often higher
indoors than out. That’s because they are released by products such as
paints, cleaning solutions, and building materials. How might you reduce
your exposure to VOCs?

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._17-6i5}

-   An increase in particulates may have these effects. It may reduce
    photosynthesis, increase precipitation, and reduce temperatures.
-   Ozone may damage native plants and some crop plants. Ozone may slow
    plant growth or damage leaves.
-   Pollutants emitted into the air cause lung and other diseases
    in humans.

# Acid Rain {#8.html#x-ck12-QWNpZCBSYWlu}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how acid rain forms.
-   Describe the consequences of acid rain.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601614] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025827686044.jpeg)
</span>

**What would the artists think?**

Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris opened in 1345. Construction took almost
200 years. For about 500 years, the cathedral was pristine. Yet this
gargoyle has pits in it. The pits are caused by acid rain. Acid rain
forms from pollutants from fossil fuel burning.

### Acid Rain {#8.html#x-ck12-QWNpZCBSYWlu_18-hmn}

**Acid rain** is rain that has a pH less than 5 ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMTAtcEgtc2NhbGU.) ). Acidity is
measured on the **pH scale** . Lower numbers are more acidic, and higher
numbers are less acidic (also called more **alkaline** ). An **acid**
has a pH of less than 7. The pH of normal rain is 5.6. It’s slightly
acidic because carbon dioxide in the air dissolves in rain. This forms
carbonic acid, a weak acid.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-N2MxMmU3NTAwOWViN2JlZWZmZDZiMGM3ZmEyMTRlYjA.-udc"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Geological Survey" -->
<!-- @@url="http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/acidrain/1.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The pH scale](ck12_8_files/20150911025827740971.png "The pH scale")

**Figure 8.37**

This pH scale includes both normal and acid rain. At what pH do fish
have problems reproducing?

</div>

#### How Acid Rain Forms {#8.html#x-ck12-SG93IEFjaWQgUmFpbiBGb3Jtcw.._18-a5h}

Acid rain forms when nitrogen and sulfur oxides in air dissolve in rain
( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMTEtYWNpZC1yYWluLWZvcm1hdGlvbg..) ).
This forms nitric and sulfuric acids. Both are strong acids. Acid rain
with a pH as low as 4.0 is now common in many areas. Acid fog may be
even more acidic than acid rain. Fog with a pH as low as 1.7 has been
recorded. That’s the same pH as toilet bowl cleaner!

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-MzI2MTk1MDhhYjY1NzJjMDQ0Y2FkOGRlMmUzNDViNTc.-9ea"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the U.S. EPA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.epa.gov/bioiweb1/aquatic/airpoll.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Nitrogen and sulfur oxides combine with rain to form acid
rain](ck12_8_files/20150911025827808584.jpeg "Nitrogen and sulfur oxides combine with rain to form acid rain")

**Figure 8.38**

Nitrogen and sulfur oxides combine with rain to form acid rain.

</div>

#### Effects of Acid Rain {#8.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0cyBvZiBBY2lkIFJhaW4._18-gx9}

The image below shows some of the damage done by acid rain ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMTItYWNpZC1yYWluLWRhbWFnZQ..) ). Acid
rain ends up in soil and bodies of water. This can make them very
acidic. The acid strips soil of its nutrients. These changes can kill
trees, fish, and other living things. Acid rain also dissolves limestone
and marble. This can damage buildings, monuments, and statues.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-ZTYxMjhmMTA3NWFmYWYzZGIwYjExNjU2OTA3YmVhNDg.-pdp"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Npik/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Acid_rain_woods1.JPG" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Acid rain has killed trees in this forest in the Czech
Republic](ck12_8_files/20150911025827868843.jpeg "Acid rain has killed trees in this forest in the Czech Republic")

**Figure 8.39**

Acid rain has killed trees in this forest in the Czech Republic.

</div>

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._18-k8x}

-   Nitrogen and sulfur compounds emitted high into the atmosphere
    create acids. These acids may fall as acid rain.
-   Acidity is measured on a pH scale. Rain that is 5.0 or less on that
    scale is considered acid rain.
-   Acid rain weakens plants and animals and damages cultural treasures.

# Ozone Depletion {#8.html#x-ck12-T3pvbmUgRGVwbGV0aW9u}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how a hole in the ozone layer forms.
-   Describe the effects of ozone loss on the environment and life.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601620] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025827923495.jpeg)
</span>

**Why can't the children in Punta Arenas go outside to play in the
spring?**

Punta Arenas, Chile is the world's most southern city. At such a high
latitude, winters are exceedingly cold and dark. Unlike the children
pictured above, the children in Punta Arenas must stay inside to avoid
the cold. Of course, they look forward to spring when they can go out to
play. But some years, it is too dangerous for the children to go
outside. The ozone hole has moved north. Too much of the Sun's harmful
UV radiation gets through.

### Loss of High-Level Ozone {#8.html#x-ck12-TG9zcyBvZiBIaWdoLUxldmVsIE96b25l_19-81w}

Ozone near the ground harms human health. Ground-level ozone is a
pollutant. But the ozone layer in the stratosphere protects us from
harmful solar rays. That’s why people were alarmed in the 1980s to learn
that there was a hole in the ozone layer.

#### Cause of Ozone Loss {#8.html#x-ck12-Q2F1c2Ugb2YgT3pvbmUgTG9zcw.._19-yr5}

What’s destroying the ozone layer? The chief cause is
chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). These are human-made chemicals that contain
the element chlorine (Cl). In the past, CFCs were widely used in spray
cans, refrigerators, and many other products. CFCs are stable compounds
that can remain in the atmosphere for hundreds of years.

Once CFCs are in the air, they float up into the stratosphere. What
happens next is pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMjItMTMtQ0ZDLW96b25lLWJyZWFrZG93bg..) ).
Sunlight breaks apart the molecules. This releases their chlorine ions
(Cl). The free chlorine ions may then combine with oxygen ions in ozone.
This breaks down the ozone molecules into an oxygen molecule and an
oxygen ion. One CFC molecule can break down as many as 100,000 ozone
molecules in this way! These forms of oxygen do not protect the planet
from ultraviolet radiation.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-MTIzMjg1NDFmYmNhM2RjMGVmNjllZmYzMGU4MjNjNmM.-fai"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US EPA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.epa.gov/ozone/science/process.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![CFCs break down ozone in the
stratosphere](ck12_8_files/20150911025827991669.png "CFCs break down ozone in the stratosphere")

**Figure 8.40**

CFCs break down ozone in the stratosphere.

</div>

#### Ozone Hole {#8.html#x-ck12-T3pvbmUgSG9sZQ.._19-3ex}

Most ozone loss it taking place over the South Pole and Antarctica. This
is the location of the ozone hole. The **ozone hole** is a region in the
stratosphere where there is less ozone than normal. Conditions are just
right for ozone destruction because it is exceedingly cold. The ozone
hole is also seasonal. The hole forms during the early part spring in
the Southern Hemisphere and then grows northward ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTUtMTUtSG9sZS1pbi1vem9uZS1sYXllcg..) ).
The ozone layer is also thinner over the Northern Hemisphere.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-ZWE5ZWY4NWI4NjBjZThhZDNlN2NjNzU2ZjU1ZDExZTA.-biq"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA Ozone Hole Watch" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=49040" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Picture of the hole in the ozone layer over
Antarctica](ck12_8_files/20150911025828050284.jpeg "Picture of the hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica")

**Figure 8.41**

The hole in the ozone layer occurs over Antarctica. How do you think the
hole in the ozone layer could affect life on Earth?

</div>

#### Effects of Ozone Loss {#8.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0cyBvZiBPem9uZSBMb3Nz_19-zm3}

With less ozone in the stratosphere, more UV rays reach the ground. More
UV rays increase skin cancer rates. Just a 1 percent loss of ozone
causes a 5 percent increase in skin cancer. More UV rays also harm
plants and phytoplankton. As a result, they produce less food. This may
affect entire ecosystems.

#### Protecting the Ozone Layer {#8.html#x-ck12-UHJvdGVjdGluZyB0aGUgT3pvbmUgTGF5ZXI._19-spr}

The Montreal Protocol is a worldwide agreement on air pollution. It
focuses on CFCs. It was signed by many countries in 1987. It controls
almost 100 chemicals that can damage the ozone layer. Its aim is to
return the ozone layer to its normal state.

The Montreal Protocol has been effective in controlling CFCs. By 1995,
few CFCs were still being used. But the ozone hole kept growing for
several years after that because of the CFCs already in the atmosphere.
It peaked in 2006. Since then, it has been somewhat smaller. The
Montreal Protocol is a shining example of how nations can come together
to solve a global environmental problem.

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._19-hwz}

-   CFCs float up into the stratosphere where they break apart. The
    chlorine pulls an oxygen ion off of an ozone molecule and
    destroys it.
-   The ozone hole forms over Antarctica in the spring.
-   Ozone loss increases the amount of high-energy ultraviolet radiation
    that strikes Earth. This can cause ecological and health problems.

# Reducing Air Pollution {#8.html#x-ck12-UmVkdWNpbmcgQWlyIFBvbGx1dGlvbg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe ways to reduce air pollution.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601626] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_8_files/20150911025828114104.jpeg)
</span>

**Can a car run on hydrogen?**

Yes! But so far this is not feasible for more than just a few models. A
major problem with hydrogen cars is the lack of hydrogen fuel. Many ways
to reduce pollution are being developed. What can you do to help?

### The Clean Air Act {#8.html#x-ck12-VGhlIENsZWFuIEFpciBBY3Q._20-1gf}

**Air quality** is a measure of the pollutants in the air. More
pollutants mean poorer air quality. Poor air quality started to become a
serious problem after the Industrial Revolution. Factories burned coal
for energy. Gasoline burned by cars and trucks added greatly to air
pollution. By the mid-1900s, air quality in many big cities was very
bad. Incidents in London and in U.S. cities alerted people to the extent
of the problem. It was clear that air quality needed to be protected.

In 1970 in the U.S., the Clean Air Act was passed. It limits what can be
released into the air. The air in the U.S. is much cleaner now than it
was 50 years ago. But air pollution has not gone away. Vehicles,
factories, and power plants still release more than 150 million tons of
pollutants into the air each year.

### Reducing Pollutants from Fossil Fuels {#8.html#x-ck12-UmVkdWNpbmcgUG9sbHV0YW50cyBmcm9tIEZvc3NpbCBGdWVscw.._20-hfb}

There are two basic types of strategies for reducing pollution from
fossil fuels:

1.  Use less fossil fuel.
2.  Prevent pollutants from entering the air.

#### Use Less Fossil Fuel {#8.html#x-ck12-VXNlIExlc3MgRm9zc2lsIEZ1ZWw._20-508}

We can reduce our use of fossil fuels in several ways:

-   Conserve fossil fuels. For example, turning out lights when we
    aren’t using them saves electricity. Why does this help? A lot of
    the electricity we use comes from coal-burning power plants.
-   Use fossil fuels more efficiently. For example, driving a
    fuel-efficient car lets you go farther on each gallon of gas. This
    can add up to a big savings in fossil fuel use.
-   Keep up with technology. Hybrid cars run on electricity that would
    be wasted during braking. These cars use gas only as a backup fuel.
    As a result, they produce just 10 percent of the air pollution
    produced by regular cars.

#### Keeping Pollutants out of the Air {#8.html#x-ck12-S2VlcGluZyBQb2xsdXRhbnRzIG91dCBvZiB0aGUgQWly_20-lnx}

Some of the pollutants from fossil fuels can be filtered out of exhaust
before it is released into the air ( **Figure**
[below](#8.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1FeGhhdXN0Q29tcG9zaXRl) ). Other
pollutants can be changed to harmless compounds before they are
released. Two widely used technologies are scrubbers and catalytic
converters.

-   Scrubbers are used in factories and power plants. They remove
    particulates and waste gases from exhaust before it is released to
    the air.
-   Catalytic converters are used on motor vehicles. They break down
    pollutants in exhaust to non-toxic compounds. For example, they
    change nitrogen oxides to harmless nitrogen and oxygen gases.

<div id="8.html#x-ck12-ZjAxNTVhNWFhYzZkZDc1ZjI5NzZjNzhhZWI0NDAzOTk.-cxr"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Left: Image copyright Olegusk, 2014; Right: Image copyright Andra&#382; Cerar, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Polluting car](ck12_8_files/20150911025828194111.jpeg "Polluting car")

**Figure 8.42**

Before catalytic converters were required, cars spewed a lot of
pollutants into the air. On the left is a car without a catalytic
converter. The car on the right has one.

</div>

#### Increasing Alternative Energy Sources {#8.html#x-ck12-SW5jcmVhc2luZyBBbHRlcm5hdGl2ZSBFbmVyZ3kgU291cmNlcw.._20-b39}

Developing alternative energy sources is important. What are some of the
problems facing wider adoption of alternative energy sources?

-   The technologies are still being developed. This includes sources of
    alternative energy, like solar and wind.
-   Solar and wind are still expensive relative to fossil fuels. The
    technology needs to advance so that the price falls.
-   Some areas get low amounts of sunlight and are not suited for solar.
    Others do not have much wind. It is important that regions develop
    what best suits them. The desert Southwest will need to
    develop solar. The Great Plains can use wind energy. Perhaps some
    locations will rely on nuclear power.

#### Ways You Can Reduce Air Pollution {#8.html#x-ck12-V2F5cyBZb3UgQ2FuIFJlZHVjZSBBaXIgUG9sbHV0aW9u_20-rp0}

Everyone can help to reduce air pollution. Just use less fossil fuels!
How can you do this?

-   Ride a bike or walk instead of driving.
-   Take a bus or carpool.
-   Buy a fuel efficient car.
-   Turn off lights and appliances when they are not in use.
-   Use energy efficient light bulbs and appliances.
-   Buy fewer things that are manufactured using fossil fuels.

All these actions reduce the amount of energy that power plants need to
produce.

National Geographic videos exploring energy conservation are found in
Environment Videos, Energy:
[http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/environment/energy-environment](energy-environment)

-   Alternative Energy
-   Fuel Cells
-   Solar Power

What you can do to your home to help reduce energy use:

(1:45)

[![](ck12_8_files/tmpHrncXP.jpeg)](FvOBHMb6Cqc%3Fwmode%3Dtransparent%26rel%3D0%26hash%3D9ac56bea8f87d476551b2bd93a46ed33)

Click on the image above for more content

### Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._20-lzn}

-   Catalytic converters reduce pollution from cars.
-   To reduce air pollution, either use less fossil fuels, or clean
    emissions before they enter the air.
-   Different types of clean energy can be developed for
    different locations. Some regions are suited for solar, others for
    wind, etc.

## Summary {#8.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-aps}

The layers of the atmosphere are divided by their temperature gradients.
The lowest layer is the troposphere. All weather takes place in this
layer. The next layer is the stratosphere. The stratosphere contains the
protective ozone layer. More sunlight strikes at the Equator than at the
poles. This is what drives the global winds. Warm air rises, moves
poleward, and then sinks when it meets with air moving toward the
Equator. The result is six atmospheric circulation cells around the
world. There are three cells in each hemisphere. Pollutants enter the
atmosphere from a few sources. The most important is fossil fuel
burning. Air pollution has bad effects on the environment and on human
health. By reducing fossil fuel use we can make the environment cleaner.
When ozone depletion was found to be a problem, the world acted. As a
result, the ozone hole has stabilized. The hole will be getting smaller
over the next decades.

</div>

# Weather and Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-V2VhdGhlciBhbmQgQ2xpbWF0ZQ..-chapter}

<div class="x-ck12-data">

## Introduction {#9.html#x-ck12-SW50cm9kdWN0aW9u-ytv}

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025845684205.jpeg)
</span>

**What's the difference between weather and climate?**

When you think of Greece, you probably think of sunshine and white
buildings. Maybe a beautiful beach. All of these are typical of Greece,
which has a warm Mediterranean climate. In the winter, snow sometimes
blankets the highlands. Rarely, though, it snows in the Greek lowlands.
Snow is so uncommon in Athens that when it happens it brings the city to
a standstill. The Acropolis sits on a rocky outcrop above Athens. It's
beautiful, but rare, to see this ancient ruin covered with snow. The
weather in the photo on the right is cold and snowy, but the climate is
still Mediterranean. Climate is the long-term average of weather.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [LESSON: 3601637] -->

# Introduction to Weather {#9.html#x-ck12-SW50cm9kdWN0aW9uIHRvIFdlYXRoZXI.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Learn what factors make up weather.
-   Understand what causes weather.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601640] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025845804864.jpeg)
</span>

**What's the weather like?**

The United States is a big country. With two coasts and a large land
mass in between, there's a chance for every kind of weather. In the next
few sections we'll visit places that have the type of weather we're
interested in studying.

### What is Weather? {#9.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBpcyBXZWF0aGVyPw..-dty}

All **weather** takes place in the atmosphere. Nearly all of it in the
lower atmosphere. **Weather** refers to the conditions of the atmosphere
at a given time and place. **Climate** is the average of weather over a
long time.

Imagine your grandmother who lives in a distant place calls you up. She
asks what your weather is like today. What would you say? Is it warm or
cold? Sunny or cloudy? Calm or windy? Clear or rainy? What features of
weather are important to mention?

A location’s weather depends on:

-   air temperature.
-   air pressure.
-   fog.
-   humidity.
-   cloud cover.
-   precipitation.
-   wind speed and direction.

All of these characteristics are directly related to the amount of
energy that is in the system, and where that energy is. The ultimate
source of this energy is the Sun.

Weather is what we experience from day to day, or minute to minute.
Weather can change rapidly.

### What Causes Weather? {#9.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBDYXVzZXMgV2VhdGhlcj8.-6l0}

Weather occurs because of unequal heating of the atmosphere. The source
of heat is the Sun. The general principles behind weather can be stated
simply:

-   The Sun heats Earth’s surface more in some places than in others.
-   Where it is warm, heat from the Sun warms the air close to
    the surface. If there is water at the surface, it may cause some of
    the water to evaporate.
-   Warm air is less dense, so it rises. When this happens, more dense
    air flows in to take its place. The flowing surface air is wind.
-   The rising air cools as it goes higher in the atmosphere. If it is
    moist, the water vapor may condense. Clouds may form, and
    precipitation may fall.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ..-zdl}

-   A region's weather depends on its air temperature, air pressure,
    humidity, precipitation, wind speed and direction, and
    other factors.
-   Climate is the long-term average of weather.
-   Weather can change in minutes, but climate changes very slowly.

# Humidity {#9.html#x-ck12-SHVtaWRpdHk.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how humidity affects temperature.
-   Understand humidity, relative humidity, and dew point.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601649] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025845922135.jpeg)
</span>

**Would you rather spend a summer day in Phoenix or in Houston?**

People who live in Phoenix, Arizona are told that summer isn't so bad
because "it's a dry heat." What does that mean? Imagine that both
Phoenix and Houston have a temperature of 90°F. In Phoenix, the relative
humidity is 20%. In Houston, the relative humidity is 90%. So in Phoenix
it feels like it's 90°. But in Houston it feels like it's 122! Of course
in Phoenix in July, the average high temperature is 106°. That's hot,
dry or not!

### Humidity {#9.html#x-ck12-SHVtaWRpdHk._1-6qv}

**Humidity** is the amount of water vapor in the air. High humidity
increases the chances of clouds and precipitation.

#### Relative Humidity {#9.html#x-ck12-UmVsYXRpdmUgSHVtaWRpdHk._1-b6l}

Humidity usually refers to **relative humidity** . This is the percent
of water vapor in the air relative to the total amount the air can hold.
How much water vapor can the air hold? That depends on temperature. Warm
air can hold more water vapor than cool air ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1SZWxhdGl2ZUh1bWlkaXR5) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-NTc2OGUzYzk1MDBmZjliMjFhM2QzYWJkNjZhMDhjOGY.-hs5"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jodi So" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Graph showing water vapor capacity and
temperature](ck12_9_files/20150911025846048354.png "Graph showing water vapor capacity and temperature")

**Figure 9.1**

How much water vapor can the air hold when its temperature is 40° C?

</div>

#### Humidity and Heat {#9.html#x-ck12-SHVtaWRpdHkgYW5kIEhlYXQ._1-90w}

People often say, “it’s not the heat but the humidity.” Humidity can
make a hot day feel even hotter. When sweat evaporates, it cools your
body. But sweat can’t evaporate when the air already contains as much
water vapor as it can hold. The **heat index** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMDItSGVhdC1pbmRleA..) ) is a measure
of what the temperature feels like because of the humidity.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-NTVjZWY2OTQxYjQ3N2M4OTE0YzY2ZjEwMDZlNjQ0ZDk.-wun"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of National Weather Service, NOAA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://oceanservice.noaa.gov/education/yos/resource/JetStream/global/hi.htm" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Graph of apparent temperature based on air temperature and
humidity](ck12_9_files/20150911025846123589.png "Graph of apparent temperature based on air temperature and humidity")

**Figure 9.2**

How hot does it feel when the air temperature is 90°F? It depends on the
humidity.

</div>

#### Dew Point {#9.html#x-ck12-RGV3IFBvaW50_1-kzw}

You’ve probably noticed dew on the grass on a summer morning. Why does
dew form? Remember that the land heats up and cools down fairly readily.
So when night comes, the land cools. Air that was warm and humid in the
daytime also cools over night. As the air cools, it can hold less water
vapor. Some of the water vapor condenses on the cool surfaces, such as
blades of grass. The temperature at which water vapor condenses is
called the **dew point** . If this temperature is below freezing, ice
crystals of frost form instead of dew ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HcmFzc1dpdGhEZXdGcm9zdENvbXBvc2l0ZQ..)
). The dew point occurs at 100 percent relative humidity. Can you
explain why?

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-Yzg2YTAwZTQ5NmVmMjcyZjdmMjI1YTZhMzNkNjg3MDU.-yxd"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Left: Jordan McCullough; Right: Adrian Byrne (Flickr:Byrnsey)" -->
<!-- @@url="Left: http://www.flickr.com/photos/ambientideas/3453840532/; Right: http://www.flickr.com/photos/byrnsey/4225206260/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Dew and frost form due to the dew
point](ck12_9_files/20150911025846297119.jpeg "Dew and frost form due to the dew point")

**Figure 9.3**

The grass on the left is covered with dew. The grass on the right is
covered with frost. The difference is the temperature of the grass.

</div>

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._1-uqg}

-   Air reaches its dew point when humidity increases or
    temperature decreases.
-   Water droplets form when the air reaches 100% humidity. If the
    temperature is cold enough, frost will form.
-   Relative humidity is how the air feels at its temperature
    and humidity.
