# Clouds {#9.html#x-ck12-Q2xvdWRz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how clouds form.
-   Describe the influence of clouds on weather.
-   Describe different types of clouds

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601653] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025846401993.jpeg)
</span>

**Where should you go if you don't want to see the Sun?**

The Pacific Northwest has the most days of heavy cloud cover. 62% of
days have more than three-quarters of the sky covered in clouds in
Seattle. Conditions are nearly the same in Portland, Oregon. If you want
to see the most sunshine, the least cloudy cities are in Arizona.

### Clouds {#9.html#x-ck12-Q2xvdWRz_2-75y}

**Clouds** form when air in the atmosphere reaches the dew point. Clouds
may form anywhere in the troposphere. Clouds that form on the ground are
called **fog** .

#### How Clouds Form {#9.html#x-ck12-SG93IENsb3VkcyBGb3Jt_2-ew8}

Clouds form when water vapor condenses around particles in the air. The
particles are specks of matter, such as dust or smoke. Billions of these
tiny water droplets come together to make up a cloud. If the air is very
cold, ice crystals form instead of liquid water.

#### Classification of Clouds {#9.html#x-ck12-Q2xhc3NpZmljYXRpb24gb2YgQ2xvdWRz_2-609}

Clouds are classified on the basis of where and how they form. Three
main types of clouds are cirrus, stratus, and cumulus; there are other
types of clouds, as well ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DbG91ZFR5cGVz) ).

-   **Cirrus clouds** form high in the troposphere. Because it is so
    cold they are made of ice crystals. They are thin and wispy. Cirrus
    clouds don’t usually produce precipitation, but they may be a sign
    that wet weather is coming.
-   **Stratus clouds** occur low in the troposphere. They form in layers
    that spread horizontally and may cover the entire sky like a
    thick blanket. Stratus clouds that produce precipitation are
    called nimbostratus. The prefix *nimbo-* means “rain.”
-   **Cumulus clouds** are white and puffy. Convection currents make
    them grow upward, and they may grow very tall. When they produce
    rain, they are called cumulonimbus.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YjVmYTI3NjgzMzExNWUyYjEyN2IxNjZhNGVkNjE2ZDI.-s2c"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Christopher M. Klaus, US Department of Energy" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Cloud_types.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Picture showing classification of
clouds](ck12_9_files/20150911025846515439.jpeg "Picture showing classification of clouds")

**Figure 9.4**

Find the cirrus, cirrostratus, and cirrocumulus clouds in the figure.
What do they have in common? They all form high in the troposphere.
Clouds that form in the mid troposphere have the prefix “alto-”, as in
altocumulus. Where do stratocumulus clouds form?

</div>

#### Clouds and Temperature {#9.html#x-ck12-Q2xvdWRz_2IGFuZCBUZW1wZXJhdHVyZQ..-ku7}

Clouds can affect the temperature on Earth’s surface. During the day,
thick clouds block some of the Sun’s rays. This keeps the surface from
heating up as much as it would on a clear day. At night, thick clouds
prevent heat from radiating out into space. This keeps the surface
warmer than it would be on a clear night.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._2-0un}

-   Water vapor condenses on particles in the air to form clouds.
-   Clouds block sunlight in the day. Clouds trap heat in the atmosphere
    at night.
-   Cloud types include cirrus, stratus, and cumulus.

# Fog {#9.html#x-ck12-Rm9n}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe different types of fog.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601659] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025846598988.jpeg)
</span>

**Where is the most famous fog in the U.S.?**

San Francisco, the city by the bay, is known for its fog. There's an old
joke: "I spent the coldest winter of my life in San Francisco one
summer." That's because of the fog! There is a big difference in
temperature between the two sides of the city. On the Pacific side,
where there is fog, temperatures are low. On the bay side, where there
isn't fog, temperatures are much higher.

### Fog {#9.html#x-ck12-Rm9n_3-tsz}

**Fog** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Gb2dDb21wb3NpdGU.) ) is a cloud on the
ground. Fog forms when humid air near the ground cools below its dew
point. Each type of fog forms in a different way.

-   **Radiation fog** forms at night. Skies are clear, and the relative
    humidity is high. The ground cools as temperature goes down. Air
    near the ground cools below its dew point. Tule fog is an extreme
    form of radiation fog. This type of fog strikes the Central Valley
    of California in winter.
-   **Advection fog** is famous in San Francisco, California. Warm,
    moist air comes in from the Pacific Ocean. The air blows over the
    cold California current. When the air cools below its dew point,
    fog forms. Sea breezes bring the fog onshore.
-   **Steam fog** appears in autumn when cool air moves over a
    warm lake. Water evaporates from the lake surface. As the water
    vapor cools, it condenses. The fog appears like steam.
-   Warm humid air travels up a hillside and cools below its dew point
    to create **upslope fog** .

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MDY0NWY3NzkwM2ExMTNkNjZmMDhiMTYwMGY0ZmM5NDY.-sjq"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(a) marya (Flickr:emdot); (b) Flickr:different2une; (c) Flickr:3rdparty!; (d) Jordan (Flickr:jshansen)" -->
<!-- @@url="(a) http://www.flickr.com/photos/emdot/73257387/; (b) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Save_me_san_francisco2.jpg; (c) http://www.flickr.com/photos/3rdparty/1415846228/; (d) http://www.flickr.com/photos/jordanhansen/1479708784/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Pictures of tule, advection, steam, and upslope
fog](ck12_9_files/20150911025846708504.jpeg "Pictures of tule, advection, steam, and upslope fog")

**Figure 9.5**

\(a) Tule fog in the Central Valley of California. (b) Advection fog in
San Francisco. (c) Steam fog over a lake in Algonquin Park, Canada. (d)
Upslope fog around the peak of Sanqing Mountains in China.

</div>

Fog levels are declining along the California coast as climate warms.
The change in fog may have big ecological changes for the state.

Learn more at:
[http://www.kqed.org/quest/television/science-on-the-spot-science-of-fog](science-on-the-spot-science-of-fog)
.

[![](ck12_9_files/tmpSqdQkl.jpeg)](19c09UgIB-4%3Fwmode%3Dtransparent%26rel%3D0%26hash%3D4136fc1c3f444ff588d008063d9b6f2f)

# Precipitation {#9.html#x-ck12-UHJlY2lwaXRhdGlvbg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe different types of precipitation and the conditions that
    create them.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601663] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025847050237.jpeg)
</span>

**Want to stay dry? Don't go to these places!**

The wettest locations in the world are in Mawsynram and Cherrapunji in
India. Monsoon rains result in more than 460" of rain annually. The
wettest place in the United States with 404" on average is on Maui (Big
Bog). The wettest place in the continental United States is Langlois,
Oregon with a mere 122" per year.

### Precipitation {#9.html#x-ck12-UHJlY2lwaXRhdGlvbg.._4-ehw}

Clouds are needed for precipitation. **Precipitation** is water that
falls from the sky. This may fall as liquid water, mostly as **rain** .
It may fall also as frozen water, such as snow.

#### Why Precipitation Falls {#9.html#x-ck12-V2h5IFByZWNpcGl0YXRpb24gRmFsbHM._4-sbe}

Millions of water molecules in a cloud must condense to make a single
raindrop or snowflake. The drop or flake falls when it becomes too heavy
for updrafts to keep it aloft. As a drop or flake falls, it may collect
more water and get larger.

#### Types of Precipitation {#9.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgUHJlY2lwaXRhdGlvbg.._4-mpv}

Why does it snow instead of rain? Air temperature determines which type
of precipitation falls. Rain falls if the air temperature is above
freezing (0° C or 32° F). Frozen precipitation falls if the air or
ground is below freezing. Frozen precipitation may fall as **snow** ,
**sleet** , or **freezing rain** . Below, you can see how the different
types form ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMDQtRnJvemVuLXByZWNpcGl0YXRpb25z) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-OGI5MzBiZGNiZDgyMzdiNGY5OWZiOWZkYWEyZGE4MDA.-8lr"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Top 3 images courtesy of NOAA; bottom left image by CK-12 Foundation - Christopher Auyeung; bottom right courtesy of National Severe Storms Laboratory" -->
<!-- @@url="Top 3 images: http://www.srh.noaa.gov/jetstream//synoptic/precip.htm; Bottom right image: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Granizo.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0 (top 3 images and bottom right images released in public domain)" -->
![Diagram of snow, sleet, and freezing
rain](ck12_9_files/20150911025847158932.jpeg "Diagram of snow, sleet, and freezing rain")

**Figure 9.6**

Frozen precipitation may fall as snow, sleet, or freezing rain.

</div>

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._4-hmt}

-   Precipitation falls when it gets too heavy to stay in a cloud.
-   Rain droplets caught up in air currents within a cloud get larger by
    the addition of condensed droplets until they are too heavy and
    they fall.
-   If the ground is very cold, rain can freeze to become sleet
    or glaze.

### Review {#9.html#x-ck12-UmV2aWV3_4-jpo}

1.  Why do raindrops fall form and fall to the ground?
2.  Why does hail only come from cumulonimbus clouds?
3.  How does sleet form?

# Air Masses {#9.html#x-ck12-QWlyIE1hc3Nlcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how air masses form, move, and influence weather.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601671] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025847280924.jpeg)
</span>

**Pick an air mass!**

A cold dry air mass forms over the interior of Alaska. The mountain is
Mt. McKinley in Denali National Park. A warm wet air mass forms over the
ocean. It sneaks onto the coastal area. Which region would you like to
visit?

### Air Masses {#9.html#x-ck12-QWlyIE1hc3Nlcw.._5-dyo}

An **air mass** is a large body of air that has about the same
conditions throughout. For example, an air mass might have cold dry air.
Another air mass might have warm moist air. The characteristics of an
air mass depend on where the air mass formed. The air must stay over
that location long enough to pick up those characteristics.

#### Formation of Air Masses {#9.html#x-ck12-Rm9ybWF0aW9uIG9mIEFpciBNYXNzZXM._5-f75}

Most air masses form over polar or tropical regions. They may form over
continents or oceans. Air masses are moist if they form over oceans.
They are dry if they form over continents. Air masses that form over
oceans are called maritime air masses. Those that form over continents
are called continental air masses. The image below shows air masses that
form over or near North America ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMDYtTm9ydGhhbWVyaWNhbi1haXItbWFzc2Vz)
).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MmY4ZDVhNzY4NjVhZmE0NjhiOTNiNzQxMTYxNDk3YWI.-gdx"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration; labels added by CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Airmassesorigin.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of North American air
masses](ck12_9_files/20150911025847400738.jpeg "Map of North American air masses")

**Figure 9.7**

North American air masses.

</div>

An air mass takes on the conditions of the area where it forms. For
example, a continental polar air mass has cold dry air. A maritime polar
air mass has cold moist air. Which air masses have warm moist air? Where
do they form?

#### Movement of Air Masses {#9.html#x-ck12-TW92ZW1lbnQgb2YgQWlyIE1hc3Nlcw.._5-n74}

When a new air mass moves over a region it brings its characteristics to
the region. This may change the area's temperature and humidity. Moving
air masses cause the weather to change when they contact different
conditions. For example, a warm air mass moving over cold ground may
cause an inversion.

Why do air masses move? Winds and jet streams push them along. Cold air
masses tend to move toward the Equator. Warm air masses tend to move
toward the poles. The Coriolis effect causes them to move on a diagonal.
Many air masses move toward the northeast over the U.S. This is the same
direction that global winds blow.

Figures and animations explain weather basics at this USA Today site:
[http://www.usatoday.com/weather/wstorm0.htm](wstorm0.htm) .

An online guide from the University of Illinois about air masses and
fronts is found here:
[http://ww2010.atmos.uiuc.edu/%28Gh%29/guides/mtr/af/home.rxml](home.rxml)
.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._5-uep}

-   An air mass has roughly the same temperature and humidity.
-   Air masses form over regions where the air is stable for a long
    enough time. The air takes on the characteristics of the region.
-   Air masses move when they are pushed by high level winds.

# Weather Fronts {#9.html#x-ck12-V2VhdGhlciBGcm9udHM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define different types of fronts.
-   Explain how fronts create changes in weather.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601675] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025847511982.jpeg)
</span>

**What happens when one air mass meets another?**

This sight is common when one air mass meets another. You can almost see
one air mass being pushed up over the other. When two air masses meet,
the result is often a storm. Have you been to the Midwestern United
States in the spring? This is a common sight.

### Fronts {#9.html#x-ck12-RnJvbnRz_6-n84}

When cold air masses move south from the poles, they run into warm air
masses moving north from the tropics. The boundary between two air
masses is called a **front** . Air masses usually don’t mix at a front.
The differences in temperature and pressure cause clouds and
precipitation. Types of fronts include cold, warm, occluded, and
stationary fronts.

### Cold Fronts {#9.html#x-ck12-Q29sZCBGcm9udHM._6-vxg}

A **cold front** forms when a cold air mass runs into a warm air mass (
**Figure** [below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMDctQ29sZC1mcm9udA..) ).
The cold air mass moves faster than the warm air mass. So the cold air
mass lifts the warm air mass out of its way. As the warm air rises, its
water vapor condenses. Clouds form, and precipitation falls. If the warm
air is very humid, precipitation can be heavy. Temperature and pressure
differences between the two air masses cause winds. Winds may be very
strong along a cold front.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MjQxNmExOTRhZjM5YTVmZWE5ZWY1YjdlZmNhMjUxZmM.-8wp"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of a cold
front](ck12_9_files/20150911025847685459.jpeg "Diagram of a cold front")

**Figure 9.8**

Cold fronts often bring stormy weather.

</div>

As the fast-moving cold air mass keeps advancing, so does the cold
front. Cold fronts often bring sudden changes in the weather. There may
be a thin line of storms right at the front that moves as it moves. In
the spring and summer, the storms may be thunderstorms and tornadoes. In
the late fall and winter, the storms may bring snow. After a cold front
passes, the cold air mass behind it brings cooler temperatures. The air
is likely to be less humid as well. Can you explain why?

#### Warm Fronts {#9.html#x-ck12-V2FybSBGcm9udHM._6-dsb}

When a warm air mass runs into a cold air mass, it creates a **warm
front** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMDgtV2FybS1mcm9udA..) ). The warm air
mass is moving faster than the cold air mass. The warm air mass then
flows up over the cold air mass. As the warm air rises, it cools. This
brings about clouds and sometimes light precipitation. Warm fronts move
slowly and cover a wide area. After a warm front passes, the warm air
mass behind it brings warmer temperatures. The warm air is also likely
to be more humid.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MmVhN2E0YjI1ZmYxMmYyOGM1NDIxMDE4M2YyYTYwNDc.-s9g"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of a warm
front](ck12_9_files/20150911025847775428.jpeg "Diagram of a warm front")

**Figure 9.9**

Warm fronts generally bring cloudy weather.

</div>

#### Occluded Fronts {#9.html#x-ck12-T2NjbHVkZWQgRnJvbnRz_6-ior}

With an **occluded front** , a warm air mass becomes trapped between two
cold air masses. The warm air is lifted up above the cold air (
**Figure** [below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMDktT2NjbHVkZWQtZnJvbnQ.)
). Cloudy weather and precipitation along the front are typical.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-ZjA3ODdmMGY4ZjFiZTgyZTUwZGU2NzU2ODQyMDVkNmE.-xtj"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of an occluded
front](ck12_9_files/20150911025847902463.jpeg "Diagram of an occluded front")

**Figure 9.10**

How does an occluded front differ from a warm or cold front?

</div>

#### Stationary Fronts {#9.html#x-ck12-U3RhdGlvbmFyeSBGcm9udHM._6-bdp}

Sometimes two air masses stop moving when they meet. These stalled air
masses create a **stationary front** . Such a front may bring clouds and
precipitation to the same area for many days.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._6-qni}

-   Much of the weather occurs at fronts, where air masses meet.
-   In a warm front, a warm air mass slides over a cold air mass. In a
    cold front, a cold air mass slides under a warm air mass.
-   An occluded front has three air masses: cold, warm, and cold.

# Thunderstorms {#9.html#x-ck12-VGh1bmRlcnN0b3Jtcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how thunderstorms form, grow, and produce lightning
    and thunder.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601683] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025848012897.jpeg)
</span>

**How do you get struck by lightning?**

An average of 55 people die from lightning strikes each year in the
United States. Here's your best chance for being struck by lightning,
according to NASA. Go golfing on a July Sunday at around 4 pm,
especially in Florida. The golf club up in the air acts as a lightning
rod. The late afternoon in July is a great time for thunderstorms.
Florida is prone to thunderstorms, and Sunday is a day on which a lot of
people like to golf. In other words, don't do these things!

### Thunderstorms {#9.html#x-ck12-VGh1bmRlcnN0b3Jtcw.._7-4gk}

**Thunderstorms** are are known for their heavy rains and lightning. In
strong thunderstorms, hail and high winds are also likely. Thunderstorms
are very common. Worldwide, there are about 14 million of them each
year! In the U.S., they are most common—and strongest—in the Midwest.

#### Thunderstorm Formation {#9.html#x-ck12-VGh1bmRlcnN0b3JtIEZvcm1hdGlvbg.._7-ayw}

Thunderstorms form when the ground is really hot ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1UaHVuZGVyc3Rvcm1Gb3JtYXRpb24.) ). The
air near the ground becomes very warm and humid. This is true in some
locations in late afternoon or early evening in spring and summer. The
warm air rises rapidly, which creates strong updrafts. When the rising
air cools, its water vapor condenses. The updrafts create tall
cumulonimbus clouds. Winds blow the cloud top sideways. This makes the
well-known anvil shape of a cloud known as a thunderhead ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMTItVGh1bmRlcmhlYWQ.) ). Water
droplets and ice fly up through the cloud. When these droplets get heavy
enough, they fall. This starts a downdraft. A convection cell develops
within the cloud. A mature thunderstorm produces gusty winds, lightning,
heavy rain, and hail.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-OWY4MTEyMzY1OGE3MDRjZWQwMTE4ZGQzMmY4MTY1MjM.-0de"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Nicholas A. Tonelli (Flickr:Nicholas_T)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/14922165@N00/543334336/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A thunderhead is a cumulonimbus
cloud](ck12_9_files/20150911025848127585.jpeg "A thunderhead is a cumulonimbus cloud")

**Figure 9.11**

A thunderhead is a cumulonimbus cloud.

</div>

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YjZkZjRkYWIyYjZhOTFjOTQ4MDk1NTdkZWUyMTkyYzI.-ino"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Thunderstorm_formation.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Formation and disappearance of a
thunderstorm](ck12_9_files/20150911025848237756.jpeg "Formation and disappearance of a thunderstorm")

**Figure 9.12**

Formation and disappearance of a thunderstorm.

</div>

#### Lightning and Thunder {#9.html#x-ck12-TGlnaHRuaW5nIGFuZCBUaHVuZGVy_7-ezx}

During a thunderstorm, some parts of a thunderhead become negatively
charged. Other parts become positively charged. The difference in charge
creates lightning. **Lightning** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMTMtTGlnaHRuaW5nLVJlcGxhY2VtZW50) )
is a huge release of electricity. Lightning can jump between oppositely
charged parts of the same cloud, between one cloud and another, or
between a cloud and the ground. Lightning blasts the air with energy.
The air heats and expands so quickly that it explodes. This creates the
loud sound of **thunder** .

Do you know why you always hear the boom of thunder after you see the
flash of lightning? It’s because light travels faster than sound. If you
count the seconds between seeing lightning and hearing thunder, you can
estimate how far away the lightning was. A lapse of five seconds is
equal to about a mile.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YWIxMzYwMjYxZTZmN2Y4Zjc1ZGNhYzBhMTE1MjZkYjE.-kf1"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="sandro visintin" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/sandro87v/7346419324/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Lightning during a
thunderstorm](ck12_9_files/20150911025848355297.jpeg "Lightning during a thunderstorm")

**Figure 9.13**

Lightning flashes during a thunderstorm

</div>

#### The End {#9.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEVuZA.._7-qbr}

The downdrafts cool the air at the base of the cloud. The air is no
longer warm enough to rise. Convection shuts down and the thunderhead
runs out of energy. A thunderstorm usually ends only 15 to 30 minutes
after it begins. New thunderstorms may start in the same area.

Many thunderstorms form individually. During some seasons, they form in
**squall lines** , long lines of thunderstorms, along a cold front.
Squall lines form in spring and early summer in the Midwestern United
States. This is because the maritime tropical (mT) air mass from the
Gulf of Mexico meets the continental polar (cP) air mass from Canada (
**Figure** [below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TcXVhbGxMaW5l) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-Mjg3MTk3MWY0OWVlYmRkMDAzMjA1NTc4ZjVlMWI2MTI.-uon"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the National Weather Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:June_5_2008_squall_line.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of a squall
line](ck12_9_files/20150911025848437125.png "Map of a squall line")

**Figure 9.14**

Cold air from the Rockies collided with warm, moist air from the Gulf of
Mexico to form this squall line.

</div>

An online guide to severe storms from the University of Illinois is
found here:
[http://ww2010.atmos.uiuc.edu/%28Gh%29/guides/mtr/svr/home.rxml](home.rxml)
.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._7-xju}

-   Thunderstorms grow where ground temperatures are extremely high.
-   Convection in the cloud causes raindrops or hailstones to grow.
    Downdrafts ultimately end convection.
-   Squall lines are long lines of thunderstorms that form along a
    cold front.

# Tornadoes {#9.html#x-ck12-VG9ybmFkb2Vz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how and where tornadoes form.
-   Describe how the severity of tornadoes is measured and the damage
    they can cause.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601687] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025848540061.jpeg)
</span>

**Where do you go to see a tornado? Tornado Alley!**

Tornadoes are deadly serious. The deadliest in recent years killed 158
people in Joplin, Missouri in 2011. More than 550 people died in the
United States from tornadoes that year. The deadliest tornado on record
killed 629 people in 1926. This "tri-state" tornado raced across
Missouri, Illinois, and Indiana.

### Tornadoes {#9.html#x-ck12-VG9ybmFkb2Vz_8-fdg}

Severe thunderstorms have a lot of energy and strong winds. This allows
them to produce tornadoes. A **tornado** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NaWR3ZXN0VG9ybmFkbw..) ) is a
funnel-shaped cloud of whirling high winds. The funnel moves along the
ground, destroying everything in its path. As it moves, it loses energy.
Before this happens, it may have gone up to 25 kilometers (16 miles).
Fortunately, tornadoes are narrow. They may be only 150 meters (500
feet) wide. Tornadoes are also called twisters.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-NDM3NmU5NTAyNmFmOGRmMjJjZmY0NDBiOTIyN2IwNDU.-cqv"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jarrod Cook/NWS" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AbingdonTornado_2.JPG" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Picture of a
tornado](ck12_9_files/20150911025848651069.jpeg "Picture of a tornado")

**Figure 9.15**

Tornadoes are small but mighty storms.

</div>

#### Classifying Tornadoes {#9.html#x-ck12-Q2xhc3NpZnlpbmcgVG9ybmFkb2Vz_8-exu}

The winds of a tornado can reach very high speeds. The faster the winds
blow, the greater the damage they cause. Wind speed and damage are used
to classify tornadoes ( **Table**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6RnVqaXRhU2NhbGU.) ).

  **F-Scale Rating**   **Wind Speed (kilometers per hour)**   **Wind Speed (miles per hour)**   **Damage**
  -------------------- -------------------------------------- --------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------
  F0                   64-116                                 40-72                             Light - tree branches fall and chimneys may collapse
  F1                   117-180                                73-112                            Moderate - mobile homes, autos pushed aside
  F2                   181-253                                113-157                           Considerable - roofs torn off houses, large trees uprooted
  F3                   254-332                                158-206                           Severe - houses torn apart, trees uprooted, cars lifted
  F4                   333-419                                207-260                           Devastating - houses leveled, cars thrown
  F5                   420-512                                261-318                           Incredible - structures fly, cars become missiles
  F6                   &gt;512                                &gt;318                           Maximum tornado wind speed

#### Tornado Alley {#9.html#x-ck12-VG9ybmFkbyBBbGxleQ.._8-39n}

Look at the map below ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Ub3JuYWRvQWxsZXk.) ). It shows where
the greatest number of tornadoes occur in the U.S. Tornadoes can happen
almost anywhere in the U.S., but only this area is called “Tornado
Alley.” Why do so many tornadoes occur here? This is where warm air
masses from the south run into cold air masses from the north.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MWVlODVmZjYxZmIxMTJhZjM4YTkxMzg5Njc2NWI3YWI.-bse"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tor_alley.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of Tornado
Alley](ck12_9_files/20150911025848788159.jpeg "Map of Tornado Alley")

**Figure 9.16**

Tornadoes are most common in the central part of the U.S.

</div>

#### Damage {#9.html#x-ck12-RGFtYWdl_8-wmo}

A tornado only strikes a small area. But it can destroy everything in
its path. Most injuries and deaths from tornadoes are caused by flying
debris ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NdXJmcmVlc2Jvcm9Ub3JuYWRvRGFtYWdl) ).
In the United States, an average of 90 people are killed by tornadoes
each year. The most violent two percent of tornadoes account for 70% of
the deaths by tornadoes.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-ODlkNDczZjJhMjhmZDYwZTEzN2I1OGVlOWVmZjE4NTk.-ur5"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Woody Hatchett" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Murfreesboro_tornado_damage.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Damage caused by a
tornado](ck12_9_files/20150911025848899010.jpeg "Damage caused by a tornado")

**Figure 9.17**

Tornado damage that occurred in the City of Murfreesboro, TN when it was
struck by an F-4 tornado.

</div>

#### April 2011 {#9.html#x-ck12-QXByaWwgMjAxMQ.._8-jy8}

Late April 2011 saw the deadliest set of tornadoes in more than 25
years. There were more than 150 tornadoes reported throughout the day!
Severe thunderstorms came about when two very different air masses met.
A warm moist air mass blew north from the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of
Mexico (mT). It rammed into a cold polar air mass (cP) that the was
sitting over the region. In addition, the jet stream was blowing
strongly in from the west ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTYtMjcuNS1Ub3JuYWRvLVNhdGVsbGl0ZQ..) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-ZDk4YzJhZDRiNTE3NmM5ZmZjOWQ4NDI2MGU3NzhjZjE.-gro"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of GOES Project Science team, NASA's Earth Observatory" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/view.php?id=50347" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Satellite image of tornado spree in
2011](ck12_9_files/20150911025849019007.jpeg "Satellite image of tornado spree in 2011")

**Figure 9.18**

April 27-28, 2011. The cold air mass is shown by the mostly continuous
clouds. The warm air mass is indicated by small low clouds.
Thunderstorms are indicated by bright white patches.

</div>

Everyone in the region was told that tornadoes were possible. But it's
impossible to know exactly where and when a tornado will touch down. The
path it will take is unknown, because tornado movement is not very
predictable.

Tornado catchers capture footage inside a tornado on this National
Geographic video:
[http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0506/feature6/multimedia.html](multimedia.html)
.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._8-aq8}

-   A tornado is a whirling funnel of air extending down from a
    cumulonimbus cloud.
-   The Fujita scale measures tornado intensity based on wind speed
    and damage.
-   Tornadoes can only be predicted over a wide region.

# Mid-Latitude Cyclones {#9.html#x-ck12-TWlkLUxhdGl0dWRlIEN5Y2xvbmVz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe mid-latitude cyclones.
-   Describe nor'easters.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601694] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025849110020.jpeg)
</span>

**Did you go out on Halloween in 2011?**

If you did, you probably don't live in the northeastern United States.
In much of the region, Halloween was postponed in 2011. A large and
early nor'easter struck the area. The massive storm dropped as much as
32 inches of snow. It caused over three million people to lose power. In
all, 39 people died.

### Mid-Latitude Cyclones {#9.html#x-ck12-TWlkLUxhdGl0dWRlIEN5Y2xvbmVz_9-vcq}

Cyclones can be the most intense storms on Earth. A **cyclone** is a
system of winds that rotate around a low pressure center. The swirling
air rises and cools. This creates clouds and precipitation.

**Mid-latitude cyclones** form at the polar front. Two very different
air masses blow past each other in opposite directions. The Coriolis
effect causes winds to strike the polar front at an angle. Warm and cold
fronts form next to each other.

Most winter storms in the middle latitudes, including most of the United
States and Europe, are caused by mid-latitude cyclones ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTE2MDMtMTA.) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-OWEwMDZlNzZkZDgwYjFjYmZlM2IyYjg4ZjAxNDI3Mzc.-aas"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Michael Billington (Wikipedia: MichaelBillington)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Uk-cyclone-2.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A hypothetical mid-latitude cyclone affecting the United
Kingdom](ck12_9_files/20150911025849272060.png "A hypothetical mid-latitude cyclone affecting the United Kingdom")

**Figure 9.19**

A hypothetical mid-latitude cyclone affecting the United Kingdom. The
arrows point the wind direction and its relative temperature; L is the
low pressure area. Notice the warm, cold, and occluded fronts.

</div>

The warm air at the cold front rises and creates a low pressure cell.
Winds rush into the low pressure. This creates a rising column of air.
The air twists, rotating counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and
clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. Since the rising air is moist,
rain or snow falls.

Mid-latitude cyclones form in winter in the mid-latitudes. The storms
move eastward with the westerly winds. These two- to five-day storms can
reach 1,000 to 2,500 km (625 to 1,600 miles) in diameter. They can
produce winds up to 125 km (75 miles) per hour.

#### Nor'easters {#9.html#x-ck12-Tm9yJ2Vhc3RlcnM._9-32d}

Mid-latitude cyclones are especially fierce in the mid-Atlantic and New
England states. They are called **nor’easters** because they come from
the northeast. About 30 nor’easters strike the region each year (
**Figure** [below](#9.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTE2MDMtMTE.) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YTFlNWY0Yjc4NTI5MTM3OTYzMDllNzUwNjcwOWJiOWU.-wu3"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Storm_of_the_century_satellite.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The 1993 “Storm of the Century” was a nor’easter that covered the
entire eastern seaboard of the United
States](ck12_9_files/20150911025849381668.png "The 1993 “Storm of the Century” was a nor’easter that covered the entire eastern seaboard of the United States")

**Figure 9.20**

The 1993 “Storm of the Century” was a nor’easter that covered the entire
eastern seaboard of the United States.

</div>

An online guide to mid-latitude cyclones from the University of Illinois
is found here:
[http://ww2010.atmos.uiuc.edu/%28Gh%29/guides/mtr/cyc/home.rxml](home.rxml)
.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._9-6wb}

-   A cyclone is a system of winds rotating around an area of
    low pressure.
-   A mid-latitude cyclone forms at the polar front. This occurs when
    the temperature difference between air masses is very large.
-   Nor'easters are mid-latitude cyclones that come from the northeast.

# Hurricanes {#9.html#x-ck12-SHVycmljYW5lcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe hurricane formation and the damage they cause.
-   Describe how hurricanes are measured.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601697] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025849512224.jpeg)
</span>

**Ever been to The Big Easy?**

New Orleans, Louisiana is a city unlike any other. The city is known for
it's Cajun food, jazz music, and full out celebration of Mardi Gras.
Residents love the city with a great intensity. Yet, many people who
evacuated before Hurricane Katrina have not returned. The population is
nearly 30% lower than it was in August 2005. Many sections of the city
have still not recovered.

### Hurricanes {#9.html#x-ck12-SHVycmljYW5lcw.._10-pqj}

Tornadoes may also come from hurricanes. A **hurricane** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTE2MDMtMTI.) ) is an enormous storm with
high winds and heavy rains. Hurricanes may be hundreds of kilometers
wide. They may travel for thousands of kilometers. The storm's wind
speeds may be greater than 251 kilometers (156 miles) per hour.
Hurricanes develop from tropical cyclones. Hurricanes are called
typhoons in the Pacific.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-N2U3NjhhYTc0ZWY3YmE1OGZiYjlkNmVmZGM4OTJjMTM.-2cb"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hurricane_structure_graphic.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A cross-sectional view of a
hurricane](ck12_9_files/20150911025849611018.jpeg "A cross-sectional view of a hurricane")

**Figure 9.21**

A cross-sectional view of a hurricane.

</div>

#### Hurricane Formation {#9.html#x-ck12-SHVycmljYW5lIEZvcm1hdGlvbg.._10-3y8}

Hurricanes are cyclones. Since they form in the tropics, they are called
tropical cyclones. These storms form over very warm ocean water in
summer and autumn. The temperature of the sea surface must be 28 ^o^ C
(82 ^o^ F) or higher. The air above the water warms and rises. This
forms a low pressure cell. The air begins to rotate around the low
pressure cell. Water vapor condenses. If conditions are right, the storm
will build into a hurricane in two to three days.

Hurricanes are huge and produce high winds. Rainfall can be as high as
2.5 cm (1") per hour. The total rainfall can be 20 billion metric tons
daily. The enormous amounts of energy released could equal the total
annual electrical power consumption of the United States. That's from
just one storm. Hurricanes can also generate tornadoes.

Hurricanes move with the prevailing winds. In the Northern Hemisphere,
they originate in the trade winds and are blown to the west. When they
reach the westerlies, they switch direction. So they travel toward the
north or northeast. You can look at a map of hurricane tracks to see
this happen ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FU0NhdGVnb3J5M0h1cnJpY2FuZVRyYWNrcw..) ).
Hurricanes may cover 800 km (500 miles) in one day.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YmUzZjA5NWUwMDhkYzVmMDg3MGMyZmM5Mzc1MjA0MDc.-req"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Titoxd/Wikimedia Commons, using image courtesy of NASA/National Hurricane Center" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Category_3_Atlantic_hurricane_tracks.png" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of Category 3
hurricanes](ck12_9_files/20150911025849719262.png "Map of Category 3 hurricanes")

**Figure 9.22**

Track map of all hurricanes that have achieved Category 3 intensity in
the Atlantic basin, without reaching higher intensities. The points show
the location of the storm at 6-hour intervals. The colour represents the
storm's maximum sustained wind speeds as classified in the
Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, and the shape of the data points
represent the nature of the storm (see source link).

</div>

#### The Eye of a Hurricane {#9.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEV5ZSBvZiBhIEh1cnJpY2FuZQ.._10-k5x}

At the center of a hurricane is a small area where the air is calm and
clear. This is called the eye of the hurricane ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1IdXJyaWNhbmVJZ29yMjAxMA..) ). The eye
forms at the low-pressure center of the hurricane. Air in the eye rises
upward.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-ZGRiOTAyOWE3ZmUwNDc5MmExZjMyM2JlYzVlNDY2MGM.-uz1"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA/International Space Station" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Eye_of_Hurricane_Igor_2010-09-14_1356Z.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The eye of a hurricane seen from
space](ck12_9_files/20150911025849844965.jpeg "The eye of a hurricane seen from space")

**Figure 9.23**

The eye of this hurricane is easy to see from space.

</div>

#### The End {#9.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEVuZA.._10-jpm}

Since hot water gives a hurricane its energy, the storm will grow
stronger as long as it stays over the warm ocean. If it goes ashore or
moves over cooler water, it is cut off from the hot water energy. This
sill cause the storm to lose strength and slowly fade away.

Hurricanes typically last for five to ten days. The winds push them
until they are over cooler water or land. When a hurricane
disintegrates, it is replaced with intense rains and tornadoes.

#### Classifying Hurricanes {#9.html#x-ck12-Q2xhc3NpZnlpbmcgSHVycmljYW5lcw.._10-z0j}

Like tornadoes, hurricanes are classified on the basis of wind speed and
damage ( **Table** [below](#9.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6U2FmZmlyU2ltcHNvbg..)
).

  **Category**      **Wind Speed (kilometers per hour)**   **Wind Speed (miles per hour)**   **Damage**
  ----------------- -------------------------------------- --------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  1 (weak)          119-153                                74-95                             Above normal; no real damage to structures
  2 (moderate)      154-177                                96-110                            Some roofing, door, and window damage; considerable damage to vegetation, mobile homes, and piers
  3 (strong)        178-209                                111-130                           Some buildings damaged; mobile homes destroyed
  4 (very strong)   210-251                                131-156                           Complete roof failure on small residences; major erosion of beach areas; major damage to lower floors of structures near shore
  5 (devastating)   &gt;251                                &gt;156                           Complete roof failure on many residences and industrial buildings; some complete building failure

#### Damage {#9.html#x-ck12-RGFtYWdl_10-ja6}

So much rain falling so fast causes some of the damage from a hurricane.
But a lot of the damage is caused by storm surge. **Storm surge** is
very high water located in the low pressure eye of the hurricane. The
very low pressure of the eye allows the water level to rise above normal
sea level. Storm surge can cause flooding when it reaches land (
**Figure** [below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMTctU3Rvcm0tc3VyZ2U.) ).
High winds do a great deal of damage in hurricanes. High winds can also
create very big waves. If the large waves are atop a storm surge, the
high water can flood the shore. If the storm happens to occur at high
tide, the water will rise even higher.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MmNmMzA5ZjhkYTNiNDI4ZjExNWExNTk1YzUxNDk2Y2M.-qwe"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Emmanuel.boutet/Wikimedia Commons, based on image by Robert Simmon, NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Surge-en.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![](ck12_9_files/20150911025849977100.png)

**Figure 9.24**

Storm surge can cause serious flooding.

</div>

There are about 100 hurricanes around the world each year. There are
many smaller tropical storms and tropical depressions. As people develop
coastal regions, property damage from storms continues to rise. However,
scientists are becoming better at predicting storms. Fatalities are
decreasing. The one major exception was Hurricane Katrina.

#### Hurricane Katrina {#9.html#x-ck12-SHVycmljYW5lIEthdHJpbmE._10-vj6}

The 2005 Atlantic hurricane season was unprecedented. The hurricane
season was longer than normal, and there were many more storms. The
damage from the storms was the greatest in history. The total cost was
estimated at more than \$128 billion. There were more than 2,280 deaths.

Hurricane Katrina was both the most destructive hurricane and the most
deadly. When the levees that protect the city broke, much of the city
was flooded ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1IdXJyaWNhbmVLYXRyaW5hRmxvb2Rpbmc.) ).
The hurricane was the costliest natural disaster in U.S. history. Nearly
2,000 people died, and damage was estimated at over \$80 billion.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-ODQxYWIyYWVlNGZmNjhhZWQ1NTYwZDcwNDJlNTY5MTA.-zer"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Paul Morse" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hurricane_Katrina_Flooding.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![](ck12_9_files/20150911025850076988.jpeg)

**Figure 9.25**

Flooding in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina caused the levees to
break. Water poured into the city.

</div>

News about Hurricane Katrina from the New Orleans Times-Picayune:
[http://www.nola.com/katrina/graphics/flashflood.swf](flashflood.swf) .

An animation of a radar image of Hurricane Katrina making landfall is
seen here:
[http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/97/Hurricane\_Katrina\_LA\_landfall\_radar.gif](Hurricane_Katrina_LA_landfall_radar.gif)
.

NASA’s short video, "In Katrina’s Wake":
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZjqvqaLltI](watch?v=HZjqvqaLltI) .

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-7zp}

-   Hurricanes are cyclones that form in tropical latitudes. They are
    called tropical cyclones.
-   Hurricanes have high winds that blow around a low pressure zone. In
    the low pressure zones, air moves upward. This is the eye of
    the hurricane.
-   The damage hurricanes cause is due largely to storm surge. High wind
    speeds and rain also cause damage.
-   Hurricane Katrina was so damaging because the levees that protected
    New Orleans broke.

# Blizzards {#9.html#x-ck12-QmxpenphcmRz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the conditions that create blizzards.
-   Explain how lake-effect snow forms.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601701] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025850228479.jpeg)
</span>

**Where are the snowiest cities in the United States?**

Eight of the top ten cities with the highest average snowfall are in
upstate New York. This region gets so much snow because it is on the
leeward side of the Great Lakes. The area receives lake-effect snow. If
you plan to visit in winter, strap on your snow shoes!

### Winter Storms {#9.html#x-ck12-V2ludGVyIFN0b3Jtcw.._11-l0v}

Like hurricanes, winter storms develop from cyclones. But in the case of
winter storms, the cyclones form at higher latitudes. In North America,
cyclones often form when the jet stream dips south in the winter. This
lets dry polar air pour south. At the same time, warm moist air from the
Gulf of Mexico flows north. When the two air masses meet, the
differences in temperature and pressure cause strong winds and heavy
precipitation. Blizzards and lake-effect snow storms are two types of
winter storms that occur in the U.S.

#### Blizzards {#9.html#x-ck12-QmxpenphcmRz_11-t8j}

A **blizzard** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMTgtV2FzaGluZ3Rvbi1ibGl6emFyZA..) )
is a snow storm that has high winds. To be called a blizzard, a storm
must have winds greater than 56 kilometers (35 miles) per hour and
visibility of ¼ mile or less because of wind-blown snow.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-Y2M2NmUwYmE0MDI5ZjNmNGRlNDYxNGM2OGQ4MzAyY2Y.-xnm"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Dave Newman" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/groovysoup/4343759488/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Blizzard in Washington
D.C.](ck12_9_files/20150911025850368385.jpeg "Blizzard in Washington D.C.")

**Figure 9.26**

Blizzard in Washington, D.C. Blizzards are unusual in Washington, D.C.
Do they ever occur where you live?

</div>

Blizzards are dangerous storms. The wind may blow the snow into deep
drifts. Along with the poor visibility, the snow drifts make driving
risky. The wind also makes cold temperatures more dangerous. The greater
the wind speed, the higher the windchill. **Windchill** is what the
temperature feels like when the wind is taken into account. It depends
on air temperature and wind speed ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMTktV2luZGNoaWxsLWNoYXJ0) ). Higher
windchill will cause a person to suffer frostbite and other harmful
effects of cold sooner than if the wind isn't blowing.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MThlZTQ0OTMzNDhkZjI1MzZkMmUzMWE5OWI4ZjBkMjE.-pqn"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of National Weather Service, NOAA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.nws.noaa.gov/om/windchill/" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Windchill temperature
chart](ck12_9_files/20150911025850489559.jpeg "Windchill temperature chart")

**Figure 9.27**

Windchill temperatures may be very low in blizzards because of the high
wind speeds. How long does it take for frostbite to occur when the air
temperature is 0° F and the wind speed is 55 miles per hour?

</div>

#### Lake-Effect Snow {#9.html#x-ck12-TGFrZS1FZmZlY3QgU25vdw.._11-jwi}

Some places receive very heavy snowfall just about every winter. If they
are near a lake, they may be getting **lake-effect snow** . The image
below shows how lake-effect snow occurs ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjAtTGFrZS1lZmZlY3Qtc25vdw..) ).
Winter winds pick up moisture as they pass over the relatively warm
waters of a large lake. When the winds reach the cold land on the other
side, the air cools. Since there was so much moisture in the air, it can
drop a lot of snow. More than 254 centimeters (100 inches) of snow may
fall in a single lake-effect storm!

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-NTM1NWJiNzQ5ODFjZGYwYzg5YzkyZGZmZGZlYmU2ODE.-inm"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of lake-effect
snow](ck12_9_files/20150911025850603069.png "Diagram of lake-effect snow")

**Figure 9.28**

Lake-effect snow falls on the east side of lakes in North America. These
snows are heaviest on the east sides of the Great Lakes.

</div>

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._11-osu}

-   Blizzards are often part of a mid-latitude cyclone. The jet stream
    brings cold air into contact with warm moist air.
-   The difference in pressure between the air masses brings about
    strong winds.
-   Cold polar air absorbs moisture as it travels over the Great Lakes.
    The air cools when it goes back over land and then dumps snow. This
    creates lake-effect snow.

# Heat Waves and Droughts {#9.html#x-ck12-SGVhdCBXYXZlcyBhbmQgRHJvdWdodHM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the causes of heat waves.
-   Describe the causes of droughts.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601704] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025850695456.jpeg)
</span>

**Is the current drought like the Dust Bowl?**

The worst heat wave in U.S. history came in 1936. The already struggling
Midwest was hit hard by extreme temperatures and drought. Crops were
destroyed, and more than 5,000 people died. The Midwest and Southwest
are currently suffering with drought. While serious, it is not yet a
situation like the Dust Bowl.

### Heat Waves {#9.html#x-ck12-SGVhdCBXYXZlcw.._12-yks}

A **heat wave** is different depending on its location. A region has a
heat wave if it has more than five consecutive days of temperatures that
are more than 9 ^o^ F (5 ^o^ C) above average. A heat wave in Portland,
Oregon might be just an average warm week in Phoenix, Arizona.

Heat waves have increased in frequency and duration in recent years. The
summer 2011 North American heat wave brought record temperatures across
the Midwestern and Eastern United States. Many states and localities
broke records for temperature and for the most days above 100 ^o^ F.

#### Causes {#9.html#x-ck12-Q2F1c2Vz_12-1xp}

A high pressure cell sitting over a region with no movement is the
likely cause of a heat wave.

What do you think caused the heat wave in the image below ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTYtNDgtSGVhdC13YXZl) )? A high pressure
zone kept the jet stream farther north than normal for August.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MDNkMzRjMzBhODJlYTA4YzY5N2Y5MzhkNDY1MjhkNzk.-rrp"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Jesse Allen, NASA's Earth Observatory" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=7968" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Satellite image of a heat
wave](ck12_9_files/20150911025850815845.jpeg "Satellite image of a heat wave")

**Figure 9.29**

A heat wave over the United States as indicated by heat radiated from
the ground. The bright yellow areas are the hottest, and the blue and
white are coolest.

</div>

### Droughts {#9.html#x-ck12-RHJvdWdodHM._12-mkc}

**Droughts** also depend on what is normal for a region. A region that
gets significantly less precipitation than normal for an extended period
of time is in drought. The Southern United States is experiencing an
ongoing and prolonged drought.

Drought has many consequences. When soil loses moisture it may blow
away. This happened during the Dust Bowl in the United States in the
1930s. Forests may be lost, dust storms may become common, and wildlife
are disturbed. Wildfires become much more common during times of
drought.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-ilg}

-   A heat wave or a drought is defined as conditions different from
    normal in a region.
-   A heat wave is caused when a warm high-pressure cell sits over
    a region.
-   Drought may have extremely severe consequences. The severity depends
    on its duration and intensity.

# Collecting Weather Data {#9.html#x-ck12-Q29sbGVjdGluZyBXZWF0aGVyIERhdGE.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how scientists collect information about weather.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601708] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025850935491.png) </span>

**What does a meteorologist need before he or she can forecast the
weather?**

Data! A meteorologist needs data about the current conditions. There are
many types of instruments available for collecting that data. According
to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a 5-day weather forecast
today is as reliable as a 2-day forecast was 20 years ago.

### Predicting the Weather {#9.html#x-ck12-UHJlZGljdGluZyB0aGUgV2VhdGhlcg.._13-9ld}

Weather is very difficult to predict. That’s because it’s very complex,
and many factors are involved. Slight changes in even one factor can
cause a big change in the weather. Still, certain “rules of thumb”
generally apply. These “rules” help meteorologists forecast the weather.
For example, low pressure is likely to bring stormy weather. So if a
center of low pressure is moving your way, you can expect a storm.

People often complain when the weather forecast is wrong. Weather
forecasts today, however, are much more accurate than they were just 20
years ago. Scientists who study and forecast the weather are called
meteorologists. How do they predict the weather?

The first thing they need is data. Their data comes from various
instruments.

### Weather Instruments {#9.html#x-ck12-V2VhdGhlciBJbnN0cnVtZW50cw.._13-sbg}

Weather instruments measure weather conditions. One of the most
important conditions is air pressure, which is measured with a
**barometer** ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjMtQmFyb21ldGVy) ). There are also a
number of other commonly used weather instruments ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjQtV2VhdGhlci1pbnN0cnVtZW50cw..) ):

-   A **thermometer** measures temperature.
-   An **anemometer** measures wind speed.
-   A **rain gauge** measures the amount of rain.
-   A **hygrometer** measures humidity.
-   A **wind vane** shows wind direction.
-   A **snow gauge** measures the amount of snow.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YWRhYjFiMDkxYjNmNTk0OWJlNjJkYmQxMGNiMDVkMTI.-ea6"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of a
barometer](ck12_9_files/20150911025851056688.png "Diagram of a barometer")

**Figure 9.30**

The greater the air pressure outside the tube, the higher the mercury
rises inside the tube. Mercury can rise in the tube, because there’s no
air pressing down on it.

</div>

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-Yjg3YTY4ZWYxZTQ0ODMzMDhiNzMzZjIxNWYxZGE4YzQ.-qc5"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Rain: Flickr:wsssst; Snow: KaCey97007; Thermometer/Hygrometer: Karl-Ludwig G. Poggemann (Flickr:quapan);  Anemometer: Aidan (Flickr:asgw); Wind vane: Flickr:BobMacInnes" -->
<!-- @@url="Rain: http://www.flickr.com/photos/28451957@N06/3893749914/; Snow: http://www.flickr.com/photos/kacey/361574480/; Thermometer/Hygrometer: http://www.flickr.com/photos/hinkelstone/9373361762/; Anemometer: http://www.flickr.com/photos/aidanwojtas/2307169752/; Wind vane: http://www.flickr.com/photos/lonetown/402414353/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Pictures of a rain gauge, snow gauge, thermometer, hygrometer,
anemometer, and wind
vane](ck12_9_files/20150911025851158280.jpeg "Pictures of a rain gauge, snow gauge, thermometer, hygrometer, anemometer, and wind vane")

**Figure 9.31**

Some of the most commonly used weather instruments.

</div>

#### Collecting Data {#9.html#x-ck12-Q29sbGVjdGluZyBEYXRh_13-des}

Weather instruments collect data from all over the world at thousands of
weather stations ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjctV2VhdGhlci1kYXRhLWNvbGxlY3Rpbmc.)
). Many are on land, but some float in the oceans on buoys. There’s
probably at least one weather station near you.

Other weather devices are needed to collect weather data in the
atmosphere. They include weather balloons, satellites, and **radar** (
**Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjctV2VhdGhlci1kYXRhLWNvbGxlY3Rpbmc.)
).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-NmY3YmNlYjE0MDY5YzdhZTViN2ZkMTNkMzFiOTI1ZTk.-t3h"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Weather Station: Courtesy of Scott Bauer, USDA; Weather Balloon: Wolke; Weather Satellite, Weather Radar: Courtesy of NOAA" -->
<!-- @@url="Weather Station: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Weather_Station_USDA.jpg; Weather Balloon: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Ballon_radiosonde_f.jpg; Weather Satellite: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:GOES_8_Spac0255.jpg; Weather Radar: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sturmfront_auf_Doppler-Radar-Schirm.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Weather stations, balloons, satellites, and radar are used to make
weather
forecasts](ck12_9_files/20150911025851256202.jpeg "Weather stations, balloons, satellites, and radar are used to make weather forecasts")

**Figure 9.32**

Weather stations collect data on land and sea. Weather balloons,
satellites, and radar collect data in the atmosphere.

</div>

**Weather stations** contain many instruments for measuring weather
conditions. The **weather balloon** ( **Figure**
[above](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjctV2VhdGhlci1kYXRhLWNvbGxlY3Rpbmc.)
) will rise into the atmosphere until it bursts. As it rises, it will
gather weather data and send it to the surface. Many **weather
satellites** orbit Earth. They constantly collect and transmit weather
data from high above the surface. A radar device sends out radio waves
in all directions. The waves bounce off water in the atmosphere and then
return to the sender. The radar data shows where precipitation is
falling. It’s raining in the orange-shaded area shown above.

#### Using Computers {#9.html#x-ck12-VXNpbmcgQ29tcHV0ZXJz_13-fry}

What do meteorologists do with all that weather data? They use it in
weather models. The models analyze the data and predict the weather. The
models require computers. That’s because so many measurements and
calculations are involved.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._13-jht}

-   Various instruments measure weather conditions: thermometers measure
    air temperature, and barometers measure air pressure.
-   Satellites monitor weather from above.
-   Radar is used to monitor precipitation.

# Weather Maps {#9.html#x-ck12-V2VhdGhlciBNYXBz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the information depicted on weather maps.
-   Analyze weather maps.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601711] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025851360369.png) </span>

**What can a weather map tell you about the weather?**

A lot! A weather map indicates all sorts of things to let you know the
forecast. It also may have some cute graphics associated with it.

### Weather Maps {#9.html#x-ck12-V2VhdGhlciBNYXBz_14-o91}

You may have seen weather maps like the one pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjgtV2VhdGhlci1tYXA.) ). A **weather
map** shows weather conditions for a certain area. The map may show the
actual weather on a given day. It may show the predicted weather for
some time in the future. Some weather maps show many weather conditions.
Others show a single condition.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-OTE4ZGNkZGE5N2I3YzY5MDJjNzMyMDYxNDAwMmY2ZTU.-uwb"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the National Weather Service, NOAA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.aviationweather.gov/adds/progs/" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Weather map showing high and low air pressure
contours](ck12_9_files/20150911025851486605.png "Weather map showing high and low air pressure contours")

**Figure 9.33**

This weather map shows air pressure contours. Which state has the lowest
air pressure shown on the map?

</div>

#### Air Pressure Maps {#9.html#x-ck12-QWlyIFByZXNzdXJlIE1hcHM._14-bsh}

The weather map pictured below ( **Figure**
[above](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTYtMjgtV2VhdGhlci1tYXA.) ) shows air
pressure. The lines on the map connect places that have the same air
pressure. Air pressure is measured in a unit called the millibar.
**Isobars** are the lines that connect the points with the same air
pressure. The map also shows low- and high-pressure centers and fronts.
Find the cold front on the map. This cold front is likely to move toward
the northeast over the next couple of days. How could you use this
information to predict what the weather will be on the East Coast?

#### Other Weather Maps {#9.html#x-ck12-T3RoZXIgV2VhdGhlciBNYXBz_14-kn1}

Instead of air pressure, weather maps may show other weather conditions.
For example, a temperature map might show the high and low temperatures
of major cities. The map may have **isotherms** , lines that connect
places with the same temperature.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-6uq}

-   Weather maps graphically depict weather conditions.
-   Isobars are lines of constant pressure.
-   Isobars indicate pressure cells.

# Weather versus Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-V2VhdGhlciB2ZXJzdXMgQ2xpbWF0ZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define climate, and know how it is different from weather.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601714] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025851622579.jpeg)
</span>

**Where in Hawaii do you want to go?**

Look at a list of cities with the best climate in the United States.
Hawaii is well represented. Now look at a list of cities with the worst
climate in the United States. (You know where this is going, don't you?)
Yes, Hawaii is also represented. Kona and Hilo are both on the Big
Island. Hilo is on the windward side where the trade winds bring in
moisture from the Pacific. Kona is on the leeward side, beyond the high
volcanic mountains. This city lies within the rain shadow. Guess which
city is more popular with tourists?

### What is Climate? {#9.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBpcyBDbGltYXRlPw.._15-kjs}

Almost anything can happen with the weather. Climate, however, is more
predictable. **Climate** is the long-term average of weather in a
particular spot. Good climate is why we choose to vacation in Hawaii in
February (usually on the leeward side). Of course, the weather is not
guaranteed to be good! A location’s climate considers the same
characteristics as its weather. These are its air temperature, humidity,
wind speed and direction, and the type, quantity, and frequency of
precipitation. For climate, these things are averaged over time.

During the mid- to late-twentieth century, California received an
enormous influx of new residents. Many of these people came from the
northeastern United States. They were sick of the cold, snow, and rain.
Southern California, especially near the coast, has a nearly perfect
climate. The average lows and highs in San Diego year round are in the
50s, 60s, and 70s ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NaXNzaW9uQmF5U2FuRGllZ28.) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-MzgyOGE0ZTk5MDEwMDE5MzZhNzllMDMxOGQyNDgxYTI.-6ni"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Dancestrokes, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![A sunny day in San Diego,
California](ck12_9_files/20150911025851730766.jpeg "A sunny day in San Diego, California")

**Figure 9.34**

A bike path along Mission Bay in San Diego, California.

</div>

The climate for a particular place is steady. Changes occur only very
slowly. Climate is determined by many factors, including the angle of
the Sun, the likelihood of cloud cover, and the air pressure. All of
these factors are related to the amount of solar energy that hits that
location over time.

The climate of a region depends on its position relative to many things.
These factors are described in the next sections.

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._15-xdz}

-   Climate is the long-term average of weather.
-   Climate changes very slowly.
-   Climate depends on a number of factors such as air temperature,
    humidity, wind speed and direction, and the type, quantity, and
    frequency of precipitation.

# Effect of Latitude on Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0IG9mIExhdGl0dWRlIG9uIENsaW1hdGU.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how latitude influences a region's climate.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601718] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025851827329.jpeg)
</span>

**Do you want to be a Snowbird?**

A Snowbird is usually a person who is retired. Like a migrating bird,
they go where the weather is good. A snowbird may spend summers "at
home" in Michigan or New York. But they travel to Arizona or Florida to
spend their winters in the Sun and warmth. What would a reverse snowbird
be? A person who spent summers in the 100+ degree heat and winters in
the sub-0 cold. Brrrr....

### Latitude and Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-TGF0aXR1ZGUgYW5kIENsaW1hdGU._16-bpu}

**Latitude** is the distance north or south of the Equator. It’s
measured in degrees, from 0° to 90°. Several climate factors vary with
latitude.

#### Latitude and Temperature {#9.html#x-ck12-TGF0aXR1ZGUgYW5kIFRlbXBlcmF0dXJl_16-kfi}

Temperature changes with latitude ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HbG9iYWxBdmVyYWdlVGVtcGVyYXR1cmU.) ).

-   At the Equator, the Sun’s rays are most direct. This is where
    temperatures are highest.
-   At higher latitudes, the Sun’s rays are less direct. The farther an
    area is from the Equator, the lower its temperature.
-   At the poles, the Sun’s rays are least direct. Much of the area is
    covered with ice and snow, which reflect a lot of sunlight.
    Temperatures are lowest here.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YTRkZjQyN2UzMzk2MjBjZGE5ZTk2Y2IxNDFhZTVmMjQ.-1vg"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@url="http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/spaceimages/details.php?id=PIA00427" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of temperatures of the
Earth](ck12_9_files/20150911025851923176.jpeg "Map of temperatures of the Earth")

**Figure 9.35**

Temperature varies with latitude. If you look closely you can see that
other factors influence temperature. Mountain ranges, for example, are
cooler than they should be for their latitude.

</div>

#### How Much Does Latitude Change Temperature? {#9.html#x-ck12-SG93IE11Y2ggRG9lcyBMYXRpdHVkZSBDaGFuZ2UgVGVtcGVyYXR1cmU__16-doe}

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-N2E5ZDIyZTkxMzE2YTg0YTYwYmFiNTU4YWVjZjdmYWI.-hj1"

Austin, Texas; Wichita, Kansas; Fargo, North Dakota; and Thompson,
Manitoba in Canada all roughly lie on the 97° west longitude line (
**Figure**
[above](#9.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1MYXRpdHVkZVdlYXRoZXJDb21wb3NpdGU.) and

). But they run the length of the North America from 30°N in Austin, to
38°N in Wichita, to 47°N in Fargo, and to 56°N in Thompson. Other
factors affect their climate, but all four cities are inland.

  --------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 **July Avg.    **July Avg.    **January Avg. **January Avg.

  -------------- -------------- -------------- -------------- --------------

The table above shows the variation in high and low temperatures that
are due primarily to latitude ( **Table**
[above](#9.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6TGF0aXR1ZGVDaXRpZXM.) ). Which latitude
would you prefer?

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._16-wku}

-   Latitude affects the amount of solar radiation a place receives.
-   The amount of solar radiation a place receives is greatest at the
    Equator and lessens toward the poles.
-   Latitude is not the only factor that determines the temperature of
    a region.

# Effect of Atmospheric Circulation on Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0IG9mIEF0bW9zcGhlcmljIENpcmN1bGF0aW9uIG9uIENsaW1hdGU.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how climate relates to the global winds.
-   Describe how atmospheric circulation influences precipitation.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601720] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025852269568.jpeg)
</span>

**Would you like to go to the horse latitudes?**

Imagine you're on a sailing ship that's carrying horses among other
cargo. You want to go from Spain to northern South America. For a smooth
ride west, you need to get the ship into the trade winds. But where the
trade winds and the westerlies meet is a zone where air flows vertically
downward. It's hard to get through there in a sailing ship. So your ship
gets stuck. For weeks. There's no more water or food for the horses so
you throw them overboard. Some people think this is where the horse
latitudes got their name.

### More Effects of Latitude on Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-TW9yZSBFZmZlY3RzIG9mIExhdGl0dWRlIG9uIENsaW1hdGU._17-14o}

We saw that the amount of solar radiation an area receives depends on
its latitude. The amount of solar radiation affects the temperature of a
region. Latitude has other effects on climate.

#### Latitude and Prevailing Winds {#9.html#x-ck12-TGF0aXR1ZGUgYW5kIFByZXZhaWxpbmcgV2luZHM._17-kyg}

Global air currents cause global winds. The figure below shows the
direction that these winds blow ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTctMDQtR2xvYmFsLXdpbmRz) ). Global winds
are the prevailing, or usual, winds at a given latitude. The winds move
air masses, which causes weather.

The direction of prevailing winds determines which type of air mass
usually moves over an area. For example, a west wind might bring warm
moist air from over an ocean. An east wind might bring cold dry air from
over a mountain range. Which wind prevails has a big effect on the
climate. What if the prevailing winds are westerlies? The westerlies
blow from nearer the Equator to farther from the Equator. How would they
affect the climate?

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YjczMzM5NmEyMTA4OGYwM2NmOWVjZTA0ZGQ3ZWIzNzE.-gqz"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of National Park Services and Parks as Classroom" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.nps.gov/archive/grsa/resources/curriculum/mid/dunes/photo_files/global_wind.htm" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Map of atmospheric circulation
cells](ck12_9_files/20150911025852405576.png "Map of atmospheric circulation cells")

**Figure 9.38**

The usual direction of the wind where you live depends on your latitude.
This determines where you are in the global wind belts.

</div>

#### Latitude and Precipitation {#9.html#x-ck12-TGF0aXR1ZGUgYW5kIFByZWNpcGl0YXRpb24._17-w5i}

Global air currents affect precipitation. How they affect it varies with
latitude ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTctMDMtR2xvYmFsLWFpci1jdXJyZW50cw..) ).
Where air rises, it cools and there is precipitation. Where air sinks,
it warms and causes evaporation. These patterns are part of the global
wind belts.

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-NmY0NzM1ZTlmNDE2YzFjNmJiNDY2ZGNkOTNhZWRkYmQ.-swd"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Global Circulation Diagram: CK-12 Foundation - Christopher Auyeung; Snow: Kitty Terwolbeck; Forest: Thomas Quine (Flickr:quinet); Desert: John Yavuz Can; Rainforest: Ivan Mlinaric" -->
<!-- @@url="Snow: http://www.flickr.com/photos/kittysfotos/7902668768/; Forest: http://www.flickr.com/photos/quinet/7406208974/; Desert: http://www.flickr.com/photos/yavuzcan/8177337117/; Rainforest: http://www.flickr.com/photos/eye1/3187012243/" -->
<!-- @@license="Global circulation diagram: CC BY-NC 3.0; Remaining images: CC BY 2.0" -->
![Map of global air currents and
climate](ck12_9_files/20150911025852536505.png "Map of global air currents and climate")

**Figure 9.39**

Global air currents are shown on the left. You can see how they affect
climate on the right.

</div>

"Five Factors that Affect Climate" takes a very thorough look at what
creates the climate zones. The climate of a region allows certain plants
to grow, creating an ecological biome:
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E7DLLxrrBV8](watch?v=E7DLLxrrBV8) (5:22)

[![](ck12_9_files/tmpl4H7l7.jpeg)](E7DLLxrrBV8)

Click on the image above for more content

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._17-3vl}

-   Prevailing winds are the result of atmospheric circulation cells.
    They influence the climate of a region.
-   Rising and sinking air can influence the precipitation of a region.
-   Atmospheric circulation cells create the general climate of
    a region.

# Effect of Continental Position on Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-RWZmZWN0IG9mIENvbnRpbmVudGFsIFBvc2l0aW9uIG9uIENsaW1hdGU.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define maritime and continental climates.
-   Explain how continental position and ocean currents affect climate.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601722] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_9_files/20150911025852648279.jpeg)
</span>

**Is latitude making the difference in weather in these three cities?**

No. These three cities are at the same latitude. They are San Francisco,
California; Wichita, Kansas; and Virginia Beach, Virginia. Proximity to
the ocean is important. Also important is the direction the winds are
blowing at this location.

### Oceans and Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW5zIGFuZCBDbGltYXRl_18-cy9}

When a place is near an ocean, the water can have a big effect on the
climate.

#### Coastal and Inland Climates {#9.html#x-ck12-Q29hc3RhbCBhbmQgSW5sYW5kIENsaW1hdGVz_18-ipx}

Places at the same latitude may have very different climates if one is
on a coast and one is inland.

-   On the coast, the climate is influenced by warm moist air from
    the ocean. A coastal climate is usually mild. Summers aren’t too
    hot, and winters aren’t too cold. Precipitation can be high due to
    the moisture in the air. This is a **maritime climate** .
-   Farther inland, the climate is influenced by cold or hot air from
    the land. This air may be dry, because it comes from over land. An
    inland climate is usually more extreme. Winters may be very cold,
    and summers may be very hot. Precipitation can be low. This is a
    **continental climate** .

#### The Influence of the Ocean {#9.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEluZmx1ZW5jZSBvZiB0aGUgT2NlYW4._18-pdu}

The ocean has a big effect on climate. This is obvious when you compare
the temperatures of these three cities. Each of these cities is located
at 37°N latitude, within the westerly winds ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtUmV2LTE3LVdlYXRoZXJfbWFw) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-YWYxZjgxNTQwYTdjZmQ1Y2VjZGUwY2ZhOTRhNDQ3NTY.-ulv"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Laura Guerin" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Difference in climate between San Francisco, Wichita, and Virginia
Beach](ck12_9_files/20150911025852750294.jpeg "Difference in climate between San Francisco, Wichita, and Virginia Beach")

**Figure 9.40**

How does the ocean influence the climate of these three cities?

</div>

The climate of San Francisco is influenced by the Pacific Ocean. The
cool California current comes from the north. Upwelling brings cold
water from the deep. So the water offshore is cold. Virginia Beach is
near the Atlantic Ocean. But its temperatures are more like Wichita than
San Francisco. Why is the climate in Virginia Beach less influenced by
the ocean than San Francisco? *Hint* : Think about the direction the
winds are going at that latitude. The weather in San Francisco comes
from over the Pacific Ocean. Much of the weather in Virginia comes from
the continent.

#### Ocean Currents and Climate {#9.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW4gQ3VycmVudHMgYW5kIENsaW1hdGU._18-eh4}

Ocean currents carry warm or cold water throughout the world’s oceans.
They help to even out the temperatures in the oceans. This also affects
the temperature of the atmosphere and the climate around the world.
Currents that are near shore have a direct impact on climate. They may
make the climate much colder or warmer. Examples of this are pictured
below ( **Figure**
[below](#9.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTQtMjAtR29sZnN0cmVhbQ..) ).

<div id="9.html#x-ck12-ZTdhOTY0Y2ExZDRjYjAwNWRjNzZkZTI0YmI1NGI0NjY.-jml"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Golfstrom.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Satellite image of the Gulf
Stream](ck12_9_files/20150911025852838066.jpeg "Satellite image of the Gulf Stream")

**Figure 9.41**

The Gulf Stream moves warm equatorial water up the western Pacific and
into northern Europe. The warm water raises temperatures in the British
Isles.

</div>

### Summary {#9.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._18-j4l}

-   A maritime climate is influenced by a nearby ocean. A continental
    climate is influenced by nearby land.
-   The temperature of offshore currents affect nearby land areas.
-   A maritime climate is less extreme than a continental climate,
    because the ocean moderates temperatures.
