# Soil Characteristics {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCBDaGFyYWN0ZXJpc3RpY3M.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of soil.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601821] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025920952666.jpeg)
</span>

**How does soil resemble weathered rock?**

The same processes that weather rock create soil. A large part of soil
is weathered rock! If weathering processes didn't exist on earth we
would have no soil. Earth wouldn't be a very good place to live. There
would be very limited plant life and not much way to grow crops.

### The Importance of Soil {#10.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEltcG9ydGFuY2Ugb2YgU29pbA.._4-q47}

You learned in the previous concept that weathering produces sediment.
Weathering also produces soil.

People could not live on earth without soil! Your life and the lives of
many land organisms depend on soil. **Soil** is only a very thin layer
over solid rock. Yet, it is the place where reactions between solid
rock, liquid water and air take place. Soil anchors plant roots and
provides them with water and nutrients. We get wood, paper, cotton,
medicines, and even pure water from soil. So soil is a very important
resource. Our precious soil needs to be carefully managed and cared for.
If we don’t take care of the soil we have, we may not be able to use it
in the future.

### Characteristics of Soil {#10.html#x-ck12-Q2hhcmFjdGVyaXN0aWNzIG9mIFNvaWw._4-0nr}

Soil is a complex mixture of different materials.

-   Some of them are **inorganic** . Inorganic materials are made from
    non-living substances like pebbles and sand.
-   Soil also contains bits of **organic** materials from plants
    and animals.

In general, about half of the soil is made of pieces of rock and
minerals. The other half is organic materials.

In some soils, the organic portion is entirely missing. This is true of
desert sand. At the other extreme, a soil may be completely organic.
Peat, found in a bog or swamp, is totally organic soil. Organic
materials are necessary for a soil to be fertile. The organic portion
provides the nutrients needed for strong plant growth.

### Soil Texture {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCBUZXh0dXJl_4-x90}

The inorganic portion of soil is made of many different size particles.
These different size particles are present in different proportions. The
sizes and proportions of particles determines some of the properties of
the soil.

-   Water can flow easily through a **permeable** soil. Spaces between
    the inorganic particles are large and well connected. Sandy or silty
    soils are permeable, water-draining types of soils.
-   Soils with lots of very small spaces are water-holding soils. When
    clay is present in a soil, the soil holds together more tightly.
    Clay-rich soil can hold more water.
-   When a soil contains a mixture of grain sizes, the soil is called a
    **loam** ( **Figure**
    [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Tb2lsVGV4dHVyZQ..) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-YTNlNGZkMzYwNmYzYzkzYzU1MDk1NTg2ZWNjYzJlZTU.-m4e"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Soil Science" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/soilscience/5086315597/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A sandy soil on the bottom and one with more clay on the
top](ck12_10_files/20150911025921083520.jpeg "A sandy soil on the bottom and one with more clay on the top")

**Figure 10.9**

Two layers of soil are shown here. A sandy soil is at the bottom. A soil
with more clay is at the top.

</div>

#### Classification {#10.html#x-ck12-Q2xhc3NpZmljYXRpb24._4-37l}

Soil scientists classify soil by measuring the percentage of sand, silt,
and clay. They plot this information on a triangular diagram. Each size
particle is at one corner ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtUmV2LTktU29pbF90eXBlcw..) ). The soil
type is then known from the location on the diagram. At the top, a soil
would be clay; at the left corner, it would be sand; at the right
corner, it would be silt. Soils in the lower middle with less than 50%
clay are loams.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZmViZjdhNGRjODZjZTFkODEyNmZiZjJhZjMzODE3YjE.-cdp"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Natural Resource Conservation Service, US Department of Agriculture; modified by CK-12 Foundation - Sam McCabe" -->
<!-- @@url="http://soils.usda.gov/education/resources/lessons/texture/" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Categorizing soil types by particle
size](ck12_10_files/20150911025921202759.png "Categorizing soil types by particle size")

**Figure 10.10**

Soil types by particle size.

</div>

#### Soil, the Ecosystem {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCwgdGhlIEVjb3N5c3RlbQ.._4-0kx}

We can think about soil as a living resource. Soil is an ecosystem all
by itself! In the spaces of soil are millions of living organisms. These
include earthworms, ants, bacteria, and fungi. ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy1FYXJ0aHdvcm1z) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZTJlNTYzODc3ZjliMjA1MGUwZjgxZjRkYjM4YWNhNDE.-fgo"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Chika Watanabe" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/chikawatanabe/848557716/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Earthworms and insects are important residents of
soils](ck12_10_files/20150911025921317883.jpeg "Earthworms and insects are important residents of soils")

**Figure 10.11**

Earthworms and insects are important residents of soils.

</div>

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._4-ihq}

-   Soil reflects the interactions between the lithosphere, atmosphere,
    hydrosphere, and biosphere.
-   Permeable soils allow water to flow through.
-   The proportions of silt, clay, and sand allow scientists to classify
    soil type.

# Soil Formation {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCBGb3JtYXRpb24.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the factors that affect soil formation: weathering,
    climate, parent rock, slope, time and biological activity.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601826] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025921431042.jpeg)
</span>

**How are these two soils different?**

What color is the soil on the left? What color is the soil on the right?
Why do you think they differ so much in color? Which soil do you think
is better for growing things? See below to find out!

### Soil Formation {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCBGb3JtYXRpb24._5-0sa}

How well soil forms and what type of soil forms depends on several
different factors, which are described below.

-   An animation of how weathering makes soil is found here:
    [http://courses.soil.ncsu.edu/resources/soil\_classification\_genesis/mineral\_weathering/mineral\_weathering.swf](mineral_weathering.swf) .

Soil development takes a very long time. It may take hundreds or even
thousands of years to form the fertile upper layer of soil. Soil
scientists estimate that in the very best soil forming conditions, soil
forms at a rate of about 1mm/year. In poor conditions, it may take
thousands of years!

#### Weathering {#10.html#x-ck12-V2VhdGhlcmluZw.._5-n6r}

Soil formation requires weathering. Where there is less weathering,
soils are thinner. However, soluble minerals may be present. Where there
is intense weathering, soils may be thick. Minerals and nutrients would
have been washed out.

#### Climate {#10.html#x-ck12-Q2xpbWF0ZQ.._5-6zt}

Climate is the most important factor determining soil type. Given enough
time, a climate will produce a particular type of soil. The original
rock type does not matter. Two rocks of the same type will form a
different soil type in each different climate. This is true because most
rocks on Earth are made of the same eight elements. When the rock breaks
down to become soil, the soil is the same.

The same climate factors that lead to high weathering also produce more
soil.

-   More rain weathers minerals and rocks more. Rain allows chemical
    reactions especially in the top layers of the soil.
-   More rain can dissolve more rock. More rain can carry away
    more material. As material is carried away, new surfaces
    are exposed. This also increases the rate of weathering.
-   Higher temperatures increase the rate of chemical reactions. This
    also increases soil formation.
-   In warmer regions, plants and bacteria grow faster. Plants and
    animals weather material and produce soils. In tropical regions,
    where temperature and precipitation are consistently high, thick
    soils form. Arid regions have thin soils.

Soil type also influences the type of vegetation that can grow in the
region. We can identify climate types by the types of plants that grow
there.

#### Parent Rock {#10.html#x-ck12-UGFyZW50IFJvY2s._5-mvq}

The original rock is the source of the inorganic portion of the soil.
Mechanical weathering breaks rock into smaller pieces. Chemical
reactions change the rock's minerals.

Soil may form in place or from material that has been moved.

-   **Residual soil** forms in place. The underlying rock breaks down to
    form the layers of soil above it. Only about one-third of the soils
    in the United States are residual.
-   **Transported soil** has come in from somewhere else. Sediments can
    be transported into an area by glaciers, wind, water, or gravity.
    Soils form from the loose particles that have been transported
    and deposited.

#### Slope {#10.html#x-ck12-U2xvcGU._5-lbn}

Weathered material washes off steep slopes and so does not stay in place
to form soil. Soil forms where land areas are flat or gently undulating.

#### Time {#10.html#x-ck12-VGltZQ.._5-vno}

Soils thicken as the amount of time available for weathering increases.
The longer the amount of time that soil remains in a particular area,
the thicker it will be.

#### Biological Activity {#10.html#x-ck12-QmlvbG9naWNhbCBBY3Rpdml0eQ.._5-0ld}

Biological activity produces the organic material in soil. **Humus**
forms from the remains of plants and animals. It is an extremely
important part of the soil. Humus coats the mineral grains. It binds
them together into clumps that hold the soil together. This gives the
soil its structure. Soils with high humus are better able to hold water.
Soils rich with organic materials hold nutrients better and are more
fertile. These soils are more easily farmed.

The color of soil indicates its fertility. Black or dark brown soils are
rich in nitrogen and contain a high percentage of organic materials.
Soils that are nitrogen poor and low in organic material might be gray,
yellow, or red ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TYW5keVNvaWw.) ). Soil with low
organic material is not good for growing plants.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZjBiYjEzMmRhNTFhZjI4ZDFmYzlkOGY1MDg5NDYyYTc.-im0"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Mike Baird" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mikebaird/6937214731/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![An area with sandy soil and low
fertility](ck12_10_files/20150911025921552150.jpeg "An area with sandy soil and low fertility")

**Figure 10.12**

This sandy soil shows evidence of very little organic activity. Plants
grow, but are far apart and short-lived. This means that little soil can
form. The soil that's there has little organic content.

</div>

-   An animation of how different types of weathering affect different
    minerals in soil:
    [http://courses.soil.ncsu.edu/resources/soil\_classification\_genesis/mineral\_weathering/elemental\_change.swf](elemental_change.swf) .

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._5-e9j}

-   Many factors affect soil formation. Some are climate, rock type,
    slope, time, and biological activity. Differences in these factors
    may produce different types of soil.
-   Soil type determines what can grow in a region.
-   Humus is the decayed remains of living organisms. Humus makes
    soil fertile.

# Soil Horizons and Profiles {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCBIb3Jpem9ucyBhbmQgUHJvZmlsZXM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of the three major types of
    soil horizon.
-   Explain the relationship of each type of soil to
    weathering processes.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601834] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025921655907.jpeg)
</span>

**What's beneath your car tires?**

Beneath an asphalt road is this incredible soil profile. Can you
identify the horizons? There are some clues in the photo that can help
you identify the climate type. What type of climate would produce this
soil?

### Soil Horizons and Profiles {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCBIb3Jpem9ucyBhbmQgUHJvZmlsZXM._6-fkq}

Soil develops over time and forms soil horizons. **Soil horizons** are
different layers of soil with depth. The most weathering occurs in the
top layer. This layer is most exposed to weather! It is where fresh
water comes into contact with the soil. Each layer lower is weathered
just a little bit less than the layer above. As water moves down through
the layers, it is able to do less work to change the soil. This is
because the chemical reactions have already occurred.

If you dig a deep hole in the ground, you may see each of the different
layers of soil. All together, the layers are a **soil profile** . Each
horizon has its own set of characteristics ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Tb2lsUHJvZmlsZVJlZHV4) ). In the
simplest soil profile, a soil has three horizons.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-YTI1NDc2YTJmNDkwOWQxNGY1YzZkMGZlMTA3YjEyNTI.-y2t"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the US Department of Agriculture" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Soil_profile.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of the soil
horizons](ck12_10_files/20150911025921768088.jpeg "Diagram of the soil horizons")

**Figure 10.13**

In this diagram, a cut through soil shows different soil layers.

</div>

#### Topsoil {#10.html#x-ck12-VG9wc29pbA.._6-rxo}

The first horizon is the “A“ horizon. It is more commonly called the
**topsoil** . The topsoil is usually the darkest layer of the soil. It
is the layer with the most organic material. Humus forms from all the
plant and animal debris that falls to or grows on the ground. The
topsoil is also the region with the most biological activity. Many
organisms live within this layer. Plant roots stretch down into this
layer. The roots help to hold the topsoil in place. Topsoil is needed to
grow most crops ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TYWxhZEdhcmRlbg..) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ODViMzg5ZTQ3YTRmOWE1OGE0ODAxZGU4YWRiZjBmZTc.-fog"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Southern Foodways Alliance" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/southernfoodwaysalliance/2593250285/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of rich
topsoil](ck12_10_files/20150911025921893855.jpeg "Picture of rich topsoil")

**Figure 10.14**

Good topsoil is great for growing plants.

</div>

Topsoil usually does not have very small particles like clay. Clay-sized
particles are carried to lower layers as water seeps down into the
ground. Many minerals dissolve in the fresh water that moves through the
topsoil. These minerals are carried down to the lower layers of soil.

#### Subsoil {#10.html#x-ck12-U3Vic29pbA.._6-rxn}

Below the topsoil is the “B“ horizon. This is also called the
**subsoil** . Soluble minerals and clays accumulate in the subsoil.
Because it has less organic material, this layer is lighter brown in
color than topsoil. It also holds more water due to the presence of iron
and clay. There is less organic material in this layer.

#### C-horizon {#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1ob3Jpem9u_6-fnt}

The next layer down is the “C” horizon. The **C horizon** is made of
partially altered bedrock. There is evidence of weathering in this
layer. Still, it is possible to identify the original rock type from
which this soil formed ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Tb2lsSG9yaXpvbnM.) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZmMxOWY2ZGViMzFjNThhOWIxMTc2MTNhM2QxNWQyMTU.-hy9"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![This image shows the various soil
horizons](ck12_10_files/20150911025922002215.png "This image shows the various soil horizons")

**Figure 10.15**

This image shows the various soil horizons.

</div>

Not all climate regions develop soils. Arid regions are poor at soil
development. Not all regions develop the same soil horizons. Some areas
develop as many as five or six distinct layers. Others develop only a
few.

-   An animation of soil profile development can be viewed here:
    [http://courses.soil.ncsu.edu/resources/soil\_classification\_genesis/soil\_formation/soil\_transform.swf](soil_transform.swf) .

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._6-mov}

-   Soil horizons are layers within a soil. Different soil horizons show
    different amounts of alteration.
-   Soil profiles reveal the different layers of soil.
-   Soil layers include topsoil, subsoil, and the C horizon.
-   Topsoil has the highest proportion of organic material. Topsoil is
    essential for farming.

# Types of Soils {#10.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgU29pbHM.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the characteristics of types of soil.
-   Describe where each type of soil is found.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601840] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025922094071.jpeg)
</span>

**Where would you rather grow crops?**

The soil on the left is in Tuscany in Italy. Tuscany is best known for
growing grapes for wine and olives for olive oil. The soil on the right
is in China. It is the soil that remained when rainforest trees were
removed. Do you know which soil would be better for crops?

### Types of Soils {#10.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgU29pbHM._7-keh}

For soil scientists, there are thousands of types of soil! Soil
scientists put soils into very specific groups with certain
characteristics. Each soil type has its own name. Let’s consider a much
simpler model, with just three types of soil. These types are based on
climate. Just remember that there are many more than just these three
types.

#### Pedalfer {#10.html#x-ck12-UGVkYWxmZXI._7-izb}

One important type of soil forms in a **deciduous forest** . In these
forests, trees lose their leaves each winter. Deciduous trees need lots
of rain — at least 65 cm of rainfall per year. Deciduous forests are
common in the temperate, eastern United States. The type of soil found
in a deciduous forest is a **pedalfer** ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QbG91Z2hlZEZpZWxk) ). This type of
soil is usually dark brown or black in color and very fertile.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MTY2ZmZlM2Y2ZDg4MGE5YjAwZGNmNDZkMTE5Zjc0ZGM.-5nj"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="E. Dronkert (Flickr:ednl)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/dnet/6208361124/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![The soil beneath a deciduous forest is a pedalfer, which are very
fertile](ck12_10_files/20150911025922194434.jpeg "The soil beneath a deciduous forest is a pedalfer, which are very fertile")

**Figure 10.16**

The soil beneath a deciduous forest is a pedalfer. These soils are very
fertile.

</div>

#### Pedocal {#10.html#x-ck12-UGVkb2NhbA.._7-qpy}

**Pedocal** soil forms where grasses and brush are common ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QZWRvY2Fs) ). The climate is drier,
with less than 65 cm of rain per year. With less rain, there is less
chemical weathering, there is less organic material, and the soils are
slightly less fertile.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZWNkMDE5MjM0YTk0YWE3NjVmOTQ5MjRiYTU3ZDY5N2E.-rdl"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Damian Gadal" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/23024164@N06/5646500639/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Grassland soils are examples of pedocal
soil](ck12_10_files/20150911025922322502.jpeg "Grassland soils are examples of pedocal soil")

**Figure 10.17**

Grassland soils are less rich than soils in more humid regions.

</div>

#### Laterite {#10.html#x-ck12-TGF0ZXJpdGU._7-qts}

A third important type of soil is **laterite** . Laterite forms in
tropical areas. Temperatures are warm and rain falls every day (
**Figure** [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1MYXRlcml0ZQ..) ). So much
rain falls that chemical weathering is intense. All soluble minerals are
washed from the soil. Plant nutrients get carried away. There is
practically no humus. Laterite soils are often red in color from the
iron oxides. If laterites are exposed to the Sun, they bake as hard as a
brick.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MDI1MGFiYmQ5ZDQ1ZDQ5NTVhYTJiMzgzOTIwMjNjNWY.-9dw"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Stephane Bidouze, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Laterite soils, which are found beneath rainforests, are not good for
growing
crops](ck12_10_files/20150911025922454902.jpeg "Laterite soils, which are found beneath rainforests, are not good for growing crops")

**Figure 10.18**

Laterite soils, which are found beneath rainforests, are not good for
growing crops.

</div>

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._7-d5z}

-   Pedalfer is the soil common in deciduous forests. Pedalfer is dark
    brown and fertile.
-   Pedocal is the soil common in grasslands. The more arid climate
    increases calcium in the soil. Pedocal is not as fertile.
-   Laterite forms in tropical rain forests. Chemical weathering strips
    the soils of their nutrients. When the forest is removed the soil is
    not very fertile.

# Soil Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-U29pbCBFcm9zaW9u}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Explain how human activities cause soil erosion.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601845] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025922588007.jpeg)
</span>

**Could it happen again?**

Farmers were forced off their lands during the **Dust Bowl** in the
1930s. The rains stopped, and the topsoil blew off these former
grasslands. This scene was repeated throughout the central United
States. During long droughts, some people wonder if another dust bowl
could come.

### Causes of Soil Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-Q2F1c2VzIG9mIFNvaWwgRXJvc2lvbg.._8-xjp}

The same agents that erode landscapes also erode soil. They are water,
wind, ice, or gravity. Running water is the leading cause of soil
erosion. Water is abundant and has a lot of power. Wind is also a
leading cause of soil erosion. Wind can pick up soil and blow it far
away.

Activities that remove vegetation, disturb the ground, or allow the
ground to dry are activities that increase erosion. What are some human
activities that increase soil erosion?

#### Farming {#10.html#x-ck12-RmFybWluZw.._8-s4u}

The photos below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTktMDItQ3JvcHMtZW5kYW5nZXItc29pbA..) )
show how farming practices can increase soil erosion. Plant roots
penetrate the soil and keep it from eroding. Plowing turns over bare
soil and cuts through plant roots. Bare soil is exposed to wind and
water. In the past, farmers always plowed fields before planting.

The problem doesn’t stop with plowing. Crops are usually planted in rows
with bare soil in between the rows. In places where crops grow only
during part of the year, the land may be bare for a few months.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-NjVmMjNlZTRhOWRjNjVjNmU2ZDA5MGNiMTRhOWIzYWE.-rle"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Clockwise from upper left: David Noah; Flickr:Smudge 9000; Fred Gasper, USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service; Chris Friese" -->
<!-- @@url="Clockwise from upper left: http://www.flickr.com/photos/davidnoah/8366575508/; http://www.flickr.com/photos/smudge9000/2937898093/; http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:NRCSMI01054_-_Michigan_%284697%29%28NRCS_Photo_Gallery%29.jpg; http://www.flickr.com/photos/free-zee/4563350230/" -->
<!-- @@license="Clockwise from upper left: CC BY 2.0; CC BY 2.0; Public Domain; CC BY 2.0" -->
![How farming can increase soil
erosion](ck12_10_files/20150911025922697878.jpeg "How farming can increase soil erosion")

**Figure 10.19**

Farming leaves some soil exposed to erosion.

</div>

The soil that is most likely to erode is the nutrient-rich topsoil. The
loss of topsoil degrades the farmland.

#### Grazing {#10.html#x-ck12-R3JhemluZw.._8-ect}

As pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTktMDMtU2hlZXAtYW5kLWdvYXRz) ), some
grazing animals, especially sheep and goats, eat grass right down to the
roots. They may even pull the grass entirely out of the ground. Grazing
animals can kill the grass. They may thin it out so much that it offers
little protection to the soil. If animals are kept in the same place too
long, the soil may become completely bare. The bare soil is easily
eroded by wind and water.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-NTE1Yjk2ZmZkMjA5OTA0ZjhhOWY5YjYzNDM2M2E0ZjM.-8c1"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="David Wright" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/dhwright/4430201444/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Sheep and goats grazing can damage plants and leave the soil
bare](ck12_10_files/20150911025922818407.jpeg "Sheep and goats grazing can damage plants and leave the soil bare")

**Figure 10.20**

Sheep and goats can damage plants and leave the soil bare.

</div>

#### Logging, Mining and Construction {#10.html#x-ck12-TG9nZ2luZywgTWluaW5nIGFuZCBDb25zdHJ1Y3Rpb24._8-9pu}

Other human actions that put soil at risk include logging, mining, and
construction. You can see examples of each below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTktMDQtTG9nZ2luZy1taW5pbmctY29uc3RydWN0aW9u)
).

-   When forests are cut down, the soil is suddenly exposed to wind
    and rain. Without trees, there is no **leaf litter** to cover the
    ground and protect the soil. When leaf litter decays, it adds humus
    and nutrients to the soil.
-   Mining and construction strip soil off the ground and leave the
    land bare.
-   Paved roads and parking lots prevent rainwater from soaking into
    the ground. This increases runoff and the potential for
    soil erosion.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZDcxMzlkZDA4NTMwOTMxYjMyNzYwMTFlMzQ2NjU3OTA.-ygz"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Logging: Image copyright TFoxFoto, 2013; Monster Trucks: Image copyright Christopher Halloran, 2013; Tractor: Image copyright tarasov, 2013; Parking Lot: Image copyright J. Helgason, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Logging, mining, construction, and paving surfaces are some of the
ways that soil erosion
increases](ck12_10_files/20150911025922980327.jpeg "Logging, mining, construction, and paving surfaces are some of the ways that soil erosion increases")

**Figure 10.21**

Logging, mining, construction, and paving surfaces are some of the ways
that soil erosion increases.

</div>

#### Recreation {#10.html#x-ck12-UmVjcmVhdGlvbg.._8-woi}

Even things that people do for fun can expose soil to erosion. For
example, overuse of hiking trails can leave bare patches of soil.
Off-road vehicles cause even more damage; examples of this are pictured
below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTktMDUtT2Zmcm9hZC12ZWhpY2xlcy1hbmQtc29pbA..)
).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-OTkwY2VmNDA1MTc1MDY3OTRhMmZhOTg0MzQ2Y2IwN2Y.-fw4"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Left: NRMA New Cars; Right: Flickr:Anya1986" -->
<!-- @@url="Left: http://www.flickr.com/photos/nrmadriversseat/5528368702/; Right: http://www.flickr.com/photos/anya1986/6051303946/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Off-road vehicles can destroy plants and leave the ground bare, which
increases
erosion](ck12_10_files/20150911025923163541.jpeg "Off-road vehicles can destroy plants and leave the ground bare, which increases erosion")

**Figure 10.22**

What’s fun for people may be bad for soil. Off-road vehicles can destroy
plants and leave the ground bare. This sets up the soil for erosion.

</div>

Soil erosion is a natural occurrence. However, human activities have
greatly accelerated soil erosion. In some locations, soil may now be
eroding about 10 times faster than its natural rate. Since Europeans
settled in the United States, approximately one-third of the topsoil has
eroded away.

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._8-orh}

-   Soil erosion is a natural process, but human activities can
    increase it.
-   The main agents of soil erosion are water and wind.
-   Soil erosion is more likely where the ground has been disturbed.
    Farming, grazing animals, logging, mining, construction, and
    recreational activities can do this.

# Avoiding Soil Loss {#10.html#x-ck12-QXZvaWRpbmcgU29pbCBMb3Nz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe steps that can be taken to minimize soil loss.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601850] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025923359710.jpeg)
</span>

**Why did someone cut designs into this hillside?**

Although the hillside is interesting, that's not why this was done.
Terracing prevents soil erosion on a hillside that is being farmed. Many
techniques can be utilized to reduce soil erosion.

### Preventing Soil Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-UHJldmVudGluZyBTb2lsIEVyb3Npb24._9-qk8}

Soil is a renewable resource, but it can take thousands of years to
form. That’s why people need to do what they can to prevent soil
erosion.

#### Farming Methods that Reduce Soil Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-RmFybWluZyBNZXRob2RzIHRoYXQgUmVkdWNlIFNvaWwgRXJvc2lvbg.._9-gkp}

The Dust Bowl taught people that soil could be lost by plowing and
growing crops. New ways of farming were developed to protect the soil.
Some of the methods are described below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTktMDYtRmFybWluZy1yZWR1Y2Utc29pbC1sb3Nz)
).

**Figure 10.23**

There are many farming methods that help prevent soil erosion.

</div>

#### Other Ways to Reduce Soil Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-T3RoZXIgV2F5cyB0byBSZWR1Y2UgU29pbCBFcm9zaW9u_9-rkd}

There are several other ways to help prevent soil loss. Some of them are
pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTktMDctUHJvdGVjdGluZy1zb2ls) ).

-   Prevent overgrazing. Frequently move animals from field to field.
    This gives the grass a chance to recover.
-   Avoid logging steep hillsides. Cut only a few trees in any
    given place. Plant new trees to replace those that are cut down.
-   Reclaim mine lands. Save the stripped topsoil and return it to
    the land. Once the soil is in place, plant trees and other plants to
    protect the bare soil.
-   Use barriers to prevent runoff and soil erosion at
    construction sites. Plant grass to hold the soil in place.
-   Develop paving materials that absorb water and reduce runoff.
-   Restrict the use of off-road vehicles, especially in hilly areas.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-NzNlZTM5ZGJkOGFjMjNkNDE5NTk2YTUyMmJmZTc0M2I.-aar"

<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under licenses from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Ways to help protect the
soil](ck12_10_files/20150911025923661566.png "Ways to help protect the soil")

**Figure 10.24**

Taking steps to control erosion can help save soil.

</div>

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._9-j79}

-   Soil is a renewable resource. Sometimes it is lost faster than it
    can be replaced.
-   Farming methods that can reduce soil erosion include terracing,
    contour cropping, windbreaks, and no-till planting.
-   Caution with grazing, recreational activities and reclaiming used
    lands can help reduce soil erosion.

# Erosion by Streams {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBTdHJlYW1z}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe different types of stream erosion.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601859] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025923828215.jpeg)
</span>

**What's different about these landscapes?**

Both of these rivers run through Yellowstone National Park. The Firehole
River is a tributary of the Madison. In this photo, it's flowing over
flat ground. The Yellowstone River on the right is cascading over
Yellowstone Falls. Which river is doing more erosion? In what direction
is the stream eroding?

### Erosion by Surface Water {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBTdXJmYWNlIFdhdGVy_10-zyt}

Water that flows over Earth’s surface includes runoff, streams, and
rivers. All these types of flowing water can cause erosion and
deposition.

#### Erosion by Runoff {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBSdW5vZmY._10-gzv}

When a lot of rain falls in a short period of time, much of the water is
unable to soak into the ground. Instead, it runs over the land. Gravity
causes the water to flow from higher to lower ground. As the runoff
flows, it may pick up loose bits of soil and sand.

Runoff causes more erosion if the land is bare. Plants help hold the
soil in place. The runoff water pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TaGVldEVyb3Npb24.) ) is brown because
it eroded soil from a bare, sloping field. Can you find evidence of
erosion by runoff where you live? What should you look for?

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-NzFhOTM5ZDg2MmY0NTIwM2VkOWFjZDQxZmYyOTcwYjM.-cnq"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of the USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/main/national/landuse/crops/erosion/" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Runoff has eroded small channels through this bare
field](ck12_10_files/20150911025923934982.jpeg "Runoff has eroded small channels through this bare field")

**Figure 10.25**

Runoff has eroded small channels through this bare field.

</div>

Much of the material eroded by runoff is carried into bodies of water,
such as streams, rivers, ponds, lakes, or oceans. Runoff is an important
cause of erosion. That’s because it occurs over so much of Earth’s
surface.

#### Erosion by Streams {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBTdHJlYW1z_10-nue}

Streams erode sediment from their banks. They pick up and transport
sediments.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ODMyM2I1ZDY1MjkzZWRlYmI5YjcxMDQzYTY2ODBlZmQ.-yli"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Gary Whitton, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![A stream in the desert erodes the cliff
face](ck12_10_files/20150911025924035214.jpeg "A stream in the desert erodes the cliff face")

**Figure 10.26**

A stream in the desert rushes past its banks. The power of the water
erodes the cliff face.

</div>

As a stream erodes its banks, it creates a V-shaped valley ( **Figure**
[above](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Fcm9kZWRDbGlmZkZhY2U.) ). This
contrasts with the U-shaped valleys created by glaciers.

#### Erosion and Water Speed {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBhbmQgV2F0ZXIgU3BlZWQ._10-mha}

Erosion by a stream depends on the velocity of the water. Fast water
erodes more material than slow water. Eventually, the water deposits the
materials. As water slows, larger particles are deposited first. As the
water slows even more, smaller particles are deposited. The graph
pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1IanVsc3Ryb21EaWFncmFt) ) shows how
water velocity and particle size influence erosion and deposition.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZjYzZTI4ZTc2OWUyOWJmMzU2ZGJhNjhmYTYwNzIwMTY.-cbt"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Graph of how particle size and water velocity affect erosion and
deposition](ck12_10_files/20150911025924162496.png "Graph of how particle size and water velocity affect erosion and deposition")

**Figure 10.27**

Flowing water erodes or deposits particles depending on how fast the
water is moving. It also depends on how big the particles are.

</div>

#### Erosion in the Mountains {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBpbiB0aGUgTW91bnRhaW5z_10-dcr}

Streams often start in mountains, where the land is very steep (
**Figure** [below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTAtMDQtbW91bnRhaW4tc3RyZWFt)
). A mountain stream flows very quickly because of the steep slope. This
causes a lot of erosion and very little deposition. The rapidly falling
water digs down into the stream bed and makes it deeper. It carves a
narrow, V-shaped channel.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MDUxOTRhNTAyYjZhOWM0NjFhNzI0ODAzZDQ0YWI1ZjY.-dce"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:jar" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/jariceiii/6287119489/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Stream flowing over a
waterfall](ck12_10_files/20150911025924263820.jpeg "Stream flowing over a waterfall")

**Figure 10.28**

This mountain stream is in Whitney Portal in the Sierra Nevada of
California. The slope is so steep that water cascades down in a
waterfall.

</div>

#### How a Waterfall Forms {#10.html#x-ck12-SG93IGEgV2F0ZXJmYWxsIEZvcm1z_10-sv3}

Mountain streams may erode waterfalls. A waterfall forms where a stream
flows from an area of harder to softer rock ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1XYXRlcmZhbGxGb3JtYXRpb24.) ). The
water erodes the softer rock faster than the harder rock. This causes
the stream bed to drop down, like a step. This creates a waterfall. As
erosion continues, the waterfall gradually moves upstream.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-NmYzZDdiMzZhNDE5NDkxOWNmYTNkZGRlYzI2Zjg5ZGI.-ce5"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jodi So" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of how a waterfall
forms](ck12_10_files/20150911025924471088.png "Diagram of how a waterfall forms")

**Figure 10.29**

How a waterfall forms and moves. Why does a waterfall keep moving
upstream?

</div>

#### Erosion by Slow-Flowing Rivers {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBTbG93LUZsb3dpbmcgUml2ZXJz_10-har}

Streams eventually run onto flatter ground. Rivers flowing over gentle
slopes erode the sides of their channels more than the bottom. Large
curves, called **meanders** , form because of erosion and deposition by
the moving water. The curves are called meanders because they slowly
“wander,” or meander, over the land. Below, you can see how this happens
( **Figure** [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NZWFuZGVyRm9ybWF0aW9u)
).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MzIwYjI5MzQ3YTQ4NGJkYWYzMzBmNzk2ZmViNDljNmQ.-jel"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of how meanders form and
move](ck12_10_files/20150911025924560680.jpeg "Diagram of how meanders form and move")

**Figure 10.30**

Meanders form because water erodes the outside of curves and deposits
eroded material on the inside. Over time, the curves shift position.

</div>

As meanders erode from side to side, they create a **floodplain** . This
is a broad, flat area on both sides of a river. Eventually, a meander
may become cut off from the rest of the river. This forms an **oxbow
lake** ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NYWNrZW56aWVEZWx0YQ..) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-NzUwMWYxNzJjY2EzNWY1MWY5YTYzYjEyOTc2OTdmYjQ.-bbv"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of GSFC/METI/ERSDAC/JAROS, and the US/Japan ASTER Science Team" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=8320" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![On oxbow lake along a
river](ck12_10_files/20150911025924672940.jpeg "On oxbow lake along a river")

**Figure 10.31**

An oxbow lake forms in the Mackenzie River Delta, Canada.

</div>

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-edb}

-   Faster water carries more and larger sediment.
-   Streams erode their banks to create V-shaped valleys.
-   A river on flat ground meanders. When a meander is cut off it may
    become an oxbow lake.
-   A floodplain is where the extra water goes when the river is
    in flood.

# Deposition by Streams {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVwb3NpdGlvbiBieSBTdHJlYW1z}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601865] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025924763939.jpeg)
</span>

**Why is there a pile of cobbles in that stream?**

A river meanders causing erosion on one side of its bank. On the other
side, sediments are deposited. In this photo of a meander, where is
there erosion and where is there deposition?

### Sediment Transport {#10.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnQgVHJhbnNwb3J0_11-lec}

The size of particles determines how they are carried by flowing water;
this is illustrated below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy0xMC0wMi1XYXRlclBhcnRpY2xlTW92ZW1lbnQ.)
).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZjQ5OTY1NTUwMWVmYmFmODUyNjM3MjQyM2JmZWRmMTE.-1ed"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyeung" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of how flowing water moves
particles](ck12_10_files/20150911025924897422.jpeg "Diagram of how flowing water moves particles")

**Figure 10.32**

How Flowing Water Moves Particles. How particles are moved by flowing
water depends on their size.

</div>

Sediments are carried as:

-   **Dissolved load** : Dissolved ions are carried in the water. These
    ions usually travel all the way to the ocean.
-   **Suspended load** : Sediments carried as solids as the stream flows
    are suspended load. The size of particles that can be carried is
    determined by the stream’s velocity ( **Figure**
    [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Db25uZWN0aWN1dFJpdmVyc1NlZExvYWQ.) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MWI2NmM5OWJiZjNmOWU0NzQzZmJhZmY4MTVjZGYyMzk.-1zt"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Robert Simmon, NASA's Earth Observatory" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=52059" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The Connecticut River is brown from the sediment it
carries](ck12_10_files/20150911025925090173.jpeg "The Connecticut River is brown from the sediment it carries")

**Figure 10.33**

The Connecticut River is brown from the sediment it carries. The river
drops the sediment offshore into Long Island Sound.

</div>

-   **Bed load** : Some particles are too large to be carried as
    suspended load. These sediments are bumped and pushed along the
    stream bed as bed load. Bed load sediments do not move continuously.
    This intermittent movement is called **saltation** . Streams with
    high velocities that flow down steep slopes cut down into the
    stream bed. The sediments that travel as bed load do a lot of
    the downcutting.

<!-- -->

-   An animation of saltation is found here:
    [http://www.weru.ksu.edu/new\_weru/multimedia/movies/dust003.mpg](dust003.mpg) .
-   A video of bedload transport is found here:
    [http://faculty.gg.uwyo.edu/heller/SedMovs/Sed%20Movie%20files/bdld.mov](bdld.mov) .

### Deposition by Streams and Rivers {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVwb3NpdGlvbiBieSBTdHJlYW1zIGFuZCBSaXZlcnM._11-bno}

When a stream or river slows down, it starts dropping its sediments.
Larger sediments are dropped in steep areas, but smaller sediments can
still be carried. Smaller sediments are dropped as the slope becomes
less steep.

#### Alluvial Fans {#10.html#x-ck12-QWxsdXZpYWwgRmFucw.._11-wbl}

In arid regions, a mountain stream may flow onto flatter land. The
stream comes to a stop rapidly. The deposits form an **alluvial fan** (
**Figure** [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BbGx1dmlhbEZhbkFuZERlbHRh)
).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZTg1N2VhYWJiZjE5ZTc1MGUyNGQ2NDlmOGYxOWI1ZTM.-dn4"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="(A) Mike Baird; (B) Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="(A) http://www.flickr.com/photos/mikebaird/8516210691/; (B) http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Nile_delta_landsat_false_color.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="(A) CC BY 2.0; (B) Public Domain" -->
![Alluvial fans in Death Valley and the Nile River Delta in
Egypt](ck12_10_files/20150911025925198098.jpeg "Alluvial fans in Death Valley and the Nile River Delta in Egypt")

**Figure 10.34**

\(A) Alluvial fans in Death Valley, California (B) Nile River Delta in
Egypt

</div>

#### Deltas {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVsdGFz_11-a1f}

Deposition also occurs when a stream or river empties into a large body
of still water. In this case, a **delta** forms. A delta is shaped like
a triangle. It spreads out into the body of water. An example is
pictured below ( **Figure**
[above](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BbGx1dmlhbEZhbkFuZERlbHRh) ).

#### Deposition by Flood Waters {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVwb3NpdGlvbiBieSBGbG9vZCBXYXRlcnM._11-sfx}

A flood occurs when a river overflows it banks. This might happen
because of heavy rains.

#### Floodplains {#10.html#x-ck12-Rmxvb2RwbGFpbnM._11-ak5}

As the water spreads out over the land, it slows down and drops its
sediment. If a river floods often, the floodplain develops a thick layer
of rich soil because of all the deposits. That’s why floodplains are
usually good places for growing plants. For example, the Nile River in
Egypt provides both water and thick sediments for raising crops in the
middle of a sandy desert.

#### Natural Levees {#10.html#x-ck12-TmF0dXJhbCBMZXZlZXM._11-yud}

A flooding river often forms natural levees along its banks. A **levee**
( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTAtMDgtbGV2ZWUtZm9ybWF0aW9u) ) is a
raised strip of sediments deposited close to the water’s edge. Levees
occur because floodwaters deposit their biggest sediments first when
they overflow the river’s banks.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZDIzNjRlZWQ2MzU1MDUyMjU2MWYyMDM3ZTk1NTIxNjE.-6xa"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![How natural levees form from
floods](ck12_10_files/20150911025925303790.jpeg "How natural levees form from floods")

**Figure 10.35**

This diagram shows how a river builds natural levees along its banks.

</div>

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._11-cmz}

-   Streams carry dissolved ions and sediments. The sizes of the
    sediments a stream can carry, its competence, depend on the
    stream's velocity.
-   Particles that are too large to be suspended move along the stream
    bed by saltation.
-   Rivers deposit sediments on levees, floodplains, and in deltas and
    alluvial fans.

# Erosion by Groundwater {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBHcm91bmR3YXRlcg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how groundwater erodes rock.
-   Describe the features that form from groundwater erosion.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601871] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025925469880.jpeg)
</span>

**What resources does a coastal city need?**

Tulum is a walled city that was once inhabited by the Maya people. Tulum
is on the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. The beautiful blue Caribbean
supplied the Maya with abundant fish. What else would the Maya people
have needed? Fresh water is found in cenotes, sinkholes that are common
in the Yucatan limestone.

### Groundwater Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-R3JvdW5kd2F0ZXIgRXJvc2lvbg.._12-haf}

Some water soaks into the ground. It travels down through tiny holes in
soil. It seeps through cracks in rock. The water moves slowly, pulled
deeper and deeper by gravity. Water in an underground rock or sediment
layer is **groundwater** . Underground water can also erode and deposit
material.

Rainwater absorbs carbon dioxide (CO ~2~ ) as it falls. The CO ~2~
combines with water to form carbonic acid. The slightly acidic water is
especially good at dissolving the rock limestone. Groundwater creates
landforms by dissolving away rock.

Florida is unique for groundwater erosion. The state is extremely flat
and is made mostly of limestone. Due to the wet climate, groundwater
surfaces in many locations. In the Everglades, rivers create a wide
floodplain and groundwater comes to the surface ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1FdmVyZ2xhZGVzTlA.) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MjJmZDNhMDdmZmM5MjY0YzM0YWQwZDIwNTIxN2Y5ODI.-k76"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Jose Antonio Perez, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![A cypress forest in Everglades National Park needs water to
thrive](ck12_10_files/20150911025925583622.jpeg "A cypress forest in Everglades National Park needs water to thrive")

**Figure 10.36**

A cypress forest in Everglades National Park needs water to thrive.

</div>

#### Caves {#10.html#x-ck12-Q2F2ZXM._12-zum}

Caves are one of the types of landforms created by groundwater erosion.
Working slowly over many years, groundwater travels along small cracks.
The water dissolves and carries away the solid rock. This gradually
enlarges the cracks. Eventually, a cave, like the one pictured in the
**Figure** [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1DYXZl) , may form.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-M2ZlMWFlZTc0MDdkNGQxNTk2MTQxMWFlMGYwN2NiNzM.-yov"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Totajla, 2014" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Water flows through a limestone
cave](ck12_10_files/20150911025925693539.jpeg "Water flows through a limestone cave")

**Figure 10.37**

Water flows through a limestone cave.

</div>

You can explore a fantastic cave, Kartchner Caverns, in Arizona, by
watching this video:
[http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/player/science/earth-sci/exploring-kartchner-sci.html](exploring-kartchner-sci.html)
.

#### Sinkholes {#10.html#x-ck12-U2lua2hvbGVz_12-r9z}

As erosion by groundwater continues, the ceiling of a cave may collapse.
The rock and soil above it sink into the ground. This forms a
**sinkhole** on the surface. Some sinkholes are large enough to swallow
up a home or several homes in a neighborhood.

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-3h9}

-   Groundwater erodes rock beneath the ground surface. Limestone is a
    carbonate and is most easily eroded.
-   Groundwater dissolves minerals and carries the ions in solution.
-   Groundwater erosion creates caves and sinkholes.

# Deposition by Groundwater {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVwb3NpdGlvbiBieSBHcm91bmR3YXRlcg..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how groundwater deposits solid materials.
-   Describe the features that groundwater deposits.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601876] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025925869397.jpeg)
</span>

**Where would you look for a spectacular cave like this one?**

Groundwater dissolves minerals and rocks into ions. Groundwater deposits
those ions into different types of structures. Limestone caves are the
best place to see these structures. Water erodes the cave and it has
deposits structures like stalactites and stalagmites. The cave pictured
here is Carlsbad Caverns in New Mexico.

### Cave Deposits {#10.html#x-ck12-Q2F2ZSBEZXBvc2l0cw.._13-gbl}

Caves are known for their spectacular mineral structures. Caves are
likely to be found in limestone where the groundwater level has gone
down. This exposes the cave and its features. **Stalactites** are
beautiful icicle-like formations. They form as water containing calcium
carbonate drips from the ceiling of a cave. The word "stalactite" has a
"c," and it forms from the ceiling. **Stalagmites** form as calcium
carbonate drips from the ceiling to the floor of a cave. The stalagmite
grow upward. The "g" in "stalagmite" means it forms on the ground. You
can see examples of both stalactites and stalagmites below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TdGFsYWN0aXRlcw..) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZGZhMmUyNTkzMWQxODQ1NWRlZGFiZjA1ZjhkMWQyMjA.-ehd"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Meetu Singal" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/meetusinghal/7926046500/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Stalactites and stalagmites can join to form a
column](ck12_10_files/20150911025925963596.jpeg "Stalactites and stalagmites can join to form a column")

**Figure 10.38**

Stalactites hang from the ceiling and stalagmites rise from the floor of
a cave. The two together form a column.

</div>

If a stalactite and stalagmite join together, they form a **column** .
One of the wonders of visiting a cave is to witness the beauty of these
amazing and strangely captivating structures.

#### Giant Crystals {#10.html#x-ck12-R2lhbnQgQ3J5c3RhbHM._13-o0e}

Some of the largest, and most beautiful, natural crystals can be found
in the Naica mine, in Mexico. These gypsum crystals were formed over
thousands of years. Groundwater that is rich in calcium and sulfur
flowed through an underground cave. Check it out:

-   **Naica Mine—Gypsum-Selenite** at
    [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6drrYFj91Ko](watch?v=6drrYFj91Ko) (2:40)

[![](ck12_10_files/tmp5iDuC4.jpeg)](6drrYFj91Ko%3Fwmode%3Dtransparent%26hash%3D8471693547e7360d0222625a5ff238f3)

Click on the image above for more content

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._13-ucm}

-   Groundwater dissolves minerals and carries the ions in solution.
-   Groundwater deposits the material in caves as stalactites,
    stalagmites, and columns.
-   Giant crystals may be found in caves.

# Erosion by Waves {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBXYXZlcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Learn how waves cause erosion.
-   Describe the landforms caused by wave erosion.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601881] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025926059639.jpeg)
</span>

**Is this erosion or deposition?**

The power of the ocean modifies landforms by erosion and deposition.
Landforms modified by both erosion and deposition are seen in this
photo. The cliff is being eroded by incoming waves. The beach is being
created as sand is being deposited.

### Wave Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-V2F2ZSBFcm9zaW9u_14-pae}

Wave energy does the work of erosion at the shore. Waves erode sediments
from cliffs and shorelines. The sediment in ocean water acts like
sandpaper. Over time, they erode the shore. The bigger the waves are and
the more sediment they carry, the more erosion they cause ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HcmVla0NsaWZmcw..) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-YzQwODY1MjgyOTRmNWJiNWMwY2MzNzY3ZGRiZDgxZWI.-r0q"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:kdask" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kdask/442065519/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Waves erode cliffs to form
beaches](ck12_10_files/20150911025926236453.jpeg "Waves erode cliffs to form beaches")

**Figure 10.39**

Waves erode sediment from sea cliffs. The sediment is then deposited on
beaches. These sandy cliffs are in Greece.

</div>

Wave refraction either concentrates wave energy or disperses it. In
quiet water areas, such as bays, wave energy is dispersed. This allows
sand to be deposited. Land that sticks out into the water is eroded by
the strong wave energy. The wave energy concentrates its power on the
**wave-cut cliff** .

#### Landforms From Wave Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-TGFuZGZvcm1zIEZyb20gV2F2ZSBFcm9zaW9u_14-yc6}

Erosion by waves can create unique landforms ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Tb3V0aFdhbGVzQ2xpZmZz) ).

-   **Wave-cut cliffs** form when waves erode a rocky shoreline. They
    create a vertical wall of exposed rock layers.
-   **Wave-cut platforms** are level areas formed by wave erosion. Since
    these platforms are above sea level, it means that either sea level
    was higher relative or the rock was lower.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MzU3OGVjZWMwNWRmNTk1ZWQ2YjFmMzg0OTkyNTU1NzM.-cal"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="David Evans" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/21081514@N08/5356607195/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A wave-cut platform is exposed in Pembrokeshire, South
Wales](ck12_10_files/20150911025926350718.jpeg "A wave-cut platform is exposed in Pembrokeshire, South Wales")

**Figure 10.40**

A wave-cut platform is exposed in Pembrokeshire, South Wales.

</div>

-   **Sea arches** form when waves erode both sides of a cliff. They
    create a hole in the cliff, like the one pictured below ( **Figure**
    [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1OYXR1cmFsQnJpZGdlQ2FsaWZvcm5pYQ..) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-NDAwY2I2ZDg5NjQ4Njk2YjBkNjVlOTNiZjUxOTM3ODU.-8zh"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Vadim Kurland (Flickr:vkurland)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/vkurland/8443060261/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A sea arch creates a natural bridge in
California](ck12_10_files/20150911025926469968.jpeg "A sea arch creates a natural bridge in California")

**Figure 10.41**

A sea arch creates a natural bridge in California.

</div>

-   **Sea stacks** form when waves erode the top of a sea arch. This
    leaves behind pillars of rock.

### Sediment Transport {#10.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnQgVHJhbnNwb3J0_14-mtw}

Rivers carry sediments from the land to the sea. Sometimes the sediments
are deposited in a delta. But if the waves are powerful, the water will
transport the sediments along the coastline. Sediments eroded from
cliffs near the shoreline may also be transported.

#### Wave Refraction {#10.html#x-ck12-V2F2ZSBSZWZyYWN0aW9u_14-0hb}

Most waves approach the shore at an angle. The part of the wave that is
nearer the shore reaches shallow water sooner than the part that is
farther out. The shallow part of the wave "feels" the bottom first. This
slows down the inshore part of the wave and makes the wave "bend." This
bending is called **refraction** .

-   In this animation, notice how the wave refracts as it comes into
    the beach.
    [http://www.grossmont.edu/garyjacobson/Oceanography%20112/Wave%20Model.htm](Wave%20Model.htm)

Most waves strike the shore at an angle. This creates longshore
currents, which are described in the concept "Surface Ocean Currents."

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-gvc}

-   Ocean waves have a tremendous amount of energy and so they may do a
    great deal of erosion.
-   Some landforms created by erosion are platforms, arches, and
    sea stacks.
-   Longshore currents are created because water approaches the shore at
    an angle.

# Deposition by Waves {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVwb3NpdGlvbiBieSBXYXZlcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Waves and currents carry sediment that they deposit on the shore.
-   Describe the landforms created by sediment deposition at the shore.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601888] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025926568652.jpeg)
</span>

**Which came first: erosion or deposition?**

Both erosion and deposition are seen in this photo. The beach sands were
deposited but waves are now eroding them away. At the shore, there's
always a battle between the two types of forces. What happens when
deposition is greater than erosion? What happens when erosion is greater
than deposition?

### Wave Deposition {#10.html#x-ck12-V2F2ZSBEZXBvc2l0aW9u_15-kad}

The transport of sediments by longshore currents is called **longshore
drift** . Longshore drift is created in this way: Sediment is moved up
the beach by an incoming wave. The wave approaches at an angle to the
shore. Water then moves straight offshore. The sediment moves straight
down the beach with it. The sediment is again picked up by a wave that
is coming in at an angle. So longshore drift moves sediment along the
shore. This zig-zag motion is pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Mb25nc2hvcmVEcmlmdA..) ) and can also
be seen at the link below.

-   [http://oceanica.cofc.edu/an%20educator'sl%20guide%20to%20folly%20beach/guide/driftanimation.htm](driftanimation.htm)

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZTBkZDQ0NjQ3YzgzNzA0ZDE0YjhhYjEwZDgxM2QxNmI.-iil"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Yefi/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Longshore_drift.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Picture of longshore
drift](ck12_10_files/20150911025926672494.png "Picture of longshore drift")

**Figure 10.42**

Longshore drift carries particles of sand and rock down a coastline.

</div>

#### Landforms Deposited by Waves {#10.html#x-ck12-TGFuZGZvcm1zIERlcG9zaXRlZCBieSBXYXZlcw.._15-y7k}

Longshore drift continually moves sand along the shore. Deposition
occurs where the water motion slows. The smallest particles, such as
silt and clay, are deposited away from shore. This is where the water is
calmer. Larger particles are deposited onshore. This is where waves and
other motions are strongest.

In relatively quiet areas along a shore, waves deposit sand. Sand forms
a **beach** ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NYW5oYXR0YW5CZWFjaFBpZXI.) ).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-YjNkNGExNWM5NjJhMWMyOTBmOTRmYTM0MDY3NDQzZTc.-i4d"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="David Krieger (Flickr:aghrivaine)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/aghrivaine/31113247" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A pier coming off a sandy
beach](ck12_10_files/20150911025926836454.jpeg "A pier coming off a sandy beach")

**Figure 10.43**

Manhattan Beach in Southern California has a pier coming off of a sandy
beach.

</div>

Waves also move sand from the beaches on shore to bars of sand offshore
as the seasons change. In the summer, waves have lower energy so they
bring sand up onto the beach. In the winter, higher energy waves bring
the sand back offshore.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZTYyZTFhZTc3ZDkzNmRmMzY0NmMzZmMwYzc1YTA0ZDg.-0wc"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Feydey/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Accreting_coast_Image6.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Examples of features formed by wave-deposited
sand](ck12_10_files/20150911025926976946.png "Examples of features formed by wave-deposited sand")

**Figure 10.44**

Examples of features formed by wave-deposited sand.

</div>

A **spit** is a ridge of sand that extends away from the shore. The end
of the spit may hook around toward the quieter waters close to shore.

Waves may also deposit sediments to form sandbars and **barrier
islands** . Pictured below are examples of these landforms ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1GbG9yaWRhQmFycmllcklzbGFuZA..) );
also, an example of all the different landforms waves create (
**Figure** [above](#10.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTAtMjYtU3BpdHMtYW5kLXNhbmQ.)
).

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZTg0NDFlODBmNTcyMTIyMGZkYzg4YTE3YjczM2ZmOTY.-b10"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright FloridaStock, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Picture of a barrier
island](ck12_10_files/20150911025927077165.jpeg "Picture of a barrier island")

**Figure 10.45**

A barrier island is a long strip of sand. The sand naturally moves in
the local currents. People try to build on barrier islands.

</div>

In its natural state, a barrier island acts as the first line of defense
against storms such as hurricanes. A natural barrier island is a
vegetated sandy areas in which sand can move. When barrier islands are
developed, hurricanes damage houses and businesses. A large hurricane
brings massive problems to the urbanized area.

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._15-owe}

-   The shore may have a lot of sediment washed from land or eroded
    from cliffs. The sediment is transported by currents.
-   Transported sand will eventually be deposited on beaches, spits, or
    barrier islands.

# Protecting Shorelines {#10.html#x-ck12-UHJvdGVjdGluZyBTaG9yZWxpbmVz}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the barriers humans construct to protect beaches.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601892] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025927225891.jpeg)
</span>

**Why do you see man-made structures on some beaches?**

When you go to a beach, you may see man-made structures like these. Most
attempt to keep the sand where people want the sand to be. A smaller
number keep the sand from coming into an area where it is not wanted.

### Protecting Shorelines {#10.html#x-ck12-UHJvdGVjdGluZyBTaG9yZWxpbmVz_16-vxf}

Shores are attractive places to live and vacation. But development at
the shore is at risk of damage from waves. Wave erosion threatens many
homes and beaches on the ocean. This is especially true during storms,
when waves may be much larger than normal. People build several types of
structures to protect beaches.

#### Breakwaters {#10.html#x-ck12-QnJlYWt3YXRlcnM._16-r3m}

Barrier islands provide natural protection to shorelines. Storm waves
strike the barrier island before they reach the shore. People also build
artificial barriers, called **breakwaters** . Breakwaters also protect
the shoreline from incoming waves. The breakwater pictured below (
**Figure** [below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TcGFpbkJyZWFrd2F0ZXI.) )
runs parallel to the coast like a barrier island.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-YTMxOGI3MDA2ZmViMzRiY2U5YzdlNzI5YTViMDMwNzM.-u4e"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:MarinoCarlos" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/marino/95717113/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A breakwater protecting a
beach](ck12_10_files/20150911025927355111.jpeg "A breakwater protecting a beach")

**Figure 10.46**

This rocky breakwater protects the beach at Tenerife in the Canary
Islands, Spain.

</div>

#### Groins {#10.html#x-ck12-R3JvaW5z_16-ulr}

Longshore drift can erode the sediment from a beach. To keep this from
happening, people may build a series of groins. A **groin** ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1HZXJtYW5Hcm9pbg..) ) is wall of rocks
or concrete. The structure juts out into the ocean perpendicular to the
shore. A groin stops the longshore movement of sand. Sand collects on
the up-current side of the groin. Sand on opposite of side of the groin
erodes. This reduces beach erosion.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-M2FmNTBkYTgzZDYxZTlmNWMyMTY2YjJhMGU0ZDdlMDE.-4th"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Rev Stan" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/revstan/3547075472/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A groin slows sand on the up-current
side](ck12_10_files/20150911025927465652.jpeg "A groin slows sand on the up-current side")

**Figure 10.47**

This groin slows sand on the up-current side. Can you determine which
way the water is moving based on where the sand is collecting?

</div>

#### Seawalls {#10.html#x-ck12-U2Vhd2FsbHM._16-pol}

A seawall is also parallel to the shore. However, a seawall is built
onshore. **Seawalls** ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TZWF3YWxs) ) protect the shore from
incoming waves.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZTZlZGZiODhkZmE2NzVkNTJmZGIzZGQzYzY1ZTAwZmY.-9dr"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Peter Stevens (Flickr:nordique)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/nordique/340517090/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A seawall protecting a
shore](ck12_10_files/20150911025927567125.jpeg "A seawall protecting a shore")

**Figure 10.48**

This seawall protects a shore in Vancouver.

</div>

### Does Protection Work? {#10.html#x-ck12-RG9lcyBQcm90ZWN0aW9uIFdvcms__16-sil}

People do not always want to choose safe building practices, and instead
choose to build a beach house right on the beach. Protecting development
from wave erosion is difficult and expensive.

Protection does not always work. The northeastern coast of Japan was
protected by anti-tsunami seawalls. Yet waves from the 2011 tsunami that
resulted from the Tōhoku earthquake washed over the top of some seawalls
and caused others to collapse. Japan is now planning to build even
higher seawalls to prepare for any future (and inevitable) tsunami.

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._16-jzy}

-   People love the shore, so they develop these regions and then must
    protect them.
-   Seawalls and breakwaters are built parallel to the shore.
-   Groins are built perpendicular to the shore. They trap sand.

# Erosion by Wind {#10.html#x-ck12-RXJvc2lvbiBieSBXaW5k}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how wind erodes sediments.
-   Describe the features wind erosion creates.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3601897] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_10_files/20150911025927662214.jpeg)
</span>

**Is wind the greatest erosional force in the desert?**

Wind can do remarkable things. It can erode rock to make beautiful
shapes. Wind has eroded this rock so that it looks like a rabbit. This
limestone formation is in the Sahara Desert in Egypt. Water is the most
important erosional force even in the desert. But wind makes its mark in
many ways.

### Sediment Transport by Wind {#10.html#x-ck12-U2VkaW1lbnQgVHJhbnNwb3J0IGJ5IFdpbmQ._17-hv5}

Like flowing water, wind picks up and transports particles. Wind carries
particles of different sizes in the same ways that water carries them (
**Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QYXJ0aWNsZVRyYW5zcG9ydEJ5V2luZA..) ).

-   Tiny particles, such as clay and silt, move by **suspension** . They
    hang in the air, sometimes for days. They may be carried great
    distances and rise high above the ground.
-   Larger particles, such as sand, move by **saltation** . The wind
    blows them in short hops. They stay close to the ground.
-   Particles larger than sand move by **creep** . The wind rolls or
    pushes them over the surface. They stay on the ground.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-YTg4YjEwNTM2NmY3MWEwYzYzZGU2NjZmM2VmODMwYzQ.-l8d"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of NASA" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Saltation-mechanics.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Diagram of how wind can transport
particles](ck12_10_files/20150911025927765735.jpeg "Diagram of how wind can transport particles")

**Figure 10.49**

Wind transports particles in different ways depending on their size.

</div>

### Wind Erosion {#10.html#x-ck12-V2luZCBFcm9zaW9u_17-jlb}

Dust storms ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1EdXN0U3Rvcm0.) ) are more common in
dry climates. The soil is dried out and dusty. Plants may be few and far
between. Dry, bare soil is more easily blown away by the wind than
wetter soil or soil held in place by plant roots.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-YjE0NzYwYjU0NzRlYjc3ZjNmZWRlNGQ3MTAxMzVmM2M.-u6i"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Sydney Oats (Flickr:expom2uk)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/57768042@N00/240219532/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of a large dust
storm](ck12_10_files/20150911025928068745.jpeg "Picture of a large dust storm")

**Figure 10.50**

When winds whip up in the desert, they can create tremendous dust
storms.

</div>

#### Deflation {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVmbGF0aW9u_17-phe}

Wind blows small particles away. As a result, the ground surface gets
lower and rockier; this is called **deflation** . The rocks that are
left are called **desert pavement** . Desert pavement is a surface
covered by gravel-sized particles that are not easily moved by wind.

#### Abrasion {#10.html#x-ck12-QWJyYXNpb24._17-4vj}

Did you ever see workers sandblasting a building to clean it? Sand is
blown onto the surface to scour away dirt and debris. Wind-blown sand
has the same effect. It scours and polishes rocks and other surfaces.
Wind-blown sand may carve rocks into interesting shapes ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1VdGFoV2luZEFicmFzaW9u) ). This form
of erosion is called abrasion. It occurs any time rough sediments are
blown or dragged over surfaces. Can you think of other ways abrasion
might occur?

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-ZWIzOTE4ODFhOTNiYWJmMjNmZDBhM2NkMTNhZTM5M2E.-prt"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Natural Resources Conservation Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:NRCSUT03016_-_Utah_(6401)(NRCS_Photo_Gallery).jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Rock formation created due to wind
erosion](ck12_10_files/20150911025928160787.jpeg "Rock formation created due to wind erosion")

**Figure 10.51**

This incredible rock formation in Utah is the result of wind erosion.

</div>

#### Desert Varnish {#10.html#x-ck12-RGVzZXJ0IFZhcm5pc2g._17-dmy}

Exposed rocks in desert areas often develop a dark brown or black
coating called **desert varnish** ( **Figure**
[below](#10.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1VdGFoUGV0cm9nbHlwaA..) ). Wind
transports clay-sized particles that chemically react with other
substances at high temperatures. The coating is formed of iron and
manganese oxides.

<div
id="10.html#x-ck12-MDhmM2U0MTk2NWEzMGZjZTc1OWYzMTcwZTNlYmYwNDY.-hue"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Frank Kovalchek (Flickr:Alaskan Dude)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/72213316@N00/5287996363/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Petroglyphs carved into desert
varnish](ck12_10_files/20150911025928278597.jpeg "Petroglyphs carved into desert varnish")

**Figure 10.52**

Ancient people carved these petroglyphs into desert varnish at Sego
Canyon, Utah.

</div>

### Summary {#10.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._17-36v}

-   Wind moves sediments by suspension, saltation, or creep.
-   In deserts, wind picks up small particles and leaves behind
    larger rocks. This forms desert pavement.
-   Moving sand may sand blast rocks and other materials
    causing abrasion.
