### The Future {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEZ1dHVyZQ.._10-w5o}

Human ingenuity has allowed the population to continue to grow. We’ve
increased Earth's **carrying capacity** for humans by our genius. We
grow crops, trade for needed materials, and design ways to exploit
resources that are difficult to get at, such as groundwater. We use
long-buried ancient organisms for fuel. We have broken the rules for
biological populations.

Of course, there's a flip side to this. For the population to continue
to grow, more advances in agriculture will be needed. The best lands are
already in use. Most rivers that can be dammed, have been dammed. In
many aquifers, groundwater is not replenished on the time frame needed.
Fossil fuels too are limited. Obtaining fossil fuels or developing new
power sources will be more costly.

#### Future Population Growth {#12.html#x-ck12-RnV0dXJlIFBvcHVsYXRpb24gR3Jvd3Ro_10-k8g}

The rate of increase of the growth rate of the human population is
decreasing ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMjAtSHVtYW4tcG9wdWxhdGlvbi1ncmFwaA..)
). The population may stop growing by the mid 2000s. Some scientists
think that the human population will peak at about 9 billion people.
What will need to change for the population to stop growing then?

</div>

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._10-o0a}

-   Humans have exceeded the carrying capacity of Earth for humans by
    their ingenuity.
-   The rate of population increase is starting to decline. The
    population is still exploding though.
-   The growth rate is higher in less developed nations.

# Sustainable Development {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VzdGFpbmFibGUgRGV2ZWxvcG1lbnQ.}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define sustainable development.
-   Explain how sustainable development can work.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602120] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030015587325.jpeg)
</span>

**Is there another way?**

Visibility in Beijing is sometimes so bad that the airport must be
closed due to smog. In their rush to develop, many nations are making
the same mistakes that the developed nations have already made. Can
everyone find a more sustainable path?

### Sustainable Development {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VzdGFpbmFibGUgRGV2ZWxvcG1lbnQ._11-puh}

Is it possible for all the world’s people to live well and still protect
the planet? That’s the aim of **sustainable development** . Its goals
are to:

1.  help people out of poverty.
2.  protect the environment.
3.  use resources no faster than the rate at which they are regenerated.

A smaller human population is part of the solution. Studies show that
educated women have fewer and healthier, children. Educating women (and
men) is a long-term goal of population control.

Developing new technologies can help. For example, fish farming can feed
people good healthy protein. The farming must be done in an
environmentally sound way.

Better use of resources is another part. For example, when forests are
logged, new trees should be planted.

Citizens can change their behavior to reduce the impact they have on the
planet. They can demand that products are produced sustainably. People
can consume less. They can think about the impact they have when they do
consume.

Everyone can help in the effort. What will you do?

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._11-9qm}

-   Sustainable development tries to bring people up to certain minimum
    living conditions. This must be done without doing further damage to
    the environment.
-   To develop sustainably, the human population must stabilize
    or decrease.
-   Resources must be developed and used consciously and in
    environmentally sound ways.

# Biological Communities {#12.html#x-ck12-QmlvbG9naWNhbCBDb21tdW5pdGllcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Identify the parts of a biological community.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602125] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030015644755.jpeg)
</span>

**Where can you find an ecosystem?**

Just about everywhere you could go in nature, you would be taking a
field trip to an ecosystem. There are underwater ecosystems and coastal
ecosystems. There are small scale ecosystems and large ones. There are
even ecosystems inside your body!

### What Is an Ecosystem? {#12.html#x-ck12-V2hhdCBJcyBhbiBFY29zeXN0ZW0__12-2am}

An **ecosystem** is a group of living things and their environment. The
word ecosystem is short for “ecological system.” Like any system, an
ecosystem is a group of parts that work together. You can see examples
of ecosystems in **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDEtVHdvLWVjb3N5c3RlbXM.) . The
forest pictured is a big ecosystem. Besides trees, what living things do
you think are part of the forest ecosystem? The dead tree stump in the
same forest is a small ecosystem. It includes plants, mosses, and fungi.
It also includes insects and worms.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NjhiYTk4OWEzOTQ1NjkwZTYwNzcxNDIyYjM3ZDhlMjQ.-3n8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Left: Alosh Bennett; Right: Flickr:erysimum9" -->
<!-- @@url="Left: http://www.flickr.com/photos/aloshbennett/3996113256/; Right: http://www.flickr.com/photos/erysimum9/6995070479/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![A forest and tree stump are both
ecosystems](ck12_12_files/20150911030015704567.jpeg "A forest and tree stump are both ecosystems")

**Figure 12.21**

An ecosystem can be big or small. A small ecosystem can be part of a
larger ecosystem.

</div>

#### Abiotic Factors {#12.html#x-ck12-QWJpb3RpYyBGYWN0b3Jz_12-bmb}

**Abiotic factors** are the nonliving parts of ecosystems. They include
air, sunlight, soil, water, and minerals. These are all things that are
needed for life. They determine which living things—and how many of
them—an ecosystem can support. Pictured below is an ecosystem and its
abiotic factors ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDItQWJpb3RpYy1mYWN0b3Jz) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-ZDQ2MTBlODgyMGZhODJhMWUyMTRiZDg2MTNhYmI5YmU.-mwm"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of US Fish and Wildlife Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.fws.gov/invasives/volunteersTrainingModule/invasives/plants.html" -->
<!-- @@license="Public domain" -->
![Diagram of abiotic factors of an
ecosystem](ck12_12_files/20150911030015756822.png "Diagram of abiotic factors of an ecosystem")

**Figure 12.22**

Which abiotic factors do you see here?

</div>

#### Biotic Factors {#12.html#x-ck12-QmlvdGljIEZhY3RvcnM._12-e9z}

**Biotic factors** are the living parts of ecosystems. They are the
species of living things that reside together.

#### Species, Niche, and Habitat {#12.html#x-ck12-U3BlY2llcywgTmljaGUsIGFuZCBIYWJpdGF0_12-tq9}

A **species** is a unique type of organism. Members of a species can
interbreed and produce offspring that can breed (they are fertile).
Organisms that are not in the same species cannot do this. Examples of
species include humans, lions, and redwood trees. Can you name other
examples?

Each species has a particular way of making a living. This is called its
**niche** . You can see the niche of a lion below ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDMtTGlvbi1odW50cy16ZWJyYQ..) ). A
lion makes its living by hunting and eating other animals. Each species
also has a certain place where it is best suited to live. This is called
its **habitat** . The lion’s habitat is a grassland. Why is a lion
better off in a grassland than in a forest?

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-OGEwNzRlNzI4MzJmY2QzYmFjZjk0MjA5NWM4OGM2OGI.-pin"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Demetrius John Kessy (Flickr:Diamond Glacier Adventures Ltd)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/diamondglacieradventures/5737115639/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Lion hunting a
zebra](ck12_12_files/20150911030015815796.jpeg "Lion hunting a zebra")

**Figure 12.23**

A lion hunts a water buffalo. What is the lion's niche?

</div>

#### Living Together {#12.html#x-ck12-TGl2aW5nIFRvZ2V0aGVy_12-cqg}

All the members of a species that live in the same area form a
**population** . Many different species live together in an ecosystem.
All their populations make up a **community** . What populations live
together in the grassland pictured below ( **Figure**
[above](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDMtTGlvbi1odW50cy16ZWJyYQ..) )?

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._12-xko}

-   All of the individuals of a species that exist together at a given
    place and time make up a population. A community is made up of all
    of the populations in an area.
-   The living and nonliving factors that living organisms need plus the
    communities of organisms themselves make up an ecosystem.
-   A habitat is where an organism lives, and a niche is what it does to
    make a living.

# Roles in an Ecosystem {#12.html#x-ck12-Um9sZXMgaW4gYW4gRWNvc3lzdGVt}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Define and describe the common roles in an ecosystem.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602141] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030015872040.jpeg)
</span>

**Can you pick out the organisms at the bottom and at the top of this
food chain?**

What's at the bottom of the food chain? A bit of the food energy comes
from above, where plankton photosynthesize. Most comes from the coral.
Coral are animals that live with tiny zooxanthellae that also
photosynthesize. Of course, you know what's at the top of this food
chain!

### Roles in Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-Um9sZXMgaW4gRWNvc3lzdGVtcw.._13-zpx}

All ecosystems have living things that play the same basic roles. Some
organisms must be producers. Others must be consumers. Decomposers are
also important.

#### Producers {#12.html#x-ck12-UHJvZHVjZXJz_13-rol}

**Producers** are living things that use energy to make food. Producers
make food for themselves and other living things. There are two types of
producers:

-   By far the most common producers use the energy in sunlight to
    make food. This is called **photosynthesis** . Producers that
    photosynthesize include plants and algae. These organisms must live
    where there is plenty of sunlight.
-   Other producers use the energy in chemicals to make food. This is
    called **chemosynthesis** . Only a very few producers are of this
    type, and all of them are microbes. These producers live deep under
    the ocean where there is no sunlight. An example is pictured below (
    **Figure**
    [below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDQtT2NlYW4tZmxvb3ItZWNvc3lzdGVt) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NWIxZTUyNDY1MTgxN2ExODhmODYxYmM3NDU2ZDU5OTQ.-xjm"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Christopher Auyueng" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" --> <!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![A picture of an ecosystem on the ocean
floor](ck12_12_files/20150911030015937260.png "A picture of an ecosystem on the ocean floor")

**Figure 12.24**

Microbes use chemicals to make food. The chemicals pour out of a crack
on the ocean floor at a mid-ocean ridge. What consumers live in this
ecosystem?

</div>

#### Consumers {#12.html#x-ck12-Q29uc3VtZXJz_13-80a}

**Consumers** can’t make their own food. Consumers must eat producers or
other consumers. Listed below are the three main types of consumers (
**Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDUtVHlwZXMtb2YtY29uc3VtZXJz) ):
**herbivores** , **carnivores** , and **omnivores** . Which type are
you?

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MGM1MzU0ZTIyMTEyYzIwZWFiOTE1NWZiMjIyMDZjOTA.-hrw"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Grasshopper: Renato Targa (Flickr:renatotarga); Mole: Peter Paquet/ Northwest Power and Conservation Council; Raccoon: Flickr:ZeMoufette" -->
<!-- @@url="Grasshopper: http://www.flickr.com/photos/rtarga/4495169959/; Mole: http://www.flickr.com/photos/nwcouncil/7362706482/; Raccoon: http://www.flickr.com/photos/zemoufette/4599528693/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Herbivores, carnivores, and omnivores are the three main types of
consumers](ck12_12_files/20150911030015994985.jpeg "Herbivores, carnivores, and omnivores are the three main types of consumers")

**Figure 12.25**

Examples of the main types of consumers. Can you name other consumers of
each type?

</div>

Consumers get their food in different ways ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDYtV2F5cy1jb25zdW1lcnMtZ2V0LWZvb2Q.)
). **Grazers** feed on living organisms without killing them. A rabbit
nibbles on leaves, and a mosquito sucks a drop of blood. **Predators** ,
like lions, capture and kill animals for food. The animals they eat are
called **prey** . Even some plants are consumers. Pitcher plants trap
insects in their sticky fluid in their “pitchers.” The insects are their
prey. **Scavengers** eat animals that are already dead. This hyena is
eating the remains of a lion’s prey. **Decomposers** break down dead
organisms and the wastes of living things ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDYtV2F5cy1jb25zdW1lcnMtZ2V0LWZvb2Q.)
). This dung beetle is rolling a ball of dung (animal waste) back to its
nest. The beetle will use the dung to feed its young. The mushrooms
pictured are growing on a dead log. They will slowly break it down. This
releases its nutrients to the soil.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-ZGI2ZDk3ZjcxYTk5OTM1ZWQ2NTZhZTk4NzdiZmUzYzQ.-zfk"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Rabbit: Dan Perry; Mosquito: Courtesy of James Gathany, CDC; Pitcher plant: Tim Mansfield; Hyena: Demetrius John Kessy (Flickr:Diamond Glacier Adventures Ltd); Dung Beetle: Teddy Fotiou (Flickr:EpochCatcher); Mushrooms: Flickr:The_Gut" -->
<!-- @@url="Rabbit: http://www.flickr.com/photos/golf_pictures/263989457/; Mosquito: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:CDC-Gathany-Aedes-albopictus-1.jpg; Pitcher plants: http://www.flickr.com/photos/timbomb/406235908/; Hyena: http://www.flickr.com/photos/diamondglacieradventures/5613845130/; Dung Beetle: http://www.flickr.com/photos/epochcatcher/8227083897/; Mushrooms: http://www.flickr.com/photos/frogbelly/8084143639/" -->
<!-- @@license="Rabbit: CC BY 2.0; Mosquito: Public Domain; Pitcher plant: CC BY 2.0; Hyena: CC BY 2.0; Dung Beetle: CC BY 2.0; Mushrooms: CC BY 2.0" -->
![The different ways consumer get
food](ck12_12_files/20150911030016061122.jpeg "The different ways consumer get food")

**Figure 12.26**

Ways consumers get food. Do you know how earthworms get food?

</div>

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._13-2of}

-   Herbivores eat plants, carnivores eat meat, and omnivores eat both.
-   Predators are animals that eat a prey animal. Scavengers eat
    organisms that are already dead. Decomposers break down dead plants
    and animals into component parts, including nutrients.
-   Producers create food energy. They are the base of all life
    on Earth. Most producers use photosynthesis but a very small number
    use chemosynthesis.

# Flow of Energy in Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-RmxvdyBvZiBFbmVyZ3kgaW4gRWNvc3lzdGVtcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe food chains and webs.
-   Explain how energy flows through ecosystems.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602148] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030016150972.jpeg)
</span>

**What is the source of energy for almost all ecosystems?**

The Sun supports most of Earth's ecosystems. Plants create chemical
energy from abiotic factors that include solar energy. The food energy
created by producers is passed through the food chain.

### How Energy Flows Through Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-SG93IEVuZXJneSBGbG93cyBUaHJvdWdoIEVjb3N5c3RlbXM._14-rzk}

All living things need energy. They need it to power the processes of
life. For example, it takes energy to grow. It also takes energy to
produce offspring. In fact, it takes energy just to stay alive. Remember
that energy can’t be created or destroyed. It can only change form.
Energy changes form as it moves through ecosystems.

#### The Flow of Energy {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEZsb3cgb2YgRW5lcmd5_14-jsa}

Most ecosystems get their energy from the Sun. Only producers can use
sunlight to make usable energy. Producers convert the sunlight into
chemical energy or food. Consumers get some of that energy when they eat
producers. They also pass some of the energy on to other consumers when
they are eaten. In this way, energy flows from one living thing to
another.

#### Food Chains {#12.html#x-ck12-Rm9vZCBDaGFpbnM._14-3ww}

A **food chain** is a simple diagram that shows one way energy flows
through an ecosystem. Pictured below is an example of a food chain (
**Figure** [below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDYtRm9vZC1jaGFpbg..) ).
Producers form the base of all food chains. The consumers that eat
producers are called primary consumers. The consumers that eat primary
consumers are secondary consumers. This chain can continue to multiple
levels.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-Y2EwNTM1NDRjYTk0OGIxYmJhOGRkYjk1YzVkMDkzZWM.-iqm"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Zappy's" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Example of a food
chain](ck12_12_files/20150911030016211427.jpeg "Example of a food chain")

**Figure 12.27**

What do the arrows stand for in a food chain?

</div>

At each level of a food chain, a lot of energy is lost. Only about ten
percent of the energy passes to the next level. Where does that energy
go? Some energy is given off as heat. Some energy goes into animal
wastes. Energy also goes into growing things that another consumer can't
eat, like fur. It's because so much energy is lost that most food chains
have just a few levels. There’s not enough energy left for higher
levels.

#### Food Webs {#12.html#x-ck12-Rm9vZCBXZWJz_14-nk6}

Food chains are too simple to represent the real world. They don’t show
all the ways that energy flows through an ecosystem. A more complex
diagram is called a **food web** ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDctRm9vZC13ZWI.) ). A food web
consists of many overlapping food chains. Can you identify the food
chains in the figure? How many food chains include the mouse?

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MjMwZWUyMGY5Y2E3MTFmMWQxNDA2MTc2YjliNTlkMGE.-ze3"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Owl: Marie Hale; Snake: Lauren Mitchell (Flickr:LOLren); Rat: Charles Jeffrey Danoff; Mouse: Giang H&#7891; Th&#7883; Ho&#224;ng; Rabbit: Don Debold; Grasshopper: Flickr:jster91" -->
<!-- @@url="Owl: http://www.flickr.com/photos/15016964@N02/5909827861/; Snake: http://www.flickr.com/photos/laurenprofeta/4320516966/; Rat: http://www.flickr.com/photos/danoff/3323774401/; Mouse: http://www.flickr.com/photos/hthg1983/2237614948/; Rabbit: http://www.flickr.com/photos/ddebold/5459789250/; Grasshopper: http://www.flickr.com/photos/jster91/2384610024/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Example of a food
web](ck12_12_files/20150911030016276110.jpeg "Example of a food web")

**Figure 12.28**

The owl in this food web consumes at two different levels. What are
they?

</div>

Food webs also overlap. For example, an eagle is part of a land food
web. But it might go to the sea to grab a fish. That fish is part of a
marine food web.

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._14-cme}

-   A food chain describes the passage of energy.
-   A food web is a set of interconnected and overlapping food chains.
-   Food webs are interconnected.

# Flow of Matter in Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-RmxvdyBvZiBNYXR0ZXIgaW4gRWNvc3lzdGVtcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how matter flows through ecosystems.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602157] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030016339094.jpeg)
</span>

**What happens when you don't get enough of a nutrient?**

Millions of sailors in the 15th through 18th centuries died
mysteriously. They developed a disease called scurvy. The scurvy, it
turns out, was due to the lack of vitamin C in their diets. It wasn't
until 1932 that the link between scurvy and vitamin C was made. Without
the right nutrients in the right amounts, you can't live. Other animals
and plants also need the right nutrients to live.

### How Matter Moves Through Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-SG93IE1hdHRlciBNb3ZlcyBUaHJvdWdoIEVjb3N5c3RlbXM._15-3kj}

Living things need nonliving matter as well as energy. What do you think
matter is used for? It's used to build bodies. It's also needed to carry
out the processes of life. Any nonliving matter that living things need
is called a **nutrient** . Carbon and nitrogen are examples of
nutrients. Unlike energy, matter is recycled in ecosystems. In the
figure below, you can see how ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMDgtRW5lcmd5LWluLWVjb3N5c3RlbQ..) ).

-   Decomposers release nutrients when they break down dead organisms.
-   The nutrients are taken up by plants through their roots.
-   The nutrients pass to primary consumers when they eat the plants.
-   The nutrients pass to higher level consumers when they eat lower
    level consumers.
-   When living things die, the cycle repeats.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-YWY0OGM1YjYwODA1YmNiZWI5OGY4YmUxNmE5MzMyN2M.-q3d"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Laura Guerin" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Cycle of energy and matter in an
ecosystem](ck12_12_files/20150911030016406088.jpeg "Cycle of energy and matter in an ecosystem")

**Figure 12.29**

This diagram shows two cycles. One is the cycle of energy, the other is
the cycle of matter. Compare the two cycles. Do you see how the Sun
keeps adding energy? That’s because energy is lost at each step of the
cycle. Matter doesn’t have to be added. Can you explain why?

</div>

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._15-jkv}

-   Nutrients are crucial to the growth of organisms.
-   Decomposers break down dead organisms into nutrients and gases so
    that they can be used by other organisms.
-   Nutrients can enter or exit an ecosystem at any point and can cycle
    around the planet.

# Nitrogen Cycle in Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-Tml0cm9nZW4gQ3ljbGUgaW4gRWNvc3lzdGVtcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe nitrogen's roles as a nutrient.
-   Define nitrogen fixation, and explain how it occurs.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602160] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030016470961.jpeg)
</span>

**Why are these fish dead?**

In a dead zone, there is so little oxygen that fish can't live. What
causes the oxygen to disappear? Indirectly, it's nitrogen.

### The Nitrogen Cycle {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIE5pdHJvZ2VuIEN5Y2xl_16-xxm}

Living things need nitrogen. Nitrogen is a key element in proteins. Like
carbon, nitrogen cycles through ecosystems. The **nitrogen cycle** is
pictured below ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMTItTml0cm9nZW4tY3ljbGU.) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MjkzMmE2MWU2OWYyMTUzMWQ3NWU5OGM0NWEwNzY0YjY.-eet"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Hana Zavadska, using deer by freedo" -->
<!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation (deer available at http://openclipart.org/detail/3412/fawn-by-freedo)" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0 (deer available in public domain)" -->
![Diagram of the nitrogen
cycle](ck12_12_files/20150911030016543562.png "Diagram of the nitrogen cycle")

**Figure 12.30**

The nitrogen cycle includes air, soil, and living things.

</div>

#### Fixing Nitrogen {#12.html#x-ck12-Rml4aW5nIE5pdHJvZ2Vu_16-34b}

Air is about 78 percent nitrogen. Decomposers release nitrogen into the
air from dead organisms and their wastes. However, producers such as
plants can’t use these forms of nitrogen. Nitrogen must combine with
other elements before producers can use it. This is done by certain
bacteria in the soil. It’s called “fixing” nitrogen.

#### Human Actions and the Nitrogen Cycle {#12.html#x-ck12-SHVtYW4gQWN0aW9ucyBhbmQgdGhlIE5pdHJvZ2VuIEN5Y2xl_16-jzq}

Nitrogen is one of the most important nutrients needed by plants. That’s
why most plant fertilizers contain nitrogen. Adding fertilizer to soil
allows more plants to grow. As a result, a given amount of land can
produce more food. So far, so good. But what happens next?

Rain dissolves fertilizer in the soil. Runoff carries it away. The
fertilizer ends up in bodies of water, from ponds to oceans. Nitrogen is
a fertilizer in the water. Since there is a lot of nitrogen, it causes
algae to grow out of control. Pictured below is a pond covered with
algae ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMTMtVG9vLW11Y2gtbml0cm9nZW4tZWZmZWN0cw..)
). Algae use up carbon dioxide in the water. After the algae die,
decomposers break down the dead tissue. The decomposers use up all the
oxygen in the water. This creates a dead zone. A **dead zone** is an
area in a body of water where nothing grows because there is too little
oxygen. There is a large dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTgtMTMtVG9vLW11Y2gtbml0cm9nZW4tZWZmZWN0cw..)
). The U.S. states outlined on the map have rivers that drain into the
Gulf of Mexico. The rivers drain vast agricultural lands. The water
carries fertilizer from these areas into the Gulf.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NTY1YmVjNDM5ZDk5M2MyZWViMzgxMzRiNjI1YjcyZTQ.-jy6"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Pond: Flickr:Misserion; Map: Courtesy of the Environmental Protection Agency, US Department of Agriculture" -->
<!-- @@url="Pond: http://www.flickr.com/photos/misserion/1097659938/; Map: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Mississippi-map.gif" -->
<!-- @@license="Pond: CC BY 2.0; Map: Public Domain" -->
![Pond covered with algae, and a dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico due to
too much
nitrogen](ck12_12_files/20150911030016615144.jpeg "Pond covered with algae, and a dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico due to too much nitrogen")

**Figure 12.31**

The pond on the left is covered with algae because there is too much
nitrogen in the water. The red-shaded area in the map on the right is a
dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico. It’s called the hypoxic (“low oxygen”)
zone in the figure.

</div>

This very thorough video on the nitrogen cycle with an aquatic
perspective was created by high school students:
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pdY4I-EaqJA](watch?v=pdY4I-EaqJA)
(5:08).

[![](ck12_12_files/tmp7wENHc.jpeg)](pdY4I-EaqJA)

Click on the image above for more content

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._16-fu9}

-   Nitrogen is an essential part of many molecules needed by
    living organisms.
-   Nitrogen is fixed when it is changed into a form that organisms
    can use.
-   Dead zones come about when excess nitrogen in the water causes algae
    to grow out of control. Decomposers use oxygen to decompose the
    algae when they die. The lack of oxygen makes it impossible for
    other organisms to live in that zone.

# Fresh Water Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-RnJlc2ggV2F0ZXIgRWNvc3lzdGVtcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the various types of freshwater ecosystems.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602164] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030016688739.png)
</span>

**What do the swamps of Florida look like?**

Orlando, Florida is home to many amusement parks. On the left is a swamp
with swamp wildlife. On the right is the village of Hogsmeade, or at
least a replica. The Wizarding World of Harry Potter is one of the many
amusement parks in and around Orlando. These amusement parks are built
on land that was mostly lakes and swamps.

### Freshwater Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-RnJlc2h3YXRlciBFY29zeXN0ZW1z_17-7yx}

Lakes, ponds, streams, springs, and wetlands are fresh water bodies. The
organisms that live in them are part of freshwater ecosystems. These
ecosystems vary by temperature, pressure (in lakes), and the amount of
light that penetrates. The type of plants that grow in these ecosystems
varies.

#### Lake Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-TGFrZSBFY29zeXN0ZW1z_17-reh}

**Limnology** is the study of the plants and animals that live in fresh
water bodies. A lake has zones just like the ocean. The ecosystem of a
lake is divided into three distinct zones ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-RWFyU2NpLTEzLTAyLTA2) ):

1.  The surface (littoral) zone is the sloped area closest to the edge
    of the water.
2.  The open-water zone (also called the **photic zone** ) has sunlight.
3.  The deep-water zone (also called the **aphotic zone** ) has little
    or no sunlight.

There are several life zones found within a lake:

-   In the **littoral zone** , sunlight allows plants to grow. Plants
    provide food and shelter to animals such as snails, insects,
    and fish.
-   Other plants and fish live in the open-water zone. These include
    bass and trout.
-   The deep-water zone is dark so there is no photosynthesis. Most
    deep-water organisms are scavengers. They feed on dead organisms
    that fall to the bottom of the lake. Crabs and catfish are two of
    these types of organisms. Fungi and bacteria are decomposers that
    live in the deep zone.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-ZjBkMGE5ODE1MTk4MzMzMGM0MjY5ZjUyMGUzNDQzMGM.-dlz"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Geoff Ruth" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Diagram of the littoral, open-water, and deep-water zones in a
lake](ck12_12_files/20150911030016757665.jpeg "Diagram of the littoral, open-water, and deep-water zones in a lake")

**Figure 12.32**

The three primary zones of a lake are the littoral, open-water, and
deep-water zones.

</div>

#### Wetlands {#12.html#x-ck12-V2V0bGFuZHM._17-0v6}

Some of Earth’s freshwater is found in wetlands. A **wetland** is an
area that is covered with water, or at least has very soggy soil, during
all or part of the year. Certain species of plants thrive in wetlands,
and they are rich ecosystems. Freshwater wetlands are usually found at
the edges of streams, rivers, ponds, or lakes. Wetlands can also be
found at the edges of seas.

#### Types of Freshwater Wetlands {#12.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgRnJlc2h3YXRlciBXZXRsYW5kcw.._17-j7t}

Not all wetlands are alike, as you can see below ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTMtMDktV2V0bGFuZHM.) ). Wetlands vary
in how wet they are and how much of the year they are soaked. Wetlands
also vary in the kinds of plants that live in them. This depends mostly
on the climate where the wetland is found. Types of wetlands include
marshes, swamps, and bogs.

-   A **marsh** is a wetland that is usually under water. It has grassy
    plants, such as cattails.
-   A **swamp** is a wetland that may or may not be covered with water
    but is always soggy. It has shrubs or trees.
-   A **bog** is a wetland that has soggy soil. It is generally covered
    with mosses.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MjQ4NDZhYzYxZGJjYmQzNDNhYzYzNjdiMmI1YjRlNmU.-g58"
class="x-ck12-img-fullpage x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Marsh: Scooter Lowrimore; Bog: User:Rosser1954/Wikimedia Commons; Swamp: Brian Stansberry (Wikimedia: Bms4880)" -->
<!-- @@url="Marsh: http://www.flickr.com/photos/vesparado/5646184641/; Bog: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Auchentiber_moss.JPG; Swamp: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Middleton-place-swamp-sc2.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Marsh: CC BY 2.0; Bog: Public Domain; Swamp: CC BY 3.0" -->
![Pictures of a marsh, bog, and swamp, which are three types of
wetlands](ck12_12_files/20150911030016816528.jpeg "Pictures of a marsh, bog, and swamp, which are three types of wetlands")

**Figure 12.33**

These are just three of many types of wetlands.

</div>

#### Importance of Wetlands {#12.html#x-ck12-SW1wb3J0YW5jZSBvZiBXZXRsYW5kcw.._17-o3u}

People used to think that wetlands were useless. Many wetlands were
filled in with rocks and soil to create solid land. This land was then
developed with roads, golf courses, and buildings. Now we know that
wetlands are very important. Laws have been passed to help protect them.
Why are wetlands so important?

-   Wetlands have great biodiversity. They provide homes or breeding
    sites to a huge variety of species. Because so much wetland area has
    been lost, many of these species are endangered.
-   Wetlands purify water. They filter sediments and toxins from runoff
    before it enters rivers, lakes, and oceans.
-   Wetlands slow rushing water. During hurricanes and other extreme
    weather, wetlands reduce the risk of floods.

Although the rate of loss has slowed, wetlands are still being destroyed
today.

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._17-afn}

-   The conditions that affect lake ecosystems are similar to those that
    affect ocean ecosystems. These include light penetration,
    temperature, and water depth.
-   Wetlands are lands that are wet for a significant portion of
    the year.
-   Wetlands are extremely important as an ecosystem and as a filter
    for pollutants.

# Types of Marine Organisms {#12.html#x-ck12-VHlwZXMgb2YgTWFyaW5lIE9yZ2FuaXNtcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe types of marine organisms.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602169] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030016878117.jpeg)
</span>

**How can you visit marine life?**

It's easiest to get to the relatively shallow seafloor just offshore.
Experienced divers can descend to 130 feet (43 ft), which gives them
access to most marine life. Manned submersibles can descend to the
bottom of the deep ocean. Where would you like to go? A coral reef or a
hydrothermal vent?

### Living Things in the Ocean {#12.html#x-ck12-TGl2aW5nIFRoaW5ncyBpbiB0aGUgT2NlYW4._18-isz}

Marine organisms range in size from tiny bacteria to the largest known
animal, the blue whale. All are adapted for life in salt water. Most are
adapted for extreme pressures.

When you think of life in the ocean, do you think of fish? Actually,
fish are not the most common life forms in the ocean. Plankton are the
most common. Plankton make up one of three major groups of marine life.
The other two groups are nekton and benthos ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTQtMjQtUGxhbmt0b24tTmVrdG9uLUJlbnRob3MtbmV3)
).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-YTMyNTZlNWNiMzEwNjUyOTg4Njg0NTM5MDRlYjc3MDc.-cka"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Zappy's" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Plankton, nekton, and benthos are the three groups of living things in
the
oceans](ck12_12_files/20150911030016992760.jpeg "Plankton, nekton, and benthos are the three groups of living things in the oceans")

**Figure 12.34**

Living things in the oceans are placed in these three groups.

</div>

#### Plankton {#12.html#x-ck12-UGxhbmt0b24._18-oum}

**Plankton** are living things that float in the water. Most plankton
are too small to see with the unaided eye ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QbGFua3Rvbg..) ). Plankton are unable
to move on their own. Ocean motions carry them along.

There are two main types of plankton:

1.  **Phytoplankton** are “plant-like” plankton. Since they make food by
    photosynthesis, they live in the photic zone. Most are algae.
2.  **Zooplankton** are “animal-like” plankton that include tiny animals
    and fish larvae. They feed on phytoplankton.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NTBkMmU4ZjQwM2E4N2I5ZmQ3YmFhZTRhYmZlNzhiNjg.-9md"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@url="Phytoplankton: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Mixed_phytoplankton.jpg; Zooplankton: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Fish3532_-_Flickr_-_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Pictures of phytoplankton and
zooplankton](ck12_12_files/20150911030017057519.jpeg "Pictures of phytoplankton and zooplankton")

**Figure 12.35**

The phytoplankton (left) and zooplankton (right) shown here have been
magnified. Otherwise, they would be too small for you to see.

</div>

#### Nekton {#12.html#x-ck12-TmVrdG9u_18-ir3}

**Nekton** are living things that swim through the water ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1OZWt0b24.) ). They may live at any
depth, in the photic or aphotic zone. Most nekton are fish, although
some are mammals. Fish have fins and streamlined bodies to help them
swim. Fish also have gills to take oxygen from the water.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-ZGZkZGM3YWExMjdiYzliNDlkMTVlZDkyYzgzYzIzN2Y.-1ia"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Nekton, like a fish, swim through ocean
water](ck12_12_files/20150911030017127611.jpeg "Nekton, like a fish, swim through ocean water")

**Figure 12.36**

Nekton swim through ocean water.

</div>

#### Benthos {#12.html#x-ck12-QmVudGhvcw.._18-ybj}

**Benthos** are living organisms on the ocean floor. Many benthic
organisms attach themselves to rocks and stay in one place. This
protects them from crashing waves and other water movements. Some
benthic organisms burrow into sediments for food or protection. Benthic
animals may crawl over the ocean floor. Examples of benthos include
clams and worms. Pictured below are two other examples ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTQtMjctQmVudGhvcw..) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-YWRhMzE4YjJlY2I3NjYwOWVlNGNlYWQxMGU4ZjA0Yzg.-5km"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Left: Flickr:tpholland; Right: Ratha Grimes (Flickr:papertygre)" -->
<!-- @@url="Left: http://www.flickr.com/photos/tpholland/3663230720/; Right: http://www.flickr.com/photos/ratha/9246414596/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Picture of an anemone and sea cucumber, which live on the ocean
floor](ck12_12_files/20150911030017181249.jpeg "Picture of an anemone and sea cucumber, which live on the ocean floor")

**Figure 12.37**

These animals live on the ocean floor.

</div>

Some benthos live near vents on the deep ocean floor. Tubeworms are an
example ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTQtMjgtVHViZXdvcm1zLUJlbnRob3M.) ).
Scalding hot water pours out of the vents. The hot water contains
chemicals that some specialized bacteria can use to make food. Tubeworms
have the bacteria living inside them. The bacteria get protection and
the tubeworms get some of the food.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MTcyYTI5ZDY5M2VmN2VlMDllNDc0MzY3NmVkNzFmZWI.-a0z"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Picture of tubeworms living near hot water
vents](ck12_12_files/20150911030017239554.jpeg "Picture of tubeworms living near hot water vents")

**Figure 12.38**

Tubeworms live near hot water vents on the deep ocean floor.

</div>

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._18-psb}

-   Plankton are tiny organisms that are swept along on currents.
    Phytoplankton are tiny plant-like organisms. Zooplankton are
    tiny animals.
-   Nekton are organisms that go through the water under their
    own power. Fish and marine mammals are nekton.
-   Benthos bury in the sediment, attach to rocks, or crawl over
    the seafloor.

# Marine Food Chains {#12.html#x-ck12-TWFyaW5lIEZvb2QgQ2hhaW5z}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Understand where the food energy comes from for marine food chains.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602173] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030017291277.jpeg)
</span>

**What's the most unusual life form you could see on Earth?**

Some people might disagree. But the most unusual life on Earth could be
the strange organisms that live at hydrothermal vents at mid-ocean
ridges. These organisms break down chemicals to make food energy. They
engage in chemosynthesis. Would you like to see an ecosystem with
chemosynthesis at its base?

### Marine Food Chains {#12.html#x-ck12-TWFyaW5lIEZvb2QgQ2hhaW5z_19-ibq}

Pictured below is a marine food chain ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTQtMjktTWFyaW5lLWZvb2QtY2hhaW4.) ).
Phytoplankton form the base of the food chain. Phytoplankton are the
most important primary producers in the ocean. They use sunlight and
nutrients to make food by **photosynthesis** . Small zooplankton consume
phytoplankton. Larger organisms eat the small zooplankton. Larger
predators eat these consumers. In an unusual relationship, some enormous
whales depend on plankton for their food. They filter tremendous amounts
of these tiny creatures out of the water.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NTZjNjYyNTQ4OGRhNjYwOTNmZDk1OWYwM2RmZDA1NTA.-hxw"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Zappy's" --> <!-- @@url="CK-12 Foundation" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY-NC 3.0" -->
![Example of a marine food
chain](ck12_12_files/20150911030017361435.jpeg "Example of a marine food chain")

**Figure 12.39**

Many marine food chains look like this example.

</div>

The bacteria that make food from chemicals are also primary producers.
These organisms do not do photosynthesis since there is no light at the
vents. They do something called **chemosynthesis** . They break down
chemicals to make food.

When marine organisms die, decomposers break them down. This returns
their nutrients to the water. The nutrients can be used again to make
food. Decomposers in the oceans include bacteria and worms. Many live on
the ocean floor. Do you know why?

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._19-4tf}

-   Photosynthesis is the base of nearly all food chains on Earth. This
    is true of marine food chains, too.
-   In chemosynthesis, organisms break down chemicals to make
    food energy.
-   As on land, marine decomposers break down dead organisms. They
    release nutrients.

# Ocean Ecosystems {#12.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW4gRWNvc3lzdGVtcw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the various types of ocean ecosystems.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602178] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030017415220.jpeg)
</span>

**What would a field trip into the ocean reveal?**

There are all sorts of incredible life forms in the seas! Most live near
the surface or come up to the surface. Some live very far below the
surface and never come up. All are well adapted to their watery
environment.

### The Intertidal {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIEludGVydGlkYWw._20-zz6}

Have you been to a rocky shore and seen the **intertidal** ? It's the
zone at the beach that is covered when the tide is up and uncovered when
the tide is out. An abundance of life is found there, but it's a
difficult place to live. Conditions change rapidly. Waves pound and the
tide goes in and out ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1FUy0xMC0wOC0wMC1UaWRlcG9vbC1DcmVhdHVyZXM.) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-Y2NjODJmMGNiMDE2ZGYyZjkzMTFiNzNhYjBhNTk5ZTQ.-krn"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Flickr:mountainamoeba" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/mountainamoeba/696520153/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Organisms in a tide pool include a sea star and a sea
urchin](ck12_12_files/20150911030017483692.jpeg "Organisms in a tide pool include a sea star and a sea urchin")

**Figure 12.40**

Organisms in a tide pool include a sea star and a sea urchin.

</div>

Many animals in the intertidal live in tide pools. What specific
adaptations do they have to that zone? The mussels on the top left have
hard shells. These protect them from waves and from drying out. The sea
anemones in the lower right are more often submerged. They can close up
during low tides. Both types of organisms have strong attachments so
they don't wash out to sea.

Many young organisms get their start in estuaries and so they must be
adapted to rapid shifts in salinity.

### Reefs {#12.html#x-ck12-UmVlZnM._20-0p2}

Corals and other animals create limestone rock **reefs** near the shore.
Coral reefs are the “rainforests of the oceans.” They have a tremendous
amount of species diversity ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1Db2xvcmZ1bENvcmFs) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MmE4NmIxYTQ1OTQ1NjQ0M2MxMzJlYWZhMGY5MzQ0OGM.-mwf"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Les Chatfield (Flickr:Elsie esq.)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/elsie/209957662/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Coral reefs are very beautiful and very
diverse](ck12_12_files/20150911030017550602.jpeg "Coral reefs are very beautiful and very diverse")

**Figure 12.41**

Coral reefs are very beautiful and very diverse.

</div>

Reefs can form interesting shapes in the oceans. Remember that there are
many volcanoes in the ocean. Coral reefs can form on volcanoes in
tropical water. Since the volcanoes are cones, the reef forms in a
circle around the volcano. Eventually the volcano becomes inactive. The
mountain subsides and erodes so that it is below sea level. This leaves
a circular coral reef ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTQtNDgtTWF1cGl0aS1Jc2xhbmQ.) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NDUzN2Q4MmUwYzM2YWQ3MTAyZDI0OWY3YzQ5MmVkNjU.-hgz"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Robert Simmon and NASA's Earth Observatory" -->
<!-- @@url="http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=41320" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![The remnants of a volcano are surrounded by the circular
reef](ck12_12_files/20150911030017624038.jpeg "The remnants of a volcano are surrounded by the circular reef")

**Figure 12.42**

In this image of Maupiti Island in the South Pacific, the remnants of
the volcano are surrounded by the circular reef.

</div>

Eventually, all that is left is a reef island called an **atoll** . A
lagoon is found inside the reef.

### Oceanic Zone {#12.html#x-ck12-T2NlYW5pYyBab25l_20-yrm}

The open ocean is a vast area. Food washes down from the land. Food is
also created by photosynthesizing plankton. Zooplankton and larger
animals feed on the phytoplankton and on each other. Larger animals such
as whales and giant groupers may live their entire lives in the open
water.

In the deepest ocean, survival is almost impossible ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTQtNDktQW5nbGVyLWZpc2g.) ). It’s very
rare to find a meal, so the fish there use very little energy. They are
very small. The fish move very little and breathe slowly. Missing a meal
could be deadly, so the fish have interesting ways of getting and
keeping food. Some species have jaws that unhinge to accept a larger
fish. Some have backward-folding teeth to keep prey from escaping.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-YTAyOTQ5YTM1ZmVkMjI1ODljN2IwNjQzMWNkYmE3OGI.-z1p"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="G Brown Goode and Tarleton H Bean" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Ceratias_holboelli.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A drawing of a deep sea angler
fish](ck12_12_files/20150911030017687097.jpeg "A drawing of a deep sea angler fish")

**Figure 12.43**

An 1896 drawing of a deep sea angler fish with a bioluminescent “lure”
to attract prey.

</div>

Many ocean-related videos are found in National Geographic Videos,
Environment Video, Habitat, Ocean section:
[http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/player/environment/]() . Just
a few are listed below.

-   “Deep-Sea Robo Help” covers how we can know what lives in the ocean.
-   Some of the results of the Census of Marine Life have been released
    and are discussed in “Record-Breaking Sea-Creature Surveys
    Released.”
-   Bioluminescence is common in the oceans and seen in “Why Deep Sea
    Creatures Glow.”

### Hydrothermal Vents {#12.html#x-ck12-SHlkcm90aGVybWFsIFZlbnRz_20-zg0}

**Hydrothermal vents** are among the most unusual ecosystems on Earth.
They are located at mid-ocean ridges where water is extremely hot. The
food source for these ecosystems is chemosynthesis ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTQtMjgtVHViZXdvcm1z) ). This ecosystem
is entirely separate from the photosynthesis at the surface. Shrimp,
clams, fish, and giant tube worms have been found in these extreme
places.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NzlhM2FhZjExOTFhYzZiOTFmNzNhYzNhZTBmNDkzMDE.-mql"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Nicolle Rager Fuller, National Science Foundation" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.nsf.gov/news/special_reports/sfs/popup/life_vc_tubeworms.htm" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Tube worms, which live at hydrothermal
vents](ck12_12_files/20150911030017752191.jpeg "Tube worms, which live at hydrothermal vents")

**Figure 12.44**

Giant tube worms are found at hydrothermal vents. They get food from the
chemosynthetic bacteria that live within them. The bacteria provide
food; the worms provide shelter.

</div>

A video explaining hydrothermal vents with good footage is seen here:
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rFHtVRKoaUM](watch?v=rFHtVRKoaUM) .

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._20-exp}

-   Life in the intertidal is difficult, but there are many types of
    organisms there.
-   There are few organisms that live in the deepest ocean. The ones
    that do have amazing adaptations to the exceptionally
    harsh conditions.
-   A hydrothermal vent ecosystem has chemosynthesis as its food source.
    The ecosystem is independent of photosynthesis at the surface.

# Evolution of Simple Cells {#12.html#x-ck12-RXZvbHV0aW9uIG9mIFNpbXBsZSBDZWxscw..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe how life began.
-   Outline the importance of cyanobacteria in early Earth history.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602182] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030017808906.jpeg)
</span>

**What would you see if you could go back 4.5 billion years?**

If you took a field trip back in time to the earliest Earth, things
would be very different. Everything would be very hot. What company
would you have? Maybe some simple microbes. Maybe not.

### Ancient Life {#12.html#x-ck12-QW5jaWVudCBMaWZl_21-gyu}

For the first 4 billion years of Earth history there is only a little
evidence of life. Organisms were tiny and soft and did not fossilize
well. But scientists use a variety of ways to figure out what this early
life was like. Note that the period from Earth's origin to the beginning
of the Phanerozoic is called the Precambrian.

#### Life Begins {#12.html#x-ck12-TGlmZSBCZWdpbnM._21-y5b}

Life probably began in the oceans. No one knows exactly how or when.
Life may have originated more than once. If life began before the Moon
formed, that impact would have wiped it out. Then life would have had to
originate again. Eventually conditions on Earth became less violent. The
planet could support life.

The first organisms were made of only one cell ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-RUNvbGk.) ). The earliest cells were
**prokaryotes** . Prokaryotic cells are surrounded by a cell membrane.
They do not have a nucleus. Their organelles are free in the cell. The
cells get their nutrients directly from the water they live in. The
cells need to use these nutrients to live and grow.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-OTk0YmNlOGFiZDU0NDBhYjEwNDc5ZTZkZWI4NWQ3YzY.-7bx"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of Rocky Mountain Laboratories, NIAID, NIH" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:EscherichiaColi_NIAID.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![E. coli, a primitive prokaryote that may resemble the earliest
cells](ck12_12_files/20150911030017874938.jpeg "E. coli, a primitive prokaryote that may resemble the earliest cells")

**Figure 12.45**

E. coli (Escherichia coli) is a primitive prokaryote that may resemble
the earliest cells.

</div>

The cells also needed to be able to make copies of themselves. To do
this they stored genetic information in **nucleic acids** . The two
nucleic acids are **DNA** (deoxyribonucleic acid) and **RNA**
(ribonucleic acid). Nucleic acids pass genetic instructions to the next
generation.

#### Oxygen Enters the Atmosphere {#12.html#x-ck12-T3h5Z2VuIEVudGVycyB0aGUgQXRtb3NwaGVyZQ.._21-ppo}

Early cells took nutrients from the water. Eventually the nutrients
would have become less abundant.

Around 3 billion years ago, photosynthesis began. Organisms could make
their own food from sunlight and inorganic molecules. From these
ingredients they made chemical energy that they used. Oxygen is a waste
product of photosynthesis. That first oxygen combined with iron to
create iron oxide. As more oxygen was produced, the gas entered the
atmosphere.

Some of the oxygen in the atmosphere became ozone. The ozone layer
formed to protect Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation. This made
the environment able to support more complex life forms.

#### Early Organisms {#12.html#x-ck12-RWFybHkgT3JnYW5pc21z_21-zb9}

The first organisms to photosynthesize were **cyanobacteria** . These
organisms may have been around as far back as 3.5 billion years.
Cyanobacteria are still alive today ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-U3Ryb21hdG9saXRlcw..) ). Now they are called
blue-green algae. They are common in lakes and seas, and they account
for 20% to 30% of photosynthesis today.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-ZmZlM2MzMmJkZjNhZGEwMjZjOGE5NjJkNjdkZDY2MGU.-eec"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Courtesy of P. Carrara, National Park Service" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Stromatolites.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![These rocks in Glacier National Park, Montana may contain some of the
oldest fossil microbes on
Earth](ck12_12_files/20150911030017928824.jpeg "These rocks in Glacier National Park, Montana may contain some of the oldest fossil microbes on Earth")

**Figure 12.46**

These rocks in Glacier National Park, Montana may contain some of the
oldest fossil microbes on Earth.

</div>

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._21-zfs}

-   A prokaryote has a cell membrane but otherwise organelles are loose
    within the cell.
-   Photosynthesis allows organisms to produce food energy with oxygen
    as a by-product. After photosynthesis evolved, iron oxidized and
    then oxygen entered the atmosphere. Ozone was created in the
    upper atmosphere.
-   Cyanobacteria, which are still around today, were the earliest known
    photosynthesizing organisms.

# Evolution of Eukaryotes to Multicellular Life {#12.html#x-ck12-RXZvbHV0aW9uIG9mIEV1a2FyeW90ZXMgdG8gTXVsdGljZWxsdWxhciBMaWZl}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe key developments in the evolution of eukaryotes.
-   Outline the evolution of multicellular organisms.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602186] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030018009762.jpeg)
</span>

**If you could go back to the late Precambrian, would you recognize
these as ancestors of modern life?**

This is a depiction of *Dickinsonia costata* , a member of the Ediacara
fauna. No one knows quite how to categorize these organisms. Some
scientists think that they are the ancestors of modern life. But most
scientists believe that the Ediacara fauna died out and that other
organisms were the ancestors of modern life. If you could go back in
time maybe you could figure it out. But since that isn't possible, is
there any way to really know?

### Life Gets More Complex {#12.html#x-ck12-TGlmZSBHZXRzIE1vcmUgQ29tcGxleA.._22-afh}

Eukaryotes evolved about 2 billion years ago. Unlike prokaryotes,
**eukaryotes** have a cell nucleus. They have more structures and are
better organized. Organelles within a eukaryote can perform certain
functions. Some supply energy; some break down wastes. Eukaryotes were
better able to live and so became the dominant life form. You can see an
example of a eukaryotic cell below ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1FdWthcnlvdGljQ2VsbA..) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-NTQ0ZjczMmE3YzI5ZDk3NWEzZjlhZDQ4OGU2Y2UxZjY.-2w8"
class="x-ck12-img-postcard x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Mariana Ruiz Villarreal (Wikimedia: LadyofHats)" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Animal_cell_structure_no_text.svg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![A eukaryotic cell from an
animal](ck12_12_files/20150911030018077840.png "A eukaryotic cell from an animal")

**Figure 12.47**

A eukaryotic cell. This one is from an animal.

</div>

### Multicellular Life Originates {#12.html#x-ck12-TXVsdGljZWxsdWxhciBMaWZlIE9yaWdpbmF0ZXM._22-4zw}

For life to become even more complex, multicellular organisms needed to
evolve. Prokaryotes and eukaryotes can be multicellular.

Toward the end of the Precambrian, the Ediacara fauna evolved (
**Figure** [below](#12.html#x-ck12-SFMtRVMtMTItMzQtRWRpYWNhcmE.) ). The
Ediacara fauna was extremely diverse. The organisms appeared after Earth
defrosted from a worldwide glaciation. The Ediacara fauna seems to have
died out without leaving descendants. Other multicellular organisms
appeared in the Phanerozoic.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-OWVkZTdiZDgyZGYwNWMxZDFhM2MxNzcyYzJmYjBiMWY.-ty5"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="User:Merikanto/Wikimedia Commons" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Spriggina_Floundensi_4.png" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.5" -->
![A fossil of an Ediacara
organism](ck12_12_files/20150911030018135090.png "A fossil of an Ediacara organism")

**Figure 12.48**

A fossil of an Ediacara organism.

</div>

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._22-zpq}

-   Eukaryotic cells have a nucleus. They also have
    well-developed structures.
-   Eukaryotes did not evolve until 2 billion years ago.
-   Ediacara organisms probably went extinct. Other organisms were the
    ancestors to modern life.

4.  What did the yeast clusters prove?

6.  What is the next step for scientists?

# Life of the Phanerozoic Eon {#12.html#x-ck12-TGlmZSBvZiB0aGUgUGhhbmVyb3pvaWMgRW9u}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the evolution of life in the Phanerozoic Eon.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602190] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030018195543.jpeg)
</span>

**Does this look like the Earth you know?**

It's not hard to take a field trip to see some ancient life. Horseshoe
crabs live along the east coast of the United States and elsewhere.
These ancient creatures have been more-or-less unchanged for the past
450 million years. This is indicated by fossils. That doesn't get them
quite back to the beginning of the Paleozoic but close. So hundreds of
millions of generations of horseshoe crabs have seen most of the
Phanerozoic go by.

### Phanerozoic Eon {#12.html#x-ck12-UGhhbmVyb3pvaWMgRW9u_23-z7g}

The **Phanerozoic Eon** is divided into three eras—the **Paleozoic** ,
the **Mesozoic** , and the **Cenozoic** ( **Figure** (
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6ZGV2ZWxvcG1lbnQtb2YtbGlmZQ..) ). They
span from about 540 million years ago to the present. We live now in the
Cenozoic Era.

Earth’s climate changed numerous times during the Phanerozoic Eon. At
the end of the Precambrian, much of the planet was covered with
glaciers. At the start of the Phanerozoic Eon, the climate became warm
and humid. Since then Earth’s climate has gone through four cycles of
frigid glaciers and warm tropical seas. Some organisms survive changes
in the climate. Others go extinct when the climate changes too much.

#### Phanerozoic Time Line {#12.html#x-ck12-UGhhbmVyb3pvaWMgVGltZSBMaW5l_23-frs}

The table below ( **Table**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6ZGV2ZWxvcG1lbnQtb2YtbGlmZQ..) ) shows
some of the life forms that developed during the Phanerozoic Eon. Life
gradually became more diverse and new species appeared. Most modern
organisms evolved from species that are now extinct.

<div id="12.html#x-ck12-dGFibGU6ZGV2ZWxvcG1lbnQtb2YtbGlmZQ..">

[![](images/table.png)](table_12-2.html)

**Click on the image above to view the table**

</div>

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._23-u0m}

-   The Phanerozoic has spanned from 540 million years ago to present.
-   The Phanerozoic Eon is made up of the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and
    Cenozoic Eras.
-   The quantity and diversity of life has exploded since the beginning
    of the Phanerozoic.

# History of Paleozoic Life {#12.html#x-ck12-SGlzdG9yeSBvZiBQYWxlb3pvaWMgTGlmZQ..}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the diversification of life during the Paleozoic.
-   Learn about the mass extinction that ended the Paleozoic.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602195] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030018402268.jpeg)
</span>

**Okay, so you wouldn't recognize the Precambrian. How about the
Paleozoic?**

Probably not. You'd see things like these bizarre animals. The creature
on the left is much like a large arthropod. The creature on the right
had five eyes, and a long nose like a vacuum cleaner hose. These
creatures were found as fossils in the Burgess shale.

### Paleozoic Era {#12.html#x-ck12-UGFsZW96b2ljIEVyYQ.._24-9vs}

The first period of the Paleozoic Era was the Cambrian. By the beginning
of the Paleozoic, organisms evolved shells. Shells could hold their soft
tissues together. Shells could protect them from predators and from
drying out. Some organisms evolved external skeletons. These are called
**exoskeletons** . Organisms with hard parts also make good fossils.
Fossils from the Cambrian are much more abundant than fossils from the
Precambrian.

#### The Cambrian Explosion {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIENhbWJyaWFuIEV4cGxvc2lvbg.._24-fyj}

The warm, humid climate of the early Cambrian was good for life. There
was a tremendous increase in diversity. There was also an amazing
increase in the number of living things. For these two reasons, this
time period is called the Cambrian Explosion.

With so much diversity, complex ecosystems could develop. All of this
life was in the seas.

#### The Paleozoic Continues {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIFBhbGVvem9pYyBDb250aW51ZXM._24-fzc}

Paleozoic seas were full of worms, snails, clams, trilobites, sponges,
and brachiopods. Organisms with shells were common.

The first fish were simple, armored, jawless fish. Fish have internal
skeletons. Some, like sharks, skates, and rays, have skeletons of
cartilage. More advanced fish have skeletons of bones. Fish evolved jaws
and many other adaptations for ocean life. Pictured below is some of the
diversity of Earth's oceans ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1NdWRza2lwcGVy) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-Zjc2NmViNmYzZTU3ZmVlYTc3MTQ2ZTliZjBhNDNlOTc.-v1m"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Thomas H Brown" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/63048706@N06/6747999869/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC-BY 2.0" -->
![Mudskippers are fish that are able to walk short
distances](ck12_12_files/20150911030018464092.jpeg "Mudskippers are fish that are able to walk short distances")

**Figure 12.49**

Mudskippers are fish that are able to walk short distances.

</div>

#### Moving onto Land {#12.html#x-ck12-TW92aW5nIG9udG8gTGFuZA.._24-zwa}

An organism that lives in water is supported by the water. It does not
need strong support structures. It also does not need to be protected
against drying out. This is not true of land. Moving from the seas to
land required many adaptations.

Algae had covered moist land areas for millions of years. By about 450
million years ago, plants began to appear on land. Once there were land
plants, animals had a source of food and shelter. To move to land,
animals needed strong skeletons. They needed protection from drying out.
They needed to be able to breathe air. Eventually they had skeletons,
lungs, and the other the adaptations they needed moved onto the land.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-ZWJjZGUyNGJjMzc2N2EzNGRiNjAzMzA1MWU4NWY4Njk.-j97"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Jakob Vinther" -->
<!-- @@url="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Halkieria_%281%29.jpg" -->
<!-- @@license="Public Domain" -->
![Scale worms are an example of a fossil life from the
Cambrian](ck12_12_files/20150911030018520544.jpeg "Scale worms are an example of a fossil life from the Cambrian")

**Figure 12.50**

Halkieria, or scale worms, are an example of a fossil life from the
Cambrian.

</div>

One group of fish evolved into amphibians. Insects and spiders were
already land dwellers by the time amphibians appeared.

### Mass Extinctions {#12.html#x-ck12-TWFzcyBFeHRpbmN0aW9ucw.._24-whr}

The eras of the Phanerozoic Eon are separated by **mass extinctions** .
During these events, large numbers of organisms became extinct very
rapidly. There have been several extinctions in the Phanerozoic. Two
mass extinctions stand out more than the others. One took place at the
end of the Paleozoic. The other took place at the end of the Mesozoic.

#### Permian Extinction {#12.html#x-ck12-UGVybWlhbiBFeHRpbmN0aW9u_24-sdc}

Between the Paleozoic Era and the Mesozoic Era was the largest mass
extinction known. At the end of the Permian, nearly 95% of all marine
species died off. In addition, 70% of land species became extinct. No
one knows the cause of this extinction. Some scientists blame an
asteroid impact. Other scientists think it was a gigantic volcanic
eruption. It is possible that multiple things went wrong for life at the
same time. The environment was changing, an asteroid impacted, and a
giant volcanic eruption took place.

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._24-h1u}

-   In the Cambrian there was an explosion of life. This explosion was
    in number and in diversity.
-   At the beginning of the Paleozoic, all life was in the seas. Later
    in the Paleozoic, life colonized the land.
-   To colonize land, animals need to be able to keep
    themselves together. They need to keep from drying out. They need to
    be able to breathe air.
-   At the end of the Permian was the largest known extinction in
    Earth history.

# History of Mesozoic Life {#12.html#x-ck12-SGlzdG9yeSBvZiBNZXNvem9pYyBMaWZl}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the diversification of life during the Mesozoic.
-   Learn about the mass extinction that ended the Mesozoic.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602201] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030018630405.jpeg)
</span>

**Would Mesozoic Earth look familiar?**

The Precambrian and Paleozoic Earth would probably not be recognizable.
How about if you visited the Mesozoic? The planet would look a lot more
like it does today. Animals would fill the niches you're used to seeing
animals fill. But the animals would be mostly reptiles. So things
wouldn't be so familiar after all.

### The Mesozoic Era {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIE1lc296b2ljIEVyYQ.._25-q7r}

The Paleozoic ended with a mass extinction. This left lots of habitats
available for new organisms. Adaptive radiation by reptiles filled these
habitats. The Mesozoic Era was the age of reptiles. The planet was
generally warmer than it is now. This climate was very good for
reptiles.

Reptiles developed adaptations for living away from water. Their thick
skin keeps them from drying out. The evolution of the amniote egg
allowed them to lay their eggs on dry land. The **amniote egg** has a
shell and contains all the nutrients and water required for the
developing embryo ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1BbGxpZ2F0b3JFZ2c.) ).

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-ODFmZDhiNTIyZTM1N2RkOGFhMTBlOGRlNGNmMmJlMDA.-bo1"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright Heiko Kiera, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Amniotic egg containing an alligator
hatchling](ck12_12_files/20150911030018754576.jpeg "Amniotic egg containing an alligator hatchling")

**Figure 12.51**

Amniotic egg containing an alligator hatchling.

</div>

#### Dinosaurs {#12.html#x-ck12-RGlub3NhdXJz_25-erp}

Earth in the Mesozoic was populated by an enormous diversity of
reptiles. Most of the reptiles were dinosaurs. Dinosaurs reigned the
planet for 160 million years. They had tremendous numbers and diversity.
Some were small and some were very large ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1UUmV4QW5kR2FsbGlz) ). Some were
peaceful plant eaters. Some were extremely frightening meat eaters. Some
dinosaurs developed protection, such as horns, spikes, tail clubs, and
shielding plates. These adaptations were defense against active
predators.

Species of dinosaurs filled all the niches that are currently filled by
mammals. Most dinosaurs lived on land. Still, pterosaurs flew the skies.
Plesiosaurs and ichthyosaurs swam in the oceans ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-TVMtRVMtMTItMTctcGxlc2lvc2F1cnM.) ). Feathered
dinosaurs gave rise to birds.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MDc3OGMwNzhmMmNlMzU5NWI1ODMxODQzNjhmNDE4Nzk.-tu2"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="Image copyright leonello calvetti, 2013" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.shutterstock.com" -->
<!-- @@license="Used under license from Shutterstock.com" -->
![Drawing of dinosaurs, including a Tyrannosaurus
Rex](ck12_12_files/20150911030018875635.jpeg "Drawing of dinosaurs, including a Tyrannosaurus Rex")

**Figure 12.52**

Some examples of Mesozoic dinosaurs include this Tyrannosaurus Rex,
pictured with two Gallimimus.

</div>

Scientists now think that some dinosaurs were endotherms (warm-blooded).
There is a lot of evidence for this hypothesis. Some dinosaurs lived in
very cold regions. Many dinosaurs grew fast and were very active.
Dinosaur bones had canals, like birds. Some dinosaurs stood upright and
had big brains. These features are more typical of endotherms.

An interesting look at the points for dinosaur endothermy is seen here:
[http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/diapsids/endothermy.html](endothermy.html)
.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-MGJhOWI4ODc0YTc1YmE1MjcyYWNmYTIzMTdjNDdmMDI.-d1f"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

<!-- @@author="The Integer Club" -->
<!-- @@url="http://www.flickr.com/photos/integer_club/6922364008/" -->
<!-- @@license="CC BY 2.0" -->
![Skeleton of a plesiosaur, a swimming
dinosaur](ck12_12_files/20150911030019052372.jpeg "Skeleton of a plesiosaur, a swimming dinosaur")

**Figure 12.53**

Plesiosaurs were swimming dinosaurs.

</div>

Plants also did well in the Mesozoic. Lush forests covered the land.
Flowering plants evolved later in the Mesozoic.

#### Rise of the Mammals {#12.html#x-ck12-UmlzZSBvZiB0aGUgTWFtbWFscw.._25-ghj}

Mammals appeared near the end of the Triassic.

#### Cretaceous Extinction {#12.html#x-ck12-Q3JldGFjZW91cyBFeHRpbmN0aW9u_25-ghd}

The most famous mass extinction was 65 million years ago. Between the
Mesozoic Era and the Cenozoic Era, about 50% of all animal species died
off. This mass extinction is when the dinosaurs became extinct. Most
scientists think that the extinction was caused by a giant meteorite
that struck Earth. The impact heated the atmosphere until it became as
hot as a kitchen oven. Animals roasted. Dust flew into the atmosphere
and blocked sunlight for a year or more. This caused a deep freeze and
ended photosynthesis. Sulfur from the impact mixed with water in the
atmosphere. The result was acid rain. The rain dissolved the shells of
the tiny marine plankton that form the base of the food chain. With
little food being produced, animals starved.

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._25-v2q}

-   The amniote egg allowed reptiles to move away from water.
-   In the Mesozoic, dinosaurs filled the niches that mammals
    fill today.
-   About half of the life forms of the Mesozoic appear to have gone
    extinct due to a giant asteroid impact.

# History of Cenozoic Life {#12.html#x-ck12-SGlzdG9yeSBvZiBDZW5vem9pYyBMaWZl}

<div class="x-ck12-data-objectives">

-   Describe the diversification of life during the Cenozoic.

</div>

<!-- Begin inserted XHTML [CONCEPT: 3602208] -->

<span class="x-ck12-img-inline"> <!-- @@author="" -->
<!-- @@license="" --> ![](ck12_12_files/20150911030019263301.jpeg)
</span>

**Do these animals look familiar?**

The ice ages were very recent as Earth history goes. The animals are
familiar, but they're still very different from modern ones. For one
thing, most of them were huge. A small surface area-to-volume ratio is
better for keeping warm (less surface to lose heat from). Although the
dominant animals were mammals, the Pleistocene Earth still does not look
quite modern.

### The Cenozoic Era {#12.html#x-ck12-VGhlIENlbm96b2ljIEVyYQ.._26-6k7}

The Cenozoic Era is going on right now! It is the age of mammals. The
Cenozoic began with the extinction of every land creature larger than a
dog. This left many niches open. Organisms evolved to fill them.

There was a huge radiation of mammals. But birds, like the few seen in
the pictures ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1QZWxpY2FuLUh1bW1pbmdiaXJkLUZhbGNvbg..)
), are more common and even more diverse. Both mammals and birds have
the ability to regulate their own body temperature. They are endotherms
(warm blooded). This was an advantage since Earth’s climate went through
sudden and dramatic changes.

<div
id="12.html#x-ck12-N2MzMjNhMzA0MTU2NDA2ZTJlMjVmMjdiMjg4NWQzZDI.-c9w"
class="x-ck12-img-thumbnail x-ck12-nofloat">

**Figure 12.54**

Left: A pelican, catching a fish. Center: A hummingbird, taking a sip
from a flower. Right: A falcon, ready to catch its prey.

</div>

#### Diversification of the Mammals {#12.html#x-ck12-RGl2ZXJzaWZpY2F0aW9uIG9mIHRoZSBNYW1tYWxz_26-ilo}

Mammals have adapted to all sorts of different environments. They were
able to spread to even more environments than the reptiles. Mammals are
endothermic and have fur, hair, or blubber for warmth. Mammals can walk,
swim, or fly. They can live in nearly all terrestrial environments.
Mammals initially filled the forests that covered many early Cenozoic
lands. When grasslands arose, mammals evolved to fill those niches too.
You can see pictures of many different mammals below ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1CYXQtV2hhbGVzLVNocmV3cy1FbGVwaGFudHM.)
).

#### Pleistocene Megafauna {#12.html#x-ck12-UGxlaXN0b2NlbmUgTWVnYWZhdW5h_26-za2}

As climate cooled during the ice ages, large mammals evolved. These are
called the Pleistocene megafauna. Mastodons, giant sloths, wooly
mammoths, giant condors, and saber tooth cats all evolved ( **Figure**
[below](#12.html#x-ck12-Qy1NUy1FUy1TYWJlclRvb3RoQ2F0) ).

on life during 4.5 billion years. Glaciations appear at minute mark

[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K6Dl\_Vs-ZkY](watch?v=K6Dl_Vs-ZkY)
(47:10).

[![](ck12_12_files/tmp6EFWad.jpeg)](K6Dl_Vs-ZkY)

Click on the image above for more content

"The Evolution of Life in 60 Seconds" scales all 4.6 billion years of
Earth history into one minute. Don’t blink at the end:
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXSEyttblMI](watch?v=YXSEyttblMI)
(1:03).

[![](ck12_12_files/tmpHhJSID.jpeg)](YXSEyttblMI)

Click on the image above for more content

Many of the organisms that made up the Pleistocene megafauna went
extinct as conditions warmed. Some may have been driven to extinction by
human activities.

Other Cenozoic animals include hooved mammals, whales, primates, and
eventually humans.

Imagine a vast grassy plain covered with herds of elephants, bison, and
camels stretching as far as the eye can see. Lions, tigers, wolves, and,
later, humans, hunt the herds on their summer migration.This was the San
Francisco Bay Area at the close of the last ice age.

Learn more at
[http://www.kqed.org/quest/television/ice-age-bay-area2](ice-age-bay-area2)
.

[![](ck12_12_files/tmpFQ15HY.jpeg)](GqNmG1NUKdY)

Click on the image above for more content

### Summary {#12.html#x-ck12-U3VtbWFyeQ.._26-we1}

-   With the extinction of the dinosaurs, niches were open for birds and
    mammals to fill.
-   Birds and mammals are endotherms. Both are diverse and abundant.
-   Many of the organisms of the Pleistocene ice ages were enormous.
    Animals with a low surface area to body ratio are better able to
    keep warm.
-   Many of the Pleistocene megafauna have gone extinct.
